{'text': "It took 100,000 people about 20 years to build the Great Pyramid.\nIt is made of more than 2 million blocks of stone.\nMost of the blocks weigh about 6,000 pounds each!\nWorkers poured water onto the logs so the blocks would roll more easily.\nThe Earth has many mysteries, or things that are not known or explained. People use science to try to understand those mysteries.\nThe pyramids are giant tombs, or graves, for Egyptian kings. Pyramids are made of huge stone blocks. Experts know that the Egyptians didn't have the same tools that we have today. So, how were those heavy blocks moved and lifted? Some experts believe that the Egyptians pushed and pulled them into place.\n1. Workers cut and shaped the stone into blocks.\n2. The workers floated the blocks down the Nile River on big barges.\n3. The workers rolled the blocks over logs from the river to the pyramid.\n4. The workers built dirt ramps so the blocks could be rolled to the top of the pyramid.\n5. Workers carefully fit the stone blocks into place on the pyramid.\nNo one knows for sure what the dinosaurs looked like. Some experts think that dinosaur skin might have looked and felt like the scaly skin of reptiles today.\nExperts study how animals today use skin color to survive. Some animals, like the chameleon, can change skin color in order to hide. Experts also say that other animals, like poison arrow frogs, have brightly colored skin to keep away their enemies.\nIt is likely that dinosaurs also used skin color to survive, say experts. {'text': "Scientists from the United States are studying elephants in Africa. They say elephants make sounds that cannot be heard by humans. Now those scientists have found a way to study the sounds and what the sounds mean.\nIn a national park in Ghana, a country in Africa, scientists watched a baby elephant. It had become separated from its family and stood quietly. But soon the scientists saw the baby elephant's family surround it. How did the family find the baby elephant? Scientists say that the baby was making very low rumbling sounds that humans cannot hear.\nScientists knew this because they had placed special recording devices in the forest. The devices recorded the rumbles that the baby elephant was making. Scientists said that the rumbles were actually calls for help.\nScientists also recorded two elephants greeting each other by calling back and forth. Another time, a family of elephants made rumbles to keep the group together as they traveled.\nScientists hope to figure out what some other elephant sounds mean. That will help them learn more about elephants and keep track of them in the forest.\nThe African elephant is the largest animal that lives on land. African elephants can weigh up to 16,000 pounds.\nAn elephant's trunk contains more than 40,000 muscles. Then they put mud in between the logs to keep out the wind and rain. Most log cabins were small because it took pioneers so long to build them. Many log cabins had only one room. Most pioneers burned a fire to keep their log cabins warm.\nMost pioneers made their own clothing. It was usually made of leather, cotton, or wool. Pioneers dried animal skins to make leather. {'text': "The ocean is filled with many different kinds of animals. This sea turtle lives in the upper zone of the water.\nKiller whales breach, or jump out of the water.\nis a large body of salt water. It can be divided into three\nor layers. The deeper the water, the colder it gets. Why? Sunlight reaches only the water near the ocean's surface. Take a look in each zone to see some of the animals that live there.\nThe top layer of the ocean is called the sunlit zone. It is lit by enough sunlight for plants to grow. All plants and most marine animals live in this zone. Whales live here because they need to swim to the surface to breathe air.\nSome fish here have special shapes to protect them from\nA predator is an animal that eats another animal for food. The porcupine fish puffs up and raises its spines when danger is near.\nTwilight Zone (650 feet to 3,300 feet)\nThe ocean is colder in the twilight zone. Only dim light reaches this area. There is not enough light for plants to grow. Fewer sea creatures are found here than in the sunlit zone. Jellyfish and octopuses are often found here.\nMany jellyfish have stinging tentacles that they use to defend themselves and to capture\nPrey is an animal that is caught and eaten by a predator. Octopuses use the suction cups on their tentacles to hold on to prey.\nMidnight Zone (3,300 feet to 19,800 feet)\nIt is pitch-dark and very cold in the midnight zone. No plants grow here. Many of the animals have sharp teeth and big jaws. Other creatures, such as the ratfish, have large eyes to see in the dark. Ratfish swim along the bottom of the ocean and eat smaller sea animals, such as shrimp and sea stars.\nSome animals, like the hatchetfish, have body parts that glow in the dark. That helps them to attract prey.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n", 'label': '1'}

{'text': 'How do bugs exchange thoughts and ideas?\nIf insects could talk, what might they say? ÒI found food.Ó ÒAre you a relative?Ó ÒWatch out for danger!Ó Of course, insects donÕt talk the way people do, but they do\nwith one another. That means they exchange information.\nA bee does the waggle dance. It walks in a figure eight and shakes its body. The farther away the food, the longer the bee shakes. The direction in which it walks tells other bees the way to the food.\nHoneybees get food from flowers. When a honeybee finds a field of flowers, it flies back to the hive. The bee tells the other bees where to find the food. How? It dances! The round dance shows that food is nearby. If the food is far away, the bee performs the waggle dance. That dance shows the location of the food.\nFireflies have a chemical inside their bodies. It makes light. Fireflies flash lights at one another. Each\nor kind, of firefly has a different flash pattern. That helps the insects find members of their own species. The flash pattern also helps male and female fireflies find one another\nGrasshoppers send messages by chirping. They often rub a back leg against a wing. That causes a vibration and makes sound. Mostly male grasshoppers make sounds. They chirp to attract females. Each species of grasshopper has its own call. Some grasshoppers make sounds to warn other males to go away.\nA leaf-cutter ant carries a piece of a leaf back to its nest.\nAnts give off scents to pass along messages. If an ant finds food, it goes back to its nest. The ant leaves a scent trail along the way. Other ants follow the trail to find the food. They walk with their antennae to the ground. Why? Ants smell with their antennae. Ants can also leave a special scent to warn about danger.\nWhat are some ways that people communicate besides talking?\nmeasures published under license with MetaMetrics, Inc.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '1'}

{'text': "California Sea Lions live along the west coast of North America. The map shows the west coast of the U.S.\nof San Francisco, California. (A pier is a platform built over water.) People like to look at boats tied up at the piers. They also enjoy watching sea lions that have made a home at one of San Francisco's piers.\nSan Francisco's Pier 39 is packed with sea lions. The sea lions sleep in the sun, bark loudly, and eat fish. (They don't always smell that great, however!)\nAnimal experts are not sure why sea lions first came to Pier 39. But the number of sea lions has grown each year since an earthquake hit San Francisco in 1989. Before the earthquake, only about 30 sea lions camped out at Pier 39. Now, the number of sea lions can be as high as 600!\nFood to Eat and Room to Spread Out\nExperts say the earthquake might have caused\n, a type of fish, to swim closer to San Francisco than before. Herring is a favorite food of sea lions, so they might have followed those fish to shore.\nSea lions might also like the pier because they have plenty of room to spread out. The Marine Mammal Center, an organization that cares for sea animals, asked the city to protect the sea lions. Now the sea lions cannot be moved from the pier.\nSea lions can grow to be up to 8 feet long and weigh up to 850 pounds.\nSea lions can swim up to 20 miles per hour.\nSea lions usually live between 20 and 30 years.\nSea lions eat fish, squid, and octopus. They have about 36 teeth but like to swallow their food whole.\nStorm drains in Oxnard, California, usually don't bark. {'text': 'What is life like in the Arctic?\nThe Arctic is cold and windy. Snow and ice cover the ground for most of the year. The\nis near the North Pole. A habitat is a place in nature where a plant or an animal normally lives. Bundle up! Meet some animals that live in the Arctic.\nThe harp seal lives in the water. It can also be found on the ice. The harp seal has thick fur. That helps it stay warm. The seal also has\nunder its skin. Blubber is fat that protects an animal from the cold.\nA harp seal rests with its pup. A pup is a baby seal.\nThe arctic fox travels on snow and ice. It has thick, white fur in the winter. The fur acts as\n(KA-muh-flahzh). It helps the animal match its surroundings. {'text': ". Mammals are animals that drink milk from their mothers. Whales live in oceans. There are many kinds of whales. Whales are some of the biggest animals alive.\n. Krill are tiny animals that look like shrimp. The humpback opens its mouth and takes in water and krill. Grooves in the whale's throat stretch to help it hold a lot of water and food. Then it pushes the water out and eats the krill.\nAll whales, like blue whales, breathe air through\n. A blowhole is an opening on top of a whale's head. The blowhole is closed when the whale is under the water. When the whale comes to the top, its blowhole opens. The whale breathes out, making water spray into the air. Then the whale breathes in and goes under the water again.\nKiller whales breach, or jump out of the water.\n. A breaching whale jumps up out of the water. Then it comes down and makes a huge splash!\nNo one is sure why whales breach. Some people say that they do it just for fun!\n. Whales communicate to talk to one another. Scientists think that a whale communicates by making sounds from its blowhole and from its mouth. Some people are poor and must work hard to survive. Some children must quit school to help their parents earn money.\nWith UNICEF's help, Colombia's government is creating a special school for those children. {'text': 'On most days, you may see clouds in the sky. Where do they come from? When the sun heats oceans and lakes, water changes from a liquid to a gas. It rises into the air and cools. As it cools, the gas changes back into a liquid. It forms tiny drops of water or ice crystals. As they come together, they become clouds.\nClouds come in different shapes. Each shape is a clue to the kind of weather that is on the way. Learn about four kinds of clouds.\n(SIHR-uhss) clouds are thin and wispy. They look like hairs. They are found high in the sky. Cirrus clouds can bring a change in the weather.\n(KYOO-myuh-luhss) clouds are big and fluffy. They may look like cotton balls. They usually form low in the sky. Cumulus clouds often bring sunny, fair weather.\n(STRAH-tuhss) clouds are long layers of clouds. They look like a blanket. They are low in the sky. Stratus clouds can bring light rain.\n(kyoo-myuh-loh-NIM-buhss) clouds are big and gray. They are a kind of cumulus cloud. They can start near the ground and be very tall in the sky. Cumulonimbus clouds can bring heavy rain and thunderstorms. They also may mean a\nis on the way. {'text': 'Have you ever wondered how snow forms? Bits of frozen water called\nform in the air when it is very cold. Many ice crystals make a snowflake. A group of snowflakes creates a snowfall.\nBefore a snowflake reaches the ground, it goes through four steps.\n1. Each snowflake begins as water droplets inside a cloud in the sky.\n2. When the temperature freezes, the water droplets turn into ice crystals.\nLibrary of Congress, Prints and Photographs Division.\n3. As more water sticks to the ice crystal, it begins to change shape.\n4. When many ice crystals stick together, snowflakes form and fall to the ground.\nThe shape of a snowflake depends on the temperature at which ice crystals form. These crystals bump into each other and stick together. That creates new shapes of snowflakes.\nSnowflakes are usually less than half an inch across.\nThe largest snowflake ever measured was bigger than a childâ€™s hand!\nSnow only looks white. It is actually clear.\nNo two snowflakes are exactly the same.\nCan you name two things that look alike but are not exactly the same?\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '1'}

{'text': "Summer is almost here! Why do experts say that summer is the most dangerous time of the year for kids? During the summer, most schools are closed. Kids have more time to play outside, ride bikes, and swim. That means kids have more chances to get hurt.\nPlaying outside gives you a chance to breathe fresh air, but it also exposes you to harmful sun rays. Harmful sun rays can cause sunburns. You can get a sunburn even if you are outside for a short amount of time. So when you are in the sun, always wear sunscreen. Use a sunscreen with a sun protection factor (SPF) of 15 or higher, and be sure to rub it evenly into your skin. You should also wear a hat and try to play in the shade.\nWhether you ride a bike, ride a scooter, or use in-line skates, be wheel safe. The most serious way kids get hurt while on wheels is by hitting their heads. So always wear a helmet when you are playing on wheels. {'text': "Experts say that Antarctica is the coldest place on Earth. They say that some of the coldest temperatures in the world have been noted in Antarctica. The South Pole is found at the bottom of Earth.\nPenguins are birds. Emperor and Adelie penguins live in Antarctica. {'text': 'Hi! My Name is Pam Pollster. This is my pet parakeet, Polly. We live in Polling Place. Polly is a smart bird. In fact, she\'s so smart, she can count very high numbers. This is good, because I need Polly\'s help--and yours--with a problem. The problem is that Polling Place needs a new motto. The one we have now is kind of lame. Want to hear it? "Polling Place. Live Here. It\'s Nice." I told you it was lame.\nThat\'s why we need a new motto. The town council came up with three choices. Now, it\'s up to Polly and me to find out which choice people like best.\nPolling Place: A Place That\'s Right on the Numbers.\nPolling Place: A Cool Place for Birds!\nHow are Polly and I going to find out everyone\'s opinion? It won\'t be easy.\nA few thousand people live in Polling Place. We sure don\'t have the time to go to every person\'s house to find out which motto he or she likes. (Besides, my bike has a flat tire and my in-line skates don\'t fit.)\nSo what should we do? Well, Polly came up with a great idea. We can poll the people of Polling Place! (Told you she was smart.)\nis a way of asking a small part of a large group of people what they think. Then, using math, you can figure out what the larger group is thinking.\nPolls are used all the time. In fact, they are really important during elections. (You know, the big thing that\'s on the news all the time?) Polls are also used to help the government, businesses, and organizations make decisions or plans.\nSo, what is the first step for our motto poll of Polling Place? Turn the page to find out!\nBelieve it or not, polling has been around for a long time in the United States. One of the first political polls was done in 1824!\nIn those days, newspapers asked readers to write in saying the person they liked for president. One newspaper did a poll that said Andrew Jackson would be president. But Jackson didn\'t get enough votes to win. John Quincy Adams won that election and became our seventh president.\nWhy was the newspaper wrong? The biggest problem was that only the readers of that one newspaper took part in the poll. It did not show what all people in the U.S. felt.\nBy the 1960s, polling became more scientific. Such a scientific poll was used by John F. Kennedy during the 1960 presidential election. The poll, done by Louis Harris, figured out what issues people were worried about. For a poll to be scientific, three things must happen.\nThe people who run a poll need to get a sample of people. A\nis a small part of a larger group of people. A sample for a poll must include ALL types of people, like boys and girls, young and old. Also, no one can know who is going to get picked for a poll\'s sample. And no one can volunteer to take part in a poll.\nA poll\'s questions must be thought out. The questions need to be\n. That means the questions don\'t lead people to answer one way or another.\nFinally, experts, sometimes with the help of math, study the\n, or people\'s answers. Then they put the data into charts so that it is easier for everyone to understand.\nIt\'s as Easy as One, Two, Three\nSo how did Polly and I poll the people of Polling Place? Here\'s how we did it.\nThe first step was to figure out the subject of the poll. That was easy! We wrote down the following on a piece of paper:\nAs a resident of Polling Place, which new town motto do you prefer?\nPolling Place: A Place That\'s Right on the Numbers.\nPolling Place: A Cool Place for Birds!\nThe tough part of polling is figuring out how to ask people our questions and get their answers. One way is to send people out to ask our questions. Another is to call people on the telephone. The Internet is also another way of polling. Polly and I decided to go out and ask a sample of all kinds of people.\nWe now have our data from the people of Polling Place! Next we will put it together into a chart.\nWhich motto did the people of Polling Place like best?\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '1'}

Since then, the U.S. Mint has made five new state quarters each year. The coins are released to the public in the order in which each state became part of the United States.\nThe front, or heads side, of each state quarter is the same. They all have a picture of George Washington. He was the first president of the United States. He became president in 1789.\nThe back, or tails side, of each state quarter is\n(yoo-NEEK). That means one of a kind. The design shows something special about that state. "The program teaches people about the rich history of the states," says Michael White. He is a spokesperson for the U.S. Mint.\nMany kids and adults started collecting coins in 1999 because of the new state quarters. "It is, by far, the most popular and successful program in U.S. Mint history," says White. "More than 140 million Americans collect them."\nUntil 1965, quarters were made of silver. Today, quarters are made of copper and nickel.\nNew Jersey\'s quarter has a picture of George Washington on each side.\nCoins last for about 30 years. {'text': "A Long Winter Sleep: How Do Animals Hibernate?\nMany animals hibernate (HIGH-behr-nayt) during the winter. When an animal hibernates, it goes into a deep sleep. Animals hibernate when the weather gets cold and it is hard to find food. Animals like frogs, chipmunks, and bears hibernate.\nIn the fall, brown bears eat a lot of food. They eat berries, plants, and fish. Bears eat to build up fat. By the end of the fall, the bears start to hibernate in dens, which are caves or openings in the ground. They breathe slower and their hearts beat slower. They don't need to eat or drink because they use their fat to stay alive.\nWhen fall comes, a chipmunk gathers extra food. It stores the extra food in its\n, or hole in the ground. The chipmunk hibernates in its burrow for the winter. Sometimes, a hibernating chipmunk wakes up. It wakes up to eat some of its stored food. It eats berries, mushrooms, and nuts.\nSome frogs hibernate in mud at the bottom of lakes or rivers. As they hibernate, they are very still and seem to be frozen. Frogs that hibernate take in oxygen from the water.\nis a gas that living things need. The frogs take in the oxygen through their skin.\nA brown bear can be about 5 feet tall while standing on all four feet.\nA brown bear can run up to 30 miles per hour.\nA baby brown bear can weigh less than 1 pound when it is born.\nto spend the winter sleeping to conserve energy\nJust before a bear begins to hibernate, it is very big. {'text': "Many people visit Hawaii each year. They admire the coral reefs that surround the islands. But those beautiful reefs have been damaged by people and ships. Recently the United States government made a law to protect the reefs around Hawaii.\nis a large strip of hard sea animal skeletons that is close to the ocean's surface. More than half of the United States' coral reefs are located in the waters around Hawaii.\nCoral reefs provide homes for sea animals. Reefs also protect coastlines from dangerous, pounding waves. When waves pass over reefs, they slow down and get smaller.\nHawaii's reefs are being hurt. People have polluted the water around the reefs and have taken too many fish.\nBefore he left office, President Bill Clinton created the Northwestern Hawaiian Islands Coral Reef Reserve. A\nis an area protected by the government. This reserve is underwater and covers 84 million acres. That is almost as big as the states of Florida and Georgia combined.\nSpecial rules make sure the reef reserve will be protected. People are not allowed to remove coral from the reefs. The number of fish taken from the reserve area cannot go up. Hawaii's reefs are now protected from further damage.\nA coral reef is built by tiny sea creatures called coral\nCoral polyps have hard outer skeletons that protect them. When the polyps die, their skeletons stay. After a long time, the coral skeletons build up, forming a reef.\nMore than 2/3 of the world's coral reefs have been damaged by pollution and too much fishing.\nCoral can be tan, orange, yellow, purple, or green.\nThe Great Barrier Reef is the largest coral reef in the world. Eat brown rice, oatmeal, and popcorn. Try whole-wheat bread instead of white bread.\nColor your plate with all kinds of veggies. They help your heart, eyes, skin, and teeth. That helps build strong muscles. Eat fish, chicken, lima beans, and nuts.\nFruits are natureÕs treats. They are sweet and tasty. They help your heart, eyes, skin, and teeth too. Eat a variety of colors. Try an apple or a banana. You can also mix pieces of different fruits to make a salad.\nHave milk and foods made with milk. Those foods are high in calcium. {'text': 'Some animals are active at night. Those animals are\nNocturnal animals can see clearly in the dark. They often have a good sense of hearing too. Bats, owls, and flying squirrels are nocturnal.\nMost bats eat insects. How does a bat find an insect in the dark? The bat makes sounds. The sounds bounce off an insect in the batÕs path. The sounds return to the bat. That lets the bat know where to find the insect and how big it is.\nFlying squirrels live in trees. Can the squirrels really fly? No! They glide in the air. The squirrel leaps up and opens its arms and legs. Folds of skin connect its wrists to its ankles. That skin acts like wings.\nOwls have large eyes. How does that help? They can see better at night than most animals. An owlÕs eyes donÕt move. They always face forward. An owl has to turn its head to see in any other direction. Its head can turn almost all the way around!\nHow might being nocturnal help animals survive?\nmeasures published under license with MetaMetrics, Inc.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '1'}

{'text': '? ItÕs hard to imagine. An invention is a new thing or idea. It can change the way people live. Some inventions solve problems and make life easier. Other inventions make life more fun (or tastier!). Read about some great inventions.\nThe next time you stick on a Band-Aid, you can thank Earle Dickson. He invented the ready-made bandage in 1920. He wanted to help his wife who often cut her fingers while cooking.\nAt the time, people had to cut pieces of gauze and tape to make bandages. They were hard to use. DicksonÕs simple idea was a big success. Today, ready-made bandages come in many shapes, sizes, and colors.\nDid you know that chocolate chip cookies were a mistake? Ruth Graves Wakefield created them in the 1930s. She was mixing a batch of chocolate cookies and was out of baking chocolate. She decided to chop up a bar of semisweet chocolate instead. When the cookies were done, the pieces of chocolate had not melted! They had kept their chip form in each cookie.\nBefore the 1920s, people often got into traffic accidents. One day, Garrett Morgan saw a bad accident between a car and a horse-drawn carriage. He decided to solve the problem by inventing a traffic signal. It was a pole with signs saying when to stop and go. TodayÕs red, yellow, and green traffic lights are based on MorganÕs idea.\nWhat other inventions can you name? {'text': 'is a large body of salt water. It can be divided into three layers called\nThe deeper the water, the colder it gets. Read a about each zone to learn more.\nThe ocean is different from top to bottom.\nThe top layer of the ocean is called the sunlit zone. It gets enough sunlight for plants to grow. All ocean plants and most ocean animals live here. Whales and dolphins live in this zone. They need to swim to the surface to breathe air.\nThe porcupine fish lives here too. It puffs up and raises its spines to scare off\nA predator is an animal that eats another animal for food.\nTwilight Zone (650 feet to 3,300 feet)\nThe ocean is colder in the twilight zone. Only dim light reaches this area. Plants cannot grow in this zone. Fewer animals live here than in the sunlit zone. Jelly fish and octopuses are often found here.\nMany jellyfish have stinging tentacles. Jellyfish use their tentacles to capture\n. Prey are animal that are eaten by predators. Octopuses have suction cups on their tentacles. That helps them hold on to prey.\nMidnight Zone (3,300 feet to 19,800 feet)\nThe midnight zone is dark. It is also very cold. Plants do not grow in this zone. Animals here often have sharp teeth and big jaws. Many animals, such as the ratfish, have large eyes. That helps them see in the dark.\nSome animals, such as the deep sea hatchetfish, give off light. Their light blends in with the small amount of sunlight from above. That helps them hide from predators below.\nWhy might it be useful to know more about the different layers of the ocean?\nmeasures published under license with MetaMetrics, Inc.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '1'}

Those are storms with heavy rain, lightning, and thunder. As lightning strikes, it heats the air around it. That causes the air to\n, or get bigger. When that happens, you hear a loud sound called thunder.\nWhen it rains, you may see a rainbow. It appears when sunlight passes through drops of water in the air. {'text': "The Liberty Bell no longer rings today. During the move, wireless technology will be attached to the bell.\nThe Liberty Bell is on the move. Right now, the bell hangs at Liberty Hall Pavilion. That is in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.\nThe area around the bell is being rebuilt and improved. Liberty Hall Pavilion is being torn down. The bell will be moved to its new home 200 yards away. It is called Liberty Bell Center.\nAlthough the new site is only a short distance away, the move will be a tricky one. The bell weighs 2,080 pounds. If it is not moved with care, the bell's famous crack could split even more.\nA team of experts has been working to protect the bell during its move. Before the move, three tiny sensors will be placed on the bell. The sensors will sound an alarm if there is any damage to the bell's crack. Special paper will be placed under the sensors so they will not scratch the bell.\nThe Liberty Bell is a symbol of American freedom. The bell was rung to call people together for special events. It rang on July 8, 1776, to gather people for the first reading of the Declaration of Independence. That was signed on July 4, 1776.\nThe Liberty Bell has a long history. The bell arrived in Pennsylvania in 1752. It cracked soon after. In 1753, people tried to fix the bell twice. Sometime in the 1830s or 1840s, it cracked again! The exact date remains a mystery.\nExperts are hopeful the bell's move will be a success. ÒBedbugs ... can travel far in search of a good meal,Ó says scientist Jody Gangloff-Kaufmann.\nBedbugs hide in homes across the country.\nThe insects can live in mattresses and couches. They come out at night to eat. While people sleep, the bugs drink their blood. The bites donÕt hurt, but they can cause itchy bumps.\nThose bumps are popping up all over. About 95 percent of U.S. pest control companies reported battling bedbugs in the past year. That is according to the National Pest Management Association. A rise in travel might be one reason. Travelers might carry the bugs in their suitcases.\nmight also be the problem. Those are chemicals that kill insects. Some pesticides may not be strong enough to get rid of bedbugs.\nOfficials arenÕt taking the attacks lying down. New York made a law to\nor stop, renters from moving into apartments that have bedbugs. That state also passed a law making schools tell parents about bedbug sightings.\nGetting the word out is a good idea, Gangloff-Kaufmann told\nÒThe best way to get rid of bedbugs starts with prevention,Ó she says.\nGot bedbugs? Dogs can tell! Experts have trained pooches to use their powerful noses to sniff out the insects.\nPeopleÕs noses are too weak to find the scent. DogsÕ noses are much stronger. The dogs can locate the insects in just a few minutes.\nOnce pups find a bedbug, they sit down nearby. Then a pest control expert comes to get rid of the insects. {'text': 'Do bats hold the answer to better-flying aircraft?\nBatman, have you heard? A new kind of "batmobile" is in the works!\nScientists in Rhode Island are studying how bats fly. The United States Air Force is funding the $6 million project. It hopes the mammals will offer clues about how to design better-flying aircraft. Mammals are warm-blooded animals that feed their babies milk.\nBats can fly in ways that birds and airplanes can\'t. The animals\' wings have more than 24 joints. The joints allow them to\n, or control, their wings while flying. Bats can stretch and bend their wings. This helps them fly higher and faster. Scientist Sharon Swartz says bats\' control of their wings is similar to humans\' control of their hands. "Bats are the only flying animals whose wings are really just like human hands," she told\nSwartz and the other scientists will study about 20 species of bats over the next five years. They are using real bats, high-tech cameras, and wind tunnels in their research. The team hopes to find out why bats can turn sharply without falling. If airplanes could do that, they could\n, or move, in tight spaces. They could also fly in more dangerous conditions. The Air Force also hopes to learn how weight affects bat flight. Bats can carry up to 50 percent of their weight while flying. If aircraft designers knew bats\' secrets, they could design airplanes that could carry more weight.\nSwartz says there is still a lot more to learn about the animals. "We expect to be studying bats long into the future," she says.\nIt\'s going to be a hair-raising Halloween for Little Rock Zoo in Arkansas. Three vampire bats were born there recently. {'text': 'Zooming down a hill, you feel the wind rushing in your face. Seconds later, you are hanging upside down! You are riding a roller coaster. Some experts worry that the rides\' sudden twists and turns are unsafe.\nHigh-speed coasters whip riders\' heads back and forth. One report blamed coasters for 13 brain injuries from 1995 to 2000. Another report says some people have nearly died from coaster-related brain injuries.\nRecently, two scientists set out to learn if coasters really do cause brain injuries. They studied the effects of riding three of the fastest coasters in the United States. The scientists say the coasters\' twists and turns are not fast enough to cause brain injuries.\n"People take more than 1 billion rides on roller coasters each year. The reports on brain injury are few and not proven," said Douglas Smith. He is one of the scientists who did the new study.\nSome experts do not think the new study proves coasters are safe-especially for kids. They say the scientists only studied how coasters affect adults, not kids. They want a new study.\nEdward Markey is a government official. {'text': "Trained rats may soon be used to find survivors who are trapped after disasters.\nMeet the soon-to-be members of rescue teams--rats! Scientists are training the rodents to help find people who are buried in buildings after earthquakes and other disasters.\nRats have a strong sense of smell, which can help them sniff out people. The rodents are also tiny enough to crawl just about anywhere. They can get into places that are too small for people and other animals, such as dogs.\nScientists trained the rats to search for the scent of people. They attached tiny electronic devices to the brain of each rat. Signals from the rat's brain are sent to a radio that is strapped to the animal's back. Rescue teams will be able to track the signals and follow the rat's path. That will help them figure out where to start digging. Scientists hope to have the rat rescuers on the job within the next six months.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n", 'label': '2'}

That is why scientists used clues to do the count.\nThe result of the panda count was a surprise to scientists. They learned that hundreds more pandas exist than experts once thought! A flash of lightning can heat the air around it to up to 60,000 degrees Fahrenheit. That is about five times hotter than the sun!\nWhen lightning heats the air around it, the air expands and makes a loud crashing sound-thunder. If you hear thunder, you are within striking distance of lightning. "Anytime you hear thunder, you should immediately move to a safe area," said scientist E. Philip Krider. {'text': "The Gal‡pagos Islands are a group of islands located in the Pacific Ocean off the coast of South America. The islands are home to some of the world's\nor most unusual, animals and plants. In January, those islands had a brush with disaster.\nOn January 16, a ship carrying oil got stuck on a\nis a chain of rocks or coral near the surface of the water.) The islands are located in the Pacific Ocean about 600 miles off the coast of Ecuador. Scientists say the oil spill put many of the islands' animals in danger.\nThe oil spill happened near San Crist—bal and Santa Fe islands, in the eastern area of the Gal‡pagos. Cleanup workers said the oil killed two pelicans and dirtied 40 others. Workers said some sea lions, birds, and tortoises also needed to be cleaned.\nOil can make animals sick if they swallow it. When oil covers an animal's fur or feathers, it can't swim, fly, or stay warm. If the oil is not cleaned off the animal, it could die.\nThe oil spill also harmed life in the water. Many sea plants, such as algae (AL-jee), were also damaged by the oil spill. Sea plants are an important food source for many Gal‡pagos animals.\nDays after the accident, however, the islands were spared further damage. Ocean currents took the oil out to sea, away from the islands.\nWhat could be done to prevent such oil spills?\nmeasures published under license with MetaMetrics, Inc.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n", 'label': '2'}

Those colonies later became the United States.\nA powerful Native American group called the Powhatan lived on the land when the English colonists settled Jamestown. At first, the Powhatan leader was friendly, but soon the two groups began fighting. They made peace in 1614 when Pocahontas married an Englishman. She was the daughter of Chief Powhatan. However, this year there weren't enough flu shots for everyone. Health experts found that one company's flu shots weren't safe. That company was supposed to supply the United States with half of the 100 million doses needed.\nThis year, there were not enough flu shots for everyone. The people at highest risk received a flu shot first.\nHang in there! The flu strikes the United States for only part of the year. Flu season usually runs from November to March.\nDespite the short supply of flu shots, there are ways to stay flu-free. To keep the virus away, practice healthful habits.\nWash your hands often with soap and water.\nAvoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth. {'text': 'The Amazon River is the longest river in South America. It flows for 4,000 miles across the continent. The location of the river\'s\nor beginning, was a mystery for centuries. A team of explorers and geography experts recently found the tiny stream where the mighty river begins.\nHigh on the Nevado Mismi, an 18,363-foot-high mountain in Peru, a stream trickles from the melting snow. A team of 22 explorers and geography experts recently announced that this small stream is the source of the mighty Amazon River.\nThe stream flows into the Apurimac (Ah-poo-REE-mahk) River, which is one of the many rivers that combine to form the Amazon.\nAndrew Pietowski, a high school math teacher in New York, led the team in search of the river\'s source. The team searched the Andes, a range of mountains that stretches the whole western length of South America. "Since the Amazon River has an end, there must be a beginning. I wanted to know where it was," Pietowski said.\nOn its way across South America, the Amazon River flows through the largest\nin the world. A rain forest is a dense forest that has a lot of rainfall and warm temperatures all year round. The Amazon rain forest is almost as big as the continent of Australia.\nScientists say about 80,000 different types of trees and plants can be found in the Amazon rain forest. More kinds of fish live in the Amazon River than in the Atlantic Ocean. The river flows through forests that are home to jaguars, armadillos, snakes, monkeys, crocodiles, and anteaters. Along the river live about 170 different groups of native people.\nMany areas of the Amazon River have never been explored. {'text': 'The world\'s largest volcano appears to be coming back to life. Scientists are keeping a close watch on it. If the volcano erupts, it could destroy nearby towns.\nA giant volcano on the island of Hawaii is beginning to show signs of life, scientists say. The volcano is called\nMauna Loa is Hawaiian for "Long Mountain." It is the largest volcano on Earth. The volcano makes up half of the island of Hawaii. Hawaii is one of the islands that make up the state of Hawaii.\nRecently, scientists have noticed changes in Mauna Loa. The top of the volcano is growing slightly. Magma is rising into the giant volcano.\nis hot, liquid rock beneath Earth\'s surface.\nThe last time Mauna Loa erupted was in 1984. A river of\nflowed from the volcano for three weeks. Lava is magma flowing out of a volcano. The lava can reach temperatures of nearly 2,100 degrees Fahrenheit. Lava can burn everything in its path.\nSince 1984, many more people have moved to areas around Mauna Loa. They have built homes on the volcano\'s slopes. If the volcano erupts now, hot lava could destroy those homes.\nFor now, people should not worry too much about an eruption, experts say. "We\'re at a stage where it\'s months to years, rather than days to weeks" before the next eruption, said scientist Peter Cervelli. Until then, scientists will continue to keep track of changes in the volcano. They hope to give people lots of warning about future eruptions.\nMauna Loa is a shield volcano. Shield volcanoes form from lava flows. When lava cools, it hardens. The lava builds up and forms a low mountain.\nWhy is it important for scientists to study volcanoes?\nmeasures published under license with MetaMetrics, Inc.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '2'}

{'text': 'Companies are pulling the plug on unhealthy food ads for kids.\nNo more cookies or candy for SpongeBob SquarePants. Dora the Explorer is also going on a diet. Recently, some companies decided to stop using cartoon characters to advertise unhealthy foods and drinks to children. This includes television commercials.\nNickelodeon will stop showing characters on junk-food packages by 2009. Starting next year, Kellogg\'s, McDonald\'s, and Kraft Foods will not advertise unhealthy products to children under 12.\nAccording to doctors, kids see 40,000 television ads per year. About half of them are food ads. Many of them are for sugary cereals and unhealthy snacks. Health experts and parents say these ads make kids want to eat junk food more often.\n"It\'s putting our children at risk," says scientist Ellen Wartella.\nObesity is the condition of being very overweight. Experts say one-third of American children are obese or at risk for becoming obese.\nCurrently, there are no laws that control how food companies advertise to children. This means it\'s up to the companies to decide how to advertise.\nJosephine Thomas is a parent. She is glad that some companies are changing their use of cartoon characters in advertisements. "As soon as [my kids] see a Shrek or Mickey Mouse [food product], they automatically look at that and they don\'t see what they really need," she says.\nYes, according to scientists at the University of Liverpool in Europe. Recently, they studied 60 children of various weights. The kids, ages 9 to 11, were shown several food and toy ads on television. Children at a healthy weight ate 84 percent more food after watching the food commercials than after watching the toy commercials. Obese kids ate 134 percent more food.\nIn what ways can advertisements affect people?\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '2'}

A recent study shows that many coral reefs around the world are being destroyed. Some scientists say more than half of the world\'s reefs may be gone by the year 2030.\nWhat is causing coral reefs to disappear? Scientists say people are largely to blame. Ships and fishing nets often damage the reefs. Other threats include pollution, storms, and disease.\nCoral reefs may look like rocks, but they are actually living structures. They are made up of tiny sea animals. Those tiny creatures are called\nThe polyps build hard shells around themselves. When a polyp dies, it leaves behind its shell. Young polyps attach themselves to the old shells. Over many years, the polyps form a coral reef.\nScientists are working hard to protect coral reefs. They are mapping and studying the reefs. Many protected areas are being widened. Fishing is not allowed in those areas.\nWhat could happen if coral reefs continue to be destroyed?\nSolving the coral reef problem is a challenge, said one scientist. By law, trees cannot be cut down in certain areas of forest where the butterflies spend the winter. However, some people are cutting down the trees illegally.\nThe trees are very important to the survival of monarchs. "The forest is like an umbrella," said butterfly expert Lincoln Brower. "If you chop holes in the umbrella, you cause trouble. The butterflies get cold and wet and freeze to death."\nMexican government officials are working with scientists to stop illegal logging. They are trying to\n, or move from one area to another. Each fall, monarchs in North America head south for the winter. Most travel to the mountains of central Mexico. Some travel to Florida, California, and Texas. In the spring, the butterflies migrate north.\nWhy might scientist want to protect monarch butterflies?\nSome monarchs travel up to 3,000 miles each way! They are the only butterflies in the world that make such a long, round-trip migration. Scientists hope to protect the magnificent monarchs by saving the forest. "If the forest continues to be cut down, the monarchs will have no place to go," said Brower.\nmeasures published under license with MetaMetrics, Inc.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '2'}

Global warming is the slow rise of Earth\'s temperature. Scientists say one cow releases up to 150 gallons of methane a day!\nAll that belching adds up. Pollutants are harmful chemicals or wastes that get into the air, land, or water.\nMost of the pollutants come from factories. Other pollutants are chemicals used to kill insects, weeds, and other pests. "Most of these chemicals come from outside the Arctic," said Arctic expert Samantha Smith. Wind and water carry the chemicals to the Arctic.\nPlants and animals are linked together by the food chain. For example, a fish eats a tiny shrimplike animal. A seal eats the fish. A polar bear eats the seal.\nIn the Arctic, the pollutants poison the\n. A food chain is made up of the various plants and animals that other animals eat.\nThe pollutants stick to plants that grow in the water. Tiny animals in the water eat the plants. Fish eat both the plants and tiny animals. The fish also eat poisons from those plants and animals.\nAnimals such as polar bears, seals, foxes, killer whales, and birds eat the poisoned fish. That is why so many animals are now in poor health. Some of them have trouble fighting diseases, scientists say.\n"If these chemicals continue to build up in Arctic animals, it will be difficult for them to have babies. {'text': "Some people are afraid of horseshoe crabs. Their hard shells, pointy tails, and six pairs of legs make them scary-looking animals. But horseshoe crabs actually help people. Their special blue blood is used by doctors to help fight diseases. Now some scientists say the number of horseshoe crabs is falling, and they need our help.\nScientists believe the horseshoe crab population around the world is falling--for many reasons. Fishermen catch horseshoe crabs and use them as bait. Pollution is hurting some of the areas in North America, from Maine to Mexico, where horseshoe crabs live. Seabirds hunt the crabs and eat the eggs that female horseshoe crabs lay.\nIn the United States, some states are passing laws that say how many crabs can be caught each year. The U.S. government wants to make Delaware Bay, where many horseshoe crabs live, a protected area. Delaware Bay is near Virginia, Maryland, and Delaware.\nHorseshoe crabs help doctors fight diseases. Doctors use horseshoe crab blood to test medicines for harmful germs. Crab blood\nor thickens, when it comes in contact with germs that can cause disease. If the crab blood does not clot, the medicine is free of bacteria, and people can safely use it.\nDoctors use a needle to remove some of the special blue blood from a crab. Blood is taken from about 300,000 horseshoe crabs each year. Scientists say that no horseshoe crabs are killed when the blood is taken. The horseshoe crabs are later returned to their\nEfforts are being made to help protect horseshoe crabs. Scientists warn it will take 20 to 30 years to see if the horseshoe crab population has increased.\nScientists say horseshoe crabs were around when the dinosaurs lived. Why haven't horseshoe crabs become extinct?\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n", 'label': '2'}

"It\'s like becoming a bird yourself," he told\nJoe Duff is the team leader of a group called Operation Migration. Members have been teaching "whoopers" to\nto Florida since 2001. When animals migrate, they move from one place to another.\nOperation Migration workers train the young whoopers to follow very light aircraft called\n. Each aircraft is flown by a pilot in a whooping crane costume. In six months, the birds will be ready to follow the aircraft and migrate to Florida for the winter.\nThe whooping crane is an endangered bird. Only one flock of whooping cranes lives naturally in the wild. Those birds migrate between Canada and Texas. Scientists decided that having more than one flock would keep these birds from dying out.\nWhooping cranes trained by Operation Migration in the past have remembered the route. They return to Wisconsin each spring and fly back to Florida in the fall.\n"We want our birds to pay attention to us for the first year, until we get them down to Florida," said Duff. {'text': "Mars is about to become a busy place. Recently, the U.S. space agency, NASA, announced plans to send six spacecraft to Mars in the next ten years. Scientists hope the missions will answer questions about Mars. The spacecraft will take pictures of the planet. Some spacecraft will even collect samples of the soil on Mars to study. NASA first sent spacecraft to Mars in the 1960s. Since then, several spacecraft have landed on Mars. One of the most exciting landings happened in 1997, when\nlanded on Mars. Millions of people on Earth watched as it's tiny rover, Sojourner, wandered over the planet's surface.\nMars is the fourth planet from the sun. It is often called the Red Planet because it looks red from Earth. Mars looks red because its surface has lots of iron. The iron has rusted and turned a reddish-brown color. Sometimes, winds on Mars whip the reddish dust into the sky, turning the sky pink.\nA dust storm whips across the Martian surface. Dust storms often form in the Martian spring. A dust storm forms when high winds pick up sand and blow it across the surface. Large dust storms can last for months and blanket the entire planet with the red dust.\nTwo dry riverbeds cut across the surface of Mars. Each riverbed is more than a half-mile deep. Scientists say the riverbeds formed when water suddenly gushed to the surface from inside Mars. The riverbeds might have formed billions of years ago, scientists say. Hundreds of dry riverbeds crisscross the Red Planet.\nValles Marineris is the largest canyon on Mars. It is nearly 2,500 miles long and about 4 miles deep. On Earth, it would almost span the distance between New York City and Los Angeles. (The Grand Canyon on Earth is only 227 miles long and 1 mile deep!) The volcanoes on Mars are larger than volcanoes on Earth. The largest Martian volcano, is about the same size as Arizona at its base.\nMars has ice caps at its north and south poles, much like Earth has. But Martian ice caps are made of water ice and frozen carbon dioxide, or dry ice. The polar ice caps grow in the winter and shrink in the summer. This photo shows the planet's south pole in summer.\nOne day on Mars is 24 hours long; one year is 687 days long.\nTemperatures on Mars range from -220 degrees Fahrenheit (F) to 68 degrees F.\nMars has two small moons, Phobos and Deimos.\nA person who weighs 50 pounds on Earth would weigh 19 pounds on Mars.\nmeasures published under license with MetaMetrics, Inc.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n", 'label': '2'}

{'text': 'After years of protection, bald eagles and other endangered animals are making a comeback.\nThe future looks bright for some endangered animals! Thanks to tough laws and hardworking scientists, many of these animals are doing well.\nThe bald eagle is one success story. The bird became the symbol of the United States in 1782. At that time, about 100,000 bald eagles lived in the lower 48 states. By 1963, only 417 nesting pairs remained.\nHunting and loss of habitat contributed to the\nor drop in number. However, the biggest threat came from DDT, a chemical used for farming. DDT made the birds’ eggshells so thin that chicks couldn’t survive.\nor not allowed. In 1973, the Endangered Species Act was created. That law protects threatened plants and animals. Bald eagles soon gained protection under this law.\nToday, there are more than 7,100 bald eagle nesting pairs in the lower 48 states. Plans are under way to take the birds off the endangered species list. If that happens, they will still be protected by other U.S. laws.\n"It is a good endangered species success story," spokesperson Nicholas Throckmorton of the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service told\n"Caring citizens have brought our national symbol back from the brink of extinction."\nThe bald eagle isn’t the only endangered species doing well. Now the number of nesting females has jumped to more than 400.\nof California were once killed by pollution and fishermen. In 1938, there were only 700 otters off the coast of California. {'text': 'Nine-year-old Steven Vance of Michigan is a hero. He recently saved his mother’s life.\nHis mother was eating a piece of chicken while walking around the kitchen. Suddenly, she began to choke on her food. She thought, "What should I do?"\nLuckily, Steven knew exactly what to do. He jumped up and rushed to his mother. Steven stood behind her and put his hands over her stomach. Then he pressed in and up, forcing out the piece of chicken.\n. That is a special move that can save the life of someone who is choking.\nHow did Steven know what to do? He had read about the lifesaving move in Weekly Reader last year. "It’s amazing that he learned it from reading a diagram," said Steven’s mother. "That information really helped me out."\n1. Stand behind the choking person and wrap your arms around his or her waist.\n2. Make a fist and hold it against the person’s stomach, about halfway between the belly button and the rib cage.\n3. Grab your fist with your other hand. Press it in with an upward thrust. Repeat until the person stops choking.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '2'}

(Told you she was smart.)\nis a way of asking a small part of a large group of people what they think. One of the first political polls was done in 1824!\nIn those days, newspapers asked readers to write in saying the person they liked for president. One newspaper did a poll that said Andrew Jackson would be president. But Jackson didn\'t get enough votes to win. John Quincy Adams won that election and became our seventh president.\nWhy was the newspaper wrong? The biggest problem was that only the readers of that one newspaper took part in the poll. It did not show what all people in the U.S. felt.\nBy the 1960s, polling became more scientific. Such a scientific poll was used by John F. Kennedy during the 1960 presidential election. The poll, done by Louis Harris, figured out what issues people were worried about. For a poll to be scientific, three things must happen.\nThe people who run a poll need to get a sample of people. A\nis a small part of a larger group of people. A sample for a poll must include ALL types of people, like boys and girls, young and old. Also, no one can know who is going to get picked for a poll\'s sample. And no one can volunteer to take part in a poll.\nA poll\'s questions must be thought out. The questions need to be\nThat means the questions don\'t lead people to answer one way or another.\nFinally, experts, sometimes with the help of math, study the\nor people\'s answers. Then they put the data into charts so that it is easier for everyone to understand.\nIt\'s As Easy As One, Two, Three\nSo how did Polly and I poll the people of Polling Place? Here\'s how we did it.\nThe first step was to figure out the subject of the poll. That was easy! We wrote down the following on a piece of paper:\nAs a resident of Polling Place, which new town motto do you prefer?\nPolling Place: A Place That\'s Right on the Numbers.\nPolling Place: A Cool Place for Birds!\nThe tough part of polling is figuring out how to ask people our questions and get their answers. In September, he climbed the seventh summit, Mount Kosciuszko in Australia.\nTo prepare for the climbs, Erik spent more than 1,000 hours training each year. He walked on a treadmill every day. "I can\'t use my eyes, so I use my hands and my feet to feel what I\'m doing," said Erik.\nThe mountains that Erik climbed are all different. Some are rocky. Others are covered in snow and ice. {'text': "The life cycle of a frog is amazing. Read below to learn more. (Note: Although many frogs have this life cycle, others do not. Some frogs don't even have tadpoles; instead their eggs hatch directly into frogs!)\nA frog begins life as a tiny egg, usually in or near water.\nAfter about 10 days, a tadpole hatches from the egg. It breathes using gills and moves like a fish.\nAfter about five weeks, the tadpole's gills disappear, and it grows lungs.\nAt about 12 weeks, the young frog grows legs, and its tail disappears. It leaves the water and can live on land.\nIn about one year, the frog is a full-grown adult. Soon, the cycle will begin again.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n", 'label': '2'}

(A century is 100 years.) The park protects the site of an ancient Native American city.\nAll year, the park has celebrated with special events. {'text': 'Did you ever wonder what it’s like to hug a beluga whale or pat its tongue? Some\neditors--including me--found out firsthand. My name is Lisa Guidone. I’m the Managing Editor of Edition 4.\nIn July, we visited Mystic Aquarium in Connecticut. At the aquarium, we waded in a tank and played with three beluga whales--Inuk, Naku, and Kela.\nBefore we got in the tank, we put on special brown overalls called\n. The waders kept us not only dry but also warm. The water in the beluga tank was about 57 degrees Fahrenheit. The temperature is kept low because, in the wild, beluga whales live in icy waters around the North Pole.\nIn the ocean, these playful white and gray whales often swim in\n, or small groups. Boris, the whales’ trainer, told us that belugas are\n, or friendly, animals that enjoy being touched. The belugas hugged us, splashed us, and even gave us high-fives with their flippers!\nBoris showed us how the beluga whales respond to different hand signals and touches. He said it takes a few days to teach a beluga a skill like waving its flipper and up to a year to teach a more complicated skill, such as jumping out of the water.\nWhen the belugas followed directions, Boris rewarded them with squid and herring. Those are part of a beluga’s diet in the wild. We playfully clapped the belugas’ tongues. Belugas don’t use their teeth to chew food. They swallow their food whole.\nAlthough they don’t look like birds, belugas are often called "sea canaries." That is because a beluga makes various noises and "talks" to other belugas. It does that by producing different sounds, including squeals and whistles, from the\non the top of its head. A beluga also breathes through its blowhole.\nNaku made different noises from her blowhole, based on how her skin was tapped. {'text': 'Heavy backpacks can put stress on your spine.\nIs your backpack weighing you down? If so, consider lightening your load. A recent study shows that lugging around a bulky backpack that doesn\'t fit correctly can lead to poor\nIf someone tells you that good posture is important, that person is referring to the position of your body when you stand, sit, or walk. Carrying around too much weight in your backpack can force you to bend forward. Slouching over can round your shoulders and cause your upper back to curve.\nOver time, the extra stress on your back can create posture problems. Some doctors think those problems may lead to neck and back pain.\nThirteen children, ages 8 and 9, participated in the backpack study. They walked about 1,130 feet. That is about the average length of a child\'s walk to school. The kids walked with backpacks that weighed 9 to 13 pounds. The children also walked without backpacks.\nThe study\'s researchers found that the heavier the backpack load, the more children bent down to support its weight. Afterward, some kids complained that their lower backs and shoulders hurt.\nHeidi Orloff, one of the researchers, said that she could tell when the backpacks were too heavy or the kids were tired. "The kids\' chins drop to their chests," she told\nAn estimated 40 million school-age children in the United States use backpacks. Some health groups say that more than half of those students may be carrying backpacks heavy enough to affect their posture.\nWhen worn correctly, backpacks have many benefits. They have lots of compartments that help you stay organized. Compared with shoulder bags, backpacks are a better way to carry around the items you need for school. Your body\'s strongest muscles-in the back and stomach-support the weight of a backpack. A shoulder bag often puts strain unevenly on your body.\nHowever, most health experts recommend that kids carry backpacks that are no more than 15 percent of their body weight. That means a 70-pound student should wear a backpack that weighs less than 10 1/2 pounds. Orloff also said that spot checks around the country show that many children are carrying backpacks that weigh between 20 and 25 pounds. Now, that\'s quite a burden!\nBelow, you\'ll find some tips to help ease your load. Your back will thank you!\nChoose a backpack that is the right size for your body.\nUse both shoulder straps and fasten the waist strap to balance the weight evenly.\nAdjust the shoulder straps so that the backpack is close to your body.\nPack only what you need and place the heaviest items closest to the center of your back.\nWhat are other ways you can help improve your posture?\nThat means you should bend at the knees when you pick up your backpack.\nmeasures published under license with MetaMetrics, Inc.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}

The soldiers cleared land mines from the area. In the future, roads and railroads might be built there. The roads would link the two countries for the first time in almost 50 years.\nThe no man\'s land was set up after fighting in the Korean War ended in 1953. It is a\nzone (DMZ). The DMZ is not under anyone\'s military control.\n"Today we are standing at the start of a new era during which the South and the North will move forward hand in hand toward the future," said a South Korean official as the search for land mines started. "We are burying a history marked by the scars of war and the pain of division."\nAfter World War II ended in 1945, Korea was divided into two countries-North Korea and South Korea. On June 25, 1950, North Korea invaded South Korea.\nSixteen countries including the United States sent soldiers to help South Korea. All 16 countries were members of the United Nations. China and the Soviet Union helped the North Koreans. About 2 million died in the war. Many of the casualties were civilians. More than 107,230 U.S. soldiers were killed.\nMost of the fighting ended when an armistice, or agreement to stop fighting, was signed on July 27, 1953. Land mines were placed in the DMZ to keep the two sides from combat.\nHowever, the two sides never signed a peace treaty. The two sides continued to fight occasionally. Now the countries are trying to settle their differences and work together.\nmeasures published under license with MetaMetrics, Inc.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}

{'text': 'A NASA Spacecraft Lands on an Asteroid for the First Time.\nOn February 12, scientists on Earth fired rockets on the\nspacecraft, turning it toward Eros. Eros is an\n, or space rock that is orbiting the sun. As the spacecraft slowly descended, it bounced and scientists were afraid the craft would crash.\nShown is the location of the asteroid belt in our solar system, and the orbit of Eros.\n: The planets and their orbits are not drawn to scale.\nbegan its incredible space odyssey five years ago. NASA (National Aeronautics and Space Administration) launched the spacecraft in 1996. For the next four years,\nsped toward Eros, covering nearly 2 billion miles.\nAfter studying a few other space objects, the spacecraft settled into orbit around Eros on February 14, 2000. During the following year, the craft took more than 160,000 photos of the potato-shaped asteroid.\ncompleted its mission orbiting Eros, NASA scientists decided to try to land the car-sized spacecraft on the asteroid. If the craft succeeded,\nwould become the first craft to land on an asteroid. Scientists knew that the odds were against a safe landing, but they thought it was worth trying. "Chances [were] less than 1 percent for [\n] to land intact," said scientist Helen Worth.\nNASA scientists on Earth guided the spacecraft toward the surface of Eros by remote control. Descending at 4 miles per hour, the spacecraft landed after bouncing once.\nThinking that the spacecraft had crashed, scientists were surprised to learn that it was sending information from the asteroid\'s surface. "It\'s working, and we are getting good information," said NASA scientist Jacob Trombka shortly after the landing. As a result of the successful landing, NASA continued the mission for an additional ten days.\nScientists already know that most asteroids orbit the sun between Mars and Jupiter in an area called the\n. Eros, however, is a kind of asteroid that comes closer to Earth than most asteroids. Such asteroids are called\n. Scientists believe that Eros may be similar to the near-Earth asteroid that slammed into Earth 65 million years ago, probably killing the dinosaurs.\nAbout 350 near-Earth asteroids have been found. Scientists carefully map the orbits of those asteroids. They say those asteroids will not hit Earth anytime soon. However, one might hit someday, scientists say.\nThere may be another 1,000 near-Earth asteroids scientists haven\'t discovered. Scientists worry that one of the unknown asteroids might threaten Earth. Scientists will use the information they gathered from Eros to protect Earth from asteroids that come too close to the third rock from the sun.\nEros is about twice the length of Manhattan, New York.\nEros orbits the sun once every 21 months.\nEros has so little gravity that a baseball hit on its surface would fly into space.\nA person weighing 200 pounds on Earth would weigh 2 ounces on Eros.\nThe daytime temperature on Eros is about 212 degrees Fahrenheit.\nThe nighttime temperature on Eros is about -238 degrees Fahrenheit.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}

{'text': '"May I stay up just a little longer?" That\'s the cry heard from kids every night in many U.S. households. That\'s because most kids don\'t want to go to bed.\nInstead of sleeping, many kids are watching latenight TV, playing computer games, reading, doing homework, or chatting with friends. According to a recent report, staying up late may be costing kids more than just a few winks.\nThe National Sleep Foundation (NSF) recently studied the sleeping patterns of 12- to 18-year olds. The NSF study says only 15 percent of kids get at least 8? hours of sleep per night. The NSF says kids need 9 to 11 hours of sleep each night.\nJennifer McCandless, age 13, said she tries to go to bed on time each night. Jennifer explained what happens if she doesn\'t get enough sleep. "I\'m like a zombie-- awake, but not doing anything," she said.\nWill Wilkoff is a children\'s doctor and sleep expert in Maine. He said one reason kids aren\'t getting enough sleep is that families are busier than ever before. Families are trying "to squeeze 28 hours of living into 24 [hours]," Wilkoff said.\nIn the past, most kids would go home right after school. Today, kids often have several after-school activities. When kids do get home, they have homework to do. All of this activity keeps kids from going to bed when they should.\nKids who don\'t get enough sleep can have problems at school. The study found that kids who don\'t get enough sleep at night often fall asleep during the day. Sixty percent of the kids in the study said they have felt tired during the day. Twenty percent said they have even fallen asleep at school.\nKids who are tired have problems remembering information. The study found that kids who don\'t get at least nine hours of sleep at night get lower grades than kids who get enough sleep.\nWilkoff said that kids have to develop a schedule that lets them get enough sleep. "Make those tough decisions," he said, "and say, \'We\'re going to have to give up one or two of our activities.\' "\nIf a kid loses one hour of sleep a night, how many hours of sleep does he or she lose in a week? A month? A year?\nmeasures published under license with MetaMetrics, Inc.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}

{'text': 'People in some states pay a deposit when they buy bottles and cans of soft drinks. When they return the empty bottles and cans to a redemption center, they get their deposits back. Now some lawmakers in Maine want people to pay a 5-cent deposit on each cigarette they buy. If the bill passes, people could return used cigarette butts to get a deposit back.\nThe lawmakers who introduced the bill say they did so for two reasons. First, such a plan would lead to fewer crushed cigarette butts littering the landscape. "I think [the law] could work to reduce waste," said Maine lawmaker Scott Cowger, who cosponsored the bill in Maine\'s House of Representatives.\nSecond, a cigarette deposit law would raise money for antismoking education programs in Maine schools. The bill\'s sponsors admit they expect only a small percentage of people will redeem cigarette butts. But those nickel deposits that aren\'t redeemed could add up to as much as $50 million for school antismoking programs.\nSome people in Maine have problems with the cigarette deposit bill. {'text': 'Our sun is a seething ball of hot gases. The sun is always active, but for the rest of this year, the sun will be more active than usual, scientists say.\nActivity on the sun can affect Earth. It can disrupt communications. It can also cause the\n, which are shifting curtains of colored light.\nWhen the sun is very active, dark spots, called\n, dot the sun\'s surface. Each day, scientists can see more than 100 sunspots on the sun. Sunspots slowly change shape and move across the sun\'s surface.\nSunspots have a temperature of 7,000 degrees Fahrenheit (F). That might seem hot, but it is cooler than the rest of the sun\'s surface, which is a sweltering 10,000 degrees F. Because sunspots are cooler than the rest of the surface, they look dark--almost like shadows.\nWhen the sun is very active, huge explosions can rip across its surface. Those explosions, called\n, propel solar material into space. About three or four days after a flare erupts on the sun, the flare may collide with Earth\'s atmosphere.\nWhen a flare reaches Earth, it can damage satellites orbiting Earth, power stations, and electrical equipment. In July, a huge flare interfered with communication satellites.\nThe sun is about 93 million miles from Earth.\nA car traveling at 55 miles per hour would take 193 years to get from Earth to the sun.\nIt takes a beam of light eight minutes to travel from the surface of the sun to Earth.\nWhen solar flares reach our planet, they can make gases in Earth\'s atmosphere glow. The glowing gases form the northern lights.\nThe northern lights can be many different colors: red, blue, green, or a combination of colors.\nScientists say the best time to see the northern lights is when the sun is active. People in many parts of the United States should be able to see the northern lights in the night sky this fall. People who live in the northern part of the United States have the best chance of seeing the dancing lights. To see them, the sky must be very dark.\nsenior editor Fran Downey once saw an aurora (the northern lights) while visiting Washington state. "It began as a dull green light and got brighter and brighter, until it lit up the sky," Downey said. "In the distance, I could hear coyotes howling at the aurora. It was beautiful."\nmeasures published under license with MetaMetrics, Inc.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}

The diagram shows the kidneys in front of other body organs so you can see them. The kidneys are actually behin these organs.\nThe kidneys filter waste from the body and make urine. Although a person has two kidneys, he or she needs only one to stay alive. People who have diseased kidneys may need a\nto stay alive. In a kidney transplant operation, doctors remove the diseased kidney and replace it with a working kidney.\nIn the United States, many people suffer from kidney disease. According to Arroyo\'s doctor, David Hull, more than 47,000 people are waiting for kidney transplants. For many of those people, finding a kidney is a problem.\nSome of Evelyn Arroyo\'s relatives offered a kidney, but their kidneys did not match the tissue that made up Arroyo\'s kidneys. Arroyo\'s family feared she might die before a matching kidney was found.\nThat\'s when Bocchichio volunteered one of his kidneys, which matched Arroyo\'s tissue. Abby lives in a forest on St. Bees Island, 19 miles off the northeastern coast of Australia.\nI am one of eight volunteers visiting this tropical island. We have joined a research team whose members hope to find ways to protect koalas throughout Australia.\nKoalas are pictured everywhere in AustraliaÑon cleaning products, on boxes of chocolate, on sports team jerseys. Yet the animals are found only in isolated pockets up and down the east coast.\nKoalas were once found throughout the entire range, but farmers cut down many of the forests where koalas lived. Hunters also killed the animals for their fur. By the early 1900s, "koalas were basically shot out of south Australia," says team leader and\nBill Ellis. An ecologist is a scientist who studies the relationships among living things and their environments.\n"Here she is!" yells Jane Stanfield, one of the volunteers, when she spots Abby. Abby is perched in a blue gum, a type of eucalyptus (yoo-kuh-LIP-tuhss) tree. The koalas on St. Bees live and sleep in the trees. Koalas eat a steady diet of eucalyptus leavesÑtheir main source of food.\nAlthough koalas can walk on the ground, they are better suited for life in the\nthe high cover of branches and leaves in a forest. Whenever we find one of the furry leaf eaters, we collect information about the trees in the area. We measure how tall and how fat the trees are. Then we put tags on their trunks so we know theyâ€™ve been recorded.\nA few days after tracking Abby, our team encounters more koalas, including one named Yellow. Ellis measures and checks both mom and baby to ensure that theyâ€™re healthy. (See sidebar "\nWhat has Ellisâ€™s research taught him so far? Compared with koalas in other areas, the St. Bees koala population seems to be healthy. Yet Ellis wonders whether the koalas on St. Bees could be headed for hard times. The island is overrun with wild goats. Ellis thinks the goats are eating the small blue gum trees.\nWithout those trees, koalas will run out of food in the future. Ellis hopes more research will help him understand how to protect the blue gumsÑand the koalas that depend on them.\n(mahr- SOO-pee-uhlz). A marsupial is an animal that often has a pouch in which to carry its young.\nThey spend most of their time in eucalyptus trees.\nA koala eats about 2 ? pounds of eucalyptus leaves each day. Koalas eat so many leaves that they often smell like eucalyptus cough drops.\nEucalyptus leaves are not very nutritious. As a result, koalas spend up to 18 hours a day sleeping. That helps them store up energy.\nBill Ellis shakes the branches of a tree where a koala named Yellow rests.\nAs volunteers hold a plastic sheet to catch Yellow, Ellis (in the red-and-blue cap) gently pushes her into a sack.\nVolunteers hold Yellow in the sack as they adjust a radio collar around her neck. {'text': 'Wildfires will be California\'s most expensive natural disaster.\nThe wildfires that recently swept through southern California have been called one of the Golden State\'s worst natural disasters. The raging wildfires destroyed homes, businesses, and forests. Nearly 750,000 acres burned-an area of land about the size of Rhode Island. "The whole sky seemed as if it was on fire," said one California resident.\nInvestigators say both people and nature were to blame for the fires. The fires spread rapidly because of the Santa Ana winds, which blow hot, dry air from the desert. Cold and rainy weather eventually rolled in to help quench the flames.\nAbout 15,000 firefighters battled flames that were out of control. Shaw, who is blind, said he felt like Cuddles from a television program. Shaw and his wife contacted the Guide Horse foundation in Kittrell, North Carolina. "Horses make excellent guides," said trainer Janet Burleson. "It is very common in the wild state for a blind horse to bond to a sighted horse that it uses as it\' guide."\nGuide horses are usually between 26 and 27 inches tall and weigh between 80 and 100 pounds-about the same size as many guide dogs. However, not just any small horse can be a guide horse, says Burleson. It needs to have the right personality and intelligence level. Like a guide dog, Cuddles has been house trained. She will tap her hoof on the door when she needs to go outside. Unlike guide dog, however, she doesn\'t sleep in the house. Instead, she sleeps in a small barn.\nShaw says that everyone wants to pet Cuddles because the tiny horse is so cute. But people should not pet Cuddles or any other service animal. Petting can distract a guide animal from its job of keeping a blind person safe. Cuddles and Shaw have traveled many places together, including the Empire State Building in New York City. "Every time I hear the gasps of amazement from an onlooker who has just realized that Cuddles is not a guide dog, I smile Shaw says.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}

{'text': 'National program is launched to erase head lice from schools.\nAn adult head louse is about the size of a sesame seed.\nSpiders and bats may spook you, but nothing will make your skin crawl more than head lice. Each year, 6 million to 12 million Americans get lice. Many of those affected are school kids.\nHead lice outbreaks are the number-one reason that kids miss school. Now the National Parent Teacher Association is fighting back against lice. The group is launching a program called Keeping Our Kids Lice Free.\nThe tiny bugs, each about the size of a sesame seed, spread quickly from one person to another. The bugs can’t fly, but they can crawl.\nExperts say the most common way to catch lice is through head-to-head contact. Lice can also be spread through the sharing of personal items such as hats, scarves, headphones, barrettes, and combs.\nHead lice don’t discriminate. They like everybody equally. It doesn’t matter how often a person showers or bathes. Health experts say to follow these tips to keep the bugs from making your head their home.\nAvoid touching your head to someone else’s head.\nDon’t share personal items with your friends or classmates.\nUse your own sleeping bag and pillow on sleepovers.\nmeasures published under license with MetaMetrics, Inc.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}
