{'text': 'How did the universe begin? Most scientists think that it happened with a giant cosmic explosion. That idea is known as the Big Bang theory. A\nis a way scientists explain how or why something happens.\nIn the past, scientists estimated that the universe was between 13 and 15 billion years old. Now, thanks to satellite technology, they are able to confirm its approximate age at 13.7 billion years old-give or take 100 million years. The snapshot provides answers to questions about the age and origins of the universe.\n"We see the results as a gold mine for learning about our universe," said NASA scientist Charles Bennett. "The future of the Yellowstone grizzly bears is bright," says Chris Servheen of the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service.\nThat wasn’t always the case. The numbers of grizzlies began to shrink in the early 1900s largely because ranchers hunted the animals and farmers destroyed their\nBy 1975, only 220 to 320 bears still lived in the Yellowstone area. That year, the grizzly was listed as a threatened species under the Endangered Species Act, which offers special protection to animals facing extinction. Today, wildlife experts estimate that more than 600 bears live in the region surrounding Yellowstone.\nGrizzly bears live in other parts of Idaho, Montana, and Wyoming as well as Washington state and will remain on the list in those areas. Grizzlies in Alaska, which number about 30,000, have never been on the list because that population is healthy.\nIt’s Not Time Yet Not everyone thinks it’s a good decision to remove grizzlies from the list. Some wildlife officials fear that if the bear is removed from the list, its habitat around Yellowstone could be used for logging, oil drilling, and development. Others worry that the bears will be hunted again. "We would love to see the grizzly bear delisted, but it’s not ready," says wildlife supporter Louisa Wilcox. "If you want to protect bears for future generations, you have to protect the habitat they need. This plan doesn’t do it."\nShould grizzlies no longer be listed as an endangered species? {'text': 'Standing atop a hill this summer in the dense jungles of Guatemala, a country in Central America, scientist Arthur Demarest felt his feet sink into the jungle vines.\nDemarest plunged into a deep, tangled snake hole up to his armpits. Hearing snakes slithering around him, Demarest froze. For half an hour, the scientist didn\'t move, waiting for the snakes to settle down so he could climb out safely. While stuck in that snaky situation, Demarest looked around and realized the pit was actually part of a jungle-covered three-story building.\nAs soon as he got out of the hole, Demarest and his team of scientists explored the hill. They found that it was an ancient palace built by the Maya people. The Mayan civilization covered parts of Mexico and Central America, and reached its greatest power between the years 250 and 900.\nDemarest\'s team also discovered a city surrounding the palace. The Maya people called the city\n, which means "place of serpents." The palace at Cancu始 was built more than 1,300 years ago by the Mayan king Tah ak Chaan.\nSo far, Demarest and his team have counted 170 rooms in the palace, which has 11 courtyards and covers an area the size of two football fields. Because of its sturdy limestone walls, the palace is in extremely good condition, Demarest said.\nDemarest said Cancu始 is different from other Mayan cities. Unlike the other Mayan cities, Cancu始 doesn\'t have temples or evidence that there was warfare. "The basis of power among the Mayan [kings] was religion and warfare," explained Demarest. "Apparently, Cancu始 needed neither."\nThe drawing shows an artist\'s idea of what the Cancu始 palace might have looked like.\nDemarest said the city must have been very powerful. But its leaders were more focused on\n, or widespread buying and selling, than on religion or warfare.\nLocated near the Pasi溶 River, Cancu始 was a thriving trading center for the Maya. Scientists even uncovered the remains of a woman who had jade false teeth! Finely carved jade statues were found in the graves of workmen.\nDemarest estimates that it will take about 10 to 15 years to\n, or dig out, Cancu始. {'text': 'Every December, certain beaches and islands along the West Coast of the United States and Mexico fill with the sights and sounds of elephant seals. Visitors can\'t miss the huge animals, which make as much noise as a pack of motorcycles.\nTo learn about elephant seals, go to\nUntil recently, however, those beaches were quieter because elephant seals were almost extinct. But in the last few years, the seals have made one of the most amazing comebacks of any animal.\nNearly a century ago, only 100 elephant seals were left in the wild. Hunters had killed the animals for their\n, or fat, which was used to make lamp oil to light people\'s homes. In addition, their skins were often used for clothing.\nIn 1972, the U.S. government passed a law protecting elephant seals. Now, because of that law, more than 150,000 of the seals live in the wild.\nElephant seals spend much of the year swimming in the Pacific Ocean, far from shore. The seals are looking for food, such as fish and squid. They can swim about 35 miles from shore and dive as deep as 5,000 feet below the ocean surface to search for food. (That\'s about as deep as a whale can dive!)\nBy December, elephant seals head for beaches in California and Mexico. They hit the beaches to mate and raise their young. When male elephant seals, called\n, haul themselves out of the water, they can weigh as much as 4,500 pounds, or two small cars.\nA–o Nuevo is Spanish for "New Year."\nThe world\'s largest colony of elephant seals spends the winter at the A–o Nuevo State Reserve in California. As many as 5,000 elephant seals spend the winter there. Visitors to the reserve can see the giant seals. One visitor said the animals are "a cross between a beanbag and a Volkswagen bug."\nHowever, visitors have to watch out for the giant animals. Seals may look fat and slow, but they anger quickly and can move 20 feet in two seconds.\nSome visitors are scientists who want to figure out ways to help seals survive.\nOne way scientists have learned about elephant seals is by attaching radios to the backs of the animals. The radios send out signals. The radios have helped scientists learn how far and how deep elephant seals swim.\nmeasures published under license with MetaMetrics, Inc.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}
{'text': 'The Aloha State shows just how strong an earthquake can be.\nHawaii is recovering from a shake-up. {'text': 'Manatees often graze in shallow waters off the coast of Florida. These seadwelling plant eaters play with divers and swimmers. The huge animals are often called sea cows because of their large size.\nManatees were once thought to be on the edge of\nor dying out completely. In the 1970s, there were only about 1,000 manatees left. Today, there are more than 3,000.\nAs a result, Florida recently removed the manatee from its list of\nEndangered species are animals or plants that are at risk of dying out.\nThe first laws protecting this slow-moving marine mammal were passed in the late 1970s. Those laws made hunting, capturing, or killing manatees illegal.\nAs Florida’s human population grew, however, manatees faced more threats. Last year alone, 396 manatees died in Florida, according to the state’s Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission.\nMany manatees have been injured or killed in collisions with boats. Others have gotten tangled in fishing gear. Manatees are also threatened because of the loss of their\nAs builders develop along the coastline, they destroy the manatees’ natural homes.\nEnvironmental factors, such as red tide, have also taken their toll on the playful creatures. Red tide occurs when millions of tiny organisms are present in an area of the water. Those tiny organisms turn the ocean red and brown. Some of them are harmful to fish and other animals.\nRed tide occurs naturally in the waters of the Gulf of Mexico. In 2005, more than 80 manatees were killed in red-tide outbreaks.\nNot everyone thinks it is a good idea to remove manatees from the list. Many wildlife experts worry that the unusual mammals will not receive the same protection they had in the past. "We can’t celebrate yet," warned manatee expert Patrick Rose in an interview with\nState officials say that the manatee is not under urgent threat. Although the huge creatures are being removed from Florida’s list, state scientists say that the animal will remain protected under the nation’s Endangered Species Act. That law offers special protection to animals and plants facing extinction.\nWildlife officials say protection of the manatees might even be strengthened. The next step calls for the writing of a plan to continue increasing the number of manatees. "There will be no less protection," says Henry Cabbage of the Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission.\nA manatee recently got a taste of the Big Apple. {'text': 'On New Year\'s Day 2001, Irene Alexander and 2,538 other people gathered at Mount Vernon, George Washington\'s home in Virginia. They came to honor the slaves who had worked there. Martha was carrying out the wishes of the country\'s first president, who had died on December 14, 1799. In his will he had requested that his slaves be freed after his wife\'s death.\nDuring the ceremony, Alexander, a descendant of a slave who worked at Mount Vernon, told visitors, "I hope you all feel, as I do, a sense of joy, a sense of sadness but also a sense of hope that the contributions of good people will always be remembered."\nJennifer Saxon, a spokesperson for Mount Vernon, told\nthat Mount Vernon couldn\'t have prospered without slave labor. Most people thought slavery was OK. When Washington was 11 years old, his father died and left him ten slaves.\nDuring the American Revolution, which began in 1775, some people began to think that slavery was wrong and should be ended. Washington was one of those people. He vowed never to buy another slave.\nIn his will, Washington wrote that all his slaves should be freed. "Upon the [death] of my wife," he wrote, "it is my...desire that all the slaves which I hold in my own right shall receive their freedom."\nTo make sure Washington\'s wishes were carried out, Martha freed his slaves in 1801, a year before she died. Martha, however, kept the slaves she owned when she freed her husband\'s slaves.\nEven though Washington freed the slaves he owned, slavery remained legal in some states for another 64 years, until 1865. {'text': 'Tyrannosaurus means "tyrant lizard," and this meat-eating dinosaur was given its name for a reason. Tyrannosaurus rex, or T. rex, had a powerful jaw and sharp teeth to attack its\n. He says that T. rex, which weighed 7 tons, was too heavy to run fast enough to catch other animals.\nAt 40 feet long, this dinosaur was about the size of a truck. {'text': 'A Look Back at Brown Board of Education\nThis May marks the 50th anniversary of a court case that changed history. That case was\n. On May 17, 1954, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled that having separate schools for black students and white students violated the U.S. Constitution.\nIn 1951, Linda Brown, a third-grade student in Topeka, Kansas, was one of many African American children forced to attend black-only schools. Even though the school for white students was just blocks from her house, Linda had to travel all the way across town to an all-black school.\n, or separate, public schools were legal at the time--as long as the black and white students had an "equal" education. That idea was known as "separate but equal."\nHowever, the reality was that segregation was unequal. Schools for black students were generally run-down and overcrowded and lacked supplies. In comparison, schools for white students were newer and had smaller class sizes and better supplies.\nWhen Linda was denied entrance to the all-white school, her father and 12 other parents sued the Topeka school system. The case was eventually heard by the Supreme Court. The Court ruled that "separate educational facilities are... unequal."\nAs a child, Linda Brown was part of the\nof America\'s public schools. Integration is the act of including people of all races.\nToday, Linda Brown is grown up. She travels around the country to speak about the case. She recently told the\n, "Little did [my father] know when he stepped off the witness stand, he stepped into the pages of history."\nA Look Back at Brown Board of Education\nParents of African American students try to enroll their children in all-white schools.\nLinda Brown\'s father and other parents file a lawsuit for integrated schools.\nThe U.S. Supreme Court first hears the case.\nAll nine Supreme Court justices rule segregation is illegal.\nmeasures published under license with MetaMetrics, Inc.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}
{'text': 'Where the Wild Things Are!: A Numbers Puzzle\nCounting giant pandas in the wild is no easy task. Just ask a team of scientists who recently put their detective skills to the test.\nThe scientists trekked through dense forests in central China to search for clues of giant pandas. China, a country in Asia, is the only place where giant pandas live in the wild.\nAfter spending four years in the country\'s mountainous region, scientists completed the largest\nof giant pandas ever done. A census is a population count.\nThe results of the census surprised scientists! They counted about 1,600 giant pandas living in the wild in China. That is double the number originally thought to live there. "We found giant pandas living in areas we didn\'t know had any," scientist Colby Loucks told\nAlthough the news is hopeful, Loucks and other scientists are quick to point out that giant pandas still need protection. Their\n, or home, is being destroyed as people cut down trees to get wood and to make farmland.\nGiant pandas must eat a lot of bamboo to get the nutrients they need. Pandas spend up to 14 hours a day eating bamboo, because it is not very nutritious.\n, or go into a long sleep, in the winter, because they can\'t store up enough fat on a bamboo diet.\nA newborn panda weighs between 3 and 5 ounces and is about the size of a stick of butter.\nEach front paw on a panda has an extra wrist bone that acts like a thumb to help the panda grasp bamboo shoots.\nScientists needed to collect clues to count pandas because the shy creatures are hard to spot in their natural environment. "Giant pandas are very hard to see in the wild," said Loucks. "They hide in the thick\nBamboo provides giant pandas with their main source of food. Each animal consumes about 80 pounds of this plant\'s stems and leaves a day.\nIn fact, the giant pandas\' survival is linked to eating bamboo. If bamboo disappears in an area, giant pandas there risk starvation.\nTo collect clues, scientists combined the latest technology with old-fashioned tracking skills. Each time they spotted a clue, such as a panda paw print in the mud or fur on the bark of a tree, they entered their finding into a computer. Computer mapping helped them pinpoint the locations of the giant pandas.\nHow will the census results help protect pandas? {'text': "Central Florida cleans up after the first tornadoes of 2007.\nThe windy season in Florida began in a big way. A tornado is a powerful, rotating tube of air that runs from the ground to a thundercloud. The recent tornado was so strong that it lifted a moving tractor-trailer off the ground and dropped it onto another truck. Fortunately, neither driver was seriously hurt. The Florida tornadoes were created by supercell storms.\n Supercells are created when fronts of warm, moist air collide with cold, dry air.\n The opposing warm and cold gusts of air create a rotating column of rising wind called a\n When the funnelshaped cloud touches the ground, it becomes a tornado.\nDuring the recent Florida tornadoes, winds reached speeds of more than 150 miles per hour. The storms were rated EF-3 on the\nScientists use the scale to measure the size and strength of tornadoes. The scale ranges from EF-0, the weakest, and EF-5, the strongest (with winds of more than 200 miles per hour).\nAverage number of tornadoes reported each year in the United States:\nLength of damage trail a tornado can leave: up to\nTornado time span: up to one hour, but most tornadoes last less than\nImagine you're the mayor of a town that has been struck by a tornado. {'text': 'New York City Subway: Then and Now\nNew York City\'s mayor, Michael Bloomberg, is a billionaire who could take a limousine to work. Instead, he rides the subway to his office at City Hall each morning.\n"A hundred years ago, a generation of New Yorkers had the courage and conviction to build a subway system that transformed our city," said Mayor Bloomberg. "Today our subway is the backbone of New York."\nOn October 27, 2004, New York City marked the\n, or hundredth anniversary, of its subway system with special ceremonies. As part of the celebration, people took tours to retrace the original 9.1-mile route from City Hall to Harlem.\nConstruction began on the subway in 1900 and took 12,000 workers four years to complete. At that time, the population of New York City was 3.4 million and growing. People, horse-drawn carriages, trolleys, and vendors packed city streets.\nLibrary of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, Detroit Publishing Company Collection, [reproduction numbers, LC-D4-17293 (L), LC-D4-17294 (R)]\nLeft: City Hall subway station c1900-1906; right: Construction of the Brooklyn Bridge subway station, around 1904.\nCity officials believed that a subway system would help people get around faster and allow them to move into outer areas. What started out as one subway line with 28 stations has grown into 26 lines with 468 stations. A fare in 1904 cost only a nickel. Today, about 4.5 million people ride the subway daily and pay $2 a ride.\nThe subway has seen plenty of change since 1904. Over the years, workers have restored many old subway stations. They have found mosaics and murals hidden under dirt.\nPublic artwork now graces 140 subway stations as part of the Art for Transit program. "You can probably say that the New York subway system is one of the largest art museums in the world," Roxanne Robertson of the New York Transit Museum told\nNew York City Subway: Then and Now\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}

So a wildlife group has begun fitting the elephants with safety reflectors.\nThe reflectors work like the ones you find on a bike, bouncing back light from oncoming cars. The reflectors are attached to ropes that hang near an elephant\'s tail and hind legs.\nIn New Delhi, about 30 elephants work at night to help clear fallen trees. Many elephants are also forced to walk in the dark, after working at weddings and other religious festivals late at night. The elephants\' dark skin makes it difficult for drivers to see them in the evening.\nA wildlife group expert said, "Most of India\'s 5,000 working elephants will soon [be wearing reflectors]." {'text': 'Rosa\'s paws are big, her nose is wet, and her coat is fluffy. But she doesn\'t live a dog\'s life. The 9-year-old shepherd is a land mine-detection dog.Rosa\'s nose has sniffed out some of the world\'s 50 million\n. Land mines are explosive devices left in the ground from wars.A land mine can explode if someone touches it, killing or injuring the person. Children often mistake the land mines for toys.\nNow Rosa\'s job is to teach U.S. children about the dangers of land mines so they can help fight the problem. I recently caught up with the clever canine at Paradise Valley Elementary School, located in Casper, Wyoming.I watched as Rosa did her job sniffing out some fake land mines. "She\'s cool," gushed fifth grader Josh Yelton.\nRosa\'s visit kicked off the Children Against Land Mines Program, also known as CHAMPS. The goal of the program is to raise money to buy, train, and transport mine-sniffing dogs.Wyoming students raised $5,000 in quarters in just a few short weeks, and adults chipped in an additional $8,000. The money will help sponsor a new dog.\nA dog\'s sense of smell and smarts make it the best land-mine locator. In fact, a team of six humans can search about 120 square feet of land in a day. A team of six dogs can search up to 3,000 square feet in a day\'s time.\nThe pooch paid for by the Wyoming students will be named Wyoming. That dog will help find buried land mines in Sri Lanka, a country off the southern coast of India.\nLand mines not only injure and kill many people, but they also\n, or stop, people from moving around freely. For example, the lush fields of Sri Lanka should be filled with crops. Instead, many fields lie unplanted. Farmers are afraid that mines litter their fields. Wyoming\'s job will be to help get rid of those land mines.\nA Sri Lanka government official told me what a huge effect Wyoming and other mine-sniffing dogs will make in his country.\nHe said, "The best part of the CHAMPS program will be when all the land mines have been removed."\nIn what other ways do dogs help humans?\nmeasures published under license with MetaMetrics, Inc.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}
{'text': 'Do you get good grades? Do you talk to your parents about what\'s happening at school and about things you and your friends are doing after school?\nA recent study shows that how kids answer those questions tells a lot about whether they are headed for trouble. The study says kids who spend their free time aimlessly often get into trouble.\nThe study, called the National Longitudinal Study of Adolescent Health, was funded by the federal government. More than 90,000 kids between the ages of 12 and 18 took part in the study. Those kids attended 134 different U.S. schools. The study followed them from 1994 to 2000.\nAbout half of the kids in the study said they were not involved in dangerous activities. But 25 percent said they had tried a cigarette, 26 percent said they had picked up a gun, and 47 percent said they had tried alcohol.\nThe study found that kids who spend their free time hanging out with nothing to do, who get poor grades, or who don\'t talk with their parents are eight times more likely to take part in unhealthful activities later on, such as smoking cigarettes or trying drugs.\nKids who hang out with friends who drink alcohol, smoke cigarettes, or have tried drugs are likely to do what their friends are doing, said Robert Blum. Blum is one of the doctors who conducted the study. In other words, kids tend to act like their friends, Blum said.\n"How young people do at school and what they do with their free time are the most important [ways of predicting] risky behavior," said Blum.\nKids should get involved in interesting activities, Blum advised. Instead of hanging out with kids who are already trying what the study calls "high-risk activities," Blum said that kids should play sports, read, talk with parents, or do homework.\nThe National Longitudinal Study finds that kids who are involved in activities usually don\'t get into trouble. Here\'s a story written by a\nkid reporter about a few kids who know how to spend their time:\nThere are a lot of good kids. {'text': 'People often take trips on our nation\'s roads and highways. But recently, several sections of an old road went on a trip of their own.\nLast month, workers in Oklahoma loaded about a dozen pieces of historic Route 66 onto trucks. Each of the 3,000-pound pieces then made a 1,400-mile trip to Washington, D.C., where they will become part of an exhibit at the Smithsonian National Museum of American History.\nRoute 66 has been called the "Main Street of America." It once stretched 2,400 miles, from Chicago, Illinois, to Los Angeles, California. The road connected eight states: Illinois, Missouri, Kansas, Oklahoma, Texas, New Mexico, Arizona, and California.\nIn the 1920s, engineer Cyrus Stevens Avery of Tulsa, Oklahoma, envisioned a road connecting the Midwest and the Pacific Ocean. During the 1930s, Route 66 was completed and was soon lined with hundreds of businesses.\nThe road became so popular that it inspired a 1960s TV show,\n, as well as a famous song, "Get Your Kicks on Route 66."\nIn the past few decades, however, Route 66 has fallen into disrepair, and parts of the old route have been dug up. Today, drivers use faster superhighways to get where they were going.\nEven though fewer people drive on Route 66 now, many people still think of the road as the Main Street of America. That\'s why the National Museum of American History wants to include the road in its new exhibit, "America on the Move." The exhibit is scheduled to open in 2003.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}

{'text': 'Nose to the Grindstone: Did their special noses protect search-and-rescue dogs after 9/11?\nOn September 11, 2001, help was needed immediately. Terrorists had crashed airplanes into the World Trade Center in New York City, New York, and the Pentagon in Washington, D.C. Police officers and firefighters weren\'t the only ones to respond. More than 200 search-and-rescue dogs used their noses to help find victims.\nDeja Vu, a German shepherd from Pennsylvania, hunted through piles of\nor wreckage, looking for survivors. The air was filled with harmful dust and smoke, but Deja Vu and the other dogs didn\'t wear protective masks. They needed their noses clear because they rely on their powerful sense of smell to find people. (See "\nA rescue dog named Billy helps an emergency worker search for survivors at the site of the World Trade Center collapse\nor dangerous, air at the World Trade Center and Pentagon sites would make the dogs sick. "The environment was so awful, I couldn\'t imagine they wouldn\'t have problems," Otto told\nSo she organized a study to track the dogs\' health.\nToday, more than five years later, Otto has surprising results: Many of the dogs are fine. In fact, the dogs in her study are just as healthy as other search-andrescue dogs not involved in the 9/11 recovery efforts.\nDeja Vu is no exception. "We were concerned [about] what the dogs were inhaling and walking through," Deja Vu\'s handler, Pat Thompson, told\n"But Deja Vu has remained in good health."\nThe study results are surprising because thousands of people who volunteered at the disaster site now have\nor breathing, problems. Scientists say the workers must have breathed in dangerous particles from the collapsed buildings.\nThe search-and-rescue dogs\' noses might have protected them from the bad air, Otto\nor guesses. A dog\'s nose, which is longer than a human\'s nose, can better filter air and keep harmful particles from reaching its lungs.\nsometimes reacts differently than a human\'s immune system does. That system protects the body against diseases and infections. For example, respiratory problems such as asthma are unusual in dogs. Otto and other researchers say that may be why the search-and-rescue dogs haven\'t developed any breathing disorders.\nThe scientists also think the dogs in the study may be healthier than the people who worked at the sites because most of the canines spent less time at the disaster sites than their two-legged counterparts. Many rescue workers who developed breathing problems spent months volunteering after the attacks. The dogs in Otto\'s study spent an average of 10 days helping.\nScientists may never pinpoint the exact reason that most of the dogs in Otto\'s study are in good health. But Otto hopes to continue the study for as long as the dogs live. She wants to stay on the lookout for any health problems that may develop over the next few years.\nShe plans to use the information she gathers to protect search-andrescue dogs on future disaster missions. "No piece of equipment can ever do the job that these dogs do," Otto told\nEach human has a unique scent, like a fingerprint. That scent comes from a mixture of sweat and tiny flakes of skin, called\nwhich people continually shed. Shampoo, deodorant, perfume, and clothing can also affect a person\'s scent.\nSearch-and-rescue dogs are trained to pick up a person\'s scent from the air. Their noses are powerful enough to smell people who are underground or even underwater. The dogs are so\nor good at what they do, that a single searchand- rescue canine team is equal to about 20 human searchers, according to the National Search and Rescue Dog Association.\nWhat are some other ways in which dogs protect people?\nmeasures published under license with MetaMetrics, Inc.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}

{'text': 'On a December morning, shortly before dawn, Danny Thompson, age 10, looked through a small telescope. He saw a round red disk-Mars. "Someday I will go to Mars," Danny said later.\nOver the years, many people have dreamed of going to Mars. The day when travel to Mars is possible is coming closer. Robot spacecraft have already traveled there. Those spacecraft have made many amazing discoveries.\nThe most recent spacecraft to journey to the fourth rock from the sun is\n. It started orbiting the red planet more than a year ago.\nRecent photos taken by Mars Odyssey show that Mars has water. Because it is very cold on Mars, the water is frozen. Most of the water is frozen under the surface of Mars.\nEven though lots of ice crystals are mixed in with the Martian soil, Mars doesn\'t have as much water as Earth has. Mars has lakes of water, not oceans of water. In fact, scientists say that if you collected all the water on Mars, it would fill a lake about twice the size of Lake Michigan.\nThere is evidence that some of the frozen water locked under the surface of Mars might melt every once in a while. Some of the water is only 18 inches below the surface. Molten rock deep beneath the surface of Mars might heat the ice. The melted ice might mix with salt deposits in the Martian soil and flow down steep canyon walls.\n- a vehicle that flies through space\n-a device that makes objects look closer than they are\nshow long, dark streaks on the walls of some canyons. The streaks might indicate areas where water recently flowed down the canyon walls.\nNot all scientists agree, however. Many scientists say wind blowing across Mars caused the streaks. Scientists have long known about powerful wind storms on Mars. Some of those storms blow across the surface for months at a time.\nEven if liquid water and life do not exist on Mars today, many scientists agree with Danny. They want to explore the red planet."I\'m interested in Mars because it\'s probably the most fascinating planet in the solar system besides Earth, and probably the only one that could have ever supported other forms of life," said one NASA scientist.\nmeasures published under license with MetaMetrics, Inc.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}

{'text': 'People Say That Sharing Music Files Is...\nThe music industry is causing hundreds of people to sing the blues. One of those people is 12-year-old Brianna LaHara from New York City. As a result, she was one of 261 people sued by the Recording Industry Association of America in early September. Brianna was targeted because she had swapped more than 1,000 songs online.\nApproximately 60 million people download music files from the Internet. In most cases, that is against the law. The music industry has compared it with shoplifting, saying most people wouldn\'t steal CDs from a store.\nThere are laws that exist to protect the rights of musicians. The laws say it is illegal to copy songs without permission from musicians and record companies.\nDuring the past three years, CD sales have fallen. He didn\'t know that his grandchildren had copied music onto his computer.\nSome people have said they didn\'t know they were breaking the law. {'text': 'Have you ever stayed up late to finish watching a movie? If so, you know that not getting enough sleep can leave you tired, grouchy, and unable to think clearly the next day.\nScientists have long known that getting a good night\'s sleep helps kids perform their best during the day. Now, a new study from German scientists shows that getting a good night\'s sleep helps improve problem-solving skills and creative thinking.\nFor the study, scientists divided volunteers into two groups to complete a math problem. The group that received eight hours of sleep solved the problem more often than the group that didn\'t get enough sleep.\nWhile you sleep, your brain is busy doing its "homework," sorting out information from your day. Getting enough sleep each night can boost your brainpower and help you perform your best in school. Experts say that, in turn, can lead to better grades.\nthat elementary-school children need at least nine hours of sleep a night. {'text': 'A group of fourth graders witnessed firsthand proof that one person\'s junk is another person\'s treasure.\njoined the students on their recent visit to the Garbage Museum in Stratford, Connecticut, where a giant, multicolored dinosaur molded out of garbage towered above them.\nwas sculpted out of a ton of trash! That is equal to 2,000 pounds of garbageÑthe amount of trash each person, on average, throws away each year. Philadelphia artist Leo Sewell scoured city dumps and created\nout of old junk, from false teeth and license plates to toys, tires, and tennis rackets.\n"I think the dinosaur is one of the coolest things I\'ve ever seen," said fourth grader Jahkwe Aquart from Park City Magnet School in Bridgeport, Connecticut. His classmate Julie Pham, 9, agreed. "Instead of throwing away our garbage, we can reuse it."\nwas made out of a ton of trash, including false teeth, license plates, and tires.\nThat is exactly the point. "The museum shows what happens to our trash, how we can reduce our trash, and what we can do instead of throwing our trash away," said museum director Sotoria Montanari.\nToday, Americans create more garbage than ever before. In the early 1900s, most items were packed in containers that could be used again. Now, most of the food we buy, from cereal to milk, comes in boxes and cartons that can be thrown away.\nSo what happens to trash after it is tossed out? Some trash ends up in\n. In a landfill, garbage gets buried between layers of soil. Because many states are running out of room for landfills, more and more garbage goes to\n(or resource-recovery) plants. At these plants, garbage is burned and converted into electricity that people use to power their lights, TVs, and video games.\nPlastic bottles can be recycled at centers like this one.\nGarbage is a form of solid waste. The Garbage Museum and its recycling plant, which are run by the Connecticut Resources Recovery Authority, provide visitors with ideas to cut down on solid waste. One way is to\n, or make less, trashÑby throwing away fewer napkins when you eat, for instance. Another way is to\n, or find new uses for, old items. Paper bags, for example, can be reused to make book covers or wrap gifts.\nPeople also help decrease their solid wastes when they\n. Recycling refers to putting old objects, such as glass, plastic bottles, newspapers, and aluminum cans through a special process so they can be used again. (See "\nRecycling has many benefits. Did you know that recycled plastic soft-drink bottles can be made into park benches, carpeting, and backpacks? The more people recycle, the less garbage ends up in landfills or waste-to-energy plants.\n, or materials from Earth. To make an aluminum can from scratch, for example, the metal needs to be mined from the ground. That process harms the land and pollutes the air and water. Making aluminum cans from recycled cans uses 95 percent less energy and protects Earth\'s natural resources. In fact, the energy saved each year from recycled cans could light Washington, D.C., for nearly four years!\nWhat are some other ways you can protect natural resources?\nAs part of their visit, the fourth graders got a look at the museum\'s recycling center. Here, they discovered that one\n, or bundle, of recycled newspapers can save 17 trees! The message seems to have stuck with 9-year-old Arron Smith. "When you recycle, you save trees and animals\' homes."\nDid you ever wonder what happens to the aluminum cans you recycle?\nwatched a recycling center in action at the Garbage Museum.\nTrucks drop off aluminum cans that are mixed with massive loads of plastic bottles and glass. The trash travels along conveyor belts to be sorted and separated.\nMachines compress aluminum cans into giant bales.\nThe bales are sold to companies that turn the recycled cans into something usable. From recycled aluminum cans, more cans are made. When you buy recycled products, you "close the loop."\nEach American throws away about 5 pounds of garbage each day. Earth Day, April 22, reminds people how important it is to reduce waste. Here are some ways:\nCarry a lunch box instead of a paper lunch bag, and pack food in reusable containers.\nUse both sides of a sheet of paper.\nDonate old clothing and toys to a charity.\npile using food scraps, leaves, and grass clippings. Composting is nature\'s way of recycling. Plants and other wastes\n, or rot, and nourish the soil.\nRecycle plastic and glass bottles and jars, newspapers, and aluminum cans. Recycling just one aluminum can will save enough energy to run your TV for three hours!\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}
{'text': 'Report Points to Mice As Asthma Cause\n17 million Americans suffer from asthma. About 5 million kids suffer from asthma.\nEach year, more than 3 million kids visit the doctor\'s office because of asthma attacks.\nWhen you run hard and play hard, you may have trouble catching your breath. Some kids, however, lose their breath even when they\'re not running or playing. Those kids have\n, a disease that makes it hard to breathe.\nFor many years, scientists have known that cigarette smoke, dog and cat\n, dust mites, and cockroaches can trigger asthma attacks. Dander is tiny bits of fur and skin. Now scientists have added a new culprit to that list--mouse dander.\nScientists studied dust samples from 608 U.S. homes with children ages 4 to 9 who suffered from asthma. The scientists found many things in the dust, including evidence of mice. About 95 percent of the homes had at least one room that had mouse dander.\nThe scientists then tested the kids in each of the homes to see if mouse dander triggered asthma attacks in them. The dander triggered attacks in 18 out of every 100 kids.\nAs a result of those tests, Dr. Robert Wood of Johns Hopkins University concluded that mice trigger many asthma attacks. In fact, he said, the "mouse is second in line [after the cockroach in causing asthma attacks]."\nMouse dander was found in many of the houses, even though not all of them had mice. Sometimes, kids tracked dander from mice and other animals into their homes when they came in from outside. Sometimes, the dander was from mice that had been in the home in the past.\nDaniel, who lives in Clarksville, Maryland, suffers from asthma. Last year, scientists collected and studied dust from his home. The scientists found cat dander in the dust, even though his family didn\'t own a cat. It was cat dander that was triggering Daniel\'s asthma attacks, said Daniel\'s doctor.\nTo keep cat dander out of their home, Daniel and his mother frequently wash the floors, walls, and other surfaces. As a result, Daniel\'s mother said Daniel hasn\'t had an asthma attack in the last year.\nMany kids who suffer from asthma might be able to breathe more easily if they could find ways to keep the dander of mice, cats, and other kinds of animals out of their homes.\nmeasures published under license with MetaMetrics, Inc.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}
{'text': 'Scientists discovered 106 new species of fish in 2004!\nA new study shows that the number of ocean creatures is on the rise.\nA gold-speckled and red-striped goby fish stands guard while a snapping shrimp digs a burrow. Both use the burrow for protection. The fish and the shrimp live off Guam, an island in the Pacific Ocean.\nThe goby fish is among 106 new\n, or types, of fish that scientists counted in the world\'s oceans in 2004 as part of a 10-year study. That means more than two new species of fish were discovered each week last year!\nAbout 1,000 scientists from 70 countries are participating in the ocean count. They will finish their study in 2010.\nWater covers about two-thirds of Earth\'s surface. The five main oceans are the Atlantic, the Pacific, the Indian, the Arctic, and the Southern.\nThis map shows the five main oceans.\nSo far, scientists have discovered nearly 15,500 species of fish in the world\'s oceans. They are among 230,000 known plants and animals living beneath the ocean\'s surface.\nScientists believe that they may find up to 2 million life-forms by the time they complete their count. "We have barely skimmed the surface," said one scientist.\nWhy are scientists conducting the study? They want to learn more about the oceans, which are among the least-known parts of Earth\'s surface. Scientists say species found below 1,200 feet are 50 times more likely to be new. One scientist involved in the study said that less is known about the ocean than is known about "the far side of the moon."\nScientists plan to use the results of the study to prevent people from overfishing. They also want to use the information to protect ocean life.\nScientists have added some new ocean creatures to their growing list.\nA previously unknown creature was found that lives near Antarctica. It has eight arms and is related to the octopus.\nCoral-like algae were found in the waters off Alaska. The hard red plants look like toy jacks.\nAn ocean creature related to the jellyfish could be new. It was found in Arctic waters.\nmeasures published under license with MetaMetrics, Inc.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}

{'text': 'Scooters are one of the hottest fads in the country. But as the number of kids who zip around on the silver scooters skyrockets, so does the number of injuries. Doctors reported treating 9,400 scooter-related injuries in the United States between January and August 2000.\nAccording to the National Safe Kids Campaign, children younger than 15 were hurt in nine out of ten of those accidents. In one-third of those scooter accidents, the rider fell and broke or dislocated an arm or a hand.\nMost scooter accidents happen when a rider goes too fast and does not wear safety equipment.\nSafety gear helps protect riders, who usually ride at about 4 miles per hour. But some people cruise at speeds of 25 miles per hour or more. In England, police gave a man a ticket for racing a scooter at 39 miles per hour!\nThe number of scooter-related accidents has prompted some U.S. communities to pass laws requiring kids who ride scooters to wear helmets and other safety gear. Many states already have helmet laws for kids who ride bicycles, and some have helmet laws for kids who use skateboards and in-line skates.\nAnn Brown, an official with the Consumer Product Safety Commission, recommends that kids use safety gear when riding scooters. "We\'re trying to head off some of the kinds of injuries that happen with in-line skates," Brown said about scooter safety. "We want people to know about the safety gear early on."\nThis isn\'t the first time scooters have been popular. Scooters have been around since 1816. According to Annette Thompson of the Bicycle Museum of America, the first scooter was made from a board and two large wheels.\nEven if scooter riders are careful, accidents can happen. Here are a few safety tips that scooter riders can use:\nAlways wear a helmet, wrist guards, and elbow and knee pads;\nMake sure your scooter works properly and is not broken;\nRide only on smooth surfaces free of traffic;\nNever hitch a ride from a bicycle or a motor vehicle;\nIn the 1930s, kids nailed roller skates to milk crates to make homemade scooters. {'text': 'For years, scientists have known about a group of icy objects, called\n, in our solar system. They circle the sun between the orbits of Saturn and Uranus. {'text': 'Fingerprint technology has a new home … in the cafeteria.\nTalk about easy money! Students in Rome, Georgia, can now pay for cafeteria food with a touch of the finger. "Our students have really enjoyed the new system," Narkissa Ware, principal of Anna K. Davie Elementary School, told\n"When the lines move faster, the students have more time to enjoy their meal."\nGetting a student’s fingerprints into the new system takes 10 minutes. After that, the student can touch the scanner at the cashier counter. The student’s picture and account information then appear on the computer screen.\nAlthough fingerprints are an easy way to pay for lunch, some parents aren’t happy with the new system. {'text': 'Astronomers have decided that eight is the magic number when it comes to our solar system. The eight planets now include Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune. Pluto belongs in a new class referred to as dwarf planets. The decision was made to create the new category because powerful telescopes have let scientists find more and more Pluto-like objects in space.\nJupiter is the largest planet. It is 88,846 miles wide.\nMercury has the fastest orbit around the sun. It moves almost 30 miles a second.\nVenus is the hottest planet. Its average surface temperature is 867 degrees.\nthe largest asteroid, was discovered in 1801. Asteroids are rocky objects that orbit the sun. Most lie in the asteroid belt between the orbits of Mars and Jupiter.\nthe frozen dwarf, is located 4 billion miles from the sun. Charon, Pluto’s largest moon, was found in 1978.\n2003 UB313 is a large object discovered in 2003. Nicknamed "Xena," it is larger than Pluto and orbits in the Kuiper belt, an outer area of our solar system.\nOK, now that Pluto is gone from the planet lineup, what memory trick will school kids use to remember the names and order of the eight planets? {'text': 'Why is one of America\'s most historic areas endangered?\nOne of the most historic regions in the United States is in trouble. The 175-mile-long area of land stretches through Virginia, Maryland, and Pennsylvania.\nThe area is home to more American history than any other slice of land in the country, according to the National Trust for Historic Preservation. George Washington built his estate at Mount Vernon, Virginia. Thomas Jefferson and James Madison also built their homes in that state. The region at the foot of the Appalachian Mountains includes many battlefields from the Civil War (1861Ð1865).\nAs people construct new houses, roads, and buildings, they are destroying acres of history. Officials say the region has lost more than 150,000 acres of farmland in the past 20 years. That is an area slightly smaller than New York City.\nTo call attention to the problem, the Trust placed this region on the 2005 list of America\'s 11 Most Endangered Historic Places. The trust works to\n"This is where the Civil War was fought," says Richard Moe, president of the trust. "This is where our Founding Fathers lived. ... There are African American sites. There are Native American sites. Our whole nation\'s history is, in one way or the other, [in this area]."\nThe following places are in the region between Pennsylvania and Virginia that was added to this year\'s list of the 11 Most Endangered Historic Places in the United States.\nIn 1863, the Battle of Gettysburg was fought in and around Gettysburg, Pennsylvania. Lava is liquid rock that comes from a volcano.\nThe lava waterfall from the Kilauea volcano spilled into the Pacific Ocean. Steam shot into the air as the lava hit the water.\n"The cliff just caved away like a glacier," Hawaii Volcanoes National Park spokesperson Jim Gale told reporters. "It just sheared off that old wall." Park officials let tourists watch the spectacular scene well away from the danger zone.\nKilauea, the world’s most active volcano, on Hawaii’s Big Island has been erupting continuously since 1983. The November collapse was the largest in 23 years. It took about four hours for the cliff to tumble into the ocean. As the lava hardened, it began to form new land. All the Hawaiian Islands formed that way.\nThe recent collapse didn’t surprise scientists. They had issued a warning months earlier because the cliff had formed cracks. Land collapses are not uncommon in the area. In 1996, a 26-acre area collapsed into the ocean, and in 1999, 25 acres of unsteady land fell into the water.\nThin strands of wiry volcanic glass, called Pele’s hair, were found about 2,000 feet away. {'text': "Your body is constantly under attack. Dirt and germs surround your body. Only one thing stands between dirt and the organs inside your body-skin.\nSkin may not seem very important, but it is. It protects your body from burns, dirt, germs, and dangerous rays from the sun. It keeps fluids inside your body. And it contains all the nerves that allow you to feel things.\nSkin is the largest organ in your body. If you stretched out an adult's skin into a flat sheet, it would cover an area of about 21 square feet. A square foot is a square whose sides each measure 1 foot.\nSkin may cover a large area, but it is very thin. It is only about 1/8 inch thick. Despite being so thin, skin is made of three layers. The outermost layer is the epidermis. Just below the outermost layer is the dermis. Beneath those two layers is the subcutaneous tissue.\nThe epidermis contains a chemical called keratin. Keratin makes skin tough and waterproof. Keratin keeps germs out of your body.\nThe dermis is mainly made of blood vessels and nerve endings. The dermis provides the epidermis with food and oxygen.\nThe lowest layer, the subcutaneous tissue protects the body from blows. It also regulates the body's temperature.\nAll three layers of your skin protect you. Because your skin protects you, you should protect it by keeping it clean and eating a healthful diet. You should use sunblock when you are in the sun. If you take care of your skin, it will last a lifetime.\nmeasures published under license with MetaMetrics, Inc.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n", 'label': '3'}

{'text': 'A new leopard species is found in Indonesia.\nScientists have "spotted" a new jungle cat. The secretive leopards are the latest of at least 52 new plant and animal species found in the rain forests on Borneo within the past year.\nScientists compared Borneo\'s clouded leopards with similar cats found on Southeast Asia\'s mainland. The Borneo leopard also has darker fur than that of the mainland species.\nThe newly discovered leopard is Borneo\'s largest\nor hunter. It can grow as large as a small panther and has the longest teeth relative to body size of any cat.\nThere are about 5,000 to 11,000 Borneo clouded leopards living on Borneo, according to scientists. {'text': "History in the Making: Surviving the Great Depression\nIn 1929, the U.S. stock market crashed. It marked the start of a period of hardship called the Great Depression. The U.S. economy suffered from low wages and reduced spending and production. Many people lost the money they had invested. During the 1930s, millions of people lost their jobs. Many families had trouble making a living. Abby interviewed her grandmother, Edith Russell, about this period.\nWhat hardships did the Great Depression cause you and your family?\nThings became scarce and unavailable. We had to go without things and work harder.\nDid your dad have a job during the Depression?\nMy father farmed his own land. Farming was not very profitable during this time. [However,] those who worked outside of farming probably only earned $1 a day.\nYes, we always had enough to eat. We always grew a huge garden with plenty of vegetables. We canned our own food; made bread, butter, and baked goods; and butchered meat.\nHow old were you then? What was it like to go to school?\nI was around 8 years old. I really enjoyed going to school. I attended a one-room schoolhouse in the country. The big downfall was that I had to walk 3 miles to and from school.\nWhen the banks failed in 1929, did your family have money in them? If so, did your family lose all of its savings?\nNo, we didn't have much money in the bank. My father wasn't [trustful] of banks and kept most of his money hidden right at home. However, the little he had in the bank was lost.\nDid you have enough money to buy clothes and shoes?\nI got a new pair of shoes once in a while for the winter, but in the summer I would go barefoot. Mama sewed most of my clothes. I only had about three different outfits.\nWhat did you and your family do for entertainment during these years?\nOur main entertainment was having the neighbors over to play ball. Once in a while, we got to listen to the radio.\nWhat effect did the Great Depression have on the way you live your life today?\nI always think back to those days and greatly appreciate everything I have today.\nThis interview made me realize how terrible life during the Great Depression must have been. It helped me\n[or picture] those horrible years because it came from the heart of someone who is so dear to me.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n", 'label': '3'}
{'text': 'An Iowa class heads into high-tech tests.\nEvery student in class has a remote control, and the kids are clicking away at the screen. But they aren\'t changing channels. They\'re taking a test! Terry Rex\'s fourth graders at Wings Park Elementary School in Oelwein, Iowa, are using a new kind of classroom technology. Instead of writing with pencils on exam papers, the students use remote controls to take tests.\n"It\'s more fun," Courtney Ricchio, 9, told\n"I don\'t have to write, and my hand doesn\'t get tired." The remote controls are part of the Classroom Performance System (CPS). When students use CPS to take a test, the questions appear on an electronic screen. Students key in their answers on the remote-control response pad.\nRex is one of the first teachers in Iowa to use CPS. His students use the technology for more than taking tests. They also play learning games with the system. Sam Myott, 9, says his favorite CPS activity is a football game. "It\'s a math game with multiplication and subtraction," he told\n"Since it\'s on the computer, it\'s more fun than a worksheet on your desk."\nSome teachers think using CPS to grade a test is more\nor a better use of time, than grading a written test. The computer keeps track of the students\' answers and prints out their grades at the end of the day. The computer also reports which questions the class found most difficult to answer, so Rex can review them with the group.\nClassrooms across the country are trying out new teaching gadgets.\nSixth graders Marina Gagliano and Kerry O\'Conner of Wellwood Middle School in Fayetteville, New York, label parts of a microscope on an interactive whiteboard. The whiteboard allows students to use their fingers to click and tap answers on the projected image.\nFourth and fifth graders at Elton Hills Elementary School in Rochester, Minnesota, are on the move. Their classrooms have no chairs! Tiny desks hold high-tech gadgets, such as laptops and iPods, with different lessons. {'text': 'Rebecca Fyfe was happy when her boyfriend gave her a cell phone. Rough weather and waves battered the boat, which started taking on water. Without a radio, the boaters couldn\'t call for help.\nFyfe, however, had her cell phone with her. Its batteries were low, so she was afraid to make a call. Instead, she used the phone\'s keypad to send an e-mail to her boyfriend, Nick Hodgson, who was in England, thousands of miles away. She typed, "Call... Coast Guard, we need help--S.O.S."\nHodgson called the Coast Guard in Thames, England. The Coast Guard then contacted rescuers in Australia and Indonesia, and a rescue operation was put together. Rescuers located the drifting boat and carried the passengers to safety after they had spent more than 30 hours at sea.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}

Last year, the president promised to return astronauts to the moonÑthe first step in an eventual mission to Mars.\nThe main goal of the mission is to build a research base on the moon where humans can live and work. The moon is very different from Earth. Unlike Earth, there is no air, wind, or weather. The moon\'s dusty surface is pitted with craters.\nWhile on the moon, astronauts hope to demonstrate that they can "live off the land." Learning how to live off the land is important for future human missions to Mars. Because Mars is so far from Earth, traveling there will require humans to stay for long periods of time.\nThe United States has already begun using robots to explore Mars. Two robotic vehicles,\n, are on the Red Planet now. They are searching for signs of water, a requirement for life. Another vehicle, called an orbiter, is on its way. The orbiter is set to arrive in March and will circle Mars, studying the planet for signs of water.\nShould We Go Back to the Moon?\nAlthough some space experts and lawmakers praise the plan to return to the moon, others oppose it because of the high cost. The project is set to cost $104 billion.\nSome people think that money should be used for other causes, such as helping to rebuild the Gulf Coast after the hurricanes Katrina and Rita. But NASA is quick to defend the space program. "[It] is a long-term investment in our future," says Griffin.\nOthers say that the public needs to keep being reminded of the ultimate goal. Scientist Louis Friedman says, "If you don\'t keep the Mars mission out front, people are going to ask, \'Why are we returning to the moon?\' It\'s got to be because we\'re extending ourselves into the solar system."\nIn 1961, President John F. Kennedy promised to land a person on the moon by the end of the 1960s. It was part of the "Space Race" with the then Soviet Union. Each country wanted to be the first to send a human to the moon. They must all open easily so that you can get out easily.\nAre there any boxes, toys, or pieces of furniture blocking your escape path? When you hear the alarm, spring into action!\nFeel around the door frame and the space between the door and frame with the back of your hand. Is it warm? For the first run through of your drill, pretend that it\'s not warm. That means you can exit the room safely because the fire is not nearby.\nFor the second drill, pretend that the door does feel warm. What\'s your plan now?\nAt the end of each drill, meet outside at your family meeting area. {'text': 'For more than 12 years, violent conflict has plagued Azerbaijan (a-zuhr-bigh-JAHN), a country in southwest Asia between Iran and Russia. For much of that time, Azerbaijan has been fighting with neighboring Armenia.\nNow Farid Dadashev, age 11, is doing something to stop the fighting.\nA few years ago, Farid said, "I don\'t want to be a soldier when I grow up. I want to be a teacher." Because of that desire for a peaceful life, Farid started the Child Peace Network. He sent out a petition to kids calling for peace between Azerbaijan and Armenia. So far, 10,000 kids from three countries have signed that petition.\nIn January, Farid traveled to the United Nations (U.N.) in New York City to talk about how the kids in his country are suffering from the war.\nAzerbaijan and Armenia have been fighting over a region called Nagorno-Karabakh. Both countries claim the region belongs to them. Most of the people who live in that region are Armenian, and in 1988, the people of Nagorno-Karabakh began asking for independence or to join Armenia.\nIn 1991, that request turned into a bloody conflict between the two countries. The fighting lasted until 1994, when a cease-fire was declared. Although the cease-fire continues, the two sides have not settled their differences, and fighting still breaks out.\n"The war affects everyone in Azerbaijan," Elmira Suleymanova, Farid\'s grandmother, told\nfrom her home in Baku, Azerbaijan. "No one can feel safe. One night, an entire community was burned to the ground."\nAccording to the U.N., the years of fighting have left 1 million people homeless. About 30 percent of those refugees are kids under age 15, said Farid.\nNo one knows if Farid\'s petition has had an impact on the armed conflict between Armenia and Azerbaijan. {'text': 'Top Ten Pet Names in the U.S.\nMany cats and dogs have turned into couch potatoes in need of more exercise and less food. Scientists report it\'s not just people gaining weight. Their pets are putting on the pounds too!\nAccording to the National Research Council, one out of every four cats and dogs in the United States weighs too much. How did these animals get so plump? Many of their owners overfeed them.\nLike people, overweight cats and dogs have a greater risk of developing heart disease and other health conditions. The clue for determining whether a pet is overweight is in the ribs. "If you can feel the ribs under your pet\'s skin but not see them, your pet is a perfect weight," animal expert Karen Volkerts told\nOwners can help their plump pups and fat cats shed some extra pounds. Animal experts recommend feeding pudgy pets smaller portions, reducing their number of feedings, and using diet pet food. Regular exercise will also help pets trim down and stay healthy.\nMany owners reward their pets or show them affection by giving them table scraps and other treats. Volkerts says that dogs and cats have their own food for a reason. "They aren\'t able to digest human food," she said. What should people do who want to spoil their pets? {'text': 'Most students spend their school days sitting at desks learning. Aurelious Woolfolk, however, does a lot more than sit at a desk when he is in school. He scrambles up high ladders, walks down the sides of buildings, and rides in a fire engine. He is learning to be a firefighter at the New Haven Fire Academy.\nWoolfolk and 28 other students are currently learning what it takes to become a firefighter. Classes at the fire academy, which is in Connecticut, last for about 22 weeks. On most days, the students go to school from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. However, once a week, school lasts until 10 p.m.\nFor two days each week, the students sit in a classroom to learn science, math, and emergency medicine. They learn the science of fires, how to calculate water pressure, and how to treat medical emergencies.\nDuring the other three days, the students go outside and learn how to hook hoses to fire hydrants, climb buildings, rescue people trapped in burning buildings, and many other things.\n"Firefighters have to know lots of different things," said Pablo Menendez, an instructor at the school. "We have to treat medical emergencies, know how to handle dangerous chemicals, and rescue people who have fallen from cliffs."\nTeamwork is one of the most important lessons students learn at the school. "Working together saves lives," said Capt. William Seward, the director of the academy. "Students need to learn that they are part of a team."\nFighting fires is not easy. The suits and equipment a firefighter wears weigh about 40 pounds.\nFirefighters are very busy. In New Haven, they respond to 32,000 emergency calls a year. Each time firefighters go out, they know they might not come back. Across the United States, about 100 firefighters die each year.\n"That\'s why the lessons learned here at the academy are so important," said Seward. "What they learn here can save their lives."\nFirefighters know how dangerous their jobs are. Their training helps them overcome their fear of heights and fires. "When you\'re up there on the ladder looking down, it\'s scary," said one student. "To do this job, you\'ve got to wipe out the fear."\nFirefighters overcome their fear for one reason. "I wanted to help other people," said Leah Harwin. "I think it is important to help other people whenever you can."\nmeasures published under license with MetaMetrics, Inc.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}

{'text': 'A sign warns boaters that manatees are in the area.\nWildlife officials in Florida have set up speed traps. The new speed traps, however, are not along highways. They are in the state\'s waterways.\nThe officials want to stop boaters from speeding in areas where manatees, or sea cows, live. Manatees are endangered mammals that live in water. Speedboats often collide with the slow-moving sea cows. Officials hope the new speed traps will slow down boaters.\nLast year, boats injured or killed 78 manatees. During the first six months of this year, 48 manatees were injured or killed by boats.\nState and wildlife officials blame the increase in manatee injuries and deaths on the number of boaters. "There are more boats [on the water] now, so that\'s causing more [manatee] deaths," said Nancy Sadusky, an official of the Save the Manatee Club.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}

The worker informed archaeologists, who believe the site dates back to the 10th century. It is one of only a few Viking cemeteries found in England.\nThe Vikings were pirates and warriors, known for their sea faring voyages. From the late 700s to 1100, the Vikings lived in Scandinavia. That region of Europe includes the present-day countries of Denmark, Norway, and Sweden.\nViking sailors spread fear throughout Europe. They raided and conquered coastal villages in Europe and along the Mediterranean coast. During their raids, Vikings captured slaves. They also\n, or stole, treasures, such as silver and gold.\nFor their voyages, Viking sailors crafted swift, narrow\nthat could navigate the stormiest seas. The Vikings were the master shipbuilders of their time. Vikings also worked as farmers and craftspeople. Others hunted and fished.\nThe Vikings\' claim to fame may have been their fearsome raids, but they were explorers and traders too. They were among the earliest explorers to travel across the Atlantic Ocean to North America.\nThe Vikings traveled to other parts of Europe, the Mediterranean, Greenland, and North America.\nOne of the most famous Vikings was explorer Leif Eriksson. He reached North America almost 500 years before Columbus arrived in 1492.\nLongships varied in size, but many were between 60 feet and 90 feet in length.\nA larger ship could carry about 50 raiders at a time.\nStrong winds allowed a longship, which had one large sail, to reach speeds of up to 17 miles an hour.\nVikings used multiple oars to row the ship when there was no wind.\nThe front end of a longship curved upward and was adorned with a wood carving of a snake\'s or a dragon\'s head.\nOver time, the Viking raiders lost their power as people learned to defend against their attacks. Today, the remains of Viking villages can be found throughout Europe and North America.\nArchaeologists plan to study the burial ground in England to learn more about the life of the Vikings. Based on the objects found, they believe the site was once a Viking settlement.\nVikings were known to bury valuable items with the dead. As one historian put it, the site will allow experts to "uncover the secrets of a time capsule more than 1,000 years old."\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}
{'text': 'In wartime, U.S. Navy ships face many dangers. As the ships cruise at top speeds through the ocean, one of the deadliest threats is from underwater bombs called\n. Ships use special sensors to locate mines.\nWithin the next few months, that same technology will be used to protect something a lot smaller and slower--manatees.\nIn the winter, West Indian manatees are found in many of the warm, shallow waters around Florida.\n. A lock is an area of water in a canal enclosed by a set of gates at each end. The gates open to allow a ship to enter. The lock then fills with water to raise the ship or drains water to lower it. A lock allows a ship to move from one elevation to another.\nCanal locks, however, can be deadly traps for manatees. An average of ten manatees a year have been killed in the gates in the past decade.\nA little more than a year ago, the canal lock at Port Canaveral, Florida, was fitted with sensors like those used by the U.S. Navy to detect underwater mines.\nThe sensors work using sound waves, said Larry Taylor, the engineer overseeing the project. "When the canal lock sensors [detect] a manatee, they stop the doors from closing," said Taylor.\nWithin a few weeks after the Port Canaveral installation, the sensors had saved seven manatees, Taylor said. He said there are plans to install the sensors at seven more Florida canal locks. "This is a great system that will really help the manatees," Taylor recently told\nmeasures published under license with MetaMetrics, Inc.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}

{'text': 'Florida is the 23rd largest state in the United States. Key West is the southernmost part of the continental United States.\nMoving slowly and silently through more than a million acres of wetlands in Florida, water is the lifeblood of the Everglades. However, for the past few decades, the Everglades has been losing its lifeblood.\nPresident Bill Clinton plans to sign a new bill into law that may breathe new life into the Everglades. The bill is called the Everglades Restoration Act. The act will help restore parts of the Everglades to the way they were many years ago, say supporters. Critics of the plan say that it does not go far enough to restore the Everglades.\nThe Everglades is like a shallow, slow-moving river that covers millions of acres. The "river of grass," as the Everglades is called, is 50 miles wide and 120 miles long. It flows from Lake Okeechobee into Florida Bay.\nA large part of the river of grass is contained within the Everglades National Park. The park covers about 1.5 million acres (about the size of Delaware). Many plant and animal species, including alligators, panthers, egrets, and manatees live in the park.\nAn alligator suns itself in the Everglades. Manatees, many kinds of birds, and panthers can be found in these wetlands.\nThe Everglades Restoration Act will spend about $8 billion to restore the river of grass over the next 30 years. The act will be managed in part by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers.\nOne important part of the act calls for the removal of dams, dikes, and flood control gates. The Corps of Engineers began installing many of those devices in 1948 to control the flow of water in the Everglades. Those devices protect towns and farms from flooding and provide\nBy removing dams and closing canals, the Corps of Engineers will restore the flow of water in the river of grass to the way it was more than 100 years ago. That\'s when people first began to drain water from the Everglades.\nThe act will also improve water treatment plants. Those plants clean wastewater coming from farms or towns near the Everglades. The improved plants will allow less water pollution to flow into the Everglades. The Corps of Engineers will also build reservoirs, relocate roads, and shut off drainage canals.\nThe maps show (1) how water flowed through the Everglades before farms and towns began draining water from the Everglades, (2) how water now flows through the Everglades, and (3) how water may flow when the plan is completed.\nMany people, from environmental groups to private citizens, applaud the act. "This is as major a restoration as one would hope for," said Charles Lee, a spokesperson for the Florida Audubon Society.\nCritics of the plan, however, say it does not go far enough toward restoring the wetlands. For example, the Everglades once covered 9 million acres, say officials from the Sierra Club, an organization that works to protect the environment. The Corps of Engineers drained much of that land so it could be used as farmland and to build houses. More of that land should be returned to the way it used to be before the 20th century, Sierra Club officials have said.\nWhatever disagreements people may have, all agree that the restoration of the Everglades will take a long time and a lot of hard work. Once the act becomes law, said Stuart Applebaum of the Corps of Engineers, it will be time to "roll up our sleeves [and get to work] for the next 30 years."\nmeasures published under license with MetaMetrics, Inc.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}

{'text': 'What is one of your worst nightmares about the school day? No recess!\nFor students in cities across the country, from Atlanta to Las Vegas, break time is over. They have to squeeze playground minutes into that half-hour block. They no longer get an additional 15- to 20-minute recess.\nMany teachers, parents, and students disagree with the decision to ban recess. {'text': 'You\'re probably familiar with this saying: An apple a day keeps the doctor away. There has been a lot of health advice in the news lately about what is good for your body. Sometimes it becomes difficult to tell what is true and what is considered a myth.\nis a made-up story that is passed down from generation to generation. Myths often become accepted as the truth. Weekly Reader spoke with a few health experts to find out the truth behind some common beliefs.\n: An apple a day keeps the doctor away.\n: Although eating this fruit won\'t cure an illness, apples are a healthful food choice. "[Apples] are good for you," said nutrition expert Dr. Melvin Heyman. "They contain nutrients."\nare vitamins and minerals that your body needs to stay healthy. Apples are also a good source of fiber, which can decrease the risk of heart disease later in life.\n: You should let a cut breathe.\n: Contrary to popular belief, cuts do not need to breathe. "The open cut or scrape should be covered," said skin expert Dr. Amy Harned. According to Dr. Harned, it\'s important to wash the wound first. Then, apply an antibiotic ointment and cover the cut with a bandage. Leaving a cut uncovered can allow germs to infect it.\n: Eating carrots will improve your eyesight.\n: Carrots are rich in vitamin A, which helps keep your eyes healthy. According to eye expert Dr. Timothy Wingert, "Eating carrots will not improve your eyesight. But eating carrots is part of a well-balanced diet. Carrots have nutrients that help your eyes to function properly." Carrots also make a tasty snack.\n: You can hurt your eyes by sitting too close to the TV.\n: There is some truth to this advice. According to Dr. Wingert, sitting too close to the television for long periods of time makes eyes tired and can cause eyestrain. "Generally, it is more comfortable on your eyes to view the television from at least 5 feet from the screen," he says. So, back up from that television or, better yet, turn it off!\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}

{'text': 'Mystery has surrounded King Tutankhamen\'s death for more than 80 years. The results of the tests indicated that Tut wasn\'t violently murdered but might have suffered a badly broken leg shortly before his death. {'text': '"May I stay up just a little longer?" That\'s the cry heard from kids every night in many U.S. households. That\'s because most kids don\'t want to go to bed.\nInstead of sleeping, many kids are watching latenight TV, playing computer games, reading, doing homework, or chatting with friends. According to a recent report, staying up late may be costing kids more than just a few winks.\nThe National Sleep Foundation (NSF) recently studied the sleeping patterns of 12- to 18-year olds. The NSF study says only 15 percent of kids get at least 8? hours of sleep per night. The NSF says kids need 9 to 11 hours of sleep each night.\nJennifer McCandless, age 13, said she tries to go to bed on time each night. Jennifer explained what happens if she doesn\'t get enough sleep. "I\'m like a zombie-- awake, but not doing anything," she said.\nWill Wilkoff is a children\'s doctor and sleep expert in Maine. He said one reason kids aren\'t getting enough sleep is that families are busier than ever before. Families are trying "to squeeze 28 hours of living into 24 [hours]," Wilkoff said.\nIn the past, most kids would go home right after school. Today, kids often have several after-school activities. When kids do get home, they have homework to do. All of this activity keeps kids from going to bed when they should.\nKids who don\'t get enough sleep can have problems at school. The study found that kids who don\'t get enough sleep at night often fall asleep during the day. Sixty percent of the kids in the study said they have felt tired during the day. Twenty percent said they have even fallen asleep at school.\nKids who are tired have problems remembering information. The study found that kids who don\'t get at least nine hours of sleep at night get lower grades than kids who get enough sleep.\nWilkoff said that kids have to develop a schedule that lets them get enough sleep.
