{'text': 'Polar bears reign as the kings of the Arctic. Yet there is trouble underfoot for those snow-colored creatures and other wildlife as their icy habitat slips away.\nThe Arctic is the icy, cold region located around the North Pole. In November, scientists from eight countries released a report saying that the Arctic is warming twice as fast as the rest of Earth.\nIn the report, scientists predict that at least half of the summer sea ice in the Arctic will melt by the end of this century. The scientists blame\nfor the Arctic thaw. That is the gradual rise in Earth\'s temperature.\nArctic ice is melting at an alarming rate. Winter temperatures in the Arctic have risen between 4 and 7 degrees Fahrenheit. During the past 30 years, polar bears have lost more than 386,000 square miles of ice--an area larger than the states of Texas and Arizona combined.\nMore than 20,000 polar bears live in the Arctic regions. Disappearing sea ice threatens polar bears and other cold-weather animals. Polar bears use the ice as a bridge to hunt seals, their primary source of food.\nAs the sea ice disappears, the mighty\n, or hunters, catch fewer seals and risk starvation. Seals also depend on the ice to rest and give birth. Scientists fear that polar bears, seals, and other animals that rely on the ice could be wiped out by the end of the century if the warm-up continues.\nSome of the 4 million people who live in the Arctic have also found themselves on shaky ground. As the frozen land thaws, buildings and roads have weakened.\nInuits (IH-nyoo-wets), a group of native people in the region, fish and hunt Arctic animals, including polar bears. They depend on those animals as their main source of food. Inuit hunters are also falling through thinning ice.\nRising sea levels have forced some people in the Arctic to move their coastal villages inland. The report warns that melting ice could cause sea levels to continue to rise--up to 3 feet by the end of this century. Towns and cities along coastlines around the world could flood as a result.\nThe warm-up also affects other parts of the planet. Arctic ice and snow reflect heat from the sun into space. Without the ice and snow, the planet would be much warmer. "The polar regions are essentially the Earth\'s air conditioner," said scientist Michael McCracken.\nWho cranked up the thermostat on the Arctic? Scientists say human activity is to blame for global warming. People use\n, such as coal, oil, and natural gas, to power cars, heat homes, and create electricity.\nFossil fuels come from the remains of plants and animals that lived millions of years ago. Burning those fuels gives off gases that trap heat from the sun and add to the overheating of the Earth.\nTo protect life in the Arctic, scientists say people need to limit their use of fossil fuels. "Climate change is not just about the future," said scientist Pal Prestud, who worked on the report. "It is happening now."\nThe burning of fossil fuels releases carbon dioxide and other gases into the air. Those gases collect in a layer and trap heat from the sun. The layer of gases is like the windows in a greenhouse. The process is called the\nToo much of those gases in the air causes temperatures to rise. That is known as\nWhat are some ways people can reduce their need for fossil fuels?\nmeasures published under license with MetaMetrics, Inc.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}

A boycott is a protest in which people refuse to\nbuy, sell, or use something. As part of the boycott, African Americans refused to ride buses in Montgomery if they couldn\'t sit in the front.\nThe Montgomery bus boycott lasted for over a year. In December 1956, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled that it was unconstitutional to segregate, or separate, whites from African Americans on buses.\nAn ordinary woman who made an extraordinary difference, Rosa Parks is often referred to as "the Mother of the Civil Rights Movement." Experts call these sports "the new PE." These individual sports are designed to help fight childhood\nby getting kids involved in fun physical activities. Obesity is the condition of being dangerously overweight. Another goal of these nontraditional activities is to promote lifelong fitness habits.\nSince 1980, the percentage of young people who are overweight has more than tripled. The time students spend in PE class, however, is decreasing. Many schools have dropped gym classes to save money or to provide students with more classroom time. Only 8 percent of elementary schools offer gym class to students every day, according to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\nBecause students have less PE time, teachers are searching for ways to keep kids moving. Students who are learning to skateboard often spend hours practicing a new trick before they get it right. "Skateboarding teaches kids to believe that if they stick with something, they will ultimately succeed," says education expert Richard Sagor of Lewis & Clark College in Portland, Oregon.\nCarlos’s skateboarding teacher at West Middle School, Eric Klassen, agrees. These days the 13,700-foot-high peak is anything but calm.\n, scientists who study space, say the mountain peak is a perfect spot to place telescopes.\nCurrently, scientists use 13 telescopes in a special 11,000-acre area called the Science Reserve on Mauna Kea. The scientists who use the telescopes pay a fee to the University of Hawaii, which built the observatories.\nThe use of the mountain for scientific research, however, is the source of a debate between scientists and some native Hawaiians. Some Hawaiians believe that the top of Mauna Kea is sacred, or an important place to their religion. The winds can be as fast as 150 miles per hour!\nScientist Bill Gray tries to help people who live in areas where hurricanes hit. Each year, he predicts the number of hurricanes that will form in the Atlantic Ocean during hurricane season, which lasts from June 1 to November 30.\nThis year, Gray predicts seven hurricanes will form in the Atlantic Ocean. Three of them, Gray predicts, may have wind speeds greater than 110 miles per hour.\nIn 1999, eight hurricanes formed in the Atlantic Ocean. Although Gray predicts fewer hurricanes will form this year, it is still more hurricanes than usual. On average, six hurricanes form each year.\nGray expects hurricanes to hit more often in years to come. "There is a strong likelihood that in coming years, we\'ll see more major storms [than we have in the past]," he said. He predicts more hurricanes because the Atlantic Ocean is warmer than usual.\nHurricanes are killers. {'text': 'Huskies along the trail during start day, March 1998.\nAnd they\'re off! Teams of specially trained dogs are racing to the finish line across one of the toughest terrains in the world.\nAlong a jagged trail of snow and ice, the teams battle Alaska\'s below-zero temperatures. They are competing in the Iditarod (igh-DIT-ah-rod) Trail Sled Dog Race, which kicked off on March 6.\nThe Iditarod is the longest sled dog race in the world. This year, about 90 sled dog teams are running the roughly 1,110-mile route.\nThe race, now in its 32nd year, starts in the city of Anchorage and ends in the city of Nome. The stretch of land the teams must cross is almost equal to the distance from New York City to Miami.\nA team of 12 to 16 dogs tow each sled. It can take more than two weeks for teams to complete the race. In 2002, a record holder completed the race in 8 days, 22 hours, 46 minutes, and 2 seconds.\nguide and care for the dogs. Mushers must stop at all 26 checkpoints along the trail. There, animal doctors, called\n, check the health of each dog.\nDuring their journey, mushers set up camp to make sure the dogs get enough food, water, and rest. The mushers and dogs are required to stop for at least one 24-hour period and two 8-hour periods.\nNot surprisingly, dog mushing is Alaska\'s state sport. Before mushing became a popular sport, dog teams served as an important form of transportation.\nIn the late 1800s and early 1900s, miners discovered gold in Alaska. Thousands of people traveled there for the gold rush.\nDuring that time, sled dogs helped people get from place to place and transported gold, mail, and supplies. "Dog teams were important to settling Alaska during this time," race director Joanne Potts told\nIn 1925, sled dogs in Anchorage delivered lifesaving medicine to sick children in Nome. The Iditarod teams follow the same route. The race\n, or honors, that event and the role dog teams have played in the state\'s history.\nExperiencing this year\'s race up close is fourth-grade teacher Jeff Peterson, from Minnesota. {'text': 'Ann Thompson is one of the best athletes in the world. She is the captain of the U.S. Paralympic women\'s basketball team. {'text': 'Reporters Ilana Novick, 16; Chad Sitgraves, 12; and Joel Solow, 13.\nOn average, kids ages 4 to 12 receive $18 a week. Here\'s how kids get that money:\nMany adults think that kids spend their money as soon as they get it. That may be true for some young people, but not for 9-year-old twins Gabriel and Dylan Greene.\nFor the past three years, Gabriel and Dylan have taken part in Save for America. Save for America is a program that teaches kids the importance of saving money. The program also teaches kids\nLast year, 750 schools and 90,000 kids took part in Save for America. Combined, those kids saved $1 million. Since the program began 12 years ago, kids have saved nearly $50 million!\nOne of the schools that takes part in the Save for America program is Setauket Elementary School, Setauket, New York. Every two weeks that school has Banking Day. Nearly 200 kids from the school deposit money on Banking Day, including Gabriel and Dylan.\nEach boy deposits about $5 in his bank account on Banking Day. So far, Gabriel has saved $350, and Dylan has saved $340.\nThe kids who participate in Save for America save money and learn valuable lessons that they will use for the rest of their lives. {'text': "This greeting wishes others good fortune and happiness in the Chinese New Year. People kick off the holiday on February 18 this year.\nThe Chinese calendar is split up into months based on the\nor moon, cycle. The Chinese New Year begins on the first new moon falling between January 21 and February 20. It ends on the full moon 15 days later, when the moon is brightest.\nPeople in Chinese communities around the world celebrate the holiday with music, dancing, fireworks, feasts, and parades. At celebrations, people wear red clothes and give children red envelopes with money for good luck. Red is considered a color that wards off bad luck.\nThe Chinese New Year ends with the Lantern Festival. On that night, children carry lanterns in a parade under the light of the full moon. The highlight of the Lantern Festival parade is the traditional dragon dance, when dancers guide a long, colorful dragon made of silk, paper, and bamboo through the streets.\nEach year in the Chinese calendar is named after one of 12 animals. Legend has it that people born in each animal's year inherit some of that animal's qualities. This year is the Year of the Pig. People born in pig years are considered honest, kind, and well informed.\nmeasures published under license with MetaMetrics, Inc.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n", 'label': '3'}

{'text': "Honest Abe's Library: Lincoln's Papers Get a New Home\nA group of librarians in Springfield, Illinois, has been booked up. The librarians are busy making sure the world's largest collection of information on President Abraham Lincoln gets to its new home safely.\nThe documents are on their way to the new Abraham Lincoln Presidential Library. The library is located in Springfield--the capital of Illinois. It is scheduled to open this fall.\nThe library will be the new home of the Illinois State Historical Library. Although the new library is only blocks away from the old one, the move hasn't been easy.\nThe six-week move involved several trucks and an army of people to help pack and transport nearly 12 million items. Of those items, about 47,000 books, maps, prints, documents, and other items are related to Lincoln.\nAbraham Lincoln was president during the Civil War (1861-1865). The U.S. Civil War was fought between the Northern states and Southern states. One of the main issues of the war was that the South wanted the right to own slaves. The North wanted to\nMore than 600,000 Americans died in the Civil War--more than any other war in history. The Civil War ended when the South surrendered.\nAbraham Lincoln (1809-1865) left his mark on Illinois. Although Lincoln was born in a log cabin in Kentucky, he worked as a lawyer in Springfield before he became the 16th president of the United States, in 1861.\nThe library's large collection of research on Lincoln includes many important\n. An artifact is a human-made object from the past.\nAmong the artifacts is a handwritten copy of Lincoln's Gettysburg Address. It is one of only five surviving copies. In 1863, Lincoln delivered the famous speech at the battlefield of Gettysburg in Pennsylvania.\nA museum dedicated to the life of Lincoln is also being built to accompany the library. {'text': 'Some experts question rewarding reading with pizza.\nEveryone loves pizza, but should it be used as a reward for reading?\nShould kids be reading for pizza? A nationwide reading program is drawing criticism for putting pizza front and center. Since 1985, the restaurant chain Pizza Hut has been running the Book It program, which rewards students for reading with personal pan pizzas. Now some people are taking a slice at Book It. They say the program promotes poor eating habits and gives Pizza Hut free advertising in public schools.\n"It\'s clear that Pizza Hut\'s Book It has no place in public schools. ... It promotes junk food," says Susan Linn, a cofounder of the Campaign for a Commercial-Free Childhood. The group has called for schools to stop participating in the Book It program.\nNearly 22 million children in 50,000 U.S. schools take part in Book It. Since the program began, more than 200 million pizzas have been given away. Each year, from October 1 through March 31, students read books to meet monthly reading goals set by teachers. When students meet their goal for the month, they get a certificate for a personal pan pizza.\n"We\'re really proud of the program," says Leslie Tubbs, the director of Book It. "We get hundreds of e-mails from [past participants] who praise it and say it helped them get started with reading." {'text': 'Educators spread the word about slavery in the North.\nSojourner Truth is best known as an outspoken\nÑsomeone who worked to end slavery. Although there were fewer slaves in the North than in the South, slavery flourished in New York City, northern New Jersey, rural Pennsylvania, and the shipping towns of Connecticut and Rhode Island. In 1771, slaves made up about 12 percent of the population of New York City.\nSome slaves in the North were offered freedom to fight for the British during the Revolutionary War (1775â€“1783). New Jersey, for example, reported 18 slaves in 1860.\nSinger explains that the slave trade helped support the\nin many major Northern cities, such as Boston and New York City. The Industrial Revolution was a rapid change in the economy in the 1800s, when factories and powerdriven machines were introduced. Many U.S. businesses got their start with profits from the slave trade and slave-produced goods.\nSinger tells students that the effects of slavery linger today through racial prejudice and discrimination. "Kids see slavery as something that happened in the deep past. I want children to know that we still live with the effects of that slavery society."\nIsabella Baumfree (1797â€“1883) was born one of 13 children but never got to know her siblings because they were sold into slavery. Being\nor severely overweight, can lead to health problems later in life.\nAs a result, schools in several states, from California to Pennsylvania, have started sending home "BMI report cards." Those schools send home a report of a student\'s\nBMI is a calculation of weight and height that tells whether a person is overweight for his or her age.\nShould schools send home BMI reports? People on both sides of the debate are weighing in.\nSome lawmakers say BMI reports alert parents to their children\'s health and help combat obesity. In 2003, former Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee helped launch the first program to report students\' BMIs. Obesity rates in that state have since stopped increasing. Pediatrician Joe Thompson helped plan the BMI program for Arkansas schools. He explains that the reports in Arkansas are sent home separately from report cards. "The misconception is students are being graded on their weight," he told\n"Just like a school screens for vision or hearing, this is a health approach to raise awareness about a risk."\nNot everyone thinks that reporting students\' BMIs is a good idea. {'text': 'A teenager\'s science project reveals long hours of video game playing could cause pain in your thumbs.\nHave you ever gotten a blister or a tingling feeling on your thumb after playing video games? Then you may have "PlayStation thumb."\nThirteen-year-old Safura Abdool Karim\'s research on this condition was published in South Africa\'s main medical journal. Safura became the youngest author to publish an article in that journal.\nAccording to Safura\'s research, the medical condition results from playing hours of video games.\n, or signs, of "PlayStation thumb" include pain, numbness, tingling, and blistersÑmainly in the thumbs.\nAs part of her science project, Safura surveyed 120 students at school. She asked kids in grades 4 through 7 how oftenÑand for how longÑthey played video games. She also asked students whether they had any pain or swelling in their thumbs.\nHer survey showed that 28 of the 60 boys and 17 of the 60 girls played regularly. {'text': 'Benjamin Franklin once said, "A penny saved is a penny earned." For the people of Boston and Philadelphia, Franklin\'s pennies have come to mean a lot.\nWhen Franklin died in 1790, he left money to both cities. Franklin chose those two cities because he was born in Boston and lived most of his life in Philadelphia.\nFranklin left the money to help people who need it. "I wish to be useful even after my death," Franklin wrote. He knew that his money would grow in value over time if it was invested right.\nBefore he died, Franklin made sure that the money would not be wasted. He left specific instructions on how the money should be used.\nFor the first 100 years, the money was used for loans to young people who wanted to learn technical skills. After the first 100 years, the money was used for education and public works. After 200 years, most of the money was given to the state governments that support each city.\nToday, the money Franklin left in his will is worth millions of dollars. {'text': 'For years, scientists have known about a huge hole in a layer of Earth\'s atmosphere. It\'s called the ozone hole. It is located above Antarctica. This year, the hole did something surprising. It split in two!\nEarth\'s atmosphere is made of several layers. Ozone is a gas that makes up one of those layers. That layer stretches from 6 miles to 30 miles above Earth\'s surface.\nOzone is an important gas. It protects life on Earth from dangerous rays from the sun. Without ozone, life couldn\'t exist. The dangerous solar rays are called ultraviolet rays, or UV rays. UV rays can cause sunburn and skin cancer.\nThe pie chart shows the two most abundant gases in Earth"s atmosphere.\nScientists first noticed the ozone hole in the 1970s. Since then, each year, the hole has opened above Antarctica for a few months in the fall. The largest hole formed in 2000. It was three times larger than the United States. This year, unusually severe storms caused the hole to split, say scientists.\nCold temperatures in the atmosphere over Antarctica and chemical pollution cause the ozone hole. Chemicals that used to be in aerosol cans, air conditioners, and refrigerators made the pollution. To protect the atmosphere, people stopped using those dangerous chemicals in the mid-1990s.\nAlthough the chemicals are no longer used, they stay in the atmosphere for a long time. Scientists say the ozone hole will continue to form for a long time. But it should start getting smaller.\nChoose the statement that best summarizes the main idea of this story.\n1. Ozone protects Earth from dangerous solar rays.\n2. The largest ozone hole formed in 2000.\n3. The ozone hole split in two.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}

Its ears are up, and its tail is held out. That\'s the theme of this year\'s Fire Prevention Week, which runs from October 5 through October 11.\nFor the past 81 years, the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) has used Fire Prevention Week to teach people how to prevent fires and how to protect themselves all year long. The NFPA has the following safety tips for you and your family:\n. Every family should have a home escape route planned. As part of the plan, identify two ways out of every room, such as a door or window exit. Be sure your plan includes a meeting place outside that is a safe distance from your home. Practice the plan at least twice a year.\n. Smoke alarms are often the first signal of a fire. Your home should have a smoke alarm on every level and in or close to each bedroom. Be sure an adult tests alarms monthly and replaces batteries once a year.\n. Whenever the stove is on, make sure there is an adult in the room. Keep a "kid-free zone" about 3 feet around the stove.\nmeasures published under license with MetaMetrics, Inc.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}

{'text': 'Mount Etna blew its top last summer. The volcano blasted molten lava nearly 1 mile into the sky.\n, scientists who study volcanoes, rushed to the mountain. Mount Etna is on Sicily, an island that is a part of Italy.\nThe scientists went to Sicily to learn from the 3,000-year old volcano. One of the things they wanted to learn is how to predict when a volcano will erupt.\nDozens of vulcanologists bravely climbed Mount Etna each day. They hoped that the mountain of fire would be a good teacher. "We will probably learn more about this volcano during this eruption than had been learned in 3,000 years", said Borris Behnke, a German scientist.\nClimbing Mount Etna is more dangerous than climbing some other volcanoes. The scientists risked being burned by the rivers of lava flowing down the volcano. Hot lava flowed from both the top of the volcano and from many\n, or holes, along the volcano\'s sides.\nEtna was also hurling huge rocks into the air. "Some of them are bigger than cars and some might be as big as trucks," said Behnke.\nSome of the scientists didn\'t need to climb Mount Etna. Over the past few years, scientists had placed hundreds of sensors on the volcano. The sensors gather data about the lava flow and send the data by radio to scientists located a safe distance from the volcano.\nThe sensors also record earthquakes. Earthquakes in a volcanic area can mean that the volcano is about to erupt. In the days before Mount Etna erupted, the sensors had picked up more than 2,600 small earthquakes.\nBehnke says that lava may erupt from Mount Etna for at least six more months. During that time, he plans to climb the volcano many times, risking his life to learn firsthand what is happening.\nmeasures published under license with MetaMetrics, Inc.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}

{'text': 'A Hurricane Hunter flies the plane into the eye of a hurricane.\nOne flight crew took Hurricane Isabel by storm. Called\n, they actually flew a plane into the center of Isabel in mid-September.\nIsabel packed winds of up to 100 miles per hour by the time it hit land. The storm walloped the coasts of North Carolina and Virginia and then moved inland.\nThe hurricane caused massive flooding and damage. More than 4.5 million people lost electricity. At least 40 deaths were blamed on the storm.\nDespite the devastation, Isabel could have been worse. Thanks to the work of Hurricane Hunters, weather forecasters accurately predicted the storm’s path. Many people received warning and fled, or\nHurricane Hunters are a special part of the Air Force. They found out how dangerous Isabel was before it battered the coast. The experienced fliers and scientists gathered information about the size, strength, and path of Isabel.\nThey sent that information to forecasters at the National Hurricane Center in Florida. The information led officials to evacuate shoreline areas in North Carolina and Virginia. The federal government in Washington, D.C., also shut down.\n"We’re just doing our part," said one Hurricane Hunter. "We help protect our coast from national disaster."\nThe Hurricane Hunters fly WC-130s into the strong winds of hurricanes.\nHurricanes are powerful, whirling storms that form over warm oceans and cause torrential rains and heavy winds. The eye of a hurricane is the calm center of the storm. The\nhas little wind and few clouds. Swirling around the eye are heavy winds.\nHurricane Hunters fly directly into the eye of a hurricane--not above it. The reason is that a hurricane can extend more than 50,000 feet high, and these planes can fly only as high as 30,000 feet.\nof Isabel, crew members experienced a rocky ride. The eye wall is a solid ring of thunderstorms around the eye. The strongest winds and heaviest rains are located here.\nThe plane contains equipment that records weather. In the eye of the storm, Hurricane Hunters released small tubes attached to parachutes. Each tube was about the size of a can of tennis balls. The tubes sent information about wind speed, power, and moisture back to the crew.\nAs part of their job, Hurricane Hunters help forecasters rate storms. Hurricanes are rated on a scale of 1 to 5.\nA storm’s rating is based on wind speed and potential for damage. Before hitting land, Isabel was a Category-5 storm. That is the most powerful type.\nSatellites in space and other weather instruments are used to measure hurricanes. However, forecasters say that Hurricane Hunters provide the most accurate prediction of the path and strength of a hurricane.\nHurricanes are rated on a scale of 1 to 5. The ratings are based on the storm’s wind and potential for destruction.\n74 to 95 miles per hour (mph)\nMinor damage to trees and shrubs; minor flooding\nSome trees and signs blown down; some flooding; no major damage to buildings; some evacuations\nSome large trees and signs destroyed; some damage to small buildings; some evacuations\nExtreme damage to buildings; major beach erosion; evacuations up to 2 miles from shore\nSevere damage to buildings; some small buildings knocked down; evacuations up to 10 miles from shore\nmeasures published under license with MetaMetrics, Inc.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}
{'text': "On March 22, Kelsey Penfield, age 9, was working at her desk at Maplehurst Elementary Schook in Norwalk, Ohio. She was also chewing her pen cap. Suddenly, she swallowed the cap.\nThe pen cap became lodged in Kelsey's throat, and she began choking on it. She tried coughing up the cap, but the cap wouldn't move. Unable to breathe, Kelsey began pointing at her throat.\nKelsey's classmate Elizabeth Muirhead, age 9, realized that Kelsey was choking. Elizabeth immediately sprang into action and performed the Heimlich maneuver on her classmate, saving her life.\nElizabeth had learned the Heimlich maneuver in an issue of\ncaught up with the two girls to ask them about that fateful day.\n: What happened the day that Kelsey started choking?\nWe were in class doing our grammar work. That's when Kelsey started choking. There was a boy between us, but he didn't know what was going on. Kelsey was pointing to her neck. I asked her if she was choking, and she nodded. That's when I ran over to her and did the Heimlich maneuver.\nWhat were your thoughts? Were you scared?\n: I was really scared. The first time I tried the Heimlich, I didn't do it that hard. I was afraid of hurting Kelsey. The second time, I squeezed a little harder. Then the third time, the pen cap just flew out. All the time I was thinking that Kelsey is my best friend and I'm not going to let her die.\nHow did you know how to perform the Heimlich maneuver?\n: We read about it in an issue of\n. Mrs. Moore put us in groups of two, and we practiced doing it.\n: Kelsey, What was this experience like for you?\n: I was really scared. I was chewing on a pen cap, and all of a sudden it slid down my throat. I couldn't breathe. I'm not going to chew on pen caps anymore. You shouldn't really chew on anything. Make a fist and hold it against the victim's stomach, about halfway between the belly button and the rib cage.\n3. Grab your fist with your other hand. Press it in with an upward thrust. Repeat until victim stops choking.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n", 'label': '3'}
{'text': 'Can you imagine not having a chance to play tag or hopscotch in the schoolyard after lunch? For many students around the country, their afternoon break is quickly becoming history. Nearly 40 percent of elementary schools have either eliminated or are considering eliminating recess, according to the American Association for the Child’s Right to Play.\nWhy? Some school officials say they want students to have more classroom time to learn. They hope that more time in class will help students perform better on standardized tests.\nIn addition, many schools are cutting recess because they can no longer afford to offer it. Those schools don’t have the money to hire lunch aides or to buy sports equipment for the playground.\nMost teachers and parents say that recess has a place in school. Nine of 10 teachers say free time spent with friends is an important part of the school day, according to a recent survey conducted by the National Parent Teacher Association (PTA).\nEducation experts also stress that the benefits of recess outweigh the lost class time. {'text': 'Experts scramble to keep this world-famous city from sinking.\nVenice attracts millions of tourists each year for its beautiful art and architecture. People weave their way through the city on boats because there are no streets. A maze of long\nor waterways, takes the place of roads. In fact, there are no cars or trucks in Venice.\nVenice is located in northern Italy on the Adriatic Sea. The city was built on a series of small islands in a\nor an area of shallow water. During some high tides, water floods the city. For hundreds of years, people have tried to keep water out of the city to save it from sinking. Now a group of scientists has introduced a bold plan to keep the city afloat. And it means adding more water!\nVenice is sinking at a rate of 1.57 inches per year, according to scientists. The Italian government has proposed the building of floodgates to control the flow of the sea.\nScientists hope to turn the tide in favor of Venice. They want to pump huge amounts of water into the ground through sturdy pipes. Scientists expect the water will expand the sand underneath and prop up the city. They hope to test the project on a small area over the next few months.\nIn Venice, a maze of long canals takes the place of roads.\nScientists behind the plan say that the pipes will work along with the floodgates to help save the city. However, other scientists are not as convinced. They warn that the plan could cause parts of the city to crumble if the work isnâ€™t carried out in a careful way.\nEveryone, however, agrees that saving the sinking city is important. {'text': 'Storytellers celebrate Hans Christian Andersen\'s 200th birthday.\nSeveral children climbed on a bronze statue of Hans Christian Andersen in Central Park in New York City. This year, however, is special because it marks the 200th year of Andersen\'s birth. Fans around the world are celebrating this anniversary. In his hometown of Copenhagen, Denmark, 15-foot-tall puppets will dance in midair every night through September. In Japan, the post office recently published a series of Andersen stamps. And in Egypt, the library in Alexandria has displayed Andersen\'s books, translated into 150 languages!\n. "They are funny and sad and joyous. I never get tired of them."\nHans Christian Andersen (1805-1875) was born in Denmark. He wrote more than 150 stories in his lifetime. He became the first author to write and publish his own fairy tales.\nAndersen grew up poor. His father was a shoemaker, and his mother could barely read. Andersen once said, "Most of what I have written is a reflection of myself. "His fairy tale "The Ugly Duckling, "about a duckling that is teased by other animals until it grows up to be a swan, was based on the way Andersen was treated as a child. His other famous fairy tales include "The Emperor\'s New Clothes," "The Little Mermaid," and "Thumbelina."\nStorytellers like Shapiro don\'t just memorize their favorite tales. They learn what happens at the beginning, middle, and end of a tale. However, they also\n, or change, the words of a story to respond to the audience. Therefore, no two tellings of a story are exactly alike. "Everyone has a story," Shapiro told\n. "You just have to find it."\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}
{'text': 'New York City schools are removing the junk food from their vending machines.\nChange is on the way for vending machines in New York City schools. {'text': 'Hiram Bingham lived for adventure. In 1911, the American explorer trekked through the jungles of Peru. He was searching for clues to explain how the once-mighty Inca Empire had disappeared.\nHis journey through the Andes Mountains in South America was not easy. Bingham hacked his way through thick forests and climbed slippery slopes. One wrong stop could have sent him plummeting off a cliff.\nAfter crawling up a snake-infested mountain, Bingham stumbled upon one of the greatest finds of the last century. He uncovered ruins from the "lost city" of Machu Picchu (MAH-choo PEE-choo).\nUntil Bingham\'s discovery, the ruins remained hidden for more than 400 years. Machu Picchu, which lies high atop a peak, is an ancient city that belonged to the Incas. Its name means "old peak."\nThanks to a traveling museum exhibit, people in the United States can go back in time to experience Incan life in Machu Picchu. The exhibit, called "Machu Picchu: Unveiling the Mysteries of the Incas," is currently on display at the Chicago Field Museum.\n"It is the first exhibit of its kind," museum project manager Hillary Hansen told\n. "It is the largest traveling exhibit of Inca objects."\nthat Bingham collected are on display--from ceramic jars to copper and bronze jewelry. Artifacts are objects that people made long ago.\nMachu Picchu is an ancient city that belonged to the Incas.\nThe Incas were people who ruled one of the largest empires in South America. Their empire extended from present-day Colombia into western Argentina.\nTheir vast civilization began to spread in about 1200. It lasted through the mid-1500s.\nWhen Bingham discovered Machu Picchu, he thought he had found the birthplace of the Inca Empire. Since that time,\nhave learned that the city served as a summer residence for Incan kings. (Archaeologists study artifacts to learn about the past.)\nThe Incas built Machu Picchu between 1450 and 1470 for the ruler Pachacuti. The royal family would relax, hunt, and entertain foreign visitors there.\nMachu Picchu wasn\'t just a home for nobles. About 500 common people lived in the stone city and worked for the royal family as farmers, artisans, and servants.\nThe city was abandoned in the mid-1500s, not long after the Spanish\n(conquerors) arrived. The Inca Empire collapsed under Spanish rule.\nToday, Machu Picchu is a popular tourist attraction. Nearly 400,000 people visit the ancient grounds each year.\nScientists still research the area to unlock more mysteries about the Incas. "In the scheme of things, we still know very little about Machu Picchu," said Hansen.\nMachu Picchu, which is located in Peru, was a city of palaces, temples, farms, and small houses.\nMany of the buildings at Machu Picchu are made of large stones. The stones are so tightly wedged together that a piece of paper cannot fit between them.\nMachu Picchu\'s farmland was carved into steps because it was hard for farmers to plow up and down the mountain. That allowed farmers to plant crops on the flat parts of the land and prevented rain from washing soil downhill.\nThe Incas had no writing, no money system, and no knowledge of the wheel. How do you think they created such a large empire?\nmeasures published under license with MetaMetrics, Inc.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}

{'text': 'Some dogs are taking part in a fun pet projectÑ helping kids read! {'text': 'Source: U.S, Census Bureau; Illustration: Art Today\nThe graph shows the percentage of kids grades 1 to 8, who use a computer at home.\nSome kids walk to school. {'text': 'Five California condors died last summer in Arizona\'s arid backcountry.\nA condor\'s wingspan is 9.5 feet across. That\'s about as wide as two kids lying down head to toe.\nWildlife experts say the condors did not die from the heat. Instead, the experts believe the huge birds died from lead poisoning. They say the condors had swallowed lead shotgun pellets.\n, which means they eat the remains of dead animals. The condors probably ate the remains of an animal that had been shot by a hunter. As they ate the dead animal\'s flesh, the birds ate the deadly pellets.\nIf swallowed, lead can make an animal sick or cause death. Lead stops the body from making red blood cells. It can also damage an animal\'s organs, including the brain and liver.\nThe five poisoned birds were among 35 condors that have been released in Arizona since 1996. The release program has cost millions of dollars.\nAfter the dead condors were found, wildlife experts recaptured and tested the 16 birds left in the Arizona group. All the birds were healthy and were soon released.\nMembers of the Peregrine Fund have been releasing and watching the condors set free in Arizona. Jeff Cilek, of the Peregrine Fund, told\nthat saving California condors is important. "Condors are good for the environment. They [eat] dead animals," Cilek said.\nCalifornia condors are among the world\'s largest birds. A hundred years ago, the birds were found in many parts of the United States. Today, the condor is on the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service\'s list of endangered species. That means the number of California condors is so low they all could disappear someday.\nWhy are scavengers an important part of the food chain?\nPeregrine Fund officials say there are 150 California condors left on Earth. What started out as a one-man project has turned into a family affair. The sculptor blasted into the mountain for the first time in 1948. The sculptor died in 1982. His wife, children, and family continue his work today.\nOnce completed, the Crazy Horse Memorial will be the world\'s largest sculpture. She grew up on a farm where they were a common sight. So it was no surprise how quickly she took to an orphaned baby bat she found squeaking on the ground outside her house ten years ago. She took the bat in and fed it milk from a goat on her farm.\nTo her delight, the little creature survived the night. Today, the bat--which she named Poppy--still lives with her. She did not release Poppy back into the wild because it identifies more with humans than with bats.\nThis bat lady, however, doesn’t keep Poppy all to herself. Poppy is one of the winged creatures that Griswold brings with her on school visits. In fact, this Halloween she is speaking at a Connecticut school. Griswold, who teaches kids about bats, is on a mission to change their reputation.\n. Many people, she says, are afraid of bats, but they’re actually gentle, shy creatures that are important to the environment.\nBats pollinate plants, spread seeds, and, most important, eat insects. "There is no animal worldwide that eats more bugs at night than bats do," said Griswold, who is full of bat trivia.\nHowever, the number of bats worldwide is in serious decline. They often lose their homes when people cut down trees.\nBut Griswold’s message seems to be spreading. After she spoke to a Brownie troop, the members built bat houses in their town. The project turned into a community effort. "The kids are making such a huge difference," she said.\nThere are almost a thousand species of bats worldwide. Bats come in different colors, shapes, and sizes. Some have huge ears and unusual faces. In fact, a bat’s face can teach you about its habits. Read on about some of these creatures.\nVampire bats can be found in Mexico, Central America, and South America. They drink blood, but it’s usually from cattle and horses--not people. A heat sensor on its nose helps it find blood close to the surface of its victim’s skin.\nEgyptian fruit bats live mainly in Asia and Africa. They eat fruit and nectar. Their long noses help them locate ripe fruit. Fruit bats use their sharp teeth to chew fruit.\nThis bat’s ears are almost as long as its head and body. It uses its ears to detect insects. This bat, which is found in parts of North America, feeds mainly on moths.\n(EHK-oh-loh-kay-shun) to navigate in the dark and to find insects. The bats make sounds that can’t be heard by humans. A bat knows where an insect is because the bat’s sounds echo, or bounce off, an insect and return to the bat’s ears. Make a fist and hold it against the person\'s stomach, about halfway between the belly button and the rib cage.\n3. Grab your fist with your other hand. Press it in with an upward thrust. {'text': 'The $10 bill is the latest in the series to get a new design.\nThe $10 bill is getting a new look! To outsmart counterfeiters, the U.S. government is rolling out a newly redesigned $10 bill that has splashes of red, yellow, and orange.\nare people who try to make fake bills that look like the real ones. Counterfeiting is a crime.\n"The new $10 note design continues the U.S. government\'s efforts to make our currency safer, smarter, and more secure," says Dawn Haley of the Bureau of Engraving and Printing, which produces all U.S. paper money.\nThe $10 bill is the latest in the series to get a new design. The $50 bill was updated last year, and the $20 bill was given a makeover in 2003.\nThere are several colorful changes on the new bill. A red image of the Statue of Liberty\'s torch appears next to the portrait of Alexander Hamilton, the first secretary of the treasury. On the portrait\'s other side is the phrase "We the People," also in bright red ink. The background is light orange, and small yellow 10s surround the torch. A new ink makes the numeral 10 in one of the corners change color from copper to green when the bill is tilted.\nBut don\'t expect to find the new $10 note in your wallet just yet. In January 2006, the U.S. government will begin to circulate the new bills. The government plans to redesign the currency every seven to 10 years to stay ahead of counterfeiters.\nmeasures published under license with MetaMetrics, Inc.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}

They dine mostly on insects. Some larger spiders also eat lizards, frogs, and even snakes.\nTo capture their food, some spiders spin webs. Other types of spiders chase down their\n, or poison, from their fangs helps paralyze their food.\nAlthough the hairy creatures spook many people, there isn\'t much reason to be afraid of spiders. "Most spiders are not very dangerous," said Bradley.\nIn fact, most are timid creatures that are unable to give humans more than a harmless bite. Although spider venom is deadly to insects, it often has little effect on humans because of our larger size.\nSpiders may have a bad reputation for being scary, but they are important to us. Bradley hopes his work shatters some\nabout spiders. (A myth is a false idea that many people believe is true.)\nSpiders eat mosquitoes and other insects that harm farmers\' crops and carry diseases. Bradley\'s research is teaching scientists more about how spiders help control\n, or communities of plants and animals. If spiders didn\'t exist, there would be a lot more insects!\n"Spiders are your friends," Bradley said. "They make our life more pleasant."\nGet caught up on some different types of spiders. Spiders come in all shapes and sizes. Crab spiders, jumping spiders, and orb weavers have made Rich Bradley\'s Ohio count. Find out more about them and other spiders.\nCan you guess how this spider got its name? It may not live in the ocean, but it looks like a crab. The crab spider lives on flowers. It can match its body color to the flower\'s color. That allows it to sneak up on insects.\nWhat a leap! The jumping spider can jump between 10 and 40 inches. To catch an insect, this hunting spider sneaks up on its prey and pounces.\nThe trap-door spider lives in a tunnel. The spider, common in the southwestern United States, lines the tunnel with silk and fashions a door made of silk and dirt. It peeks out of the slightly open door and grabs passing insects.\nThe tarantula is a large, hairy spider found mainly in warm regions, including the southwestern United States. Although the tarantula\'s bite is painful, it is not very poisonous to humans. Tarantulas hunt insects, lizards, mice, toads, and frogs.\nE. B. White\'s famous spider Charlotte was an orb weaver. The orb-weaving spider spins a wheel-shaped web. When an insect flies into the web, the spider races toward its meal.\nWhat other animals frighten people but are good for the environment? In what ways are they good for the environment?\nmeasures published under license with MetaMetrics, Inc.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}

The land also contains more than 25 percent of the world\'s\nA tropical rain forest is a dense forest in a warm region that gets at least 100 inches of rainfall a year.\nEnvironmentalists from the group Conservation International say this area of the northern Amazon has more\nthan all tropical forests on the planet. Biodiversity is the variety of plants and animals in an environment. The Amazon is home to more\nor types, of plants and animals than any other place in the world.\nSince 1970, more than 232,000 square miles of the Amazon rain forest have been destroyed. That is nearly the size of Texas! The destruction has endangered many animal species. Experts predict that the continued\nor clearing of trees, at this rate would endanger the entire region by 2050.\nOfficials were especially concerned about preserving the forests. Part of the area is believed to contain more than half of all bird, animal, and plant species found in the Amazon. Many endangered animals, including the giant Amazon otter, make their homes there. Under the government\'s plan, those parts of the Amazon will be off-limits to the public.\n"If any tropical rain forest on Earth remains intact a century from now, it will be this portion of [the northern Amazon]," says Russell Mittermeier, president of Conservation International.\nThe Amazon rain forest is the world\'s largest tropical rain forest. {'text': 'The Flordia panther is a protected species.\nDo Florida panthers have nine lives? Scientists sure hope so! The wild cats are on the brink of\nDuring the early 1900s, hundreds of the large, light-brown cats roamed the southeastern United States. Today, panthers can be found only in southern Florida. Wildlife officials estimate that only between 80 and 100 panthers are left in the Sunshine State.\nWhat is causing the sharp decline in the panther population? Hunting and habitat loss are mainly to blame. During the mid- to late 1900s, millions of people flocked to Florida for its warm climate and inexpensive land. As people built homes and roads, panthers were squeezed out of their habitat.\nIn 1967, Florida panthers were placed on the endangered species list in the United States. The list was created to protect animals that are on the edge of extinction.\nToday, wildlife officials are working to keep the wild cats out of\n, or danger. Workers have installed fencing along 40 miles of public roads in south-western Florida to prevent panthers from colliding with cars and other vehicles.\nOfficials are also making efforts to save the land where panthers live from further development. The scientists studied the images to see how accurately the satellite was able to spot different species of zoo animals, such as giraffes.\nSo far, the scientists are impressed with the results. They hope to use the satellite technology to track endangered wildlife in\n, or hard-to-reach, places around the world. Endangered animals are at risk of becoming\n"Taking a count is the first step in finding out if a species is in danger of extinction," scientist Scott Bergen told\nScientists have used satellites to track animals in the past. {'text': 'HI! MY NAME IS PAM POLLSTER. This is my pet parakeet, Polly. We live in Polling Place. Polly is a smart bird. In fact, she\'s so smart, she can count very high numbers. This is good, because I need Polly\'s help--and yours--with a problem. The problem is that Polling Place needs a new motto. The one we have now is kind of lame. Want to hear it? "Polling Place. It won\'t be easy.\nA few thousand people live in Polling Place. We sure don\'t have the time to go to every person\'s house to find out which motto he or she likes. (Besides, my bike has a flat tire and my in-line skates don\'t fit.)\nSo what should we do? Well, Polly came up with a great idea. We can poll the people of Polling Place! (Told you she was smart.)\nis a way of asking a small part of a large group of people what they think. Then, using math, you can figure out what the larger group is thinking.\nPolls are used all the time. In fact, they are really important during elections. (You know, the big thing that\'s on the news all the time?) Polls are also used to help the government, businesses, and organizations make decisions or plans.\nSo, what is the first step for our motto poll of Polling Place? Turn the page to find out!\nBelieve it or not, polling has been around for a long time in the United States. One of the first political polls was done in 1824!\nIn those days, newspapers asked readers to write in saying the person they liked for president. One newspaper did a poll that said Andrew Jackson would be president. But Jackson didn\'t get enough votes to win. John Quincy Adams won that election and became our seventh president.\nWhy was the newspaper wrong? The biggest problem was that only the readers of that one newspaper took part in the poll. It did not show what all people in the U.S. felt.\nBy the 1960s, polling became more scientific. Such a scientific poll was used by John F. Kennedy during the 1960 presidential election. The poll, done by Louis Harris, figured out what issues people were worried about. For a poll to be scientific, three things must happen.\n. The people who run a poll need to get a sample of people. A\nis a small part of a larger group of people. A sample for a poll must include ALL types of people, like boys and girls, young and old. Also, no one can know who is going to get picked for a poll\'s sample. And no one can volunteer to take part in a poll.\n. A poll\'s questions must be thought out. The questions need to be\n. That means the questions don\'t lead people to answer one way or another.\n. Finally, experts, sometimes with the help of math, study the\n, or people\'s answers. Then they put the data into charts so that it is easier for everyone to understand.\nIt\'s As Easy As One, Two, Three\nSo how did Polly and I poll the people of Polling Place? Here\'s how we did it.\n. The first step was to figure out the subject of the poll. That was easy! We wrote down the following on a piece of paper:\nAs a resident of Polling Place, which new town motto do you prefer\nPolling Place: A Place That\'s Right on the Numbers.\nPolling Place: A Cool Place for Birds!\n. The tough part of polling is figuring out how to ask people our questions and get their answers. One way is to send people out to ask our questions. Another is to call people on the telephone. The Internet is also another way of polling. Polly and I decided to go out and ask a sample of all kinds of people.\n. We now have our data from the people of Polling Place! Next we will put it together into a chart.\n? Which motto did the people of Polling Place like best?\nmeasures published under license with MetaMetrics, Inc.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}

{'text': 'In 1970, only one in ten kids in the United States was overweight. In the 1980s, one-third of kids were overweight. In the 1990s, three-fifths of kids were overweight. A new study links the increase in the number of overweight kids to an increase in the amount of TV kids watch.\n"We found that kids who were [light] TV watchers were [thinner]. The kids who were the fattest were those who watch a lot of TV," said Dr. Carlos Crespo. Crespo and Dr. Ross Anderson wrote the study.\nThe doctors said kids today watch more TV than kids did 30 years ago. Today, one in three kids watches four or more hours of TV a day. Watching that much TV, they said, is unhealthful.\nAccording to the doctors, kids are not entirely to blame for watching too much TV. Part of the problem comes from a lack of safe places for kids to play.\nCrespo and Anderson aren\'t against watching TV, as long as kids limit the time they spend in front of the tube.\n"There are a certain number of hours in the day you\'re supposed to sleep [and] do your homework," said Crespo. "You\'re supposed to go to school, and then there is a certain amount of hours that you are free to do whatever you want. {'text': 'Is silencing parents a winning idea for kids\' sports?\nLoud parents are a growing problem at youth sporting events. Nearly 60 percent of people think that parent behavior in youth sports is worse today than it was five years ago, according to the National Association of Youth Sports. "Parents are trying to yell and scream to make their kids play better, and that just doesn\'t work," sports expert and former coach Gregory Dale told\nDale and other sports experts are fans of an idea called "Silent Saturdays." Silent Saturdays are special game days during which parents aren\'t allowed to yell, scream, shout, or even speak. They can only clap to celebrate good plays and whisper to each other. Sports programs from California to New Jersey have instituted Silent Saturdays. Is quieting the sidelines a good call?\nSilence helps keep parents\' behavior under control.\nSome sports leagues think zipping parents\' lips is a great idea. The Dynamo Soccer Association in Bourbonnais, Illinois, started having Silent Saturdays last year. "We\'re not trying to punish parents," Dynamo Soccer board member Ben Smith told\n"It\'s just a stress-free day for the kids."\nAt first, some parents were skeptical, or unsure, of the idea. But Smith says the quiet games were a big success. Instead of shouting, parents held encouraging signs and applauded. Everyone could hear the kids talking to each other on the field during the games. "There was no negative criticism throughout the day," adds Smith. This year, the Dynamo board is considering two Silent Saturdays, and nearby soccer leagues are giving the program a try.\nParents should be allowed to cheer on their kids.\nSilence doesn\'t work for everyone. For example, two grandparents in Bourbonnais were disappointed because they had traveled to cheer at their grandkids\' game, but they had arrived on a Silent Saturday. Some experts think keeping family members quiet isn\'t the solution. "Parents hate it," Jim Thompson, head of Positive Coaching Alliance, told\n"If you want parents to be positive, this is not the best way to do it."\nThompson says the solution is to train parents to cheer in a way that promotes\nor fair play. Thompson prefers "Honor the Game Days" to Silent Saturdays. What\'s the difference? "Rather than telling parents to be quiet, at Honor the Game Days, [we tell parents] how to support their kids," he says.\nAre Silent Saturdays a winner for youth sports? {'text': "Did you ever open a bag of cookies and wonder why they were broken into so many pieces? Scientists now know why. Contrary to popular belief, it has nothing to do with the way the cookies were packaged, loaded on shelves, or transported from the store to your home.\nAccording to scientists in England, cookies pick up moisture as they cool after coming out of the oven. The moisture causes the cookies to expand and contract, which results in cracks. The cracks cause cookies to easily break when they're moved or packaged.\nBakers can use that information to adjust the temperature during the cooling process. Scientists hope the discovery will help keep cookies from crumbling during normal handling.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n", 'label': '3'}
{'text': 'For climber Erik Weihenmayer, one of the hardest parts of climbing Mount Everest, the tallest mountain in the world, was leaping over\n. A crevasse is a deep crack in a\n, a huge sheet of moving ice.\n"I never got used to these 4- or 5-foot crevasses that are hundreds of feet deep," said Weihenmayer. "You had to jump across them. You have to be very careful when you land."\nFor most climbers, jumping over a crevasse is hard enough. But for Weihenmayer, jumping over the cracks was particularly hard because he is blind.\nLast spring, Erik Weihenmayer became the first blind climber to reach the peak of Mount Everest. He was part of a team of climbers that was sponsored by the National Federation of the Blind.\nMount Everest is 29,035 feet tall and sits on the border between Nepal and China, two countries in Asia. According to many climbers, Mount Everest is one of the hardest and deadliest mountains in the world to climb because of the mountain\'s height.\n"There are a lot of things that can happen up there. You\'re not ever really sure that you\'re going to make it," Weihenmayer told\n. Climbers can suffer from illnesses caused by many things, including the altitude.\nsickness occurs when a climber does not get enough oxygen.\nThe team took more than two months to complete the climb. Weihenmayer spent much of his time moving the team\'s supplies up the mountain to a base camp, which was located at 17,600 feet. The time spent moving gear helped Erik Weihenmayer get used to the altitude. "You\'re letting your body get used to the elevation, the air, the temperature," Weihenmayer said.\nWeihenmayer, who had already climbed several of the world\'s highest peaks, had help getting up Mount Everest. "[People] would walk ahead of me with a bell," he said. "I tried to stay in their footsteps. I tried to stay [close] behind them so I could hear their steps, and I stepped into those places."\nFor Weihenmayer, climbing Mount Everest was the toughest but most rewarding experience of his life. When he got to the top, Weihenmayer stopped to think about what he had done.\n"I thought about the ground underneath me. I felt these cool flags [at the peak] that were up there in the breeze," Weihenmayer said. {'text': 'Would you know what to do if a fire started in your home? Every year, more than 400,000 fires begin in U.S. homes. You can prepare for an emergency by making and practicing a home fire escape plan!\nall rooms, doors, windows, and smoke alarms.\nat least two ways out of each room. {'text': 'Kaleb works on a plantation in the southern United States during the mid-1800s. The young slave faces the toughest decision of his life. For a chance at freedom, he must risk everything and run away from home. That means leaving behind his family and all that is familiar.\nThe National Underground Railroad Freedom Center is located in Cincinnati, Ohio.\nWhat would you do if you were in Kaleb\'s shoes? Using an interactive exhibit, kids who visit the recently opened National Underground Railroad Freedom Center in Cincinnati, Ohio, can help Kaleb make a decision. They can also learn about the consequences of that decision.\n"The exhibit gives kids a sense of the risk and losses that were part of trying to gain freedom," museum official Stephen DeVillez told\nThe new museum opened in August 2004 on the northern bank of the Ohio River. That river once marked the line between slavery and freedom. Historians believe that thousands of slaves who escaped through the Underground Railroad from the South, where slavery was allowed, crossed the Ohio River.\nThe Underground Railroad was not a real railroad. During the late 1700s to mid-1800s, the Underground Railroad was actually a secret system of safe routes that runaway slaves could use as they fled from the South to free Northern states, Canada, and Mexico.\nThe Underground Railroad covered hundreds of hidden routes. Most slaves escaped through Ohio, Indiana, and western Pennsylvania. Slaves made their way to freedom any way they could. Most hid during the day and traveled at night.\nAlong the way, a vast network of black people and white people called\nrisked their lives to provide escaped slaves with food, clothing, and shelter. An abolitionist was someone who worked to end slavery.\nThe Underground Railroad got its name because it operated in secrecy. Hiding places for slaves were known as\nprovided slaves with food and shelter. Other people, called\n, guided slaves to freedom. In 1865, the 13th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution\nLibrary of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, Civil War Photographs, [reproduction number, LC-DIG-cwpb-01468]\nInterior view of a slave pen. Slaves were locked up in pens before they were sold at auction.\nArtifacts, paintings, and murals are at the heart of the Freedom Center. Along with films, the exhibits recount the story of slavery in the United States, the dangerous road to freedom, and the continued struggle for liberty around the world today.\nA slave pen found on a farm in Maysville, Kentucky, serves as the museum\'s centerpiece. Built in 1830, the wooden pen is about the size of a small house. Slaves were locked up in the pen for months before they were sold at auction to the highest bidder.\n, or reproduction, of a wagon with a fake bottom that was used to hide and transport fleeing slaves on the Underground Railroad. Visitors can also crawl inside a replica of the wooden box that the slave Henry Brown used to ship himself from Virginia to Pennsylvania.\n"The Underground Railroad wouldn\'t have existed if it wasn\'t for brave people who took a risk to stand up for freedom," said DeVillez. "The museum is a learning center that teaches lessons of courage and the fight for freedom that exists even today."\nSome key people fought against slavery during the mid-1800s.\nHarriet Tubman was a former slave who became the most famous conductor of the Underground Railroad. From 1850 to 1860, she led about 300 slaves to freedom. Tubman once said, "On my Underground Railroad, I [never] run my train off [the] track, and I never [lost] a passenger."\nHarriet Beecher Stowe was a teacher and a minister\'s wife from Ohio who wrote\nin 1852. The book was about a cruel slave master who beat a slave named Tom to death. Her book convinced many people that the horrors of slavery needed to end.\nFrederick Douglass was born a slave in Maryland in 1817. He escaped in 1838 to New York and moved to Massachusetts, where he founded\n. It was one of the first African American abolitionist newspapers that spoke out against slavery.\nHow did the Underground Railroad shape the United States?\nmeasures published under license with MetaMetrics, Inc.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}
{'text': 'Past presidents will appear on $1 coin.\nJust in time for Presidents\' Day on February 19, the U.S. Mint is releasing new $1 coins honoring former U.S. presidents. Beginning February 15, the mint will circulate the first coin, which depicts George WashingtonÑand that\'s only the start.\nThe series will honor four different presidents per year in the order in which they served in office. On the reverse side of the coin will be the Statue of Liberty. The next three coins released this year will feature John Adams, Thomas Jefferson, and James Madison. They will\n"I believe this program is a great opportunity for educating both children and adults about the history of our country," says lawmaker Michael Castle from Delaware. He helped pass the new coin\nWith the exception of Grover Cleveland, each president will appear on only one coin. Cleveland was the only president to serve two terms that weren\'t\nor back-to-back. To be depicted on a coin, a president must have been dead for at least two years.\nPast presidents aren\'t the first people to be depicted on $1 coins. Female leaders Susan B. Anthony and Sacagawea have appeared on the coins. Anthony dedicated her life to fighting for women\'s rights in the 1800s. Native American guide Sacagawea led explorers Meriwether Lewis and William Clark on their westward journey to find a route to the Pacific Ocean.\nThe idea of rotating coin designs comes from the 50 State Quarters Program. Those quarters began circulating in 1999. The state quarters program has been very popular, introducing millions of people to coin collecting. The U.S. Mint hopes the presidential coins will be as successful.\nmeasures published under license with MetaMetrics, Inc.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}

{'text': 'The mummy which may be Nefertiti lies in Egypt\'s Valley of the Kings.\nQueen Nefertiti\'s name means "the beautiful one has come." It is not surprising that she was given such a name. Queen Nefertiti has long been admired for her swanlike neck and high cheekbones.\nBut Nefertiti was more than just a pretty face. She is believed to have been one of the most powerful women who ever lived. She ruled Egypt more than 3,000 years ago. Egypt is a country in Africa.\nMysteriously, no one knows how Queen Nefertiti died. Her remains have never been found--until now, perhaps.\nled by Joann Fletcher uncovered three mummies in a tomb in Egypt. (Archaeologists are scientists who dig up ancient objects and study them to learn about the past.) Fletcher believes that one of the mummies is Queen Nefertiti.\nModern science is helping Fletcher prove her idea and identify the face of the mummy. After X-rays of the mummy were taken, scientists put together a computerized version of what the face would have looked like.\nWhat they discovered was amazing! The re-created face resembles a famous sculpture of Queen Nefertiti that was made during her reign.\n"If the mummy is who we think it is, it would certainly help to answer a lot of unanswered questions," said Fletcher.\nScientists are quick to point out that the computerized version of the face does not prove that the mummy is Queen Nefertiti. The re-created face, however, isn\'t the only clue to the past.\nThere are other pieces of the puzzle that make Fletcher\'s team think the mummy is Nefertiti. First, the mummy\'s hair had been shaved off. Nefertiti preferred a shaved head so that her crown would fit tightly. A shaved head also helped her stay cool in Egypt\'s heat. Second, traces of a wig found next to the mummy matched the kind Nefertiti would have worn.\nIn addition, the mummy\'s left earlobe was pierced twice. Statues of Nefertiti show her having a double-pierced ear. The mummy\'s forehead showed the mark of a tight-fitting band--a sign of royalty. Another clue was the mummy\'s bent arm, which was broken off. Royalty were usually buried with their arms bent.\nNot all scientists are convinced that the mummy is Nefertiti.\n"If the mummy is female and if it is royal, then you still do not necessarily have Nefertiti," one archaeologist told\nAnother scientist from Egypt expressed doubts that the mummy is even a female. He said that both men and women could have double-pierced ears.\nBut Fletcher believes that she has found the long-lost queen and has returned Nefertiti to her rightful place in history.\nThe mummy which may be Nefertiti lies in Egypt\'s Valley of the Kings. That is an ancient burial ground for royalty. It is located in the desert, south of Cairo (the capital of Egypt) and along the west bank of the Nile River.\nScientists are starting to piece together more about the legendary queen\'s life. Nefertiti is now one of the most popular faces from ancient history, but that wasn\'t always the case.\n, ruled Egypt together and had many enemies. Pharaoh is a name given to Egyptian kings.\nThe pharaoh and Nefertiti were disliked because they challenged the religion of the time. They began to worship one god instead of many gods. As part of their new religion, they moved from the city of Thebes and built a new capital in the heart of the desert. The new capital was called Akhetaton (ah-keh-TAHT-uhn).\n(The modern name is Amarna.) They also made many changes to the style of art and architecture of the time.\nMany historians think that when Nefertiti\'s husband died, she became pharaoh.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}

{'text': 'Thousands of children were separated from their families after Hurricane Katrina battered the Gulf Coast of the United States in August. {'text': 'Will new fencing along the U.S.-Mexico border help stop illegal immigration?\nPresident George W. Bush and many members of the U.S. Congress think so. On October 26, Bush signed the Secure Fence Act of 2006 into law. The law will allow the building of 700 miles of new fencing along the 2,100-mile border between the United States and Mexico.\nThe fence is designed to keep people from entering the United States without permission. About 6 million illegal immigrants from Mexico live in the United States today. An\nis someone who leaves one country to live in another country. If people enter a country without permission, they are called illegal immigrants.\nMost illegal immigrants leave Mexico to find jobs in the United States. They usually can’t find jobs in Mexico that pay as much as those in the United States do.\nSome Americans say illegal immigrants take away jobs from U.S. citizens. Others say, however, that illegal immigrants help the U.S. economy by doing jobs that many Americans don’t want.\nThe signing of the bill led to great anger in Mexico. Mexican officials say a fence would not stop illegal immigration and would be an insult to Mexico. Mexican President-elect Felipe Calderón pledged to challenge the fence at the United Nations. Bush, however, called the fence "an important step in our nation’s efforts to secure our borders."\nmeasures published under license with MetaMetrics, Inc.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}
{'text': 'About 140 years ago, the Pony Express delivered mail to some parts of the United States. Today, mail is delivered to most communities by cars, trucks, trains, and planes. But in Supai, Arizona, mail carriers still deliver the mail the way carriers did 100 years ago--by mules.\nAbout 600 Native Americans live in Supai. The town is located at the bottom of a canyon near the Grand Canyon.\nLetter carrier Charlie Chamberlain loads packages on mules. The mules deliver mail to Supai, Arizona.\nBefore being delivered in Supai, mail arrives in the post office in Peach Springs, Arizona, about 70 miles from Supai. From Peach Springs, delivery trucks take the mail to the rim of the canyon. Letter carriers then use mules to carry the mail to Supai.\nLetter carriers who deliver to Supai don\'t just carry letters and small packages; they deliver almost everything that goes to Supai.\n"It\'s amazing what people can do when they put their minds to it," said Charlie Chamberlain, a letter carrier. {'text': "North and South Korea are countries in eastern Asia.\nTwo brothers crept carefully through the mountains in China. The boys, along with their mother, sister, and aunt, had fled their home in North Korea. They hoped to find a better life in South Korea.\nLike China, North and South Korea are countries in Asia. If the Chinese police had found the family, they would have sent them back to their country to be punished or even killed.\nThe brothers, Young Hoon* and Young Jun, and their family members walked, rode in cars, and flew on an airplane to reach South Korea. Their journey took about a year.\nThey were lucky. There are about 200,000 to 300,000 North Koreans now hiding in China. But only about 2,000 of them are expected to make it to South Korea this year.\nYoung Hoon, Young Jun, and their family members risked their lives to reach South Korea. Why? If they had stayed in North Korea, they faced starvation. Many North Korean children are hungry because their families cannot find food. In fact, over the past ten years, about 2 million people in North Korea have starved to death.\nAbout a year after their arrival, the brothers tell me they are happy in Seoul, the busy capital city of South Korea. I visited Young Hoon and Young Jun at the Hannuri School, an after-school program for teens who have left North Korea and come to South Korea to start new lives.\nTeachers at Hannuri help the North Koreans with their schoolwork. Many of the teens did not go to school regularly in North Korea, so they are behind in their lessons.\nEven though North and South Korea are neighbors, the two countries are very different. North Korea is very poor. Its leader spends most of the country's money on the army, not on food for the people.\nSouth Korea is more like the United States. The country has enough food for everyone, and most people drive cars, go to work, and eat at restaurants.\nYoung Hoon, 18, and Young Jun, 15, say that in North Korea they lived in a hut and ate mostly corn and potatoes. {'text': 'World leaders meet to discuss the planet’s water problems.\nIt isn’t easy for Mexico City resident\nCarmen Martinez to get water. She lives in Iztapalapa, one of the poorest slums of the Mexican capital. A\nis a crowded, dirty area with poor living conditions within a large city.\nOnce every eight days, she wakes up before dawn and treks down a hill from her run-down shack to a pumping station to beg for water. She stands in line with as many as 150 other people. When her turn finally comes, she gets aboard a tanker truck full of brownish, smelly liquid.\nThe truck then climbs the hill and pours the water into a dumpster and six barrels. Martinez and her family use that water to bathe, clean, and wash. Although the water is free, it is not\nor drinkable, so Martinez also buys bottled water at a store. She imagines what it would be like "to just turn on a faucet."\nRepresentatives from 148 countries recently met in Mexico City for the fourth World Water Forum in the hopes of making Martinez’s dream a reality. More than 1 billion people around the world do not have access to safe drinking water, according to the United Nations. The forum participants met to exchange ideas about how to quench the thirst of the world’s soaring population.\nAlthough more than two-thirds of Earth’s surface is covered in water, there is only a limited amount of drinking water in the world. Salty seawater makes up about 97 percent of the world’s water. Another 2 percent of water is frozen at the North and South poles.\nHalf a percent is too far underground to be reached, which leaves about half a percent of\nfor all the people and animals on Earth. Freshwater does not have any salt in it. Earth’s freshwater supply is renewable only by\nAlthough most Americans have access to clean water, people in many countries around the world do not. Some countries in Central and South America, Asia, and Africa have some of the most\nor dirty, water in the world. Chemicals from factories, fertilizers from farms, and untreated sewage all get washed into the water supply. In addition, many poor countries don’t always have a way to collect and\nParticipants at the seven-day World Water Forum discussed ways of pooling the world’s money and resources to save water. They proposed building more dams to collect rainwater.\nThe participants suggested that more decisionmaking power about water be given to people in small towns and villages. They also called for governments, not corporations, to take charge of providing water. Around the world, people agree that access to water is a basic human right.\nGovernments know they need to act now to save the world’s liquid resource. "Water is endangered and so are we all," Loïc Fauchon, president of the World Water Council, told reporters.\nWater moves from the air to the land and back to the air again and again. The repeated journey is known as the\nBecause water travels in a cycle, it can carry pollutants into the ocean, the air, and the ground.\nThe sun’s heat changes water into a gas, or vapor.\nThe water vapor meets cool air and changes back into tiny droplets of water.\nThose water droplets form clouds. As the drops get heavier, they fall from the clouds as rain, sleet, or snow.\nMost precipitation falls into the ocean. Some falls on the land and moves into bodies of water.\nWhat are some ways in which you can help conserve water?\nmeasures published under license with MetaMetrics, Inc.\nAll trademarks and logos are property of Weekly Reader Corporation.\n', 'label': '3'}

{'text': 'Do you know the words to the Pledge of Allegiance by heart? If you\'re like most kids in the United States, you probably have said those words countless times.\nNow the pledge has found itself in a firestorm of controversy. Next year, the Supreme Court will decide whether to ban the phrase "under God" from the Pledge of Allegiance in public schools.\nLast year, a federal appeals court in California ruled that the pledge is\nbecause it contains the phrase "under God."\nIf something does not uphold the principles of the U.S. Constitution, it is considered unconstitutional.\nAccording to this lower court, the words "under God" suggest the government\n, or supports, religion. That violates the First Amendment. The First Amendment of the Constitution guarantees freedom of speech, religion, and press. People often refer to this freedom as the separation of church and state.\nThe court\'s decision affects nearly 10 million schoolchildren in nine western states. The states that are part of the lower court\'s ruling include Alaska, Arizona, California, Hawaii, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, Oregon, and Washington. The ruling does not apply to public schools elsewhere in the United States.\nMichael Newdow of California brought the case to court. He argued that his daughter, now in the fourth grade, should not have to listen to the pledge recited daily, because of its reference to God. "I\'ll keep fighting to uphold the Constitution," he told CNN.\nThe Elk Grove School District in Sacramento, California, didn\'t agree.
