{'text': "We can show the forces acting on an object using a\n. In a force diagram, each force is shown as a force arrow. An arrow shows:\nthe size of the force (the longer the arrow, the bigger the force)\nthe direction in which the force acts.\nThe arrow is usually labelled with the name of the force and its size in newtons. Text books often show a force with a thick coloured arrow, but it is best if you just use a pencil and ruler to draw an arrow with a single line.\nWhen two forces acting on an object are equal in size but act in opposite directions, we say that they are\nIf the forces on an object are balanced (or if there are no forces acting on it) this is what happens:\nan object that is not moving stays still\nan object that is moving continues to move at the same speed and in the same direction\nSo notice that an object can be moving even if there are no forces acting on it.\nHere are some examples of balanced forces.\nThe forces on this hanging crate are equal in size but act in opposite directions. The weight pulls down and the tension in the rope pulls up.\nThe forces on this hanging crate are balanced.\nObjects float in water when their weight is balanced by the upthrust from the water. The object will sink until the weight of the water it pushes out of the way is the same as the weight of the object.\nA boat floats because its weight is balanced by the upthrust from the water\nWhen an object rests on a surface such as the ground, its weight is balanced by the reaction force from the ground. The ground pushes up against the object. The reaction force is what you feel in your feet as you stand still. Without this balancing force you would sink into the ground.\nThe weight of a book lying on a table is balanced by the reaction force from the table top\nSomething is pulling your mouse towards this link.\nJoin Questionaut's quest to find his friend's hat.\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. You need to rearrange the equation into a form with just the y value on the left of the equation.\nSo add 4x to both sides to give\nTo find y divide both sides by 2 to give\nNow that you have found the equation in terms of y, you can plot the graph using the usual method.\nGet from X to Y with this activity.\nJoin Questionaut's quest to find his friend's hat.\nUp for a challenge? {'text': '> Number patterns - Even and odd numbers\nNumber patterns - Even and odd numbers\nAny number that can be divided by 2 is called an\nExamples of even numbers are 2, 4, 6, 8, 10, 22, 144 and 2020.\nIf a number ends with an even digit, then it is even. For example 1 023 458 is even, because its final digit (8) is even.\nAny number that cannot be divided by 2 is called an\nExamples of odd numbers are 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 35, 177, 2435, etc.\nIf a number ends with an odd digit, then it is odd. For example 3 702 443 is odd, because its final digit (3) is odd.\nFollow the rules and try this activity!\nUse your knowledge to help Spherox find his way home.\nGo back to basics with KS2 Bitesize.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "> The Tempest second key extract - What happens\nThe Tempest second key extract - What happens\nIn this section you will see buttons at the end of some paragraphs. These will give you extra information. If you want this information, just mouse over the buttons as you read through.\nThe Second Key Extract takes place outside Prospero's cave. Ferdinand is carrying logs. He thinks to himself that he doesn't mind the hard work because he is doing it for Miranda,\nFerdinand's soliloquy (speech that represents a character's thoughts) at the beginning of this section tell us a lot about him. He is a prince, but he understands that hard work can make even the commonest man noble.\neven if her father is cruel and grumpy.\nFerdinand says that Prospero is 'crabbed'. Miranda says later that Prospero isn't always like this. Is this just an act that Prospero is putting on as part of his plan? You might argue that Ferdinand's description seems to be pretty accurate of Prospero for most of the play!\nMiranda comes to see him. Neither of them realise that Prospero is watching them from a distance.\nOn film, it is easy enough to show that a character is watching events from a distance, but how do you create the same effect on the more confined space of a stage? Can you think of some creative ways to show that Prospero is watching the lovers from a distance?\nMiranda says that the log that Ferdinand is carrying 'will weep for having wearied' him when it burns. This is a technique called personification: a kind of metaphor where an object is given human characteristics. You could say that Miranda's metaphor makes her seem quite child-like and innocent.\nbut he says he has too much to do, so she offers to carry some logs for him.\nIn Shakespeare's lifetime, noble women were not expected to work. You might think to yourself that Miranda's offer to help Ferdinand carry the logs shows that she sees herself as his equal.\nHe says he would rather break his back than see her work. Miranda insists again that she should help him.\nLove/ Illusion - Miranda and Ferdinand recognise the sweetness within each other's character. They can't seem to do enough for each other. Their exchange with one another sounds more like true love than a magic trick at this point.\nLooking on, Prospero sees how much Miranda is in love with Ferdinand.\nProspero calls Miranda 'Poor worm' and says that being in love is like being 'infected' with a disease, perhaps like the plague. A 'visitation' in this case is an 'epidemic'. It's not a very romantic way to describe first love. You might wonder what this tells you about Prospero that he uses such language to describe love.\nFerdinand asks Miranda her name and when she tells him, she remembers that in doing so, she has broken her promise to her father.\nIllusion - Miranda thinks that Prospero will be angry with her for telling Ferdinand her name - Prospero has made her think that - but in reality, it is part of his plan to make the young couple fall in love\nFerdinand admits that he has liked lots of different women in the past\nFerdinand uses the word 'bondage' to describe his reaction to listening to beautiful women talk. It links back to the issue of Freedom and Slavery in the play. Ferdinand means that he has been like a slave to beautiful women in the past.\n, but they have always disappointed him with some fault or other in the end.\nFerdinand admits that Miranda is not his first love. He has been in love with lots of beautiful women in the past. He has always found some fault with them. He says that Miranda is perfect! He called her a 'goddess' in the first extract. Do you think that Ferdinand is really in love with Miranda or do you think that it is Prospero's magic that makes him feel this way?\nHowever, Miranda, he says, is perfect. Miranda, on the other hand, hasn't met any men except for her father, or any women, except for herself. Even so, she says that she can't imagine liking anyone more than she likes Ferdinand.\nIn contrast with Ferdinand's experience, Miranda has never had a boyfriend. In fact, Ferdinand is the only man other than her dad that she has ever seen (apparantly, Caliban doesn't count).\nFerdinand tells her that he is a prince, possibly a king (although he hopes his father isn't dead). He wouldn't usually put up with having to carry logs like a slave\nFerdinand compares his work for Prospero to slavery and says that he is a 'slave' to his love for Miranda.\nbut he knew as soon as he saw Miranda that he'd do anything for her. When Miranda asks him if he loves her, Ferdinand says he loves, prizes and honours her more than anything else in the world. This makes Miranda so happy that she cries. As Prospero watches them together, he is moved.\nLove/ Illusion - Having congratulated himself and Ariel all along for the success of their plan to get Miranda and Ferdinand together, Prospero finally seems to admit that the feelings his daughter and her lover have for one another move him. When he says to himself: 'Fair encounter/Of two most rare affections!' you could argue that he recognises that their love is not an illusion after all.\nFerdinand asks Miranda why she is crying. She says she thinks she isn't good enough for him\nMiranda seems to be a very modest character. She is so in love with Ferdinand she offers to be his servant. You might think that this shows that she is quite weak. In Shakespeare's time, men would have made all of the decisions concerning marriage, so you could argue that this shows Miranda to be strong, assertive and a little ahead of her time!\nbut realising she is being silly, she tells Ferdinand she will be his wife if he wants to marry her, and even if he doesn't, she won't ever marry anyone else. Ferdinand happily agrees to marry her. They say goodbye and part.\nProspero is happy for them, but he claims that their engagement is no surprise to him as it was all part of his plan. He goes to get his magic book because he has lots of work to do before supper time.\nFerdinand's soliloquy (speech that represents a character's thoughts) at the beginning of this section tell us a lot about him. He is a prince, but he understands that hard work can make even the commonest man noble.\nFerdinand says that Prospero is 'crabbed'. Miranda says later that Prospero isn't always like this. Is this just an act that Prospero is putting on as part of his plan? You might argue that Ferdinand's description seems to be pretty accurate of Prospero for most of the play!\nOn film, it is easy enough to show that a character is watching events from a distance, but how do you create the same effect on the more confined space of a stage? Can you think of some creative ways to show that Prospero is watching the lovers from a distance?\nMiranda says that the log that Ferdinand is carrying 'will weep for having wearied' him when it burns. This is a technique called personification: a kind of metaphor where an object is given human characteristics. You could say that Miranda's metaphor makes her seem quite child-like and innocent.\nIn Shakespeare's lifetime, noble women were not expected to work. You might think to yourself that Miranda's offer to help Ferdinand carry the logs shows that she sees herself as his equal.\nLove/ Illusion - Miranda and Ferdinand recognise the sweetness within each other's character. They can't seem to do enough for each other. Their exchange with one another sounds more like true love than a magic trick at this point.\nProspero calls Miranda 'Poor worm' and says that being in love is like being 'infected' with a disease, perhaps like the plague. A 'visitation' in this case is an 'epidemic'. It's not a very romantic way to describe first love. You might wonder what this tells you about Prospero that he uses such language to describe love.\nIllusion - Miranda thinks that Prospero will be angry with her for telling Ferdinand her name - Prospero has made her think that - but in reality, it is part of his plan to make the young couple fall in love\nFerdinand uses the word 'bondage' to describe his reaction to listening to beautiful women talk. It links back to the issue of Freedom and Slavery in the play. Ferdinand means that he has been like a slave to beautiful women in the past.\nFerdinand admits that Miranda is not his first love. {'text': 'Now consider the following extract. Read through it carefully and note down three things you think it tells us about the main character. Once you\'ve done this, compare your ideas against ours.\nStanley didn\'t have many friends at home. He was overweight and the kids at his middle school often teased him about his size. Even his teachers sometimes made cruel comments without realising it. On his last day of school, his math teacher, Mrs Bell, taught ratios. As an example, she chose the heaviest kid in the class and the lightest kid in the class, and had them weigh themselves. Stanley weighed three times as much as the other boy. Mrs Bell wrote the ratio on the board, 3:1, unaware of how much embarrassment she had caused both of them.\nWhat does this extract show us about the main character?\nStanley is another big male, but it is clear that the writer wants us to react differently to him than we did to Jim Wellings in the earlier extract.\nStanley is a lonely boy, because he "didn\'t have many friends at home". He is bullied and teased, even by adults. {'text': "Conditioning is a type of behaviour involving a response to a stimulus that is different from the natural one. It's a type of\nIvan Pavlov (1849 to 1936) was a Russian scientist who investigated conditioning. He discovered that dogs produced extra saliva when they were offered food. This is a natural response to a stimulus - food makes a dog's mouth water. The saliva produced is needed to start digesting food and to make swallowing food easier.\nPavlov noticed that they also did this when the person who fed them came into the room, even if the person had not brought any food. Pavlov went on to ring a bell at the start of feeding time, and eventually the dogs produced extra saliva when they heard the bell, before any food was brought in.\nA dog salivating when it hears a bell is not a natural response. They would not do this without being conditioned to do so. The behaviour has been learned. It's called a\nPeople and animals can be conditioned to avoid certain things. For example, grazing animals get an unpleasant electric shock when they touch an electric fence. They eventually avoid the fence, even when it is turned off.\nIs it instinct or conditioning that makes you study science?\nJoin Questionaut's quest to find his friend's hat.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. While you will be able to view the content of this page in your current browser, you will not be able to get the full visual experience. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n", 'label': '4'}
{'text': "> Compounds and mixtures - Separating mixtures\nThe different substances in mixtures are usually easily separated from one another. The method you use depends upon the type of mixture you have.\nThis is good for separating dissolved substances that have different colours, such as inks and plant dyes. It works because some of the coloured substances dissolve in the liquid better than others, so they travel further up the paper.\nfrom a liquid. (An insoluble substance is one that does not dissolve).\nSand, for example, can be separated from a mixture of sand and water using filtration. That's because sand does not dissolve in water.\nfrom a liquid (a soluble substance does dissolve, to form a solution).\nFor example copper sulfate crystals can be separated from copper sulfate solution using evaporation. Remember that it is the water that evaporates away, not the solution.\nfrom a solution. For example, water can be separated from salty water by simple distillation. This method works because the water evaporates from the solution, but is then cooled and condensed into a separate container. The salt does not evaporate and so it stays behind.\nfrom each other. For example, ethanol (alcohol) can be separated from a mixture of ethanol and water by fractional distillation. This method works because the two liquids have different boiling points.\nHow will you react to this activity?\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': '> Variation and classification - Variety within a species\nVariation and classification - Variety within a species\nWithin a population of animals, plants or any living organisms, there will be\n. Within each species the individuals with the variations best suited to the environment will survive better than the others. More of them will survive to reproduce than the others. When they do, they pass on the genetic information for these variations to their offspring.\nSpecies gradually evolve in this way. This process is called\nOver time a population can change so much it may even become a new species, unable to reproduce successfully with individuals of the original species.\nto produce new varieties of a species. A variety is a type of a particular species that is different in some clear way from other varieties of that species.\nFor example, pedigree dogs come in lots of different varieties, called breeds of dog. They may be different colours and sizes, but they are all still dogs. They are all still the same species. Different varieties of dog have been produced by selective breeding.\nSuppose you wanted a variety of cow that produced a lot of milk. This is what you could do:\nchoose or select the cows in your herd that produce the most milk\nselect the offspring that produce the most milk\nkeep repeating the process of selection and breeding until you achieve your goal.\nThe key here is to identify the feature you want, and only breed from the individuals that have that feature. Here are some examples of what selective breeding can produce:\nhens that lay big eggs of a particular colour\ntomato plants that produce lots of tomatoes\ncrops that are resistant to certain plant diseases.\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. While you will be able to view the content of this page in your current browser, you will not be able to get the full visual experience. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n', 'label': '4'}
{'text': "> Introduction to formulas - Like terms\nAlgebraic terms that have the same letter are called like terms. Only like terms can be added or subtracted.\nSo 9b, -7b and 13b are like terms, but 6t, 5x and -11z are not like terms.\nWhen like terms are added and subtracted it is called\nThe Khan family and the Norman family visit the zoo together - there are 8 children and 7 adults in the group. Because there are more than 10 people, the families can take advantage of a special offer - 1 child can be admitted free of charge.\nfor the cost of child admission, and\n3g + 3k + 5g + 4k - g\nSimplified = 3g + 5g - g + 3k + 4k =\nA term, like a number, belongs with the\nthat sits in front of it. So in the expression 2k - g, g belongs with the - sign that sits in front of it, so it is - g; and 2k belongs with the + sign that sits in front of it, making it + 2k.\nCollect all the like terms together, eg, re-write the expression 3g + 2k + 5g + 4k - g with all the g s and all the k s together: 3g + 5g - g + 2k + 4k\nWhen you add or subtract terms, keep each term with their + or - sign.\nSimplify 4x + y - 2x + 6y.\nRe-write the expression by putting the like terms next to each other. remember to keep the plus or minus signs with the terms they belong to.\n4x + y - 2x + 6y\n= 4x - 2x + y + 6y\nTime to formulate a new revision plan!\nCan you match Viral Vinnie's appetite for English, Maths and Science?\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "> Introduction to equations - More complex equations\nIntroduction to equations - More complex equations\nSometimes an equation will have multiples of an unknown, eg, 5y = 20. To solve this you need to get the unknown on its own. To do this, divide both sides by 5.\n5y รท 5 = 20 รท 5\nSometimes an equation will have multiples of an unkown and other numbers, eg, 3x + 2 = 8\nIn equations of this type, your aim is to get all the 'x's (or unknowns) on one side and all the numbers on the other.\nLet's solve the equation 3x + 2 = 8. We can show this in a picture like this, where each bag is an 'x'.\nWe want to get the 'x' on it's own. {'text': "> Quadratic sequences - Finding the nth term\nQuadratic sequences - Finding the nth term\nLook again at the sequence of square numbers:\nWhenever a sequence has a second difference of 2, it will be connected to the sequence of square numbers and the n\nterm will have something to do with n\nterm of the sequence 3, 6, 11, 18, 27, ... ?\nThe second difference is 2, so the n\nterm has something to do with n\nThe sequence of square numbers is: 1, 4, 9, 16, 25, ...\nOur sequence is: 3, 6, 11, 18, 27, ...\nEach term is 2 bigger than the corresponding term in the sequence of square numbers, so the rule for the n\nterm of the sequence 0, 3, 8, 15, 24, ... ?\nThe second differences are 2, so the formula has something to do with n2.\nThe sequence of square numbers is: 1, 4, 9, 16, 25, ...\nOur sequence is: 0, 3, 8, 15, 24, ...\nEach term in our sequence is 1 less than the corresponding term in the sequence of square numbers, so the rule for the n\nWhat comes next? {'text': '> Approximation - Rounding to the nearest whole number\nApproximation - Rounding to the nearest whole number\nIt is not always necessary to give the exact number. For example, if there were 54 785 inhabitants in a town, you could say that its population was approximately 55 000.\nBy doing this we have rounded 54 785 to the nearest thousand to give 55 000.\nWhat is 1484.5 to the nearest 1000?\nIt is between 1000 and 2000, but it is closer to 1000, so round down.\n1484.5 rounded to the nearest thousand is 1000.\nWhat is 1484.5 to the nearest 100?\n1484.5 is between 1400 and 1500, but it is closer to 1500, so round up.\n1484.5 rounded to the nearest hundred is 1500.\n1484.5 lies between 1480 and 1490, but it is closer to 1480, so round down.\n1484.5 rounded to the nearest ten is 1480.\n1484.5 lies between 1484 and 1485 and it is exactly halfway between them. In this situation round up.\n1484.5 rounded to the nearest whole number is 1485.\nRound up, round up and try this activity!\nMake sure your maths skills add up.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "You already know that the volume of a cuboid is\nlength by its breadth by its height (l × b × h)\nThe area of the shaded end of the cuboid (the cross section) is b × h, so you can also say that the volume of a cuboid is:\nvolume of a cylinder = area of circle × length\nvolume of triangular prism = area of triangle × length\nvolume of 'L'-shaped prism = area of 'L'-shape × length\nQ1. What is the volume of this triangular prism?\nQ2. What is the volume of this prism?\nA1. volume = area of triangle × length\nA2. The area of the cross section is 5cm\nand the length is 8cm, so the volume is 5 × 8 = 40 cm\nRemember that the volume is the area of the cross section × the length.\nUse your knowledge to help Spherox find his way home.\nMake sure your maths skills add up.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "> Romeo and Juliet second key extract - Language\nRomeo and Juliet second key extract - Language\nThink about how language is used in the two Key Extracts - for example, where it seems the same in both, and where it seems different.\nWhen Montague talks about how Romeo is in a bad mood and avoiding sunlight, he uses lots of imagery to do with darkness.\nWhen Romeo describes Juliet he uses lots of words and imagery to do with light. Even the night imagery involves brightness with stars and the moon.\nThe metaphors and similes used by the characters in the first extract (especially Romeo) are quite complicated. Benvolio and Romeo enjoy using puns to make jokes together. Language is used in clever ways.\nRomeo still uses language skillfully, but Juliet wants honesty rather than clever poetry. When Romeo starts to swear by the moon, she won't let him finish his clever metaphor. Juliet uses imagery to make her thoughts clear, eg Romeo is like a rose; Juliet's love is as deep as the sea.\nMuch of the first extract is in rhyme. In the scene between Romeo and Benvolio, this helps to bring out the humour in their banter.\nRomeo and Juliet both speak in blank verse: they are talking about love in a much more sensitive way than Romeo did when he was talking to Benvolio. Juliet's final line in the scene finishes Romeo's to make one line of blank verse. (Blank verse is unrhymed and has lines that have 10 syllables each). This shows how close they have become.\nIf you get a question about language in the Key Extracts, here is how to use PEE to help you with your answer:\nHow is love described in the two extracts?\nLove is described in many different ways in the two extracts. By the second extract, love is described in a more positive light.\nIn the first extract, Romeo uses oxymorons because he is confused about his feelings for Rosaline. Romeo compares love to poison and madness.\nIn the second extract, Romeo uses words to do with light and heaven when describing his feelings for Juliet. Juliet talks about love in terms of truth and promises.\nIn the first extract, love means many different things to Romeo. Love is confusing to Romeo and seems to have a dark side that he has no control over. Love is ruining his life. By the end of the first extract, you might think that Romeo has confused his feelings of lust for love. In the second extract, love is related to light and heaven for Romeo. Perhaps when he meets Juliet, he realizes what true love is. For Juliet, love is about truth and honesty. She is almost overwhelmed by her feelings for Romeo. For both characters, love is a powerful and wonderful force.\nMore from Romeo and Juliet second key extract:\nRead the full text online and make your own notes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. While you will be able to view the content of this page in your current browser, you will not be able to get the full visual experience. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n", 'label': '4'}
{'text': '> Whole numbers - Dividing by 10, 100, and 1000\nWhole numbers - Dividing by 10, 100, and 1000\nWhen we divide by 10, every figure moves\nplace to the right. Thousands become hundreds, hundreds become tens and tens become units.\nWhen we divide by 100, every figure moves\nplaces to the right. Thousands become tens, hundreds become units, and tens and units become fractions of a unit.\nWhen we divide by 1000, every figure moves\nplaces to the right. Thousands become units. Hundreds, tens and units become fractions of a unit.\nPerplexed by place values? Then try this activity.\nMake sure your maths skills add up.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "> Analyse, review and comment - Writing to analyse\nAnalyse, review and comment - Writing to analyse\nWhen you are writing to analyse you tend to be quite distant - don't show your personal opinions and be detached from the conclusions you reach.\nSome students feel that there is still too much unhealthy junk food in school. They want more healthy dishes. Others say they wouldn't eat the healthy food and would just bring in their own food or go out to the chip shop, which is out of bounds. We need a solution!\nWrite a speech, to be given at a School Governors' meeting, analysing the advantages and disadvantages of making school dinners healthier.\nYou have to forget about your own preferences. Be thoughtful and give a balanced view of the problem. You could start with ideas like these:\nBetter for us - will improve health and learning\nStudents won't go out of school for food\nYou must also come to a reasonable conclusion. Remember, it has to be a formal speech, that can provide a solution which will solve the problem.\nMake all that writing make sense. {'text': "This can be another tricky area - you shouldn't just stop writing. Instead, make the ending memorable.\nThere are many different ways of doing this. If it's a ghost story, you can leave it unsure and open, as if something else might happen next. Like this…\nHe turned away just as a shadow rose up from the bricks. Was it a trick of the light? Or something else?\nIn other pieces, you need to come to a definite answer, like this…\nOnce the trees are chopped down and the play equipment bulldozed away it will be too late. Too late to save our park. Too late to think about our children. And too late to remember those who died for our freedom. So act now to safeguard this valuable, beautiful area for the future.\nIf you get it wrong, it can seem silly, like these examples…\nOnce the trees are chopped down and the play equipment bulldozed away it will be too late. Act now to safeguard this valuable, beautiful area for the future. But remember that it could still be a car park, and create jobs for our community. Think about it - are you sure? I certainly don't know what to think.\nThis person isn't sure what they want. So how can they convince anyone else?\nOnce the trees are chopped down and the play equipment bulldozed away - well who knows, really. It's one of those things, and who can blame anyone.\nThis argument has just fizzled away. There is no more detail. Make sure you don't waffle at the end.\nThe importance of beginnings, middles and ends.\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "Ducklings are able to walk almost immediately after hatching from the egg, and can even swim after a few days. They recognise their mother because of a behaviour type called\nDucklings will follow the first moving object they meet after hatching. They become socially attached to this object and treat it as their mother.\nImprinting lets young animals recognise their mother from a young age. They can follow her for food and protection.\nImprinting is useful if the first moving object they see really is their mother. But ducklings will imprint on people, balls and even cardboard boxes if these happen to be the first things they see.\nGeese, chicks, and other baby birds that can walk around shortly after hatching, also show imprinting behaviour. Konrad Lorenz (1903 to 1989) was an Austrian scientist who studied animal behaviour.\nHe discovered that if he reared geese from when they hatched, they became imprinted on him. They followed him around and preferred to be near him even when they had grown into adult geese. Lorenz won the 1973 Nobel Prize for Physiology and Medicine because of his experiments on animal behaviour.\nIs it instinct or conditioning that makes you study science?\nJoin Questionaut's quest to find his friend's hat.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. While you will be able to view the content of this page in your current browser, you will not be able to get the full visual experience. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n", 'label': '4'}
{'text': "3 × 3 can also be written as 3\n2 × 2 × 2 = 8\n2 × 2 × 2 can also be written as 2\n. The small digit is called the index number or\n= 3 × 3 = 9, and that 2\n= 2 × 2 × 2 = 8.\n(five to the power of 4) = 5 × 5 × 5 × 5 = 625\n(three to the power of 5) = 3 × 3 × 3 × 3 × 3 = 243.\nThe index number tells you how many times to multiply the numbers together.\nWhen the index number is two, the number has been '\nWhen the index number is three, the number has been '\nWhen the index number is greater than three you say that it is has been multiplied '\nis 'three to the power of seven',\nis 'four to the power of five'.\nLook at the table and work out the answers. {'text': "If you toss a coin, the probability of obtaining a head is\nand the probability of obtaining a tail is also\nIf we choose a letter at random from the word 'SUMS', the probability of obtaining the letter 'S' is\n, the probability of obtaining the letter 'U' is\nand the probability of obtaining the letter 'M' is\nsum of the probabilities of all possible outcomes is 1\nThe probability that I am late for work tomorrow is\n. What is the probability that I am not late for work?\nThere are two possible outcomes - being late and not being late. The sum of their probabilities must add up to 1, so the probability of not being late is 1 -\nWhat are the chances of you trying this activity?\nCan you match Viral Vinnie's appetite for English, Maths and Science?\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': '> Romeo and Juliet first key extract - What happens\nRomeo and Juliet first key extract - What happens\nIn this section you will see buttons at the end of some paragraphs. These will give you extra information. If you want this information, just mouse over the buttons as you read through.\nThe Montagues and Capulets have just had a fight in a public place in Verona. Prince Escalus stopped it and warned that if it happens again, those involved will be punished by death.\nThe first set scene begins with Montague asking Benvolio how the fight began.\nBenvolio is the peacemaker of the play. He tried to stop the servants from fighting. However, he did it by taking out his sword.\nBenvolio tells him that servants from both families were fighting and that when he tried to stop them, Tybalt turned on him.\n- Love and Hate - You might agree with Benvolio\'s opinion that Tybalt is \'fiery\', but Benvolio\'s description of Tybalt\'s behaviour is full of hatred too. He is quick to place all of the blame on Tybalt.\nAfter that, lots of other people joined in until the Prince came and stopped the fighting.\nLady Montague is worried about her son, Romeo. He wasn\'t involved in the fighting but she wonders where he is. Benvolio explains that he saw him skulking about before dawn. Montague says that this is not unusual behaviour for Romeo: people have seen him crying and sighing on his own before daybreak before.\nThe audience finds out a lot about Romeo before he even walks onto the stage. What are your first impressions of Romeo?\nMontague says he has tried to talk to his son, but he won\'t open up to him.\nParents and children - You might be able to sympathise with Romeo not wanting to talk about his feelings with his father.\nHe says he is like a flower that never gets to open because it has been stopped from blossoming by a worm that has eaten into it.\nThis is a simile to show that no one can get near to Romeo whilst he is in such a bad mood.\nWhen Romeo arrives, Montague and Lady Montague leave Benvolio to try and find out why he is in such a bad mood all of the time.\n- Time - There are lots of references to time in this play. The events in this play take place in just less than one week. Romeo and Juliet both feel that time drags whilst they are apart from one another.\nRomeo tries to explain that he is in love with a girl who doesn\'t love him back. He doesn\'t make himself very clear though and Benvolio has to work hard to get him to tell him about it. Romeo comes up with lots of confusing descriptions of love to try and explain how he feels.\nThe list of opposites in Romeo\'s speech (\'loving hate\', \'heavy lightness\', etc) are called oxymorons. They give us an important clue to his character. His confusing speech shows us how confusing the world is to him as a young man. It also shows us that Romeo likes to play with language.\n"Here\'s much to do with hate, but more with love"\n- Love and Hate - Romeo is commenting on the street brawl that has just happened: it\'s about hating an opposing family and feeling love and loyalty towards their own. Taken on its own, the line sums up the play as a whole: it\'s about two families that hate each other, but more about the love between Romeo and Juliet.\nRomeo speaks in rhyme to try to describe how he feels.\nRomeo\'s speeches are often in rhyme. He also likes wordplay, metaphors and similes. Romeo loves to talk about love, but does he really know what love is at this point? You could say that Romeo, at this point is \'all talk and no action\'.\nHe says that love is like smoke made from the hot breath of lovers and that the flames are the sparks in their eyes. But if it doesn\'t work out, love is a sea of tears. He also describes love as a kind of madness and a poison.\n- Love - The language that Romeo uses to describe love gives us an idea of what Romeo believes love to be at this point. For him it\'s about desire, which sounds like lust rather than true love.\nBenvolio brings Romeo back to earth with a straightforward question: who is the girl he is in love with?\nWhilst Romeo is pouring his heart out, Benvolio\'s responses could be performed in a number of ways- sympathetic, impatient, humorous. All three work.\nRomeo still won\'t give him a straight answer though.\nRomeo and Benvolio are good friends. We can see this through the way they banter with one another.\nHe tells Benvolio that the girl is very beautiful but she doesn\'t want to fall in love. It seems that she is very pure and Romeo says that because she isn\'t interested in men, her beauty will be wasted!\n- Love - We never meet Rosaline in the play and only have Romeo\'s description of her to go by. It\'s hard to tell whether she really is a very good girl or whether she simply doesn\'t fancy Romeo!\nThen she hath sworn that she will still live chaste?\nShe hath, and in that sparing makes huge waste\nBenvolio says that the best thing to do is to forget her. He advises Romeo to look at other attractive girls. Romeo swears that he can never forget her; he\'ll never find anyone as beautiful as her. Benvolio bets that he will.\nBenvolio is the peacemaker of the play. He tried to stop the servants from fighting. However, he did it by taking out his sword.\n- Love and Hate - You might agree with Benvolio\'s opinion that Tybalt is \'fiery\', but Benvolio\'s description of Tybalt\'s behaviour is full of hatred too. He is quick to place all of the blame on Tybalt.\nThe audience finds out a lot about Romeo before he even walks onto the stage. What are your first impressions of Romeo?\nParents and children - You might be able to sympathise with Romeo not wanting to talk about his feelings with his father.\nThis is a simile to show that no one can get near to Romeo whilst he is in such a bad mood.\n- Time - There are lots of references to time in this play. The events in this play take place in just less than one week. Romeo and Juliet both feel that time drags whilst they are apart from one another.\nThe list of opposites in Romeo\'s speech (\'loving hate\', \'heavy lightness\', etc) are called oxymorons. They give us an important clue to his character. His confusing speech shows us how confusing the world is to him as a young man. It also shows us that Romeo likes to play with language.\n- Love and Hate - Romeo is commenting on the street brawl that has just happened: it\'s about hating an opposing family and feeling love and loyalty towards their own. Taken on its own, the line sums up the play as a whole: it\'s about two families that hate each other, but more about the love between Romeo and Juliet.\nRomeo\'s speeches are often in rhyme. He also likes wordplay, metaphors and similes. Romeo loves to talk about love, but does he really know what love is at this point? You could say that Romeo, at this point is \'all talk and no action\'.\n- Love - The language that Romeo uses to describe love gives us an idea of what Romeo believes love to be at this point. For him it\'s about desire, which sounds like lust rather than true love.\nWhilst Romeo is pouring his heart out, Benvolio\'s responses could be performed in a number of ways- sympathetic, impatient, humorous. All three work.\nRomeo and Benvolio are good friends. We can see this through the way they banter with one another.\n- Love - We never meet Rosaline in the play and only have Romeo\'s description of her to go by. It\'s hard to tell whether she really is a very good girl or whether she simply doesn\'t fancy Romeo!\nMore from Romeo and Juliet first key extract:\nRead the full text online and make your own notes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. It has a volume of 1cm\nThis cuboid contains 12 cubes. Each cube has a volume of 1cm\n. So the volume of this cuboid is 12cm\nFind the volume of the following cuboids:\nb) There are two rows of nine cubes, so the volume is 18cm\nUse your knowledge to help Spherox find his way home.\nMake sure your maths skills add up.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "> Explore, imagine and entertain - Appealing to the senses\nExplore, imagine and entertain - Appealing to the senses\nOne way of being creative is appealing to the senses.\nLet's go back to our description of a coastline. Imagine you want to write about a cliff, concentrating on the sense of sound, sight, touch, taste and smell.\n- the waves crashed on the rocks beneath and I heard the gulls screaming above me.\n- the heavy, grey rocks looked as if they were about to slide into the leaden sea.\n-the wind lifted my hair and I felt sudden gusts sting my face.\n- the spray from the waves hit my face and I could taste the salty water on my lips.\n- the damp, warm scent of the seaweed rose gently.\nNow, see if you can use the same list of senses to describe another sea scene. {'text': "> More on formulas - Multiplying brackets\nWhen multiplying expressions in brackets, make sure that everything inside the bracket is multiplied by the term (or number) outside the bracket.\nUse either method, but remember that everything inside the bracket must be multiplied by the term (or number) outside the bracket.\nWhat happens when we have more than a single term or number outside the bracket? What happens when we have another bracket.\nFor example, if we want to expand\n, we need to make sure that everything in the second bracket is multiplied by everything in the first.\nWe can do this in two ways, using boxes or lines.\nIn order to see this content you need to have both\nIn order to see this content you need to have both\nYou can choose either method, boxes or lines, but make sure that you multiply everything. {'text': '> Measures of average - The mean\nThe mean is the most common measure of average.\nTo calculate the mean add the numbers together and divide the total by the amount of numbers:\nMean = sum of numbers รท amount of numbers\nFive friends compare their marks in a French test. These are shown below:\nMean = (41 + 54 + 79 + 26 + 65) รท 5\nCheck your answer by asking yourself if it looks about right. If you had forgotten to divide by 5 then the answer would have been 265, which would not have made sense. Always check that your answer seems sensible.\nA die is thrown 10 times. The following results are obtained:\n3, 5, 1, 2, 6, 4, 2, 5, 6, 1\nTo find the answer, add the numbers together and divide by the amount of numbers:\nMean = (3 + 5 + 1 + 2 + 6 + 4 + 2 + 5 + 6 + 1) รท 10\nHow mean are you? {'text': 'How a text ends is just as important as how it begins. Good endings should leave the reader feeling satisfied.\nTake a look at the final paragraph of the article about boxing.\nIn conclusion, both sides of the debate have solid foundations. As has been shown, the arguments for and against have been put forward since boxing began. And, it would seem, the argument will continue for at least the foreseeable future, as compromise seems unlikely. Both sides do agree, however, that the debate is better held whilst boxing is licensed and controlled rather than unlicensed and uncontrolled. The latter would make it, in my opinion, neither sport nor spectacle.\nAs you can see, the writer clearly signals that the end is approaching by using the connecting phrase "In conclusion". It maintains the impersonal approach it set out with by stating that the argument will continue and that "compromise seems unlikely". The last sentence is a statement of the writer\'s own opinion, but this doesn\'t alter the fact that it is, or has been, a discursive text.\nSo, when answering how effective the beginning or ending of a text is, here\'s a quick checklist you might find helpful:\nDoes it use language in the same way as the rest of the text?\nIs it satisfying? Do you really feel that the text is complete?\nDoes it suit the tone of the whole extract?\nDoes it use language in the same way?\nWhat do you need to construct a text?\nLove books? {'text': "> Explore, imagine and entertain - Ending short-stories\nExplore, imagine and entertain - Ending short-stories\nThe other problem some writers have is ending the story. It doesn't matter if it's a happy ending or not, but it has to make sense. There are lots of ways of ending, such as:\n, where we have to wait until the final moment until we know. For instance, the spy who manages to stop the bomb two seconds before it explodes.\n, where we are fairly sure about something, but in the final part everything changes. For example, we then learn that this is a fake bomb, and the real one is hidden somewhere else and will explode in five minutes.\n, where the story stops, but we aren't sure what has actually happened at the end. For instance, the bomb is defused and everyone is safe. But then an army commander reports the theft of another bomb... only this time twice as powerful.\nHowever, there are two endings to avoid:\n, where a bomb will inevitably explode and as it does, the narrator wakes up - it was all a dream. Some English teachers don't mind this sort of thing, but others hate it. You have been warned.\n, where the secret agent suddenly stops worrying about the bomb, retires, and goes off to play golf. This is even worse, and no-one likes it because the ending has nothing to do with the story.\nWhatever kind of story you write, decide on your ending and include it in your plan.\nWriting that explores, imagines or entertains depends on being creative. You need to experiment a little and not be frightened to try something new.\nCan you match Viral Vinnie's appetite for English, Maths and Science?\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': 'Fiction texts can be divided into three main types:\nFiction texts are written mainly to entertain the reader - they usually tell a story, but they can often be thought-provoking. Some may help you to make sense of, or understand, life better; some are a way for the writer to give their views and opinions of the world.\nIt seemed like just another cold, wet, winter night in downtown Pelleville. He hiked up his collar, stepped nearer the kerb and hailed a cab. {'text': '> Energy transfer and storage - Energy transfer diagrams\nEnergy transfer and storage - Energy transfer diagrams\nEnergy transfer diagrams show the locations of\n. For example, consider the energy transfers in the simple electrical circuit below.\nWe can show the transfers like this:\nthe energy to the surroundings by light. These are the\nenergy transfers - we use electric lamps to light up our rooms.\nBut there are also energy transfers that are not useful to us. In the example above, the lamp also transfers energy to the surroundings by\n. If we include this energy transfer, the diagram looks like this:\nSankey diagrams summarise all the energy transfers taking place in a process. The thicker the line or arrow, the greater the amount of energy involved. This Sankey diagram for the lamp shows that it transfers most of the energy by heating, rather than by light:\nNotice that the total amount of energy transferred to the surroundings is the same as the amount of electrical energy. We say that the energy has been conserved. Energy is always conserved, it is never "lost" or "wasted", although some energy transfers are useful and some are not.\nCan you match Viral Vinnie\'s appetite for English, Maths and Science?\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "There are two main types of language: literal and figurative.\nLiteral language is explicit, obvious, out in the open and plainly stated. It is a major part of non-fiction texts, but can also be found in fiction.\nFigurative language infers or suggests things rather than stating them. Figurative language can give a text more richness and depth. It is often found in fiction texts and autobiographies, but can also be found in non-fiction.\nFind out the difference between fact and fiction.\nJoin Questionaut's quest to find his friend's hat.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "The extract comes from a book called 'Face' by Benjamin Zephaniah. Natalie is a Year 9 student and lives in East London. She is out with her boyfriend and his friends. They have stopped to chat with some boys from school. Answer the question below and then check your ideas against ours. You can use the bullet points to help you.\nAfter a couple of minutes she realised that her every move was being watched by a group of three girls and she couldn't help noticing how tough they looked. All three were wearing dark blue baggy jeans. She was pretty sure they were Londoners born and bred but thought they could find a job working for the Jamaican tourist board, not simply because of their dark skin but also because of their clothing. One had a T-shirt saying 'I love Jamaica'. Another wore a T-shirt that was a Jamaican flag and the third just had a West Ham football shirt on, but she, like the others, was adorned with yellow, black and green bangles, badges and necklaces. Natalie thought they looked good, but dangerous.\nNatalie shifted nervously. She didn't know quite where to look but she had to put on a front. The other three girls made no attempt to hide the fact that they were on Natalie's case. They began to whisper to each other and smile as they stared at her. Natalie felt illuminated in her green satins and began to wish she had chosen clothes which weren't so loud. What are they grinning at? she wondered. Is it my clothes? My shoes? My hair? Do I look too innocent? Suddenly the three girls began to walk toward Natalie. Her heart began to race, the palms of her hands began to sweat. She felt like falling apart but she held herself together.\n'You from round here, den?' said the big girl wearing the Jamaican flag.\n'Yeah, I wanid to go there but they wouldn't let me, said I had ta go ta Lonsdale Park, said it was nearer. What ya doing here?'\nThe other two girls continued to look her up and down. Natalie expected trouble and in her mind she cursed the boys for bringing her there and for the way they had got lost in their silly conversation about football and cars.\n'I'm just hanging around with my boyfriend and his mates.'\nAt this point the girl wearing the West Ham shirt reached into her back pocket. Natalie swallowed hard as the girl pulled out a couple of leaflets. After separating one from the other she handed one to Natalie. 'Dat's the place to be, check it out, good vibes, good music. Ya like rap?'\nNatalie wanted to kick herself. She had completely misread the situation. They weren't out for a fight, they wanted to find out if she liked clubbing. They wanted to find out if she was one of them, an Eastender.\n'Yeah,' Natalie replied, feeling a sense of relief. 'Yeah, rap's cool...' She began to wonder if she sometimes looked threatening and if she herself had been misjudged in the past. For people to be friendly, did they have to have permanent smiles on their faces?\nHow does the writer show Natalie's thoughts and feelings changing during the extract?\nher first reactions to the girls she sees\nthe way she acts just before, and when, they speak to her\nher thoughts at the end of the passage.\nJust before the girls speak to her, Natalie seems even more anxious. She is used to being out on the streets of London and feels she needs to 'put on a front' and look tough. She is afraid they may be laughing at her clothes or hair, which makes her seem insecure about herself. However, when the girls come up to speak to her she hides her nerves and answers their questions. The way she uses short answers like 'Yeah' suggests she does not want to give too much away about herself or get into a fight.\nWhen she realises the girls are actually being friendly and want to give her a flyer for a club, Natalie's feelings change completely. She is ashamed of being suspicious and feels like 'kicking herself'. She realises the girls are Eastenders just like her. The writer shows how this makes her think about her own image. She wonders if people think she looks threatening, too. At this point she comes across as an intelligent, thoughtful girl who wants to learn how to judge people fairly in the future.\nWhack and zap mad professors and aliens!\nLove books? {'text': "You may get told off if you swing around on one leg of a chair instead of sitting properly. Apart from the risk that you will damage the chair or hurt yourself, the chair leg can damage the floor. This is because it puts too much\nTo work out pressure, we need to know two things:\nthe area over which the force or weight works.\nThis is the equation for working out pressure:\nA force of 20 N acted over an area of 2 m\n(two square metres). What is the pressure?\nNotice that the unit of pressure here is N/m\n(newtons per square metre). Sometimes you will see another unit being used. This is called the\n, so in the example above the pressure is 10 Pa.\nDrawing pins make good use of pressure\nDrawing pins have a large round end for you to push. The round end has a large area, so it applies a low pressure to your thumb. The sharp end has a very small area. The same pushing force produces a high pressure there, so it pushes into the notice board.\nIf you swing round on one leg of a chair, you put four times as much pressure on one point of the floor as you do if you sit properly. This is because four chair legs spread the pressure over four times more area than one chair leg can.\nSomething is pulling your mouse towards this link.\nJoin Questionaut's quest to find his friend's hat.\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "> Variation and classification - Inherited & environmental\nVariation and classification - Inherited & environmental\nSome variation within a species is inherited, and some variation is due to the environment.\nVariation in a characteristic that is a result of genetic inheritance from the parents is called\nChildren usually look a little like their father, and a little like their mother, but they will not be identical to either of their parents. This is because they get half of their inherited features from each parent.\nEach egg cell and each sperm cell contains half of the\nneeded for an individual. When these join at fertilisation a new cell is formed with all the genetic information needed for an individual.\nHere are some examples of inherited variation in humans:\nGender is inherited variation too, because whether you are male or female is a result of the genes you inherited from your parents.\nCharacteristics of animal and plant species can be affected by factors such as climate, diet, accidents, culture and lifestyle. For example, if you eat too much you will become heavier, and if you eat too little you will become lighter. A plant in the shade of a big tree will will grow taller as it tries to reach more light.\nVariation caused by the surroundings is called\n. Here are some other examples of features that show environmental variation:\nflower colour in hydrangeas - these plants produce blue flowers in acidic soil and pink flowers in alkaline soil.\nSome features vary because of a mixture of inherited causes and environmental causes. For example, identical twins inherit exactly the same features from their parents. But if you take a pair of twins, and twin 'A' is given more to eat than twin 'B', twin 'A' is likely to end up heavier.\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "> Coordinates - x and y coordinates\nAll graphs have an x-axis and a y-axis. Here is a diagram of a typical set of axes.\nThe x-axis is horizontal, and the y-axis is vertical.\nOne way to remember which axis is which is '\nCoordinates are written as two numbers, separated by a comma and contained within round brackets. For example, (2, 3), (5, 7) and (4, 4)\nCoordinates are written alphabetically - so x comes before y (x, y). One way to remember is 'you go along the hallway before you go up the stairs'\nLost the plot? {'text': "The environment, the Earth and the universe\n> Astronomy and space science - The Moon\nAstronomy and space science - The Moon\nThe Moon orbits the Earth, so it is called a\n. No-one built it or launched it into space.\nGravitational forces between the Moon and the Earth keep the Moon in orbit. The Moon does not produce light. But it does\nlight from the Sun, which is how we are able to see it from Earth. (Only stars produce light and they are called luminous for that reason.)\nIt takes the Moon 28 days to make a complete orbit of the Earth. As it orbits, we see the Moon lit from different angles. This is why we see\nSometimes the Moon looks like a full circle. That is called a 'full Moon'. At other times we see a crescent shaped Moon, because we can only see the edge of the part that is lit by the Sun.\nRemember that we can only see the part of the Moon that reflects the Sun's light. How much of that we can see depends upon the position of the Moon in its orbit.\nThis slideshow shows the phases of the Moon, as seen from the Earth.\nA common mistake is to think that the phases of the Moon happen because the Earth gets in the way, and casts its shadow onto the Moon. That is not how the phases are caused.\nHowever sometimes it does happen that the Earth's shadow falls on the Moon. Then we get an\nof the Moon. The whole Moon goes from full, to dark, and back again to full, in the course of a few hours.\nMore from The environment, the Earth and the universe\nTry an activity that's out of this world!\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': '> Argue, persuade and advise - Writing to persuade\nArgue, persuade and advise - Writing to persuade\nWhen you are persuading people, you usually use a different style. You don\'t need to show both sides - all you have to do is present your ideas. For instance, imagine you had to persuade people to buy a certain toothpaste. You could write about the great taste, or how clean your teeth feel or how white they are. It doesn\'t really matter what you find to write about as long as you get them to buy it.\nBut you wouldn\'t write about other makes of toothpaste. You don\'t persuade like this, because it sounds like you aren\'t sure. So the first thing to remember is:\n- if you are writing about how great chips are, keep repeating the idea. Convince yourself how good they are - they might even be a healthy option, because lots of doctors are bound to like them and chips wouldn\'t be so popular if they weren\'t really great, would they? Once you have convinced yourself, it\'s much easier to convince others. So next you need to remember to...\n- it\'s always better to hear how good your idea is rather than how bad other people\'s are. So write about the things that show your ideas in the best light. For instance, aren\'t chips just great for a quick snack? Why were chips voted the most popular option in our school at lunchtime? And finally don\'t be frightened to...\n- If you don\'t seem too sure, or if you can\'t make your ideas stand out, then you aren\'t really persuading as much as you can. And if that is the case, you need The Persuaders\' Toolkit.\n- don\'t worry about saying the same thing again and again - people forget, so repeat yourself and they will remember. Even when you think they might remember, you can always repeat yourself another time.\n- using words such as "we" or "I" always sounds a lot more convincing. We all know that, don\'t we?\n- why would you use questions? Well, they make people think. They also get your readers involved in what you are writing. So will you use them when you persuade? If not, why not?\n- words are your ammunition. In seconds, they can make your friends laugh, or your teacher angry, so why not use them properly to persuade your readers?\nFor instance, don\'t just write "the pressure of doing school work", because there is no real feeling there. Instead, how about: "the endless trauma, the desperation and the mindless suffering that school work inflicts on students".\nWant to get your own way? Try this activity to learn some techniques\nUse your knowledge to help Spherox find his way home.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n', 'label': '4'}

{'text': "> Electric current and voltage - Electric charge\nElectric current and voltage - Electric charge\nHave you ever heard a crackle when taking off your jumper? This is caused by tiny electric charges on your clothes. It's called\nYour jumper and shirt get electrically charged as they rub together, and then negative electric charges jump from one to the other. This makes sparks that crackle - you can even see them in a dark room.\nWhen electric charges move in a wire, we say that an\nflows in the wire. It's like the way a current of water flows in a river.\nFor an electric current to flow, we need two things:\nsomething to make the electricity flow, such as a battery or power pack\na complete path for the current to flow in. This is called an electric circuit.\nAn electric current will not flow if we do not have a\n(a cell, battery or power pack). It also won't flow if the circuit is not\n. One end of the power source must be joined to the other end by the wires and components of the circuit.\nThe simplest complete circuit is a piece of wire from one end of a battery to the other. An electric current can flow in the wire from one end of the battery to the other, but nothing useful happens. The wire just gets hot and the battery goes flat.\nTo do something useful with the electric current, we need to put an electrical\ninto the circuit, such as a lamp or motor, that can use the current to make something happen.\nThe bulb will only light if there is a battery and a complete circuit\nto the circuit, so that we can break the circuit and stop the electric current when we want to.\nDanger! Danger! High voltage! {'text': '> Linear sequences - HCF and LCM\nThe factors of a number are any numbers that divide into it exactly.\nThe factors of 12 are 1, 2, 3, 4, 6 and 12\nThe factors of 18 are 1, 2, 3, 6, 9 and 18\n1, 2, 3 and 6 are factors of both 12 and 18.\nThey are known as the common factors of 12 and 18.\nSo the Highest Common Factor (HCF) of 12 and 18 is 6.\nWhat is the HCF of 24 and 30?\nThe factors of 24 are 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 12 and 24\nThe factors of 30 are 1, 2, 3, 5, 6, 10, 15 and 30.\nSo the HCF of 24 and 30 is\nThe multiples of a number are all the numbers that it will divide into.\nThe multiples of 4 are 4, 8, 12, 16, 20, 24, 28, 32, 36, 40, 44, ...\nThe multiples of 6 are 6, 12, 18, 24, 30, 36, 42, 48, 54, 60, 66, ...\n12, 24, and 36 are multiples of both 4 and 6 and are known as the common multiples of 4 and 6.\nThe lowest number that is a multiple of 4 and 6 is 12. So the LCM of 4 and 6 is 12.\nWhat is the LCM of 5 and 8?\nThe multiples of 5 are 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 35, 40...\nThe mulitples of 8 are 8, 16, 24, 32, 40, 48, 56...\nSo the LCM of 5 and 8 is\nWhat comes next? {'text': "> Fractions - Common factors and simplest form\nFractions - Common factors and simplest form\nof a number are those numbers that divide into it exactly.\nNumbers have common factors if the same number divides into both of them.\nSo 4 is a common factor of both 8 and 12, as it divides into both of them. 2 is a common factor of both 2 and 6, as it divides into both of them.\n4 and 12 have a common factor (4), so\n(divide the top and the bottom by 4).\n2 and 6 have a common factor (2), so\n(divide the top and the bottom by 2).\nHowever, 1 and 3 have no common factors, so\ncannot be simplified. {'text': '> Collecting and recording data - Tally & frequency charts\nCollecting and recording data - Tally & frequency charts\nsystem to record your results is faster than writing out words or figures all the time.\nIf you record your findings in a tally chart, the data is already collected into groups, and you will not need to group it later on.\nTo investigate the most popular colour of car passing your house, it is easier to draw tally marks in one of five columns than to write red, blue, silver, silver, red, other, black etc.\nIf you use a tally chart, you could note down the colour of the cars as they pass, and find the total frequencies at the end of the one-hour period.\nLook at the tally chart below. {'text': "> Food chains - Getting carbon dioxide, light and water\nFood chains - Getting carbon dioxide, light and water\nRemember that the equation for photosynthesis is:\ncarbon dioxide + water (+ light energy)\nLet's see how plants get the carbon dioxide and water they need for this process.\nPlants get carbon dioxide from the air through their leaves. The carbon dioxide\nthrough small holes in the underside of the leaf called stomata. (One of these holes is called a stoma. The plural is stomata.)\nThe lower part of the leaf has loose-fitting cells, to allow carbon dioxide to reach the other cells in the leaf. This also allow the oxygen produced in photosynthesis to leave the leaf easily.\nA leaf usually has a large surface area, so that it can absorb a lot of light. Its top surface is protected from water loss, disease and weather damage by a waxy layer.\nThe upper part of the leaf is where the light falls, and it contains a type of cell called a\n. This is adapted to absorb a lot of light. It has lots of chloroplasts and is shaped like a tall box.\nTurgid plant that's watered regularly and a flacid plant without enough water.\nPlants get the water they need for photosynthesis through their roots.\nThe roots have a type of cell called a root hair cell - these project out from the root into the soil. Roots have a big surface area and thin walls, which allow water to pass into them easily.\nNote that root cells do not contain chloroplasts, as they are normally in the dark and cannot photosynthesise.\nThe water absorbed by the root hair cells passes through the plant in\ntubes, and eventually reachers the leaves. If a plant does not absorb enough water, it will wilt or go floppy. Without water it may also not photosynthesise quickly enough, and it may die.\nHungry for knowledge? Prey on this activity.\nWhack and zap mad professors and aliens!\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "> Listening - Showing you are listening\nIt sounds weird, but you can show that you are a good listener by talking! The trick is to know what to say and when to say it.\nGood listeners show that they are listening by:\nMaking eye contact with the person that is talking to them\nUsing facial expressions to show that they understand or are reacting to what is said\nAllowing the person who is speaking finish before they respond\nRepeating, in their own words, what the person has said to show that they understand\nReferring back to comments that have already been made\nRead this conversation between Abdul, Emily and Matt. {'text': '> Formal and informal writing - Informal writing\nFormal and informal writing - Informal writing\nWriting is informal when it reads as though someone is chatting to the reader. In the right situation, it makes your writing seem more friendly and natural.\nWhich of the following would you NOT write using informal language?\nb) An essay about a Shakespeare play\nc) A talk aimed at students your own age or younger\ne) A story written from the point of view of a character (in the first person)\nb) An essay should always be written using formal language. All of the other situations would suit a more informal style.\nTips to make your informal writing more effective\n"Dear reader, I\'m really glad you\'ve found the time to open this letter."\n2. It\'s okay sometimes to use the kind of words that are more usual in speech than writing:\n"You don\'t have to put up with bullying. We\'ll stick together and make it stop."\n3. Contractions sound more natural in certain types of writing eg a talk to fellow students:\n"It\'s good to know that we\'re all going to work together on this."\nDon\'t baffle your reader with too much slang.\nThink carefully about structure - informal writing is different to speech and needs carefully planned paragraphs to keep it clear and easy to read.\nSometimes there is opportunity to break the rules of Standard English and use English in unexpected ways. Two good examples of writers who achieve this are poet Benjamin Zephaniah and writer Andrea Levy in her book Small Island.\nIf you\'re asked to write a story, it would be a mistake for you as the author to use incorrect grammar and slang - but inside speech marks, your characters can!\nJoin Questionaut\'s quest to find his friend\'s hat.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': '> Decimals - Adding and subtracting decimals\nWhen adding and subtracting decimals, remember is to keep the decimal points in line in the question and the answer.\nDavid is doing some DIY. He buys a 2m length of wood. He needs to cut two pieces of wood - one of length 0.6m and one of length 1.02m.\nWhat is the total length of wood that David needs to cut?\nSo the total length of wood that David needs to cut is 1.62m.\nYou can add zeros to the end of a decimal without affecting its value, so 0.6 is the same as 0.60.\nDavid originally had 2m of wood. What is the length of the piece of wood that is left?\nDavid cut off 1.62m, so we need to calculate 2 - 1.62\nSo there is 0.38m of wood left.\nConnect the dots with this decimals activity.\nWhack and zap mad professors and aliens!\nMake sure your maths skills add up.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': 'Imagine that you are buying a t-shirt for £9.99, a pair of socks for £1.49 and a belt for £8.99 The cashier charges you £23.47. You feel that this is too much - but how do you know?\nOne way of finding out whether you have been over-charged is to estimate what the total amount should be. Round the different prices into easier numbers - £9.99 is approximately £10, £1.49 is approximately £1.50 and £8.99 is approximately £9 - and you can do the calculation quickly in your head.\n£10 + £1.50 + £9 = £20.50\nThis is almost £3 less than the cashier asked for, so obviously you have been over-charged.\nBy rounding the actual values to more manageable numbers, you can estimate the answers to many problems:\n£3 + £3 + £1 = £7\nRound up, round up and try this activity!\nMake sure your maths skills add up.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': 'Persuasive texts try to persuade you to do something - like buy something or give money to charity. Magazine articles and newspaper reports may try to persuade you to agree with them.\nAre you tired of the daily grind? Sick of working all hours of the day for little reward? Tired of never having enough money to really enjoy yourself?\nHere\'s how to spot this type of text:\nIt tries to convince you to do or agree with something.\nIt contains a mix of fact and opinion.\nIt may use repetition, "soundbites" and persuasive or emotive language.\nIt often seems to speak directly to the reader.\nArgument texts should be balanced and fair, and give all sides of an argument before coming to a conclusion.\nHere\'s an extract from an argument text:\nFoxhunting is a subject that provokes very strong feelings. Many people believe that it is cruel to hunt a fox with dogs, and totally agree with its ban.\nMany farmers, and even conservationists, however, have always argued that the fox is a pest, which attacks livestock and must be controlled.\nHere are some clues to help you identify an argument text:\nIt discusses an issue, considering all points of view.\nIt often uses a formal and impersonal style to seem balanced.\nIt uses connectives to connect points, for example "however", "but", "similarly"\nFind out the difference between fact and fiction.\nJoin Questionaut\'s quest to find his friend\'s hat.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "You already know that the probabibility of an outcome is:\nnumber of ways an outcome can happen รท total number of possible outcomes\nHowever, finding the total number of possible outcomes is not always straightforward - especially when we have more than one event.\nTwo coins are tossed, once each. What is the total number of possible outcomes when they land, with either their heads or their tails uppermost?\nThe total number of possible outcomes is not three (two heads, a head and a tail or two tails). To find the true number of possible outcomes, we must list the results or use a table.\nFrom both these methods we can see that there are four possible outcomes. We can use this fact to calculate probabilities.\nEg: there is only one way of obtaining two heads, so the probability (P) of obtaining 2 heads is\nWe can say P (two heads) =\nThere are two ways of obtaining a head and a tail, so P (head and tail) =\nWhen listing possible outcomes, try to be as logical as possible. If you repeat or forget any of them, it will affect the rest of your answers.\nCopy and complete the following table, which shows the sum of their scores:\na) What is the most likely outcome?\nb) What is the probability that the sum of the scores will be 3?\nc) What is the probability that the sum of the scores will be greater than 5?\nb) The probability of getting the sum 3 =\nc) The probability of a sum greater than 5 =\nWhat are the chances of you trying this activity?\nCan you match Viral Vinnie's appetite for English, Maths and Science?\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "Living things have certain life processes in common. There are seven things that they need to do to count as being alive. The phrase\nMaking more living things of the same type\nIt can be easy to tell if something is living or not. A teddy bear might look like a bear, but it can't do any of the seven things it needs to be able to do to count as being alive.\nWhat about a car? A car can move, it gets energy from petrol (like nutrition), it might have a car alarm (sensitivity), and it gets rid of waste gases through its exhaust pipe (excretion). But it can't grow or make baby cars. So a car is not alive.\nWhack and zap mad professors and aliens!\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled.
