{'text': '> Atmosphere and setting - Identify implicit meaning\nAtmosphere and setting - Identify implicit meaning\nNow\'s your chance to see if you can spot implicit meaning. Read the following extract from a short story by HG Wells.\nwhat sort of atmosphere Wells was trying to create\nthe way he used figurative language to do this\nMake at least two points about each. A few words and phrases have been put in bold to give you some clues. When you have finished, click on the \'Check ideas\' button to see our ideas.\nThe long, draughty, subterranean [which means underground] passage was chilly and dusty, and my candle flared and\n. The echoes rang up and down the spiral staircase, and\na shadow came sweeping up after me\ninto the darkness overhead. I came along the landing and stopped there for a moment, listening to a rustling sound that I fancied I heard; then, satisfied of the absolute silence, I pushed open the baize-covered door and stood in the corridor.\nWhat sort of atmosphere is Wells trying to create and how does he use figurative language to do this?\nThe writer is trying to create an atmosphere of fear and tension in the extract. He describes the passage as being "draughty" and mentions that it is underground. This makes it seem creepy and ghostly. The fact that the character only has a candle to light his way makes the story seem old-fashioned, and also creates drama because we know that the draught could blow it out! The way the echoes "rang up and down" and the fact that the man stops because he thinks he hears a sound, adds to the ghostly effects.\nThe shadows also help to create a sinister atmosphere as they flicker around and make it even harder for the man to see what\'s ahead. The writer uses figurative language such as personification to describe them. He says that they "cower and quiver", come "sweeping up" and that they "fled". All of this makes them sound alive, or perhaps like ghosts. The words used are all linked with fear, so that even the shadows seem to be afraid of what\'s in the corridor. This is very eerie and helps to create a very tense atmosphere.\nWhat does it all mean? Find out with this activity.\nLove books? Get your reviews published on Student Life.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "> Electric current and voltage - Measuring amps & volts\nElectric current and voltage - Measuring amps & volts\nYou need to know how to measure current and voltage.\nCurrent is a measure of how much\nflows through a circuit. The more charge that flows, the bigger the current.\n. For example, 20A is a bigger current than 5A.\nA device called an ammeter is used to measure current. Some types of ammeter have a pointer on a dial, but most have a digital readout. To measure the current flowing through a component in a circuit, you must connect the ammeter in\nVoltage is a measure of the difference in\nbetween two parts of a circuit. The bigger the difference in energy, the bigger the voltage.\n. For example, 230V is a bigger voltage than 12V.\nVoltage is meaured using a voltmeter. Some types of voltmeter have a pointer on a dial, but most have a digital readout. To measure the voltage across a component in a circuit, you must connect the voltmeter in\nUsing a voltmeter to measure the voltage across a lamp\nYou can measure the voltage across a cell or battery. The more cells, the bigger the voltage.\nThe more cells, the bigger the voltage\nDanger! Danger! High voltage! {'text': "The environment, the Earth and the universe\n> Astronomy and space science - Years and seasons\nAstronomy and space science - Years and seasons\nA planet's year is the time it takes to make\naround the Sun. The Earth goes once round the Sun in one Earth year. That's 365 Earth days.\nWe've seen already that that different planets take different lengths of time to orbit the Sun. That means their years are different lengths. Mercury has a year of just 88 Earth days, and Neptune has a year of 164 Earth years.\nThe Earth's axis is the imaginary line through the centre of the Earth between the South and North poles. This axis is\nslightly compared to the way the Earth orbits the Sun.\nWe get different seasons (winter, spring, summer and autumn) because the Earth is tilted. This is how it works:\nWhen the northern hemisphere is tilted towards the Sun it is summer in the UK.\nWhen the northern hemisphere is tilted away from the Sun it is winter in the UK.\nWhen it is summer in the northern hemisphere, it is winter in the southern hemisphere.\nBecause of the tilt of the Earth's axis the Sun moves higher in the sky in summer, when we tilt towards it, than in winter.\nMore from The environment, the Earth and the universe\nTry an activity that's out of this world!\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n", 'label': '4'}
{'text': '> Atoms and elements - Chemical symbols\nEach element is given its own chemical symbol, like\nfor chlorine. Chemical symbols are usually one or two letters long, but sometimes three letters are used.\nletter, with the second or third letters written in lower case.\nis the correct symbol for magnesium, but mg, mG and MG are wrong.\nTake care to write chemical symbols correctly\nSometimes it is easy to tell which element a symbol stands for. For example,\nBut sometimes the symbol comes from a name for the element that is not an English word.For example,\nstands for tungsten (from the word wolfram) and\nstands for sodium (from the word natrium).\nThe reason is that the same chemical symbols are used all over the world, no matter which language is spoken, which makes them most useful.\nUse your knowledge to help Spherox find his way home.\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': 'The beginning, or opening, is one of the most important sections of your writing. It should grab the reader\'s attention and make them want to read on. For instance, which is the best beginning for a ghost story?\na) The house was built in 1975. It was a typical semi-detached, but it did have quite an impressive front door. Most of the windows were double glazed and the garden was quite neat.\nb) The creaking door swung open to reveal an empty hall. Ben shivered as he stepped inside, his footsteps echoing on the cold tile floor.\nThere are no prizes for guessing that the second one is scarier. Of course, if you were trying to describe the house and nothing else, then the first extract is better, because it tells us more.\nSo you need to think about TAP (text, audience and purpose) and make a good start to your writing. You should try to \'set a context\', which is like setting the scene. So if it\'s a speech, you might start by asking people a question and getting them to think. But if it\'s a newspaper article, you need to write what happened and where it happened very early on.\na) The subject I am going to write about today is why the local park should not be closed.\nb) Have you ever stopped to wonder how many hundreds of people make regular use of our Memorial Park?\na) It is unlikely that newspaper readers who enjoy all the things that our park has to offer will want it to disappear forever under tons of concrete.\nb) \'Ashfield Park will be ruined,\' claim protestors who held a meeting last night to organise opposition to the council\'s plans for a car park.\nIt should be clear that the "b" versions are better - they fit the style and show that the writer has used TAP to make their writing work. Remember - you need to make it interesting right from the start.\nThe importance of beginnings, middles and ends.\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': '> Forces - Weight, mass and gravity\nPeople often confuse mass and weight. Remember that weight is a force, and is measured in newtons. Mass is measured in kilograms (kg).\nThe mass of an object is the\nor "stuff" it contains. The more matter an object contains, the greater its mass. An elephant contains more matter than a mouse, so it has a greater mass. Mass is measured in\nA 100 kg object has a greater mass than a 5 kg object. Remember an object\'s mass stays the same wherever it is.\nAll objects have a force that attracts them towards each other. This is called\n. Even you attract other objects to you because of gravity, but you have too little mass for the force to be very strong.\nGravity only becomes noticeable when there is a really massive object like a moon, planet or star. We are pulled down towards the ground because of gravity. The gravitational force pulls in the direction towards the centre of the Earth.\n"Down" is towards the centre of the Earth, wherever you are on the planet\nWeight is a force caused by gravity. The weight of an object is the\nbetween the object and the Earth. The more mass the object has the greater its weight will be.\nWeight is a force, so it\'s measured in\n. On the surface of the Earth an object with a mass of 1 kg has a weight of about 10 N.\nThe mass of an object stays the same wherever it is, but its weight can change. This happens if the object goes somewhere where gravity is stronger, or weaker, such as the Moon.\nThe Moon has less mass than the Earth, so its gravity is less than the Earth\'s gravity. This means that objects weigh less on the Moon than they do on the Earth.\nThe Moon\'s gravity is one sixth of the Earth\'s gravity. A 120 kg astronaut weighs 1200 N on Earth. On the Moon they would weigh only 200 N. The astronaut\'s\nThe weight of an object changes if the strength of gravity changes\nRemember: a mass of 1kg has a weight of about 10N on Earth.\nSomething is pulling your mouse towards this link.\nJoin Questionaut\'s quest to find his friend\'s hat.\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "Sometimes your teacher will 'hot seat' a student at a crucial moment in the book or play that the class is reading. That person has to pretend they are the character in the story at that very moment. They have to speak, think and feel as though they are that character.\nIf you've read any of the books and plays below, you could practise the art of 'hot seating'. Focus on the emotions (eg surprise, excitement, terror, anger, happiness, sadness, confusion) that your character is feeling at that moment.\nHarry Potter after his first kiss in The Order of the Phoenix.\nLyra as she watches Lord Asriel kissing Marisa Coulter in Northern Lights.\nFerdinand in The Tempest when Ariel sings the song that makes him think that his dad is dead.\nJuliet in Romeo and Juliet, when she discovers that Tybalt has been killed.\nHot seating helps actors get into character. If you can think, feel and speak like that character, an audience is more likely to believe you are that character.\nDon't be such a drama queen! {'text': "A debate is an organised argument. You might think you've never taken part in a debate before but you probably have without realising it! When you discuss topics in class or at home, and put forward different points of view - this is debating. Debating allows you to discuss your ideas and find out what other people think about a particular topic.\nIf you're asked to take part in an organised debate at school, this is likely to be a more formal discussion and follow a set of rules.\nHere are some simple rules for formal debates:\nFirst of all, you need two teams: the proposition team and the opposition team.\nThen you need something to argue about. This is called a motion.\nThe proposition team starts. Their first speaker has to tell everyone what the motion is all about.\nThe opposition team goes next. Then the teams take it in turns until everyone has had their say.\nThe last speaker on each team has to sum up their team's main argument.\nYour team will need to do plenty of preparation - writing out the main points of your argument. During the debate, your team is allowed to pass notes to each other so that you can add or change things as you go along. The most convincing team wins the debate. Try to guess in advance what your opposing team might argue to avoid being caught out.\nUse these tips to make your arguments as convincing as you can:\nUse facts - it's hard to argue against a fact so use as much evidence and as many statistics as possible.\nUse opinion too - debating is all about getting your opinion across and persuading others to agree with you, so use a good balance of fact and opinion.\nListen to the other team and comment on what they have said. You then have a chance to convince the audience of the other side of the argument.\nStructure your argument - as if you were writing an essay, you need a clear introduction, a middle and a conclusion.\nArguing isn't about shouting the loudest - present your arguments in a clear controlled voice. Don't lose your temper or get too emotional about the arguments.\nImprove your public speaking and maybe you'll be TV Presenter one day. But it's not all bad!\nTalk your way out of trouble using your English skills.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. While you will be able to view the content of this page in your current browser, you will not be able to get the full visual experience. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n", 'label': '4'}
{'text': "> The Tempest second key extract - Characters\nThe Tempest second key extract - Characters\nIf you get a question about characters in the Key Extracts, here is how to use PEE to help you with the answer.\nQuestion: What do we learn about Miranda in the two extracts?\nIn the two Key Extracts we learn that Miranda is young and inexperienced, but not necessarily weak. She has a pure heart and sees the best in Ferdinand and even defends Prospero. In the First Key Extract she must do what her father says, even though his behaviour is questionable. In the Second Key Extract, she knows her own mind and goes behind her father's back (or thinks she has) to ask Ferdinand to be her husband.\nMiranda can be read as a strong female character. Even though Prospero is a controlling father, Miranda shows from the beginning of the extract that she is beginning to test his power over her.\nShe relies on her own judgement and questions her father's actions. She stands up for Ferdinand against her father and is on the receiving end of Prospero's ugly temper. She replies with dignity and even tries to excuse her father's bad behaviour to Ferdinand. However, throughout the first extract, she is being unwittingly manipulated by Prospero.\nIn the second extract she openly defies her father (although it is part of Prospero's plan that she does this). She demonstrates that she is Ferdinand's equal by offering to share his workload. She claims that she is not worthy of him, but then shows her independence by proposing marriage.\nMiranda pleads with Prospero to see the best in Ferdinand, but perhaps her father, who is more experienced, is wise to test Ferdinand's love for his daughter. Miranda is open about her feelings for Ferdinand, but in doing so believes that she is betraying her father's wishes. Miranda is sometimes weak and sometimes strong. She is a complex character.\nThroughout the two extracts we see Miranda's growing independence. The truth is, however, that although she thinks she is rebelling against her father by following her own heart, her actions are part of Prospero's plans.\nMore from The Tempest second key extract:\nUp for a challenge? {'text': "> Measures of average - Mean and modal class\nMeasures of average - Mean and modal class\nCalculating the mean and modal class for grouped data is very similar to finding the mean from an ungrouped frequency table, except that you do not have all the information about the data within the groups so can only estimate the mean.\nThis table shows the weights of children in a class.\nTo estimate the mean weight, you know that 7 children are between 30kg and 40kg, but you don't know exactly how much they weigh, so assume that they all weigh 35kg (the midpoint of the group).\nDo the same for all the other groups:\na) Estimate of mean = 1215 รท 25 =\nb) The modal class is the class that has the highest frequency. {'text': "What is wrong with the following statement?\nThe probability of obtaining a 6 when I throw a die is\n- so if I throw the die 6 times I should get exactly 1 × 6.\nIn theory this statement is true, but in practise it might not be the case. Try throwing a die 6 times - you won't always get one 6.\nKate and Josh each throw a die 30 times.\na) How many times would you expect Kate to obtain a 6?\nb) How many times would you expect Josh to obtain a 6?\nc) How many times would you expect Kate or Josh to obtain a 6?\na) In theory, Kate should obtain a 6 on\nof her throws. Therefore, in theory she should throw a 6 on\nb) Josh should also throw to obtain a 6 on\nc) In total, Kate and Josh have thrown the die 60 times. You would expect them to obtain a 6 on 10 of those throws. However, it is very unlikely that Kate and Josh obtained exactly the same results, or that either of them threw a 6 on 5 occasions.\nAs you can see, if an experiment is repeated, the results are not necessarily the same each time.\nHowever, it is more likely that their combined results were closer to the expected outcome (10 × 6s) than their individual results.\nIn other words, if you do a large number of trials you will get a more accurate result.\nWhat are the chances of you trying this activity?\nCan you match Viral Vinnie's appetite for English, Maths and Science?\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "> Approximation - Rounding to a given number of places\nApproximation - Rounding to a given number of places\nDecimal places are counted from the decimal point:\nSo, the number 5.1492 has four decimal places and 4.34 has two decimal places.\nTo round a number to a given number of decimal places, look at the number in the next decimal place.\nIf it's less than 5 round down\nIf it's 5 or more, round up\nQ1. Round 7.2648 to 2 decimal places (d.p.)\nQ2. Round 8.352 to 1 decimal place\nTo round to two decimal places, look at the number in the third decimal place. It's a 4, so round down.\nTo round to one decimal place, look at the number in the second decimal place. It's a 5, so round up.\nTo round a number to a given number of decimal places then the answer must have that number of decimal places, even if you have to add some zeros.\nFor example, rounding 3.40021 to two decimal places gives 3.40 (2 d.p.).\nYou need to write both decimal places, even though the second number is a zero, to show you rounded to two decimal places.\nRemember to look at the number after the one you're interested in. If it's less than 5, round down. If it's 5 or more, round up.\nRound up, round up and try this activity!\nMake sure your maths skills add up.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': 'is made from different substances that are\nFor example powdered iron and powdered sulfur mixed together makes a mixture of iron and sulfur. They can be separated from each other without a chemical reaction, in the way that different coloured sweets can be picked out from a mixed packet and put into separate piles.\nMixtures have different properties from compounds. The table summarises these differences.\nVariable composition – you can vary the amount of each substance in a mixture.\nDefinite composition – you cannot vary the amount of each element in a compound.\nThe different substances are not chemically joined together.\nThe different elements are chemically joined together.\nEach substance in the mixture keeps its own properties.\nThe compound has properties different from the elements it contains.\nEach substance is easily separated from the mixture.\nIt can only be separated into its elements using chemical reactions.\nWater, carbon dioxide, magnesium oxide, sodium chloride.\nAn example - iron, sulfur and iron sulfide\nRemember that iron and sulfur react together when they are heated to make a compound called iron sulfide. What are the differences between a mixture of iron and sulfur, and iron sulfide? Here are some of them:\nThe mixture can contain more or less iron, but iron sulfide always contains equal amounts of iron and sulfur.\nThe iron and sulfur atoms are not joined together in the mixture, but they are joined together in iron sulfide.\nThe iron and sulfur still behave like iron and sulfur in the mixture, but iron sulfide has different properties from both iron and sulfur.\nYou can separate the iron from the mixture using a magnet but this does not work for iron sulfide.\nHow will you react to this activity?\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "> Linear sequences - More on finding the nth term\nLinear sequences - More on finding the nth term\nSo the sequence of numbers in the 5 times table has a common difference of 5 and an n\nBut what happens if things get more complicated?\nThe common difference is still 5, but it's not the 5 times table.\nThe 5 times table is 5, 10, 15, ...\nThe sequence is 7, 12, 17, ...\nEach term in the sequence is 2 more than the corresponding term in the 5 times table, so the n\nterm of the Sequence: 8, 11, 14, ... ?\nThe common difference is 3, so it must be related to the 3 times table (3n)\nThe 3 times table is 3, 6, 9, ...\nThe sequence is 8, 11, 14, ....\nEvery term in the sequence is 5 more than the corresponding term in the 3 times table, so the n\nWhat comes next? {'text': "> Paragraphs - How paragraphs are set out\nParagraphs - How paragraphs are set out\nThere are two main ways of setting out paragraphs, with a few small variations:\nBy putting an indent at the start\nThe first example shows how new paragraphs can be started on the next available line, but with the first word beginning slightly to the right, or indented.\n\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0We've just come back from a lovely holiday in Southsea. The weather was glorious and Albert has still got a deep, golden glow from the sunshine. It's a pity it can't be like that all year round.\n\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0\xa0The hotel we stayed in was spotless. We felt like royalty because the bedsheets were changed twice, in the same week! I told Albert not to get too used to it as I wasn't going to carry that sort of thing on when we got home. We also got nice, clean fluffy towels every other day too.\nThe second example shows how new paragraphs can be started by missing a line. In this type of example, indenting the first new word is not necessary.\nWe've just come back from a lovely holiday in Southsea. The weather was glorious and Albert has still got a deep, golden glow from the sunshine. It's a pity it can't be like that all year round.\nThe hotel we stayed in was spotless. We felt like royalty because the bedsheets were changed twice, in the same week! I told Albert not to get too used to it as I wasn't going to carry that sort of thing on when we got home. {'text': 'Respiration is a chemical reaction that happens in all living cells. It is the way that energy is released from glucose, for our cells to use to keep us functioning.\nthe same as breathing (which is properly called ventilation).\nThe glucose and oxygen react together in the cells to produce carbon dioxide and water. The reaction is called\nbecause oxygen from the air is needed for it to work.\nHere is the word equation for aerobic respiration:\n(Energy is released in the reaction. We show it in brackets in the equation because energy is not a substance.)\nNow we will look at how glucose and oxygen get to the cells so that respiration can take place and how we get rid of the carbon dioxide.\n, obtained through digestion of the food we eat. Digestion breaks food down into small molecules. These can be absorbed across the wall of the small intestine into the bloodstream.\nGlucose is carried round the body dissolved in blood plasma, the pale yellow liquid part of our blood. The dissolved glucose can diffuse into the cells of the body from the\n. Once in the cell glucose can be used in respiration.\nWhen we breathe in oxygen enters the small air sacs, called\n, in the lungs. Oxygen diffuses from there into the bloodstream.\nOxygen is not carried in the plasma, but is carried by the red blood cells. These contain a red substance called\n, which joins onto oxygen and carries it around the body in the blood, then lets it go when necessary. Like glucose, oxygen can diffuse into cells from the capillaries.\nRed blood cells carry oxygen around the body\nCarbon dioxide from cells to the air\nThe carbon dioxide produced during respiration diffuses out of the cells and into the blood plasma. The blood carries it to the lungs. It then diffuses across the walls of the alveoli and into the air, ready to be exhaled.\nWhack and zap mad professors and aliens!\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "> Food chains - Changes to food webs\nFood chains - Changes to food webs\nLet's look at the food web again and ask some questions about its predator-prey relationships, with some possible answers.\nWhat would happen if the grass died?\nThe grass is the producer, so if it died the consumers that feed on it - rabbits, insects and slugs - would have no food. They would starve and die unless they could move to another habitat. All the other animals in the food web would die too, because their food supplies would have died out. The populations of the consumers would fall as the population of the producer fell.\nWhat would happen if the population of slugs decreased?\nSlugs, rabbits and insects all eat grass. If there were fewer slugs there would be more grass for the rabbits and insects. With more food the populations of rabbits and insects would increase. However, the thrushes would have to eat more insects to maintain their population, so it is also possible that the population of insects could decrease. This is turn may reduce the populations of voles and frogs.\nWhat would happen if the population of insects decreased?\nThere would be more food for the rabbits and slugs, so their populations would increase. However, there would be less food for the frogs and voles, so their populations would decrease. This means less food for the foxes and hawks. However, there are likely to be more rabbits and thrushes for them to eat, so their populations are likely to stay the same.\nHungry for knowledge? Prey on this activity.\nWhack and zap mad professors and aliens!\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n", 'label': '4'}
{'text': "> Measures of average - The median\nIf you place a set of numbers in order, the\nIf there are two middle numbers, the median is the mean of those two numbers.\nFind the median of each of the following sets of numbers:\na) 2, 4, 7, 1, 9, 3, 11\nb) 4, 1, 3, 10, 6, 9,\n1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 9, 11\nThe middle number is 4. Therefore the median is\nthere are two middle numbers (4 and 6), so we find the mean of these two numbers. The median is therefore:\nIf there are n numbers, the median will be the (n + 1) รท 2 = th number\nIf there are 3 numbers, the median will be the (3 + 1) รท 2 = 2nd number.\nIf there are 4 numbers, the median will be the (4 + 1) รท 2 = 2\nRachel records the number of goals scored by her five-a-side team in their first 20 matches.\nThe results are shown in the frequency table below:\nWhat is the median number of goals scored?\n20 matches were played, so the median will be the 21 รท 2\n7 matches scored 0 goals, and 5 matches scored 1 goal.\nvalue lies in the '1 goal' category.\nTherefore, the median number of goals is 1.\nHow mean are you? {'text': "> Preparing, planning and checking - TAP\nWhen you're writing a piece for English, remember to TAP:\nRemembering to TAP will help you develop a plan.\nrefers to the type of text you are being asked to write: letter, magazine article, story, etc. They all have particular features and you need to remember these to do well. For instance, if you write a letter, it shouldn't read like a Harry Potter story. Also, your English homework shouldn't be written like a text message.\nis who you are writing for. This may be teenagers, adults or even children. It helps to put yourself in your audience's place - so for example, if you are writing a letter informing parents about a school trip, it is likely that parents will want to know about cost, safety and key facts such as times and places. Writing for adults doesn't necessarily mean you have to use long or complicated words - just ensure your writing is clear, sensible and interesting.\nrefers to the point of the text and what it is aiming to do. Persuasive texts often encourage readers to buy something, or back a particular cause (eg charity) so they need to use informative and emotive language. Whereas an entertainment text is likely to be more light-hearted.\nfor all sorts of questions. The more you practise it, the better you'll get.\nWhy must you prepare and plan? {'text': "> Inform, explain and describe - Explaining\nWhen you explain, you don't just write information - you also need to give\n. In very basic terms you can think of the difference between informing and explaining in terms of answering a slightly different set of questions:\nExplain = What? When? Who? Where? How? Why?\nThis difference is reflected in the question you will be asked, so our question about the leaflet might look a little different now:\nWrite a leaflet for both the pupils and their parents, outlining some of the main features of school life in Year 7 and beyond. In particular, explain why pupils have several teachers each day and why the detention system is used.\nThis is a little harder than the earlier version, but it's still about your school. Therefore, you still need lots of information about the classes, the organisation and the timetable. So you could still use our two basic approaches, timelines and topic centres, like this:\nHowever, you can also put these together, like this:\nNow, we can see a number of topics, so perhaps the three big circles represent registration, lesson times and detentions. They occur in that order each day, but the reasons for them are very different. So the smaller circles answer how and why as well as what, when and who. For instance, what are detentions? When do they take place? Who is in charge of them? How do pupils get put in detention? Why does the school use detentions?\nThis approach gives your answer a very clear structure. The writing deals with a number of subjects in turn and each subject should be in its own paragraph. You can add details and explanations as you write out each paragraph. It makes it easier for you to write and easier for your audience to read or listen to.\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. When the river reaches a lake or the sea, its load of transported rocks settles to the bottom. We say that the rocks are\n. The deposited rocks build up in layers, called\nThe weight of the sediments on top squashes the sediments at the bottom. This is called\n. This process is called\nThese processes eventually make a type of rock called sedimentary rock. It may take millions of years for sedimentary rocks to form.\nThese are the different processes in order:\nThe river transports bits of rock, and deposits them on the bottom of the river bed.\nSedimentary rocks contain rounded grains in layers. {'text': "> Magnets and electric current - Heating effect\nMagnets and electric current - Heating effect\nHousehold wires and cables transfer electricity very efficiently. That means they donâ€™t lose much of the energy as heat on the way. The electricity flows freely from the plug and is transferred into other forms of energy in household appliances, like toasters, lights and CD players.\nThe heating element in a toaster is made from a special wire different to wire in the power cables. The wire in the heating element transfers lots of its electrical energy into\nand gets very hot. Exactly what you need to make toast or run an electric heater.\nIn most uses of electricity we don't want to produce heat. Any heat that is produced is wasted energy. Appliances that transfer less of the electricity they use into wasted heat are more\nFor example energy efficient light bulbs transfer less of their energy into heat. They also use less energy than normal bulbs to produce the same amount of light. So the energy efficient light bulb wastes less energy.\nMagnets and effects of electric current activity\nUse your knowledge to help Spherox find his way home.\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "This is the heart of your piece - it contains the key points and will probably have three, four or five paragraphs. You should have one basic idea in each one, and the paragraph explains this, develops it and makes it relevant for your readers.\nSo paragraphs are like stepping stones - they lead the reader from one end of your writing to the other. But when do you start a new paragraph? Well some people like using\n, so let's see how this works.\n, so start a new paragraph for a different time period.\n, so start a new paragraph for each new place.\n, so start a new paragraph for each new topic, idea or subject.\n, so start a new paragraph for each new speaker.\nLook at this sample question about the park and see if you can TiPToP it.\nWrite an article for your local paper, arguing that the local park should be preserved.\nIn this question, we are mainly dealing with ideas, so we need to concentrate on changes in topic. So where would you put the new paragraph in the following passage? Just click 'Check ideas' to see.\nThe park is excellent for children. There is a small playground with a slide and swings, but there are also places where children can run around safely. In fact it's the best place in town to take children to because there is always something to do.\nThe war memorial was first constructed in 1922, with the names of the people who died in the first world war. Since then other names have been added, from the Second World War and also from more recent times, such as Northern Ireland. We cannot just forget these people and we certainly cannot just destroy the memorial.\nIt's important to use paragraphs, and to use them in the right places. So TiPToP it by using a new paragraph when...\nYou are writing a story with speech and you change speaker.\nYou are describing a number of different things.\nYou move from writing details about something in the past and then a number of details about the present.\nIn fact, TiPToP it when you change Time, Place, Topic or Person. There is no set length for a paragraph either. A short paragraph, sometimes just a line long, can be ideal and grab your attention.\nThe importance of beginnings, middles and ends.\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "If someone is cooking in the kitchen it doesn't take long for the smell to travel around the house to other rooms. This is because of diffusion.\nWhen chemicals, like the smell of perfume or burning toast, are let loose in a room, the particles mix with the air particles. The particles of smelly gas are free to move quickly in all directions. They eventually spread through the whole room. This is called\nYou don't have to mix the gases by waving your arms around - it mixes on its own. Diffusion in gases is quick because the particles in a gas move quickly. It happens even faster in hot gases\nDiffusion can also happen in liquids. This is because the particles in liquids can move around each other, which means that eventually they are evenly mixed.\nFor example if you drop a little bit of paint into a jar of water the colour will spread slowly through the water. This is by diffusion.\nDiffusion in liquids is slower than diffusion in gases because the particles in a liquid move more slowly.\nhappen at all in solids because the particles in a solid can only vibrate on the spot, rather than being able to move from place to place.\nUnder pressure? See what happens when you cool down.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. While you will be able to view the content of this page in your current browser, you will not be able to get the full visual experience. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n", 'label': '4'}
{'text': '> Magnets and electric current - Electric bell\nMagnets and electric current - Electric bell\n. They are found in electric motors and loudspeakers. Very large and powerful electromagnets are used as lifting magnets in scrap yards to pick up, then drop, old cars and other scrap iron and steel.\nElectric bells like the ones used in most schools also contain an electromagnet.\nWhen the current flows through the circuit, the electromagnet makes a magnetic field.\nThe electromagnet attracts the springy metal arm.\nThe arm hits the gong, which makes a sound.\nThe circuit is broken now the arm is out of position.\nThe electromagnet is turned off and the springy metal arm moves back.\nThe cycle repeats as long as the switch is closed. Check your understanding of this with the animation.\nIn order to see this content you need to have both\nMagnets and effects of electric current activity\nUse your knowledge to help Spherox find his way home.\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "> Speaking - Presentations and reading aloud\nPresentations are sometimes less formal than speeches, and you'll probably be asked to present in groups rather than on your own. Use the tips on the previous page to make your performance strong.\nHere are some extra tips for group presentations:\nOrganise the presentation fairly between each group member - ensure that everyone gets their chance to present. If you're shy, don't hide behind your group - you need to take part too!\nA group presention needs to come across as a team effort - be careful not to allow over enthusiastic members to dominate.\nWork together - if one person is speaking, another person can point to relevant visual aids.\nYou may be asked to find a poem or an extract from a story to read aloud to your class. Here are some tips to help you with reading aloud:\nIf you can choose a text you are familiar with this will probably boost your confidence.\nPractise your reading using gestures and movement, and don't be tempted to hide behind your book.\nTry to look up from your reading several times and make eye contact with your audience.\nVary your pitch and tone and make it relevant to your subject matter. If you're reading something spooky, try to reflect this in your voice. If you're reading a conversation between two characters, attempt to distinguish their voices.\nThink about volume and pace - ensure that your audience can hear you clearly.\nImprove your public speaking and maybe you'll be TV Presenter one day. {'text': "Many living things are so small that they can only be seen through a microscope. These living things are called\n. {'text': "> Inform, explain and describe - Informing\nThe key thing about writing to inform is that you stick to the information. You shouldn't really show many of your own feelings, and you definitely don't want to tell your audience how they should feel. Instead, when you inform you make the facts easy to understand, with a clear structure.\nWrite an information leaflet for Year 6 pupils, telling them about the school day and what they need to know when they start your school in September.\nIt's important to structure your answer well. Think of the answer in terms of a drawing, like this:\nThis is a timeline - the arrow is time moving forwards and the four lines are different events in order. Now, you can think of the school day as the arrow, and plan the different events in a typical day. For instance, you could have registration, then an assembly, then two lessons followed by break. It should be easy to add information and detail. The structure also makes it easy for the Year 6 pupils to follow your information. Another way to inform is by subject, as in the diagram below:\nThese are points linked together. It is not in order of time, but in order of subject. So you could have PE at the centre with all the information connected to PE in the little circles around. For instance, you could have different types of PE kit, the different sports, the sort of exercises you do. Once you have written about PE, you can move on to look at other areas of the school.\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "> Reproduction - Fertilisation and foetal development\nDuring sexual intercourse the man's penis releases semen into the woman's vagina. If a sperm cell meets with an egg cell there, fertilisation can happen. {'text': "> Writer's tricks - The effect on the reader\nWriter's tricks - The effect on the reader\nYou will now be very familiar with the idea that every text is intended to affect its readers in some way.\nEvery reader is, of course, different too, and sometimes a text will affect you in ways a writer didn't imagine, or you might notice depth in it that others won't. This is particularly true if the text matches your personal experience. A story about your home town might interest you more than one about somewhere else, or a text about smoking might affect you more if you know somebody who is trying to give it up.\nRemember, you get marks for noticing the intended effect on the reader. Even if something doesn't interest, horrify, amuse or persuade you, you need to spot what the writer meant to do. It's usually better not to mention your personal opinion unless you are asked to.\nUse your knowledge to help Spherox find his way home.\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "> Introduction to formulas - Constructing formulas\nThe advert says that the cost of a party is £50 plus £5 per person, so what would be the cost of a party for 10?\n50 + 10 × 5 = 50 + 50 = £100\nWhat would be the cost of a party for 20?\n50 + 20 × 5 = 50 + 100 =\nHow do you work out the cost if you don't know the number of people who will attend the party?\nThe cost for 10 people is 50 + 5 × 10 = £100\nThe cost for 20 people is 50 + 5 × 20 = £150\nSo the cost for n people is 50 + 5 × n = £(50 + 5n)\nWith this formula you can work out the cost of a party for any number of people.\nHave a go at the next question to see if you can use\nAlexa is 12 years old. How old will she be in n years time?\nyears time her age will have increased by n. So her age will be n more than it is now.\nCheck your answer. In 1 years time she will be 13. If we put 1 in for the value of\nwe get 12 +1 = 13. So that is correct.\nIn ten years she will be 22, and putting n=10 gives us\nage = 12 + 10 = 22\nTime to formulate a new revision plan!\nCan you match Viral Vinnie's appetite for English, Maths and Science?\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "> Negative numbers - Adding and subtracting\nTo add and subtract numbers always begin counting from zero.\nWhen dealing with positive numbers count to the right.\nWhen dealing with negative numbers count to the left.\nImagine moving up and down a number line to get to the answer.\nStarting from zero, count up to 4. Then subtract 5. Then subtract 3. The answer is -4.\nCalculate: - 2 + 9 - 10 + 6\nIf you wrote the answer 3 or +3, then well done!\nWhen adding or subtracting negative numbers, remember that when two signs appear next to each other and are different, then you subtract. {'text': "The environment, the Earth and the universe\n> The rock cycle - The rock cycle\nThe rock cycle - The rock cycle\nRemember that there are three main types of rock:\n, for example chalk, limestone, sandstone and shale;\nThe Earth's rocks do not stay the same forever. They are continually changing because of processes such as weathering and large earth movements. The rocks are gradually recycled over millions of years. This is called the rock cycle.\nFor example sedimentary rocks can be changed into metamorphic rocks, and these can be weathered and the pieces transported away. These pieces could be deposited in lakes or seas and eventually form new sedimentary rock. Many routes through the rock cycle are possible.\nThe processes in the rock cycle are shown in this diagram. Make sure that you understand how each type of rock forms, and be ready to give an example of each type of rock.\npresses the layers and sticks the particles together. This creates\nRocks underground that get heated and put under pressure are changed into\nRocks underground that get heated so much they melt turn into\n. Magma is liquid rock. Magma also comes from deeper inside the Earth, from an region called the mantle.\nPressure can forces magma out of the ground. This creates a volcano. When the magma cools it turns into solid rock, called\nMagma that cools underground forms solid rock called\nAreas of rock can move slowly upwards, pushed up by pressure of the rocks forming underneath. This is called\nbreaks down rocks on the surface of the Earth. There are three types of weathering - physical, chemical and biological.\nWind and water move the broken rock particles away. This is called\nin lakes and seas, where they build up to form layers. This starts the process of sedimentation which will create sedimentary rock.\nMore from The environment, the Earth and the universe\nJoin Questionaut's quest to find his friend's hat.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. Steel is a mixture of elements but mostly iron, so it is also magnetic. The other metals are not magnetic.\nYou may have to match the use of a metal with a property that makes it suitable for that use. For example, copper is used for electrical wiring because it is a good conductor of electricity, not because it is a good conductor of heat.\nUse your knowledge to help Spherox find his way home.\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "> Electric current and voltage - Series & parallel circuits\nElectric current and voltage - Series & parallel circuits\nThere are two types of circuit we can make, called\nThe components in a circuit are joined by wires.\nif there are no branches then it's a series circuit\nif there are branches it's a parallel circuit\nIn a television series, you get several episodes, one after the other. A series circuit is similar. You get several components one after the other.\nIf you follow the circuit diagram from one side of the cell to the other, you should pass through all the different components, one after the other, without any branches.\nIf you put more lamps into a series circuit, the lamps will be dimmer than before.\nIn a series circuit, if a lamp breaks or a component is disconnected, the circuit is broken and all the components stop working.\nSeries circuits are useful if you want a warning that one of the components in the circuit has failed. They also use less wiring than parallel circuits.\nIn parallel circuits different components are connected on different branches of the wire. If you follow the circuit diagram from one side of the cell to the other, you can only pass through all the different components if you follow all the\nIn a parallel circuit, if a lamp breaks or a component is disconnected from one parallel wire, the components on different branches\n. And, unlike a series circuit, the lamps stay bright if you add more lamps in parallel.\nParallel circuits are useful if you want everything to work, even if one component has failed. This is why our homes are wired up with parallel circuits.\nDanger! Danger! High voltage! {'text': "> The Tempest first key extract - The text\nThe Tempest first key extract - The text\nSECTION 1 - Act 1, Scene 2, lines 376 to 505\n(Other spirit voices in the air) Bow-wow!\nWhere should this music be? I'the air or the earth?\nIt sounds no more; and, sure, it waits upon\nSome god o'the island. Sitting on a bank,\nWeeping again the King my father's wreck,\nThis music crept by me upon the waters,\nAllaying both their fury and my passion\nWith its sweet air. Thence I have followed it –\nOr it hath drawn me rather. But 'tis gone.\n(Song) Full fathom five thy father lies –\nThose are pearls that were his eyes.\n(Chorus of spirit voices) Ding dong –\n(ARIEL and spirit voices) Ding dong bell.\nThe ditty does remember my drowned father.\nThis is no mortal business, nor no sound\nThat the earth owes. I hear it now above me.\n(To MIRANDA) The fringèd curtains of thine eye advance,\nLord, how it looks about! Believe me, sir,\nIt carries a brave form. But 'tis a spirit.\nNo, wench: it eats and sleeps and hath such senses\nAs we have, such. This gallant which thou see’st\nWas in the wreck – and, but he’s something stained\nWith grief (that’s beauty’s canker), thou might’st call him\nA goodly person. He hath lost his fellows,\nAs my soul prompts it. (To ARIEL) Spirit, fine spirit! I’ll free thee\nOn whom these airs attend! Vouchsafe my prayer\nMay know if you remain upon this island –\nAnd that you will some good instruction give\nHow I may bear me here. My prime request,\nWhich I do last pronounce, is – O, you wonder! –\nI am the best of them that speak this speech,\nWhat wert thou, if the King of Naples heard thee?\nA single thing, as I am now, that wonders\nTo hear thee speak of Naples. He does hear me –\nAnd that he does I weep. Myself am Naples,\nWho with mine eyes, ne’er since at ebb, beheld\nAnd his more braver daughter could control thee,\nIf now ’twere fit to do’t. At the first sight\nI’ll set thee free for this. (To FERDINAND) A word, good sir.\nI fear you have done yourself some wrong. A word.\nWhy speaks my father so ungently? This\nIs the third man that e’er I saw – the first\nThat e’er I sighed for. Pity move my father\n(Aside) They are both in either’s powers. But this swift business\nI must uneasy make, lest too light winning\nMake the prize light. (To FERDINAND) One word more: I charge thee\nThat thou attend me. Thou dost here usurp\nThe name thou ow’st not – and hast put thyself\nUpon this island as a spy, to win it\nThere’s nothing ill can dwell in such a temple.\nIf the ill spirit have so fair a house,\nGood things will strive to dwell with’t.\n(To MIRANDA) Speak not you for him; he’s a traitor. (To FERDINAND) Come!\nI’ll manacle thy neck and feet together.\nSea-water shalt thou drink: thy food shall be\nThe fresh-brook mussels, withered roots, and husks\nHe draws his sword but is prevented from moving by\nMake not too rash a trial of him, for\nMy foot my tutor? (To FERDINAND) Put thy sword up, traitor –\nWho mak’st a show, but dar’st not strike, thy conscience\nIs so possessed with guilt. Come from thy ward –\nFor I can here disarm thee with this stick\nShall make me chide thee, if not hate thee. What!\nThou think’st there is no more such shapes as he,\nHaving seen but him and Caliban. Foolish wench!\nTo the most of men this is a Caliban,\nAre then most humble. I have no ambition\nThy nerves are in their infancy again,\nMy spirits, as in a dream, are all bound up.\nMy father’s loss, the weakness which I feel,\nThe wreck of all my friends, nor this man’s threats,\nTo whom I am subdued, are but light to me,\nMight I but through my prison once a day\nBehold this maid. All corners else o’the earth\nLet liberty make use of: space enough\n(Aside) It works. (To FERDINAND) Come on.\n(To ARIEL) Thou hast done well, fine Ariel! (To FERDINAND) Follow me.\n(To ARIEL, whispering more instructions) Hark what thou else shalt do me.\nMy father’s of a better nature, sir,\nThan he appears by speech. This is unwonted\n(To ARIEL) Thou shalt be as free\nAs mountain winds. But then exactly do\n(To FERDINAND) Come, follow. (To MIRANDA) Speak not for him.\nMore from The Tempest first key extract:\nUp for a challenge? {'text': '> Representing data - Constructing pie charts\nTo construct a pie chart you need to work out the fraction of the total that the sector represents. You can then convert this to an angle and draw the sector on the chart.\nConstructing pie charts - using a table\nThe table below shows the grades achieved by 30 pupils in their end-of-year exam.\nTo show this information in a pie chart, take the following steps:\nWork out the total number of pupils\n: 7 + 11 + 6 + 4 + 2 = 30\nTo work out the angle of each segment,\nwork out the fraction of the total that got each grade\nThere are 360° in a full turn, so to work out the angle,\nThe grade A sector has an angle of 84°\nRepeat this process to find the angle of the segments for the other grades\nOnce you have calculated the angles of the segments, construct the pie chart\nCopy and complete the following table, then use the data to construct a pie chart.\nUse your knowledge to help Spherox find his way home.\nUp for a challenge? {'text': "> Acids, bases and metals - Naming salts\nAcids, bases and metals - Naming salts\nA salt is always made when an acid is neutralised by a base. But the exact salt made depends upon which acid and base were used.\nThe name of a salt has two parts:\nthe first part comes from the metal in the base used\nthe second part comes from the acid that was used\nWhere does the name potassium nitrate come from?\nThese are the rules for the second part of the name of a salt:\nHow can we make copper sulfate? The first part of the name is 'copper', so we need a base containing copper. We could use copper oxide or copper carbonate, for example. The second part of the name is 'sulfate', so we need to use sulfuric acid.\nHere are word equations for those reactions.\ncopper sulfate + water + carbon dioixde\nHow can we make sodium chloride? The first part of the name is 'sodium', so we need a base containing sodium. We could use sodium hydroxide or sodium hydrogen carbonate, for example. The second part of the name is 'chloride', so we need to use hydrochloric acid.\nHere are word equations for those reactions.\nsodium chloride + water + carbon dioxide\nIt would be very difficult to neutralise the acid in these reactions perfectly exactly. Some acid or base would be left over. So it would not be safe to taste the sodium chloride solution produced.\nWhack and zap mad professors and aliens!\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "> Variation and classification - Classifying organisms\nThere are millions of species on our planet. It would be difficult if we just tried to describe and name each one individually. Although species can be very different from each other, many of them have similar features that allow us to put them into groups.\nIn the eighteenth century Carl Linnaeus started the modern system of putting species of organism into certain groups and giving them scientific names. Each species is given a name using Latin words, so that the same name can be used all over the world.\nFor example, the scientific name for human beings is 'homo sapiens'. Putting different species into different groups according to their features is called\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': '> Romeo and Juliet second key extract - Issues and ideas\nRomeo and Juliet second key extract - Issues and ideas\nThe two extracts deal with some deep issues. You will need to discuss how these are brought out. Some of the \'big\' themes are:\nIf the question asks you to comment on how the theme of time is explored, consider these points:\nMontague and Benvolio discuss the "ancient quarrel" and how it escalated so swiftly because of the quick tempers of servants from each opposing family along with Tybalt\'s "fiery" reaction.\nTime passes slowly for Romeo whilst he is in a bad mood. He hides himself away during the daytime.\nRomeo is impatient to have a physical relationship and does not want to wait for Rosaline.\nRomeo gets over Rosaline quickly and falls for Juliet suddenly. Juliet falls in love just as quickly with Romeo.\nHaving spent one evening together they are planning their wedding for the next day.\nCan love happen so quickly? Maybe Romeo and Juliet have not considered the consequences of their relationship so it was bound to go wrong from the start. Or maybe this a classic example of love at first sight: sudden, powerful, and beyond the control.\nMore from Romeo and Juliet second key extract:\nRead the full text online and make your own notes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "> Fractions - Mixed numbers and improper fractions\nFractions - Mixed numbers and improper fractions\nA whole number can be written as\n, because it is made up of a whole number and a fraction.\n, because the top number is bigger than the bottom number.\nConverting from a mixed number to an improper fraction\nYou can write the whole number part as a fraction, then add the fractions together.\nConverting from improper fractions to mixed numbers\nYou can separate out the fraction into smaller fractions, like this:\nAnother way to convert an improper fraction is to find how many whole numbers you get, by using a division.\nWe start by dividing the top number by the bottom number.\n17 divided by 5 is 3 remainder 2.\nSo the whole number part is 3, and the remainder 2 means there are\n= 20 รท 7 = 2 remainder 6, so\nIf your calculator has a fraction button you can use this to convert from improper fractions to mixed numbers. Type in the improper fraction, press '=', and the calculator will convert it to a mixed number.\nDenominator? Numerator? {'text': "> Inequalities and Simultaneous Equations - Algebra\nYou can solve simultaneous equations by adding or subtracting the two equations from each other.\nAdd the two equations together and you will find that the y disappears:\n3x + 2x + y - y = 9 + 1\n6 - 5 = 1 (which is correct)\nTo make the 3x's disappear we can subtract equation (2) from equation (1):\n3x - 3x + 2y - (-y) = 8 - 5\n6 - 1 = 5 (which is correct)\nSo the solution is x = 2, y = 1\nUse your knowledge to help Spherox find his way home.\nUp for a challenge? {'text': "> Romeo and Juliet Summary - The plan\nRomeo and Juliet Summary - The plan\nJuliet's mother tells her to cheer up because her father has arranged for her to marry Paris. Juliet loses her temper and refuses. Her father comes in and can't believe how ungrateful she is being. He threatens to throw her out and disown her. He says he wants to hit her. She asks her mother to stand up for her, but she refuses.\nThe Nurse tells Juliet to forget Romeo and marry Paris\nWhen Juliet's mother and father have left, Juliet asks the Nurse what she should do. The Nurse says to forget Romeo and just marry Paris without owning up. In those days, that would have been a sin, and to marry two people at once would mean that she would be sent to hell. Juliet says that she will do what the Nurse suggests, but when she leaves the room, Juliet says to herself that the Nurse is two-faced. She decides to see if Friar Lawrence will help her. If not, she thinks she will have to commit suicide.\nParis goes to visit Friar Lawrence to arrange his wedding to Juliet. The Friar tries to stall for more time. When Juliet arrives, she gives Paris 'the cold shoulder' until he leaves. She begs the Friar to help her, threatening to kill herself. The Friar has a plan if Juliet has the guts to carry it through. He knows of a drug that will make her seem as though she is dead for forty-two hours. This will mean that she will be put in the family tomb along with Tybalt. Then the Friar will let Romeo know the truth, so that he can come and take her away when she wakes up and they can go off together to Mantua. Juliet isn't scared. She takes the drug home with her.\nEveryone is busy with wedding preparations at the Capulets' house. Capulet is in a good mood. Juliet tells her father that she has been to see the Friar to confess her sins and asks for her dad's forgiveness. Even the Nurse believes her.\nJuliet says good night to her mum then starts to panic about what she is about to do. She might die. She might go mad when she wakes up in a tomb full of dead people. There might be ghosts. She imagines that she sees Tybalt's ghost. She takes the poison and falls unconscious on her bed.\nThe Nurse finds Juliet and thinks she is dead. She is beside herself with grief. The family comes running and her mother and father can't believe it. Friar Lawrence arrives pretending that he has come to take Juliet to church to marry Paris. Paris comes and is shocked at the news.\nRead the full text online and make your own notes.\nUp for a challenge? Head to GCSE Bitesize.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "> Drama - Drama from your imagination\nTaking part in drama doesn't always involve learning lines from scripts - often you'll be asked to improvise. Usually you will work in groups or pairs to devise a piece of drama from your own imagination. You'll need to be able to think on your feet and become a different character.\nThis might sound difficult, but you've probably improvised before without realising it - in games you used to play as a child. If you've ever played pirates, nurses or superheroes when you were younger, you were improvising - although don't think running around your classroom with a tablecloth for a cape pretending to be Superman will impress your drama teacher - it probably won't!\nAs with any English work, you need to think about your audience when you devise drama. Your drama needs to entertain them and keep their attention. Your drama also needs to be believable - your audience is likely to become disconnected if your story or characters are too far fetched.\nThe story of your drama begins with your character. Ask yourself: what does my character feel, think and react?\nHere are two ideas for a character:\nYou are a journalist who has uncovered a story that will have big consequences and you're about to tell the world. Would your character be confident or scared?\nYou are a global superstar - singer, actor and producer - and paparazzi follow your every move. You live a glamorous and privileged life, but what are the secrets behind the smiles?\nWhen you have decided on your character, you need to create a scene.\nHere are some ideas for a scene based on the characters above. Can you think of any more?\nYou're about to appear on the most popular morning TV programme and expose your discovery when you suddenly receive a startling phone call. Who is on the phone? What do they say? How do they make you feel?\nYou've landed a part in a popular soap but you don't get on with the other actors. Should you tell the press the truth or pretend that you all get along?\nYou've been working late in the library just double checking a few facts for your article when you notice a menacing looking man watching you. Does your character panic or keep calm? Do they run or confront the man? Maybe they are being paranoid?\nThe press have published some false rumours about you and you're really upset. Your agent has secured a slot on a popular chat show to give your side of the story. Do you accept the offer or decide to lie low? How do you feel?\nYour article has been published and has been a massive hit. You're receiving job offers from high profile newspapers and magazines and your life is about to change for the better. How do your family react? What do you decide to do?\nYou've found out that one of the other band members is planning to leave the group and go solo. You confront them - can you persuade them to stay, or would it be better for everyone if they left?\nWhen you have a rough idea of your character and scene, you can think about what your character might say. If you're given time to prepare you should write a short script. If working in pairs or a group, you could improvise the scene first to get more ideas.\nYou may be allowed to use props to make your scene more realistic and interesting. Only use a prop if it is relevant, otherwise it could end up distracting you and your audience. If you decide to use props and costumes, always practice with them first.\nDon't be such a drama queen! Try this activity.\nTalk your way out of trouble using your English skills.\nGet creative, go backstage and find drama tips and inspiration.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. While you will be able to view the content of this page in your current browser, you will not be able to get the full visual experience. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n", 'label': '4'}

{'text': "> Ratio - Division in a given ratio\nRatio - Division in a given ratio\nDave and Lisa win £500 between them. They agree to divide the money in the ratio 2:3.\nThe ratio 2:3 tells us that for every 2 parts Dave receives, Lisa will receive 3 parts. There are 5 parts in total.\n£500 represents 5 parts. Therefore, £100 represents 1 part.\nDave receives 2 parts: 2 × £100 = £200\nLisa receives 3 parts: 3 × £100 = £300\nIt's important to notice what order the parts of the ratio are written in. 2:3 is not the same as 3:2.\nIn the example, the ratio of Dave's money to Lisa's was 2:3. If we swap the order to 3:2 then Dave would get more than Lisa.\nTo keep it the same as in the example we could say that the ratio of Lisa's money to Dave's would be 3:2\nQ1. Amelia and Shabana win a sum of money, which they agree to share in the ratio 5:3.\nIf Amelia receives £150, how much will Shabana receive?\nQ2. A necklace is made using gold and silver beads in the ratio 3:2. If there are 80 beads in the necklace:\nA1. Amelia receives 5 parts, which is equivalent to £150. Therefore, £150 represents 5 parts.\nShabana receives 3 parts: 3 × £30 = £90.\nA2. Gold : Silver = 3:2, so there are 5 parts altogether.\n80 ÷ 5 = 16, so 1 part represents 16 beads.\na) Gold = 3 × 16 = 48 beads\nb) Silver = 2 × 16 = 32 beads\nJoin Questionaut's quest to find his friend's hat.\nMake sure your maths skills add up.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n", 'label': '4'}
{'text': 'is a category within the classification system. Living things of the same type belong to the same species. For example, humans are one species and dogs are another species.\nIndividuals of the same species can reproduce to make more individuals of the same species. Two individuals belonging to different species cannot normally reproduce together. If they do, their offspring is usually infertile and unable to reproduce.\nFor example animals called ligers are produced when a male lion and a female tiger reproduce. But a liger cannot have offspring. This means that lions and tigers are different species.\nAll people are human. They belong to the same species. Your friends and classmates may have different eye colour and hair colour. Some will be boys and some will be girls. Some will be tall and some will be shorter. The presence of differences between living things of the same species is called variation.\nVariation between different species is always greater than the variation within a species.\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. While you will be able to view the content of this page in your current browser, you will not be able to get the full visual experience. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n', 'label': '4'}
{'text': "> The Tempest second key extract - The text\nThe Tempest second key extract - The text\nSECTION 2 - Act 3, Scene 1 (whole scene)\nThere be some sports are painful, and their labour\nDelight in them sets off. Some kinds of baseness\nAre nobly undergone, and most poor matters\nPoint to rich ends. This my mean task\nWould be as heavy to me as odious, but\nThe mistress which I serve quickens what's dead,\nAnd makes my labours pleasures. O, she is\nTen times more gentle than her father's crabbed –\nAnd he's composed of harshness! I must remove\nSome thousands of these logs, and pile them up,\nUpon a sore injunction. My sweet mistress\nWeeps when she sees me work, and says such baseness\nHad never like executor. I forget –\n– But these sweet thoughts do even refresh my labours,\n, who watches from a distance, unseen.\nWork not so hard! I would the lightning had\nBurnt up those logs that you are enjoined to pile!\nPray, set it down, and rest you. When this burns,\n'Twill weep for having wearied you. My father\nIs hard at study. Pray, now, rest yourself.\nThe sun will set before I shall discharge\nI'll bear your logs the while. Pray give me that:\nI had rather crack my sinews, break my back,\nAs well as it does you – and I should do it\nWith much more ease, for my good will is to it,\nNo, noble mistress. 'Tis fresh morning with me\nWhen you are by at night. I do beseech you –\nChiefly that I might set it in my prayers –\nI have broke your hest to say so!\nIndeed the top of admiration – worth\nWhat's dearest to the world! Full many a lady\nI have eyed with best regard, and many a time\nThe harmony of their tongues hath into bondage\nBrought my too diligent ear. For several virtues\nHave I liked several women – never any\nWith so full soul, but some defect in her\nDid quarrel with the noblest grace she owed,\nAnd put it to the foil. But you – o you,\nSo perfect and so peerless – are created\nOne of my sex – no woman's face remember,\nSave, from my glass, mine own. Nor have I seen\nMore that I may call men than you, good friend,\nAnd my dear father. How features are abroad,\nI am skilless of – but, by my modesty,\nThe jewel in my dower, I would not wish\nAny companion in the world but you –\nBesides yourself, to like of. But I prattle\nSomething too wildly, and my father's precepts\nA prince, Miranda: I do think, a King\nI would not so! – and would no more endure\nThe flesh-fly blow my mouth. Hear my soul speak:\nThe very instant that I saw you, did\nMy heart fly to your service – there resides,\nTo make me slave to it – and for your sake\nO heaven, O earth, bear witness to this sound\nAnd crown what I profess with kind event,\nIf I speak true! If hollowly, invert\nWhat best is boded me to mischief! I,\nBeyond all limit of what else i'the world,\nTo weep at what I am glad of.\nOf two most rare affections! Heavens rain grace\nAt mine unworthiness, that dare not offer\nWhat I desire to give; and much less take\nWhat I shall die to want. But this is trifling –\nAnd all the more it seeks to hide itself,\nThe bigger bulk it shows. Hence, bashful cunning!\nAnd prompt me, plain and holy innocence!\nI am your wife if you will marry me:\nIf not, I'll die your maid. To be your fellow\nYou may deny me; but I'll be your servant,\n(He kneels) And I thus humble ever.\nAs bondage e'er of freedom! Here's my hand.\nAnd mine, with my heart in't. And now farewell\nSo glad of this as they I cannot be,\nWho are surprised with all – but my rejoicing\nAt nothing can be more. I'll to my book –\nFor yet, ere supper-time, must I perform\nMore from The Tempest second key extract:\nUp for a challenge? {'text': "Behaviour can be investigated in the ‘field’ or in the laboratory.\nIt can be observed and measured, and experiments can be designed to test how it works.\nHuman behaviour is affected by many variables. It can be more difficult to study than the behaviour of other animals.\n‘Fieldwork’ does not always mean you have to work in a field. It means investigations that take place outside the laboratory.\nSome scientists spend many hours watching and studying the behaviour of animals. They may be interested in how the animals live alone, group into families or form large groups such as herds.\nScientists can tag sharks to study their behaviour.\nAnimals can signal to each other. For example, they may call to each other to warn of danger. Some scientists are interested in such signals. They record and study them to try to work out what the signals mean.\nSome animals migrate over large distances to find food or nesting sites.\nAnimals can be ‘tagged’ by attaching tracking devices to them. Tagging lets scientists follow the journeys the animals make.\nThe work of Lorentz and Pavlov has been mentioned in this Revision Bite. These scientists studied animal behaviour under controlled conditions.\nThe behaviour of woodlice is often studied in schools. Several woodlice are put into a choice chamber with four different conditions:\nThe woodlice are left on their own for a while, and then the number of animals in each quarter is counted. Woodlice prefer dark and damp conditions. The quarter of the choice chamber with these conditions contains most or all of the woodlice.\nIs it instinct or conditioning that makes you study science?\nJoin Questionaut's quest to find his friend's hat.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': '> Character - First, second and third person accounts\nCharacter - First, second and third person accounts\nA text can be written in the first, second or third person. This is all about who is telling the story. Here is a quick summary:\nmeans "I" or "we". The narrator of the account will be a character in the text and we will read about events from their point of view. We will also tend to relate to and sympathise with their feelings because of this.\nmeans "you". It is very rare to find a story written in the second person (why not have a go at writing a piece to see how difficult it is). Parts of adverts or leaflets are addressed directly to you, however, which can be a very persuasive way of writing.\nmeans "he", "she", "it" or "they". The narrator of the story will usually be the writer. The text may give many different characters\' viewpoints. Some stories focus on one character, the hero or heroine, and we usually relate to and sympathise with them more than others.\nTake a look at these three extracts. Decide which "person" each one is written in and check your answers to see if you are correct.\nWhen you arrive at Oldcastle Cottage you\'ll receive a warm welcome. Your every need will be taken care of by your hosts.\nIs the extract above written in the first, second or third person?\nperson. The writer is talking directly to you.\nMr. Fogg\'s wardrobe was amply supplied and in the best taste. Each pair of trousers, coat, and vest bore a number, indicating the time of year and season at which they were in turn to be laid out for wearing; and the same system was applied to the master\'s shoes.\n\'Around the World in Eighty Days\' - Jules Verne\nIs the extract above written in the first, second or third person?\nperson. The writer is telling you about Mr Fogg\'s clothing and how it is arranged.\nI continued walking in this manner for some time, endeavouring by bodily exercise to ease the load that weighed upon my mind.
