{'text': "> Ratio - Equivalent ratios and simplest form\nRatio - Equivalent ratios and simplest form\nIf you are making orange squash and you mix one part orange to four parts water, then the ratio of orange to water will be 1:4 (1 to 4).\nIf you use 1 litre of orange, you will use 4 litres of water (1:4).\nIf you use 2 litres of orange, you will use 8 litres of water (2:8).\nIf you use 10 litres of orange, you will use 40 litres of water (10:40).\nBoth sides of the ratio can be multiplied or divided by the same number to give an equivalent ratio.\nWrite the ratio 40:28 in its simplest form.\nTo work this out, look for a number that will divide into 40 and 28.\n2 divides into both numbers, so 40:28 can be written as 20:14.\nYou can divide these by 2, so the simplified ratio is\nNo number divides into 10 and 7, so 10:7 is the simplest form of the ratio.\nJoin Questionaut's quest to find his friend's hat.\nMake sure your maths skills add up.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "> Explore, imagine and entertain - Original ideas\nExplore, imagine and entertain - Original ideas\nThere's no formula for having a brilliant idea. What you really need is an idea to start with. Then you need to make this idea a little different. This is the creative part, taking something that appears very ordinary and turning it into something unusual.\nFor example, you may be asked to write a description of a coastline. You might start to think straight away about a crowded beach - children playing, deck chairs, sun shining, happy sounds. But if you stop for a moment, you realise that's been done before. It's OK, but it's not very creative.\nWhat about turning that on its head - not crowded, but deserted? Not summer, but winter? Not lovely and inviting, but covered in oil and polluted? It's not a pretty picture, but it's original - and that gives impact.\nCan you match Viral Vinnie's appetite for English, Maths and Science?\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "> Electric current and voltage - Current in series circuits\nElectric current and voltage - Current in series circuits\nThe current is the same everywhere in a\n. It does not matter where you put the ammeter, it will give you the same reading.\nAll three ammeters give the same reading in this series circuit\nThe current in a series circuit depends upon the number of cells. The more cells you add, the greater the current.\nThe more cells, the greater the current\nYou might think that the current gets less as it flows through one component after another. But it is not like this. The current is not used up by the components in a circuit. This means that the current is the same everywhere in a series circuit, even if it has lots of lamps or other components.\nThe current is the same everywhere in a series circuit\nDanger! Danger! {'text': 'We can see why variety is important by looking at this list below. It is taken from a story called "You are now entering the human heart", by Janet Frame, and is actually one of her paragraphs broken down into simple sentences:\nNone of them had ever touched a live snake.\nThey were waiting for the drama to begin.\nThe attendant took a green snake out of a basket.\nHe draped the snake around the teacher\'s neck.\nShe did not have a chance to protest.\nHe stepped back to admire the sight.\nIt doesn\'t really sound right. How could the writer change this to convey the drama of the situation? Look again at the sentences and decide what changes you could make, which ones you could join. Then click here to compare your ideas with the version in the book.\nHer eyes faced the lighted exit. I saw her fear. The children, none of whom had ever touched a live snake, were sitting hushed, waiting for the drama to begin; one or two looked afraid, as the attendant withdrew a green snake about three feet long from the basket and with a swift movement, before the teacher could protest, draped it around her neck and stepped back, admiring and satisfied.\nSo the key points to remember about sentences are:\nYou should have a variety of sentences in each piece you write.\nComplex sentences cause the most problems, but they can be the best for linking ideas and arguing your point.\nDifferent types of sentence suit different purposes, so think carefully about what you are trying to do.\nConnectives are a good way of linking ideas. They can provide a more detailed structure and help readers.\nYou write sentences all the time. Find out when and where to use them.\nWhack and zap mad professors and aliens!\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "> Acids, bases and metals - Reactions of acids with bases\nAcids, bases and metals - Reactions of acids with bases\nA chemical reaction happens if you mix together an acid and a base. The reaction is called\n, and a neutral solution is made if you add just the right amount of acid and base together.\nMetal oxides and metal hydroxides are two types of bases. For example copper oxide and sodium hydroxide.\nHere are general word equations for what happens in their neutralisation reactions with acids.\nare always produced. The mixture usually warms up a little during the reaction, too. The exact salt made depends upon which acid and base were used.\nCarbonates and hydrogen carbonates are two other types of base. They also make a salt and water when we neutralise them with acid. But this time we get\nThe reaction fizzes as bubbles of carbon dioxide are given off. This is easy to remember because we see the word 'carbonate' in the chemical names.\nThese are the general word equations for what happens:\na salt + water + carbon dioxide\na salt + water + carbon dioxide\nFarmers use lime (calcium oxide) to neutralise acid soils.\nYour stomach contains hydrochloric acid, and too much of this causes indigestion. Antacid tablets contain bases such as magnesium hydroxide and magnesium carbonate to neutralise the extra acid.\nBee stings are acidic. They can be neutralised using baking powder, which contains sodium hydrogen carbonate.\nWhack and zap mad professors and aliens!\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': 'The environment, the Earth and the universe\n> Astronomy and space science - Days and nights\nAstronomy and space science - Days and nights\nas they orbit the Sun. It takes the Earth 24 hours to make one complete turn on its axis, so an Earth day is 24 hours long.\nDifferent planets take different amounts of time to make one complete turn, so they have different lengths of day.\nThe Sun lights up one half of the Earth, and the other half is in shadow. As the Earth spins we move from shadow to light and back to shadow and so on. It is daytime in the UK when our part of the planet is in the lit by the Sun. And it is night-time in the UK when our part of the planet is facing away from the Sun.\nDuring the day, the Sun appears to move through the sky. Remember that this happens because the Earth is spinning on its axis. In the UK if we look south and follow the path of Sun in the sky during the day, it looks like this:\nThe sun rises in the east and sets in the west\n. That\'s because the Earth is spinning towards to the east, so we see the Sun first appear there at the start of the day. The Sun \'rises\' in the east and \'sets\' in the west.\nOne way to remember which way the Earth turns is to remember "\n", which means the Earth spins from west to east.\nStar trails made by leaving the camera shutter open during the night\nDuring the night, we cannot see the Sun. But the Earth is still spinning on its axis. This means that the stars appear to move from east to west in the sky, just as the Sun does in the day.\nMore from The environment, the Earth and the universe\nTry an activity that\'s out of this world!\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. While you will be able to view the content of this page in your current browser, you will not be able to get the full visual experience. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n', 'label': '4'}

The other side is divided by 3. The Lowest Common Multiple of 2 and 3 is 6, so multiply both sides by 6.\n3(x - 3) = 2(x - 2)\n3x - 9 = 2x - 4\nUp for a challenge? {'text': '> The Tempest Summary - Drunken clowns\nAriel brings Ferdinand (the King\'s son) to Prospero\'s cave. Ferdinand thinks he\'s the only survivor from the shipwreck. Miranda, who has seen no other man but her father during her time on the island, sees Ferdinand and thinks he must be a spirit - while Ferdinand thinks Miranda is a goddess. The two young people fall in love, but Prospero is not pleased, and makes Ferdinand his prisoner.\nOn another part of the island we discover one of the groups of shipwreck survivors. They begin to wake up. They\'re surprised that their clothes seem fresh and new.\nAriel\'s magical song puts them to sleep again - all except Sebastian (the King\'s brother) and Antonio (Prospero\'s brother). Antonio convinces Sebastian that they should kill the King (Alonso) so that Sebastian can take his place. Fortunately everyone else wakes up again, before they can carry out their plan.\nElsewhere on the island, Trinculo, a jester who was on board the ship, comes across Caliban. Trinculo\'s drunken friend Stephano turns up, and gives Caliban strong alcohol. This makes Caliban believe that Stephano is more powerful than Prospero (who Caliban hates).\nMeanwhile, Ariel, who has made himself invisible, watches the three drunken clowns. He causes havoc by whispering the accusation "thou liest" in Caliban\'s ear, then Stephano\'s. They become confused and fight.\nCaliban reveals his plans to destroy Prospero and take over the island. Stephano drunkenly agrees. Caliban is delighted that Stephano has agreed to his plan and they sing to celebrate. Ariel plays a tune to accompany their singing which frightens both Trinculo and Stephano.\nCaliban tells them not to be afraid in a moving speech that describes the beauty and magic of the island. Stephano, Trinculo and Caliban follow the sound of the music.\nUp for a challenge? Head to GCSE Bitesize.\nGet creative, go backstage and find drama tips and inspiration.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "The table shows some of the most common units and their equivalents. Make sure you know these conversions.\nTo convert a larger unit to a smaller unit (eg m to cm), first check the number of smaller units needed to make 1 larger unit. Then, multiply that number by the number of larger units.\nTo convert a smaller unit to a larger unit (eg cm to m), first divide it by the number of smaller units which are needed to make 1 larger unit.\nTo convert from a larger unit to a smaller one,\nTo convert from a smaller unit to a larger one,\nSo, to convert from m to cm multiply by 100, and to convert from cm to m divide by 100.\n3.2m = 320cm (3.2 ร\x97 100 = 320)\n400cm = 4m (400 รท 100 = 4)\nConvert the following to the units given in brackets:\nRemember that 1kg = 1000g. To convert from g to kg, divide by 1000.\nRemember that 1cl = 10ml. To convert from cl to ml, multiply by 10.\nRemember that 1m = 1000mm. To convert from mm to m, divide by 1000.\nCan you match Viral Vinnie's appetite for English, Maths and Science?\nMake sure your maths skills add up.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': '> Analyse, review and comment - Writing to analyse\nAnalyse, review and comment - Writing to analyse\nThis is one version of the speech. You will find comments beneath each paragraph, explaining what the writer has done well.\nI\'m sure you\'ve all heard the saying "we are what we eat". Have you been into the school canteen recently? The selection is similar to that in many schools: a main meal which is usually meat-based, a variety of burgers and pizzas, a dessert and, for the health-conscious, jacket potatoes with one or two cold fillings. The question we are here to consider today is whether this is a reasonable selection, or whether changes could be made in Grange High School\'s canteen.\nThe speech begins dealing with the problem straight away. It starts with a short, familiar phrase and a rhetorical question, to involve the audience and make them listen to the speech. The current selection of food is outlined to set the scene, followed by the main question to be tackled. The opening is very friendly and easy to follow. This is a great start.\nA survey conducted recently by Year 9 students suggested that many students are happy with the food on offer. They stated that the burgers and pizzas were their favourite food and that they were "tasty, filling, cheap and quick". These choices, sometimes called "junk food", are the best sellers and the canteen staff say the profit from these makes it possible to offer some of the less popular options.\nThe writer now looks at the evidence for keeping junk food. They\'ve imagined a survey and comments from the canteen staff - this is fine as it\'s relevant and makes sense.\nSome students admit that the junk food in the canteen is the only reason they stay in school at lunchtimes. Although we are not allowed off site during school times, it is well known that some students do sneak out to local chip shops and other takeaways. A substantial number of students who took part in the canteen\'s survey said they would be more likely to do this if the canteen offered more healthy food.\nThe final argument for junk food is explained. The writer introduces a rather controversial point, but softens it with the phrase \'it is well known...\' so that no one is blamed. Again this keeps things formal and balanced.\nSo far, the writing looks really good, but it seems like the conclusion will be in favour of junk food. Is there any way of balancing the argument? Go to the next page to see how this is done.\nMake all that writing make sense. Try this!\nJoin Questionaut\'s quest to find his friend\'s hat.\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': 'If you are asked to summarise a text, you will need to identify what the text is about and write this in as few words as possible.\nSumming up a piece of text in a few words can actually be quite difficult, but it is a useful skill.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "Many harmful microbes can pass from one person to another. Diseases caused by such microbes are said to be infectious diseases. Here are some ways that harmful microbes can be spread:\nDroplets containing microbes fly into the air when people sneeze or cough. The microbes they contain get into other people if breathed in.\nChicken pox, colds, flu, measles and tuberculosis are spread like this.\nAnimals may carry harmful microbes. The microbes can get into a person who is scratched or bitten by such an animal.\nis a tropical disease spread by a tiny fly called a mosquito.\nFood can have harmful microbes in and on it. The microbes get into the body when the food is eaten, causing food poisoning. Thorough cooking kills most microbes, but they can survive under-cooking. Careless handling of food increases the risk from harmful microbes.\nMicrobes can be passed from one person to another when people touch each other, or when they touch something an infected person has handled. Athlete's food is spread like this.\nBacteria on the skin can be killed by antiseptics, and bacteria on surfaces can be killed by disinfectants. Washing your hands reduces the chance of spreading microbes.\nWater can have harmful microbes in it. The microbes get into the body when the water is swallowed.\nis a disease caused by a bacterium that spreads like this. Thorough boiling or adding chlorine to the water can reduce the chance of spreading microbes in this way.\nUse your knowledge to help Spherox find his way home.\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. While you will be able to view the content of this page in your current browser, you will not be able to get the full visual experience. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n", 'label': '4'}
{'text': "> The Tempest first key extract - What happens\nThe Tempest first key extract - What happens\nIn this section you will see buttons at the end of some paragraphs. These will give you extra information. If you want this information, just mouse over the buttons as you read through.\nBefore this scene, Prospero and his slave, Caliban have exchanged cross words.\nThe First Key Extract begins with Ferdinand hearing Ariel's song.\nAriel's song calms the stormy waters. In 'The Tempest', music is linked closely to magic and illusion.\nHe wonders where the sounds are coming from.\nIllusion - Ferdinand does not know where the sound is coming from. He assumes that it is magic and tells us that the music not only calmed the storm, but also made him feel better.\nHe follows the sound, and when the song begins again, it suggests to Ferdinand that his father has drowned.\nWhen Miranda sees Ferdinand approaching, she can't believe her eyes. She doesn't think that Ferdinand is real.\nIllusion - Ferdinand is a living human being, but Miranda is convinced that he is a magical creature. In 'The Tempest', things are never quite as they at first seem.\nProspero explains that he is a man, not a spirit and that he is looking for other survivors of the shipwreck. Prospero feels excited that Miranda and Ferdinand seem to like each other: it was his plan all along\nPower - Prospero claims that he has used magic to make Miranda and Ferdinand fall in love. Prospero likes to control and manipulate people through his magic.\n, and he promises to reward Ariel with his freedom for helping to get them together.\nFerdinand asks Miranda if she is an ordinary girl or a goddess.\nMiranda can't believe that Ferdinand is an ordinary mortal. She thinks he's a 'spirit'. She calls him 'divine' and 'noble'. Ferdinand refers to her as a 'goddess'. The language they use suggests that they worship one another.\nHe is shocked when she speaks his language. When he hints that he is the King of Naples, Prospero challenges him.\nProspero likes to be in control. As soon as Ferdinand suggests that he has any sort of power, Prospero tries to undermine him. Prospero's questions are sarcastic and mocking in his attempt to show Ferdinand who is boss.\nFerdinand sadly explains that he believes that his father, the King of Naples, has drowned in the shipwreck along with the Duke of Milan and his son. Prospero watches Ferdinand and thinks to himself that he will be able to manipulate him easily now that Ferdinand is in love with his daughter.\nThink carefully about what kind of man Prospero is. Is he a caring father who will do anything to get the best for his daughter? Is he manipulative and controlling? Love is a powerful emotion. Should people use love to control others?\nMiranda can't understand why her father is being so abrupt with Ferdinand. She has fallen in love at first sight with Ferdinand.\nLove - Miranda admits that she has feelings for Ferdinand. It is the first time she has ever felt this way. Do you think that she would have fallen in love with Ferdinand even without Prospero's magic?\nShe wishes that her father could see things from her point of view.\nWhen Ferdinand offers to make Miranda his queen, Prospero steps in. He is worried that his plan won't work if Ferdinand wins Miranda's heart too easily.\nProspero says: 'But this swift business I must uneasy make, lest too light winning/Make the prize light'. He means that he can't let Ferdinand think that it was too easy to get Miranda to be his girlfriend, because he might not treat her well if it's really easy to make her love him.\nHe says that Ferdinand is lying about being a king and accuses him of being a spy.\nPower/ Illusion - Prospero wants to manipulate Ferdinand. He will make him suffer and work hard for Miranda's love. When Ferdinand claims to have some power of his own as the heir to the throne, Prospero takes this power away by accusing him of being a spy and taking him prisoner. Prospero knows that Ferdinand is the heir to the throne. 'The Tempest' is all about the confusion between what is true and real, and what is illusion.\nMiranda tries to speak up for him\nYou might think that Miranda is brave to speak up for Ferdinand. Apart from being a powerful magician, Prospero has quite a temper! Her speech also shows us how innocent she is. She can't believe that anyone who looks so lovely on the outside can be anything other than lovely on the inside. In 'The Tempest', Shakespeare shows us that things are not always as they first seem.\nbut Prospero tells her off and threatens to imprison Ferdinand.\nProspero calls Ferdinand a 'traitor'. He threatens to 'manacle' his neck and give him sea water to drink and acorn shells to eat. Prospero doesn't mean any of these threats, but in making them he shows that he has power over Ferdinand and could make him a slave just as he made Caliban his slave. Throughout the extract, Prospero uses words like 'usurp', 'traitor' and 'impostor' which all seem a bit strong when referring to Ferdinand. When Antonio took Prospero's place as Duke of Milan, he did 'usurp' him, and in doing so, he was a 'traitor' and in calling himself the Duke of Milan, Antonio is an 'imposter'.\nWhen Ferdinand draws his sword, Prospero uses magic to make it impossible for Ferdinand to move.\nMiranda tries desperately to stop her father but he won't listen. Ferdinand comes to the conclusion that all his problems - his father's death, the shipwreck, Prospero's threats - mean nothing, as long as he can see Miranda once a day, even if he is in prison.\nLove/ Illusion - Ferdinand suddenly doesn't mind being Prospero's prisoner, as long as he has Miranda to love. He says it's all like a 'dream'. Does love have that kind of dream-like power to overcome difficulties? Or is it another one of Prospero's spells?\nProspero is pleased that his plan to make Ferdinand fall in love with Miranda has worked. He praises Ariel\nLove/ Illusion - When Prospero tells Ariel that he has done well, this suggests that Miranda and Ferdinand's attraction towards one another is not true love, but a magic trick, an illusion, that Ariel has conjured.\nProspero promises Ariel that he will be free\nFreedom and Slavery - Just as Prospero has made Caliban a slave and threatened to imprison Ferdinand, he has the power to set Ariel free. When Prospero arrived on the island, Ariel was trapped in a pine tree and Prospero set him free, so he has a debt of gratitude towards him. Also, Ariel is gentle whereas Prospero has a temper. It could be that Ariel is a little afraid of his master.\nif he carries out all of his commands. Ariel agrees. Prospero orders Ferdinand to follow him and tells Miranda not to try and speak up for him.\nAriel's song calms the stormy waters. In 'The Tempest', music is linked closely to magic and illusion.\nIllusion - Ferdinand does not know where the sound is coming from. He assumes that it is magic and tells us that the music not only calmed the storm, but also made him feel better.\nIllusion - Ferdinand is a living human being, but Miranda is convinced that he is a magical creature. In 'The Tempest', things are never quite as they at first seem.\nPower - Prospero claims that he has used magic to make Miranda and Ferdinand fall in love. Prospero likes to control and manipulate people through his magic.\nMiranda can't believe that Ferdinand is an ordinary mortal. She thinks he's a 'spirit'. She calls him 'divine' and 'noble'. Ferdinand refers to her as a 'goddess'. The language they use suggests that they worship one another.\nProspero likes to be in control. As soon as Ferdinand suggests that he has any sort of power, Prospero tries to undermine him. Prospero's questions are sarcastic and mocking in his attempt to show Ferdinand who is boss.\nThink carefully about what kind of man Prospero is. Is he a caring father who will do anything to get the best for his daughter? Is he manipulative and controlling? Love is a powerful emotion. Should people use love to control others?\nLove - Miranda admits that she has feelings for Ferdinand. It is the first time she has ever felt this way. Do you think that she would have fallen in love with Ferdinand even without Prospero's magic?\nProspero says: 'But this swift business I must uneasy make, lest too light winning/Make the prize light'. He means that he can't let Ferdinand think that it was too easy to get Miranda to be his girlfriend, because he might not treat her well if it's really easy to make her love him.\nPower/ Illusion - Prospero wants to manipulate Ferdinand. He will make him suffer and work hard for Miranda's love. When Ferdinand claims to have some power of his own as the heir to the throne, Prospero takes this power away by accusing him of being a spy and taking him prisoner. Prospero knows that Ferdinand is the heir to the throne. 'The Tempest' is all about the confusion between what is true and real, and what is illusion.\nYou might think that Miranda is brave to speak up for Ferdinand. Apart from being a powerful magician, Prospero has quite a temper! Her speech also shows us how innocent she is. She can't believe that anyone who looks so lovely on the outside can be anything other than lovely on the inside. In 'The Tempest', Shakespeare shows us that things are not always as they first seem.\nProspero calls Ferdinand a 'traitor'. He threatens to 'manacle' his neck and give him sea water to drink and acorn shells to eat. Prospero doesn't mean any of these threats, but in making them he shows that he has power over Ferdinand and could make him a slave just as he made Caliban his slave. Throughout the extract, Prospero uses words like 'usurp', 'traitor' and 'impostor' which all seem a bit strong when referring to Ferdinand. When Antonio took Prospero's place as Duke of Milan, he did 'usurp' him, and in doing so, he was a 'traitor' and in calling himself the Duke of Milan, Antonio is an 'imposter'.\nLove/ Illusion - Ferdinand suddenly doesn't mind being Prospero's prisoner, as long as he has Miranda to love. He says it's all like a 'dream'. Does love have that kind of dream-like power to overcome difficulties? Or is it another one of Prospero's spells?\nLove/ Illusion - When Prospero tells Ariel that he has done well, this suggests that Miranda and Ferdinand's attraction towards one another is not true love, but a magic trick, an illusion, that Ariel has conjured.\nFreedom and Slavery - Just as Prospero has made Caliban a slave and threatened to imprison Ferdinand, he has the power to set Ariel free. When Prospero arrived on the island, Ariel was trapped in a pine tree and Prospero set him free, so he has a debt of gratitude towards him. Also, Ariel is gentle whereas Prospero has a temper. It could be that Ariel is a little afraid of his master.\nMore from The Tempest first key extract:\nUp for a challenge? {'text': '> Analyse, review and comment - Useful phrases\nAnalyse, review and comment - Useful phrases\nYou should have spotted that the second sentence uses the detached, impersonal tone. The phrase "it is often argued" is a useful one. Here are a few more:\nYou can also use words like these:\ncould... might... can... if... perhaps... maybe... some...\nNow, try to rewrite the sentences below so that they are fairer, more reasonable and detached. You can use some of the phrases and words above, and you can add your own details too - but try to keep the basic idea without losing your objectivity.\nFast food is bad for our health and should carry health warnings.\nChildren nowadays don\'t walk enough and it\'s making them all overweight.\nManchester United is the best football club in the world.\nI hate the smell of cigarette smoke - smoking should be banned in public places.\nBeaches are the best places to go on holiday.\nMiami is a waste of time in the winter.\nFour-wheel drive cars are the only way to travel - they are brilliant!\nLearning French at school is a waste of time because you\'ll never get to use it properly.\nWriting to analyse isn\'t difficult, but it needs practice and thought.\nMake all that writing make sense. {'text': '> The Tempest Summary - The shipwreck\nAriel tells Prospero what has happened to the ship and its passengers and crew. He tells how he appeared on the ship as a flame (he is after all a magic spirit), and frightened the passengers so much that they had jumped in to the sea. Only the crew remained on the ship.\nProspero wants to be sure that the crew and the passengers are safe. Ariel tells him how he saw to it that the passengers were washed up on the island in separate groups. He made sure the ship was safe, and that the crew were sleeping peacefully. He had sent the rest of the fleet back to Naples, with everyone believing that their king\'s ship had been sunk, and its passengers drowned.\nAriel now changes the subject, and says he\'s getting impatient. He reminds Prospero there is a time limit on how long he had to be Prospero\'s servant, after his release from Sycorax\'s spell. Ariel wants his freedom, and reminds Prospero that he\'s been a good servant.\nIn order to see this content you need to have both\nProspero, in reply, reminds Ariel of the horror he was released from. He tells him that he needs him to work for two more days and then he will be free. Prospero sends him off to keep watch over the washed-up passengers.\nAs Ariel leaves, Prospero wakes Miranda and tells her that they are going to see Caliban. This doesn\'t please Miranda, who refers to Caliban as a "villain" that she does not "love to look on". It is clear, too, from the names he calls him, that Prospero has not forgiven Caliban for an attack he once made on his daughter.\nUp for a challenge? Head to GCSE Bitesize.\nGet creative, go backstage and find drama tips and inspiration.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': '> Romeo and Juliet first key extract - The text\nRomeo and Juliet first key extract - The text\nExtract 1 - Act 1, Scene 1, lines 98 to 232\nWho set this ancient quarrel new abroach?\nSpeak, nephew. Were you by when it began?\nHere were the servants of your adversary\nAnd yours, close fighting ere I did approach.\nI drew to part them. In the instant came\nThe fiery Tybalt, with his sword prepared,\nWhich, as he breathed defiance to my ears,\nHe swung about his head and cut the winds,\nWho, nothing hurt withal, hissed him in scorn.\nWhile we were interchanging thrusts and blows,\nCame more and more, and fought on part and part,\nTill the Prince came, who parted either part.\nO where is Romeo? Saw you him today?\nRight glad I am he was not at this fray.\nMadam, an hour before the worshipped sun\nPeered forth the golden window of the east,\nA troubled mind drove me to walk abroad –\nThat westward rooteth from this city side,\nSo early walking did I see your son.\nTowards him I made, but he was ware of me,\nAnd stole into the covert of the wood.\nI, measuring his affections by my own,\nWhich then most sought where most might not be found,\nBeing one too many by my weary self,\nAnd gladly shunned who gladly fled from me.\nMany a morning hath he there been seen,\nWith tears augmenting the fresh morning’s dew,\nAdding to clouds more clouds with his deep sighs.\nBut all so soon as the all-cheering sun\nShould in the farthest east begin to draw\nAway from light steals home my heavy son,\nAnd private in his chamber pens himself,\nShuts up his windows, locks fair daylight out,\nBlack and portentous must this humour prove,\nUnless good counsel may the cause remove.\nMy noble uncle, do you know the cause?\nI neither know it, nor can learn of him.\nHave you importuned him by any means?\nBoth by myself and many other friends:\nIs to himself – I will not say how true –\nBut to himself so secret and so close,\nAs is the bud bit with an envious worm\nEre he can spread his sweet leaves to the air,\nOr dedicate his beauty to the sun.\nCould we but learn from whence his sorrows grow,\nWe would as willingly give cure as know.\nSee where he comes. So please you, step aside.\nI’ll know his grievance or be much denied.\nI would thou wert so happy by thy stay\nTo hear true shrift. Come, madam, let’s away.\nWas that my father that went hence so fast?\nIt was. What sadness lengthens Romeo’s hours?\nNot having that which, having, makes them short.\nOut of her favour where I am in love.\nAlas, that Love, so gentle in his view,\nShould be so tyrannous and rough in proof!\nAlas, that Love, whose view is muffled still,\nShould without eyes see pathways to his will!\nWhere shall we dine? O me! What fray was here?\nYet tell me not, for I have heard it all.\nHere’s much to do with hate, but more with love.\nWhy then, O brawling love, O loving hate,\nFeather of lead, bright smoke, cold fire, sick health,\nStill-waking sleep, that is not what it is!\nThis love feel I, that feel no love in this.\nGriefs of mine own lie heavy in my breast,\nWhich thou wilt propagate to have it pressed\nWith more of thine. This love that thou hast shown\nDoth add more grief to too much of mine own.\nLove is a smoke made with the fume of sighs:\nBeing purged, a fire sparkling in lovers’ eyes;\nBeing vexed, a sea nourished with loving tears.\nWhat is it else? A madness most discreet,\nA choking gall, and a preserving sweet.\nAnd if you leave me so, you do me wrong.\nTut, I have lost myself. I am not here.\nThis is not Romeo: he’s some other where.\nTell me in sadness, who is that you love?\nWhat, shall I groan and tell thee?\nBid a sick man in sadness make his will –\nA word ill urged to one that is so ill.\nIn sadness, cousin, I do love a woman.\nI aimed so near when I supposed you loved.\nA right good mark-man! And she’s fair I love.\nA right fair mark, fair coz, is soonest hit.\nWell, in that hit you miss. She’ll not be hit\nWith Cupid’s arrow. She hath Dian’s wit,\nAnd in strong proof of chastity well-armed,\nFrom Love’s weak childish bow she lives uncharmed.\nShe will not stay the siege of loving terms,\nNor bide th’ encounter of assailing eyes,\nNor ope her lap to saint-seducing gold.\nO, she is rich in beauty – only poor\nThat when she dies, with beauty dies her store.\nThen she hath sworn that she will still live chaste?\nShe hath, and in that sparing makes huge waste,\nShe is too fair, too wise, wisely too fair,\nTo merit bliss by making me despair.\nShe hath forsworn to love, and in that vow\nDo I live dead, that live to tell it now.\nBe ruled by me: forget to think of her.\nO, teach me how I should forget to think!\nTo call hers – exquisite – in question more.\nThese happy masks that kiss fair ladies’ brows,\nBeing black, puts us in mind they hide the fair.\nHe that is strucken blind cannot forget\nThe precious treasure of his eyesight lost.\nShow me a mistress that is passing fair:\nWhat doth her beauty serve, but as a note\nWhere I may read who passed that passing fair?\nFarewell. Thou canst not teach me to forget.\nI’ll pay that doctrine, or else die in debt.\nMore from Romeo and Juliet first key extract:\nRead the full text online and make your own notes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. While you will be able to view the content of this page in your current browser, you will not be able to get the full visual experience. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n', 'label': '4'}
{'text': "> Decimals - Multiplying decimals by 10, 100 and 1000\nDecimals - Multiplying decimals by 10, 100 and 1000\nWhen a decimal is multiplied by 10, every figure moves one place to the left.\nWhen multiplying by 100, every figure moves two places to the left.\nWhen multiplying by 1000, every figure moves three places to the left.\nWhich is bigger: 0.005 × 10 or 0.0004 × 1000?\nIf you didn't get it right, remember that multiplying by 10 moves each digit one place to the left.\nMultiplying by 1000 moves each digit three places to the left.\nConnect the dots with this decimals activity.\nWhack and zap mad professors and aliens!\nMake sure your maths skills add up.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "To check the accuracy of a rounded number, you need to find the largest and smallest numbers that it could have been rounded from.\nQ1. The number of children in a school is 800, correct to the nearest 100. What is the largest possible, and smallest possible number of children in the school?\nQ2. Amelia spends £80 in the local supermarket, correct to the nearest £10. What is the greatest and least amount that Amelia could have spent?\nThe number of children in the school has been rounded to the nearest 100 to give 800.\nThe smallest number that rounds to 800 is 750.\nThe largest number that rounds to 800 is 849.\nSo, the smallest possible number of children in the school is 750, and the largest possible number of children is 849.\nNote: 850 is exactly halfway between 800 and 900, but 850 rounds up to give 900, so we use 849.\nThe smallest number that rounds to £80 is £75.\nThe largest number that rounds to £80 is £84.99.\nRemember that £85 is halfway between £80 and £90, but 85 rounds up to 90, so we must go for the smallest possible unit less than 85 (in this case a penny less), which is £84.99.\nCan you match Viral Vinnie's appetite for English, Maths and Science?\nMake sure your maths skills add up.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n", 'label': '4'}

You need to know the symbols we use to draw circuit diagrams.\nAn ammeter measures electric current, in amps, by measuring how much charge is flowing in the circuit. A voltmeter measures, in volts, the difference in electrical energy between two points of a circuit.\nDanger! Danger! High voltage! His results are shown in the table below:\nThis is an example of a two-way table and it is used to show two different features in a survey.\nYou can find out lots of information from this table. For example, you can see that there are 2 left-handed boys in the class. You can also see that there are 13 girls in the class (1 left-handed and 12 not left-handed)\nQ1. How many right-handed children are there in the class?\nQ2. How many children are there in total?\nA1. There are 14 right-handed boys and 12 right-handed girls, so 14 + 12 =\nThis is the total of all the numbers in the table.\nDoes everything tally up? {'text': "Try out these example questions about relative frequency.\nQ1. 100 people were asked whether they were left-handed. Four people answered 'yes'. What is the relative frequency of 'left-handed'?\nQ2. A white counter was taken from a bag of different coloured counters, and then replaced. The relative frequency of getting a white counter was found to be 0.3. If the bag contained 20 counters, estimate the number of white counters.\nA1. The relative frequency is 4/100 =\nA2. The relative frequency of white counters is 0.3, and there are 20 counters in the bag, so, as an estimate, 0.3 Ã— 20 =\nRelative frequency can only be used as an estimate.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "Forces can make objects turn if there is a\n. Think of a playground see-saw. The pivot is the thing in the middle of it. When no-one is on the see-saw it is level, but it tips up if someone gets onto one end. Turning forces around a pivot are called\nIt is possible to balance the see-saw again if someone else gets onto the other end and sits in the correct place. This is because the turning forces are balanced. We say the moments are equal and opposite.\n, we need to know two things:\nthe distance from the pivot that the force is applied.\nThis is the equation for working out a moment:\nImagine that a force of 10 N acted on a see-saw 2 m from the pivot. This is how we would work out the moment:\nNotice that the unit of moment is\n(newton metre). Don't get confused with a 'newton meter', which is another name for a forcemeter.\nHere is an example of balanced moments. 10N at 2m from the pivot is balancing 20N at 1m from the pivot. The objects create moments of 20Nm that are equal and opposite, so the see-saw is balanced.\nA see-saw will balance if the moments on each side of the pivot are equal. This is why you might have to adjust your position on a see-saw if you are a different weight from the person on the other end.\nIf a nut is difficult to undo with a short spanner, a longer spanner will help. This is because there will be a bigger moment on the nut, when the same force is applied further from the pivot.\nUsing the same principle you can increase the moment applied by a lever or a crowbar, and this can help you move heavy objects more easily.\nSomething is pulling your mouse towards this link.\nJoin Questionaut's quest to find his friend's hat.\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': '> Argue, persuade and advise - Writing to advise\nArgue, persuade and advise - Writing to advise\nOnce you can argue and persuade, it should be easy to advise. The trick is to be gentle - it\'s no good pushing your ideas at your readers, or trying to impress them. Instead, you should come across as friendly, as someone who just wants to help.\nFor instance, imagine you\'re writing to advise someone in Year 9 who is moving house and has to change schools. We know that it won\'t be easy - they\'ll have to make new friends and cope with all sorts of changes. So you need to be sympathetic and give some ideas you think could help.\nThe first thing might be to plan each main idea in a separate paragraph because it\'s easier to follow like this. Then think about how you want to present your ideas. It might be fine to give some information as an order, such as:\nIf you\'re not sure what to do on the first day, ask someone.\nYou can add information to this - perhaps explaining why and giving an example of what to do, so now your paragraph looks like this:\nIf you\'re not sure what to do on the first day, ask someone. Most people will be glad to help and it\'s the quickest way to make friends. You can ask a teacher, but it might be better to ask one of the other pupils. Choose a friendly face if you can, and don\'t be shy - it might be their first day too.\nIt is not just the information that makes this a good piece of advice, it\'s also the style. It includes words like "might" and "can". These make the ideas softer - they are not in your face and pushing you to agree, they just guide you. And they are very simple to use, so make sure you include words like "should, can, could, might, ought to and may" - each one turns an idea into a piece of advice.\nWant to get your own way? Try this activity to learn some techniques\nUse your knowledge to help Spherox find his way home.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. While you will be able to view the content of this page in your current browser, you will not be able to get the full visual experience. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n', 'label': '4'}

{'text': '> Compounds and mixtures - Chemical formulae\nRemember that we use chemical symbols to stand for the elements. For example,\nstands for sodium. For a molecule we use the chemical symbols of the atoms it contains to write down its\nFor example the formula for carbon monoxide is\n. It tells you that each molecule of carbon monoxide consists of one carbon atom joined to one oxygen atom.\nTake care when writing your symbols and formulae. Be careful about when to use capital letters. For example\nmeans a molecule of carbon monoxide but\nThe word \'formulae\' ("form-u-lee") is the plural of \'formula\'. If we have more than one formula, we don\'t say formulas, we say formulae.\nIf the molecule contains more than one atom of an element we use numbers to show this. The numbers are written below the element symbol. For example, the formula for carbon dioxide is\n. It tells you that each molecule has one carbon atom and two oxygen atoms.\nTake care when writing these formulae. The small number go at the bottom. For example CO\nSome formulae are more complicated. For example, the formula for sodium sulfate is\n. It tells you that sodium sulfate contains two sodium atoms (\nAll compounds have a definite composition. Let\'s look at water as an example. A water molecule always has two hydrogen atoms and one oxygen atom - it cannot be a water molecule if it has different numbers of these atoms. {'text': "Whenever an object moves against another object, it feels\nforces. These forces act in the opposite direction to the movement. Friction makes it harder for things to move.\nfriction between our shoes and the floor stop us from slipping\nfriction between tyres and the road stop cars from skidding\nfriction between the brakes and wheel help bikes and cars slow down\nFrictional forces are much smaller on smooth surfaces than on rough surfaces, which is why we slide on ice.\nFriction can also be unhelpful. If you don't lubricate your bike regularly with oil, the friction in the chain and axles increases. Your bike will be noisy and difficult to pedal.\nWhen there is a lot of friction between moving parts, energy is lost to the surroundings as\n. Think of what happens when you rub your hands together quickly. The friction warms them up.\nas they move. Air resistance is caused by the frictional forces of the air against the vehicle. The faster the vehicle moves, the bigger the air resistance becomes. The top speed of a vehicle is reached when the force from the cyclist or engine is balanced by air resistance.\nRacing cyclists crouch down low on their bikes to\nthe air resistance on them. This helps them to cycle faster. They also wear streamlined helmets. These have special, smooth shapes that allow the air to flow over the cyclist more easily.\nModern cars are also streamlined. Their smooth shapes make the air resistance smaller, which allows them to travel further on the same amount of fuel.\nSomething is pulling your mouse towards this link.\nJoin Questionaut's quest to find his friend's hat.\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. While you will be able to view the content of this page in your current browser, you will not be able to get the full visual experience. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n", 'label': '4'}
{'text': 'Something that is implicit is inferred - it is suggested, but not actually said. Implicit meaning can be a little harder to find than explicit meaning. Writers like to draw you into their text and get you involved. It\'s up to you to make your mind up about a character, just as it is when you meet someone in real life.\nThe clues you need to make up your mind about a character are all in the text. Look for the following:\nTake another look at one of the extracts from \'Holes\'. Stanley has just arrived at the prison camp. What can you tell about the character of Mr Sir, the man in the cowboy hat, from reading between the lines? Some important phrases have been put in bold to give you a few clues.\nA man was sitting with his feet up on a desk.\nHe turned his head when Stanley and the guard entered, but otherwise didn\'t move. Even though he was inside,\nhe wore sunglasses and a cowboy hat\n. He also held a can of cream soda, and the sight of it made Stanley even more aware of his own thirst.\nHe waited while the bus guard gave the man some papers to sign.\n"That\'s a lot of sunflower seeds," the bus guard said.\nStanley noticed a burlap sack filled with sunflower seeds on the floor next to the desk.\n," said the man in the cowboy hat. He had\na tattoo of a rattlesnake on his arm\n, and as he signed his name, the snake\'s rattle seemed to wiggle. "I used to smoke a pack a day. Now I eat a sack of these every week."\nOn the surface, this extract doesn\'t tell us much about Mr Sir, but you\'ve probably begun to\nabout him. If we read between the lines, we can tell that he likes to make an impression and wants to be seen to be in charge. He is sitting "with his feet up on a desk" and has made his appearance even more striking by wearing sunglasses and a cowboy hat indoors.\nSometimes people who act like this can like power a bit too much, and can be bullies. Could Mr Sir be a bully?\nWhen we consider the can of cream soda, we can say that the fact that Mr Sir fails to offer either Stanley or the bus driver anything to drink after their nine-hour, cross-desert journey suggests that he is a\nman. That he keeps his own drink in full view of Stanley and the bus driver further suggests that he is cruel and likes to see other people\'s discomfort.\nWe learn that Mr Sir stopped smoking recently. We could then expect him to be bad- and short-tempered. The tattoo of a rattlesnake, a dangerous reptile that is supposed to have a bad temper, adds to this impression. The sunflower seeds are, we are led to believe, there to help him as an alternative to cigarettes, but we don\'t get the feeling of optimism that they\'ll be successful.\nSo there we have it; Mr Sir is a bad-tempered, selfish bully!\nWhack and zap mad professors and aliens!\nLove books? {'text': 'The environment, the Earth and the universe\n> Changes in the environment - Humans\nHumans are very successful living things. We compete with other organisms for many natural resources. These include:\nThe world’s population of humans is increasing all the time. In the year 1800 it was about\n, and now it is more than\nMore people mean more use of natural resources, and bigger changes to the environment. The graph shows population growth over the last 200 years.\nHumans use machines to move large amounts of earth to make new roads and buildings. We straighten rivers and build walls to stop them flooding. In some countries, such as the Netherlands, land is reclaimed from the sea. Barriers are built and water is pumped out. New dry land forms for people to use.\nWe also large areas of land for quarries. These are large holes in the ground where rocks containing useful metals are taken out.\nThe environment is also changed when land is flooded to make reservoirs for drinking water or hydroelectric power schemes. The animals and plants that live in the forest or on the land lose their habitat. They may die out in that region as a result.\nHumans have been cutting down trees for thousands of years. We do this to clear land for farming and building, and for wood to use as a fuel or building material.\nas long as forests are allowed to replace themselves, or are replanted after felling, but often this is not done. The result is that the world’s forests are steadily shrinking.\nThe maps below show the loss of forest across the world over the last 10 thousand years.\nMore from The environment, the Earth and the universe\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. While you will be able to view the content of this page in your current browser, you will not be able to get the full visual experience. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n', 'label': '4'}

{'text': "Scatter diagrams show the relationship between two sets of variables. By looking at the diagram you can see whether there is a link between variables. Where there is a link it is called\nThe English and Maths results of ten classmates are shown in the table below:\nTo see whether there is a correlation between the Maths and English marks, you could plot a scatter diagram.\nThe Maths mark is on the horizontal scale and the corresponding English mark on the vertical scale.\nBill's Maths mark was 60 and his English mark was 65, so his results are represented by the orange point at coordinates (60, 65).\nIn the scatter diagram above, whose mark does the small red cross represent?\nThe co-ordinates of the cross are (80, 70).\nTherefore, the Maths mark is 80 and the English mark 70.\nYou can see that all the points representing Maths marks and English marks lie approximately along a straight line. This shows that there is a correlation between these two variables.\nThe table below shows the correlations that you can deduce from different patterns of scatter.\nThe points lie close to a straight line, which has a positive gradient.\nThis shows that as one variable increases the other increases.\nThe points lie close to a straight line, which has a negative gradient.\nThis shows that as one variable increases, the other decreases.\nThere is no pattern to the points.\nThis shows that there is no connection between the two variables.\nWould you expect there to be positive correlation, negative correlation, or no correlation between the following pairs of variables:\na) As temperature increases, the sales of ice-cream are also likely to increase. Therefore, there is likely to be positive correlation.\nb) It is unlikely that there is a connection between height and intelligence. Therefore, there is no correlation.\nUse your knowledge to help Spherox find his way home.\nUp for a challenge? {'text': '> Romeo and Juliet second key extract - The text\nRomeo and Juliet second key extract - The text\nSECTION 2 - Act 2, Scene 2, lines 1 to 157\nHe jests at scars that never felt a wound.\n, below, sees the light at the window, then realises it is\n– But soft! What light through yonder window breaks?\nIt is the east, and Juliet is the sun.\nArise, fair sun, and kill the envious moon,\nWho is already sick and pale with grief\nThat thou her maid art far more fair than she.\nBe not her maid, since she is envious:\nHer vestal livery is but sick and green,\nAnd none but fools do wear it. Cast it off.\n– It is my lady! – O, it is my love!\nShe speaks – yet she says nothing. What of that?\nHer eye discourses. I will answer it.\n– I am too bold. ‘Tis not to me she speaks.\nTwo of the fairest stars in all the heaven,\nHaving some business, do entreat her eyes\nTo twinkle in their spheres till they return.\nWhat if her eyes were there, they in her head?\nThe brightness of her cheek would shame those stars\nAs daylight doth a lamp. Her eyes in heaven\nWould through the airy region stream so bright\nThat birds would sing and think it were not night!\nSee how she leans her cheek upon her hand.\nO that I were a glove upon that hand,\nO speak again, bright angel! – For thou art\nAs glorious to this night, being o’er my head,\nAs is a wingèd messenger of heaven\nOf mortals that fall back to gaze on him\nAnd sails upon the bosom of the air.\nO Romeo, Romeo! Wherefore art thou Romeo?\nDeny thy father and refuse thy name –\nOr if thou wilt not, be but sworn my love\nAnd I’ll no longer be a Capulet.\n(Aside)Shall I hear more, or shall I speak at this?\n‘Tis but thy name that is my enemy.\nThou art thyself, though not a Montague.\nWhat’s ‘Montague’? It is nor hand, nor foot,\nNor arm, nor face, nor any other part\nBelonging to a man. O, be some other name!\nWhat’s in a name? That which we call a rose\nBy any other word would smell as sweet.\nSo Romeo would, were he not Romeo called,\nRetain that dear perfection which he owes\nWithout that title. Romeo, doff thy name –\nAnd for that name, which is no part of thee,\nCall me but love, and I’ll be new-baptized.\nWhat man art thou, that thus bescreened in night\nI know not how to tell thee who I am.\nMy name, dear saint, is hateful to myself\nBecause it is an enemy to thee.\nHad I it written, I would tear the word.\nMy ears have yet not drunk a hundred words\nOf thy tongue’s uttering, yet I know the sound.\nNeither, fair maid, if either thee dislike.\nHow cam’st thou hither, tell me, and wherefore?\nThe orchard walls are high and hard to climb –\nAnd the place death, considering who thou art,\nIf any of my kinsmen find thee here.\nWith love’s light wings did I o’erperch these walls,\nFor stony limits cannot hold love out –\nAnd what love can do, that dares love attempt.\nTherefore thy kinsmen are no stop to me.\nIf they do see thee, they will murder thee.\nAlack, there lies more peril in thine eye\nThan twenty of their swords. Look thou but sweet\nAnd I am proof against their enmity.\nI would not for the world they saw thee here.\nI have night’s cloak to hide me from their eyes.\nAnd but thou love me, let them find me here.\nMy life were better ended by their hate\nThan death proroguèd, wanting of thy love.\nBy whose direction found’st thou out this place?\nBy love, that first did prompt me to inquire.\nHe lent me counsel, and I lent him eyes.\nI am no pilot, yet wert thou as far\nAs that vast shore washed with the farthest sea,\nThou knowest the mask of night is on my face,\nElse would a maiden blush bepaint my cheek\nFor that which thou hast heard me speak tonight.\nFain would I dwell on form – fain, fain deny\nWhat I have spoke. – But farewell compliment!\nDost thou love me? I know thou wilt say ‘Ay’ –\nAnd I will take thy word. Yet if thou swear’st\nThou mayst prove false. At lovers’ perjuries\nThey say Jove laughs. O gentle Romeo,\nIf thou dost love, pronounce it faithfully.\nOr if thou think I am too quickly won,\nI’ll frown, and be perverse, and say thee nay,\nSo thou wilt woo – but else, not for the world.\nIn truth, fair Montague, I am too fond,\nAnd therefore thou mayst think my ’haviour light.\nBut trust me, gentleman, I’ll prove more true\nThan those that have more cunning to be strange.\nI should have been more strange, I must confess,\nBut that thou overheard’st, ere I was ware,\nAnd not impute this yielding to light love,\nWhich the dark night hath so discoverèd.\nLady, by yonder blessèd moon I vow,\nThat tips with silver all these fruit-tree tops –\nO swear not by the moon, th’ inconstant moon,\nThat monthly changes in her circled orb,\nLest that thy love prove likewise variable.\nOr if thou wilt, swear by thy gracious self,\nWhich is the god of my idolatry,\nWell, do not swear. Although I joy in thee,\nI have no joy of this contract tonight.\nIt is too rash, too unadvised, too sudden –\nToo like the lightning, which doth cease to be\nEre one can say ‘It lightens’. Sweet, good night.\nThis bud of love, by summer’s ripening breath,\nMay prove a beauteous flower when next we meet.\nGood night, good night! As sweet repose and rest\nCome to thy heart as that within my breast.\nO wilt thou leave me so unsatisfied?\nTh’ exchange of thy love’s faithful vow for mine.\nI gave thee mine before thou didst request it –\nAnd yet I would it were to give again.\nWould’st thou withdraw it? For what purpose, love?\nBut to be frank and give it thee again:\nAnd yet I wish but for the thing I have.\nMy bounty is as boundless as the sea,\nMy love as deep. The more I give to thee,\nThe more I have, for both are infinite.\nis heard calling from inside the house.\nI hear some noise within. Dear love, adieu!\n– Anon, good Nurse! – Sweet Montague, be true.\nStay but a little: I will come again.\nO blessèd, blessèd night! I am afeard,\nBeing in night, all this but a dream,\nThree words, dear Romeo, and good night indeed.\nIf that thy bent of love be honourable,\nThy purpose marriage, send me word tomorrow\nBy one that I’ll procure to come to thee,\nWhere and what time thou wilt perform the rite –\nAnd all my fortunes at thy foot I’ll lay,\nAnd follow thee, my lord, throughout the world.\nI come! Anon! – But if thou mean’st not well,\n– To cease thy suit, and leave me to my grief.\nA thousand times the worse, to want thy light!\nLove goes toward love as schoolboys from their books,\nBut love from love, toward school with heavy looks.\nMore from Romeo and Juliet second key extract:\nRead the full text online and make your own notes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. While you will be able to view the content of this page in your current browser, you will not be able to get the full visual experience. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n', 'label': '4'}

{'text': 'Try and find the answers to these questions.\nQ1. Work out the value of the following:\na) 4 × 5 - 3 × 2\nb) (2 + 3) × (5 - 1)\na) In BODMAS multiplication comes before subtraction, so work out the multiplication first and then do the subtraction:\n4 × 5 - 3 × 2 = 20 - 6 = 14\n(2 + 3) × (5 - 1) = 5 × 4 = 20\nc) In BODMAS division comes before addition, so\n2 + 6 ÷ 2 = 2 + 3 = 5\n8 - (6 - 1) = 8 - 5 = 3\ne) BODMAS states that brackets come before multiplication, so work out the bracket first:\n3 × (4 + 2) = 3 × 6 = 18\nWhack and zap mad professors and aliens!\nUp for a challenge? {'text': "The environment, the Earth and the universe\nAnimals and plants can wear away rocks. This is called\nweathering. For example, burrowing animals such as rabbits can burrow into a crack in a rock, making it bigger and splitting the rock.\nYou may have seen weeds growing through cracks in the pavement. If you have gone for a walk in the countryside, you may even have seen bushes or trees growing from cracks in rocks or disused buildings. This is because\ncan grow in cracks. As they grow bigger, the roots push open the cracks and make them wider and deeper. Eventually pieces of rock may fall away.\nPeople can even cause biological weathering just by walking. Over time, paths in the countryside become damaged because of all the boots and shoes wearing them away.\nMore from The environment, the Earth and the universe\nJoin Questionaut's quest to find his friend's hat.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "> Romeo and Juliet Summary - The party\nRomeo and Juliet Summary - The party\nRomeo and his friends decide to gate-crash the party. Romeo has a bad feeling about the outcome of this evening, but decides to let fate take its course.\nCapulet is having a great time at his party. People are dancing. Romeo and his friends arrive wearing masks. Romeo spots Juliet. He thinks to himself that he didn't really know what true beauty was until he saw her. He doesn't know that she is a Capulet. Tybalt recognises Romeo from his voice and threatens to kill him because he is a Montague, but Capulet stops him. Romeo and Juliet flirt and finally kiss. The Nurse tells Romeo that Juliet is a Capulet and he is dismayed. He leaves with Benvolio. Juliet is distraught when the Nurse tells her who Romeo is.\nThe Chorus recaps events for us: Romeo has forgotten Rosaline and is now in love with Juliet. Juliet feels the same way.\nRomeo runs away from his friends. Mercutio shouts rude things because he thinks Romeo has gone off to find Rosaline.\nRomeo hides in the Capulets' garden and watches Juliet who is on a balcony outside her bedroom. Juliet doesn't know that he is there at first and, talking to herself, declares her love for him. She is shocked and embarrassed when he replies. They have only met that evening, but they know that they love each other. Juliet promises to send a messenger to him in the morning to find out where and what time their wedding will be! They find it difficult to part.\nRomeo goes to see Friar Lawrence, the priest, who is worried that he has spent the night with Rosaline. When Romeo says that he wants to marry Juliet, Friar Lawrence tells him off for falling in love so easily, but agrees to the wedding because he thinks that it might be a solution to the rift between the Capulets and the Montagues.\nRead the full text online and make your own notes.\nUp for a challenge? {'text': "There are two different methods for finding the area of this shape:\nDivide the shape into squares and rectangles, find their individual areas and then add them together.\nArea = 16 + 16 + 48 = 80cm\nImagine the shape as a large rectangle with a section cut out.\nFind the area of the large rectangle (12 × 8) and then subtract the part that has been cut out (4 × 4)\nArea = (12 × 8) - (4 × 4) = 96 - 16 = 80cm\nIn the right area? When your teacher announces that it\'s time for a drama lesson, do you:\na) Stand up waving your arms frantically to ensure you get the best part.\nb) Immediately start sword fighting your friend with a ruler.\nc) Pack away your pens and books and prepare to get into character.\n2. Your teacher says that you\'ll start by warming up. Do you:\na) Pull on your tights and leggings and begin limbering up.\nb) Run really fast round the room, punching your friends.\nc) Shed your embarrassment in case you\'re asked to do something unusual and prepare to focus.\n3. Your teacher asks you to bring in a costume and some props. Do you:\na) Come in full Elizabethan costume with wig and authentic make-up.\nb) Stuff some balloons up your jumper.\nc) Bring in a couple of hats and your little brother\'s plastic sword and hope that you can come up with something by sharing what you\'ve got with your friends.\n4. Me!"\nb) Nudge your friend and giggle as you pretend your bum has been burnt.\nc) Avoid the teacher\'s eye as you\'d rather it wasn\'t you.\n5. In fact, they\'d be better off sitting down and letting you get on with it.\nb) Laugh so much that no one can see the good work you were doing before the focus was placed on you.\nc) Swallow your shyness, keep your nerves steady and try your best to work as a team.\n6. Your group is reading out a play together. Do you:\na) Insist on the biggest role, perhaps even two or three roles. You could play them all brilliantly and better than anyone else.\nb) Keep losing your place and laughing, then read in a silly or monotone voice to hide your embarrassment.\nc) Offer to narrate or read the stage directions, although secretly you\'d love to take a big role.\n7. {'text': '> More on equations - Equations with x on both sides\nMore on equations - Equations with x on both sides\nThe same rules apply if an equation has x on both sides. Keep the equation balanced and perform the same operation to both sides.\nSolve the equation 2x + 2 = x + 4\nThe equation 2x + 2 = x + 4 is represented by the following diagram:\nAs usual, the bags represent the unknown (x) and the sweets represent the numbers. Aim to get unknowns on just one side of the equation, so begin by subtracting x from each side:\nNow you have the type of equation that you recognise, all you need to do is subtract 2 from both sides.\n2x + 2 = x + 4\nSubtract x from both sides to give x + 2 = 4\nSubtract 2 from both sides to give x = 2\nUp for a challenge? {'text': "> Whole numbers - Writing and describing\nWhen describing whole numbers, remember the place values of the original digits.\nHowever, some digits are 'joined' in their description. For example - when describing the number 35, we do not say 'three tens and five units', but instead describe it by the more common name of 'thirty five'.\nIn the same way the thousands, ten-thousands and hundred-thousands columns are usually described together. Here are some examples.\n2 000 is described as 'two thousand'\n62 000 is described as 'sixty two thousand', and\n162 000 is described as 'one hundred and sixty-two thousand'\nThe number 3 147 286 can be written in words as\nthree million, one hundred and forty seven thousand, two hundred and eighty six.\nQ1. {'text': "Here are two examples of instinctive behaviour in animals:\nInstincts are useful because they do not have to be learned and they can be complex, like the examples above. Instincts let animals form groups for protection, choose mates, fight to be in charge, and show many other behaviours.\nReflexes are a type of instinct. They happen automatically because of a particular stimulus. For example, if your hand touches something hot by accident, it automatically and quickly moves away. You do not have to learn to do this.\nIn order to see this content you need to have both\nWhen the school bell rings at the end of break time, the students leave the playground and go to their lessons. People may say that the students are acting on instinct. But they would be wrong.\nAn instinct is a behaviour that happens automatically without any learning needed. The students have learned that the bell is a signal to do something, so leaving the playground when the bell rings is not an instinct. It is learned behaviour.\nIs it instinct or conditioning that makes you study science?\nJoin Questionaut's quest to find his friend's hat.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "> More on formulas - Collecting like terms\nMore on formulas - Collecting like terms\n, remember that any term that contained the same letter can be combined by adding and subtracting.\n3g + 2k + 5g + 4k - g\n= 3g + 5g - g + 2k + 4k\nLike terms with powers can be added or subtracted but only if the powers are the same.\nx is not the same as x\n, so they cannot be added together.\nRearrange the expression so that like terms are next to each other:\n+ 3x - 2x + 5 - 1\nPeople usually write the expression with the 'x\n' term first, then the 'x' term and finally the number term.\nTo get the answer, rearrange the expression:\n+ 2x - 4x + 5 - 3\nTime to formulate a new revision plan!\nUse your knowledge to help Spherox find his way home.\nUp for a challenge? {'text': "> Electric current and voltage - Circuit symbols\nElectric current and voltage - Circuit symbols\nWe use circuit symbols to draw diagrams of electrical circuits, with straight lines to show the wires. The diagram shows some common circuit symbols.\nNotice the difference between the symbol for a\n? The battery is made from joining cell symbols together.\nThink of what we usually call a single battery, like the type you put in a torch. In physics, each of these is actually called a\n- it is only when you have two or more of these cells connected together that you call it a battery.\nThe idea of a circuit diagram is to use circuit symbols instead of drawing each component in the circuit. Always try to make the wires\nlines, and don't be tempted to make them wiggly.\nThe whole point is to make it easier to see what is connected to what. Here you can see how the symbols for a cell (not a battery!) and a lamp look in a circuit diagram.\nIf you have to draw a circuit diagram from scratch, it is usually easier to draw the circuit symbols first, and then add all the wires. If you have to draw wires to join circuit symbols that are already shown, use a ruler and don't let the wires cross each other.\nDanger! Danger! High voltage! {'text': "> Romeo and Juliet first key extract - Performance\nRomeo and Juliet first key extract - Performance\nWhen you write about performance, mention the tone or feeling you get at a particular point in the play, and the effect it might have on the audience.\nYou can find evidence for your ideas in the four question areas:\nharacters and how you respond to them\nanguage used - the detail about love, for example\nssues and ideas - like time, love and hate\nOnce you understand how the audience should feel, you can decide how you might direct a particular scene. Remember, there are lots of different ways to perform the same scene. A good answer depends on how well you explain yourself.\nHere is an example of an answer to a question about performance. Think about how you might answer the same question.\nHow should an actor playing Benvolio behave?\nBenvolio's replies to Romeo could either show that he is a good listener who wants to understand his friend's problems, or that he is amused by what Romeo has to say because he knows that his friend is not serious about this girl.\nWhen Benvolio speaks to Montague, the mood is serious. When Romeo arrives, he has to ask lots of questions because Romeo is evasive. Some of Benvolio's comments could be said in a sarcastic or sympathetic way. The jokes that the two characters share show that they are good friends. Benvolio gives advice at the end of the scene that shows that he doesn't believe Romeo's love for Rosaline is serious.\nThe way Benvolio behaves towards Romeo shapes the way the audience perceives Romeo. This is important because Romeo is the main character. The audience has to like him and worry about him for the tragedy to work. If the actor playing Benvolio speaks his lines in a patient and sympathetic way, it makes Romeo seem like a young man who finds the world confusing. If Benvolio's lines are spoken humorously, the comedy in Romeo's speeches will be brought to life.\nOnce you understand the First Key Extract, you are ready to move on to the second.\nMore from Romeo and Juliet first key extract:\nRead the full text online and make your own notes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': 'The body has natural barriers to stop harmful microbes getting inside the body. Here are some of them:\nacid in the stomach kills many microbes\nsticky mucus in the lungs traps microbes, and then cilia sweep it out of the lungs\nthe skin stops microbes from getting into the body\nscabs form on the skin if you get a cut, stopping microbes from getting into your body\nThe body has an immune system that kills microbes if they get past the natural barriers.\nare very important in the immune system. There are different sorts of these cells, but they can do two main jobs.\nSome white blood cells can engulf microbes and kill them.\nSome white blood cells can make substances called antibodies that stick to microbes.\n. Different microbes have different antigens. White blood cells have chemicals called\nWhite blood cells can stick to microbes if they have the right antibody to match the antigen on the microbe. When this happens the microbes can be killed, or clumped together to make it easier for other white blood cells to kill them.\nUse your knowledge to help Spherox find his way home.\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "> Decimals - Place value and ordering decimals\nDecimals - Place value and ordering decimals\nWe use a decimal point to separate units from parts of a whole (like tenths, hundredths, thousandths, etc).\n0.1 is a tenth, 1/10 of a unit\n0.01 is a hundredth, 1/100 of a unit\n0.001 is a thousandth. 1/1000 of a unit\nIn 52.13, the value of the figure 1 is 1/10 , and the value of the figure 3 is 3/100.\nWhen ordering numbers, always compare the left digits first.\nEg Which is greater, 2.301 or 2.32?\nBoth numbers have two units and three tenths, but 2.301 has no hundredths, whereas 2.32 has two hundredths. Therefore, 2.32 is greater than 2.301.\nAnother way to look at it is to add a zero to the end of 2.32 (this doesn't change its value as it's after the decimal point).\nThe two numbers are now 2.320 and 2.301 and it is quite easy to see that 2.320 is bigger (just as 2 320 is bigger than 2 301).\nQ1. In the number 3.546, what is the value of the figure 4?\nQ2. Place the following numbers in order, smallest first: 3.2, 3.197, 3.02, 3.19\nA1. The value of the figure 4 is 4/100.\nA2. Did you get 3.02, 3.19, 3.197, 3.2?\nAll the numbers have three units, so start by comparing the tenths. 3.02 has no tenths, 3.197 and 3.19 have one tenth, and 3.2 has two tenths. Therefore, 3.02 is the smallest and 3.2 is the largest.\nYou could also write the numbers as 3.020, 3.190, 3.197 and 3.200 and compare them.\nConnect the dots with this decimals activity.\nWhack and zap mad professors and aliens!\nMake sure your maths skills add up.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled.
