{'text': 'Standard English is the style of English grammar, spelling and vocabulary that is widely accepted in spoken and written English. In formal speaking and listening situations, you will need to communicate using Standard English, eg when writing or giving a speech.\nThe key to presenting the perfect speech is preparation and practice. World leaders don\'t just stand up and make up a speech on the spot - they carefully prepare beforehand. They even employ people to write their speeches, although remember, this is not an option at school!\nUse the English language skilfully - as you have time to prepare your speech in advance, you can show off your English language skills and vocabulary.\nBe memorable - former prime minister Tony Blair was famous for making a speech that included the phrase "Education, education, education". This use of repetition made the speech memorable and helped his audience identify his key point.\nMake people think - you may have heard of Martin Luther King who repeated the phrase "I have a dream" when he campaigned for equal rights for black Americans. This was a speech designed to inspire and connect with his audience.\nExcerpt from Martin Luther King\'s \'I have a dream\' speech\nI have a dream that my four little children will one day live in a nation where they will not be judged by the colour of their skin but by the content of their character.\nI have a dream that one day, down in Alabama, with its vicious racists, with its governor having his lips dripping with the words of interposition and nullification; one day right there in Alabama little black boys and little black girls will be able to join hands with little white boys and white girls as sisters and brothers.\nRead the speech in full on the\nA good speech might contain the following:\nHere is an example of a speech to a group of students. {'text': "> Romeo and Juliet first key extract - Characters\nRomeo and Juliet first key extract - Characters\nIf you get a question about characters in the Key Extracts, here is how to use PEE (see page 2) to help with the middle part of your answer:\nDo you think Romeo knows what love is?\nRomeo is obviously a very sensitive young man. He seems to be exploring the idea of love. He may well long to be in love. Some of his ideas about love are confused and confusing.\nRomeo does not join in with the street brawl and is sad that the violence takes place. He says that he understands that the violence is more to do with love and loyalty towards family than it is to do with hatred. He has been unhappy for some time and his family is worried. When Romeo talks to Benvolio, he finds it difficult to make himself clear. He is more interested in using language cleverly. When he uses oxymorons like 'heavy lightness' it is as though he isn't really sure what love is. When he talks about Rosaline, he focuses on her beauty. He says he loves her, but he is annoyed by her virtuous personality.\nRomeo lives amongst people who will kill others and risk their own lives for the sake of their own family, so he knows about passion. The fact that he won't talk to his father about why he is unhappy isn't very loving. Romeo talks about love in an abstract way. He likes the idea of love, and he might have been influenced by what poets have said about love. It could be argued that if Romeo really loved Rosaline, then he would respect her wishes to remain a virgin. Towards the end of the extract, Romeo seems more interested in sex than true love.\nMore from Romeo and Juliet first key extract:\nRead the full text online and make your own notes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': 'When you have a series of large numbers that are not in number order, it is sometimes difficult to make sense of them.\nHere is a table showing the daily profits of an online music store, written in order of days:\nIf these numbers were put into a place value table, it would be easier to arrange them in order.\nThe figures for Friday and Saturday will be the largest as these have figures in the tens of thousands column.\nLooking at the thousands column shows that there is a 4 in the thousand column for Saturday and a 0 in the thousands column for Friday. Therefore Saturday has the largest number.\nHere is the table written in order of days:\nPerplexed by place values? {'text': "> Drama - Working from a script\nThere's much more to acting than just reading a script out loud. If you're nervous, it's tempting to read the lines really quickly, using the same tone of voice all the way through, but this isn't very interesting for your audience.\nTry to think of the punctuation as musical notes telling you when to pause for a breath (or for dramatic effect!). Don't be tempted to take a little break at the end of each line - the piece might not make sense.\nTo understand this, first read the script below, pausing at the end of each line. Then try again using the punctuation as your guide for when to pause.\nJuliet is waiting for the nurse to come home and tell her whether the wedding with Romeo is still on. Time is ticking and she's pretty fed up.\nThe clock struck nine when I did send the Nurse;\nIn half an hour she promised to return.\nPerchance she cannot meet him. That's not so.\nO, she is lame! Love's heralds should be thoughts,\nWhich ten times faster glide than the sun's beams,\nAnd therefore hath the wind-swift Cupid wings.\nNow is the sun upon the highmost hill\nOf this day's journey, and from nine till twelve\nIs three long hours, yet she is not come.\nHad she affections and warm youthful blood\nShe would be as swift in motion as a ball:\nMy words would bandy her to my sweet love,\nBut old folks, many feign as they were dead -\nUnwieldy, slow, heavy, and pale as lead.\nWhich way worked better? Using the punctuation as your guide makes it sound like a real person thinking aloud.\nDon't be such a drama queen! Try this activity.\nTalk your way out of trouble using your English skills.\nGet creative, go backstage and find drama tips and inspiration.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "> Tone and style - Style tips\nAnother top style tip is to avoid being boring. It sounds obvious, but many writers put in far too much information. In fact, some even write most of the question out again when they start their answer. So what should you do?\nAt the beginning, don't waffle, get straight to the point. Don't just repeat things in your conclusion. Put yourself in the reader's shoes - which of these two starts to a school magazine article do you prefer?\nDo you know someone who is being bullied right now? Don't know what to do? Well we decided to send Stuart Smith (Year 8) around the school to find out just how bad bullying is, and to come up with some ideas about what we can do to stop it.\nBullying is when people are cruel to other people. It can be hurting them, like kicking them, or hurting them using horrible names. It could be other things too. My article for the school magazine is about bullying. I am going to start by saying what the problem of bullying is and then...\nThe first one is much better - it gets straight to the point and you want to read on. The second version repeats parts of the question, but for no reason. People who are reading the school magazine don't have to be reminded in each article that it is the school magazine. We also know the article is about bullying from the first sentence, but Stuart's definition is poor and the whole article is slow to get started.\nYou've got tone and style. Work it!\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': '> Tone and style - Avoid repetition\nOne quick way to improve your style is to avoid repeating words. Look for other choices. So instead of writing "John was bullied", you could change to "picked on" and instead of writing "Satnam was the quickest runner", you could alter this to "the fastest" or "the best" or "the swiftest" etc.\nYou might not realise you have repeated a word, so look back over your writing to see what you can change. An examiner won\'t mind you altering something if it will improve it.\nIn order to see this content you need to have both\nOf course, it\'s fine to use the same word if you really want your readers to remember something. So if you are persuading them, you probably need to repeat your key ideas and key words.\nYou\'ve got tone and style. {'text': "> Approximation - Significant figures - decimals\nRounding 12.756 or 4.543 to 1 decimal place (d.p.) seems sensible, as the rounded figures are very close to the actual value.\nBut what happens if you round a very small number to 1 d.p?\nThis is not a useful answer. Another way to find an approximate answer with very small numbers is to use\nSignificant figures start at the first non-zero number, so ignore the zeros at the front, but not the ones in between. Look at the following examples:\nFrom the first significant figure onwards, all zeros are included. {'text': '> Food chains - Toxic materials in the food chain\nFood chains - Toxic materials in the food chain\nToxic materials are poisonous. Some quickly break down into harmless substances in the environment. Others are\nand do not break down. Instead, they accumulate in the food chain and damage the organisms in it, especially the top predators.\nMercury compounds were used until quite recently to make\n(chemicals that kill the insects that damage crops) and special\nthat stop barnacles growing on the hulls of ships.\nUnfortunately, when it gets into the food chain mercury damages the\nof mammals, including humans. The diagram shows how mercury can accumulate in the food chain.\nTiny plankton in the sea absorb the mercury compounds. When the plankton are eaten by small fish, the mercury they contain stays in the fish. As the fish need to eat a lot of plankton, the concentration of mercury in them becomes higher than its concentration in the plankton.\nThe small fish are eaten by larger fish, and these are eaten by still larger ones, such as tuna fish. This creates a high concentration of mercury in the tuna. People eating contaminated tuna may get mercury poisoning. Mercury is now banned from many chemical products and mercury use in industry is carefully regulated.\nDDT is an insecticide that can pass up the food chain from insects to small birds, and then from the small birds to birds of prey, like hawks. It can accumulate in the birds of prey, giving them a large amount of DDT. Concentrations of DDT in birds causes weakness in their eggs, and reduces their population. DDT is now banned because of this.\nHungry for knowledge? Prey on this activity.\nWhack and zap mad professors and aliens!\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "> Food chains - Plants and photosynthesis\nBefore we look at food chains we will go over the way green plants capture energy from the Sun to make food. This is the start of all the food chains we will look at.\nAnimals eat food to get their energy. But green plants don't. Instead they make their own food, glucose, in a process called photosynthesis. We say that plants can photosynthesise.\nThese are the things that plants need for photosynthesis:\nThese are the things that plants make by photosynthesis:\nWe can show photosynthesis in a word equation, where light energy is shown in brackets because it is not a substance:\ncarbon dioxide + water (+ light energy)\nPlants get carbon dioxide from the air through their leaves, and water from the ground through their roots. Light energy comes from the sun.\nThe oxygen produced is released into the air from the leaves. The glucose produced can be turned into other substances, such as starch, which is used as a store of energy. This energy can be released by\nPhotosynthesis takes place inside plant cells in small things called\n. Chloroplasts contain a green substance called chlorophyll. This absorbs the light energy needed to make photosynthesis happen. Plants can only photosynthesise in the light.\nHungry for knowledge? It causes around 80 per cent of deaths from\nin the UK, and almost a fifth of UK deaths from\nTobacco smoke contains many harmful substances. These include:\nA normal lung and a lung from a smoker:\nof the lungs, mouth and throat. It coats the surface of the breathing tubes and the alveoli. This causes coughing and damages the alveoli, making it more difficult for gas exchange to happen.\nCells in the lining of the breathing tubes produce sticky mucus to trap dirt and microbes. Cells with tiny hair-like parts, called\n, normally move the mucus out of the lungs.\nHot smoke and tar from smoking damages the cilia. So smokers cough to move the mucus and are more likely to get\n- it causes a smoker to want more cigarettes. Nicotine also increases the heart rate and blood pressure, and makes blood vessels narrower than normal. This can lead to heart disease.\nCarbon monoxide is a gas that takes the place of oxygen in red blood cells. This reduces the amount of oxygen that the blood can carry. This means that the circulatory system has to work harder, causing heart disease.\nCan you match Viral Vinnie's appetite for English, Maths and Science?\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': '> Atmosphere and setting - Implicit meaning\n- it\'s suggested, but not openly stated. Implicit meaning can be harder to figure out than explicit meaning. Writers like to be clever and draw you into their text. It\'s up to you to make your mind up about a setting, in just the same way that it\'s up to you what to make of a new place you visit. Writers often use language in clever ways to build up a sense of atmosphere and setting.\nTake a look at the following extract from Robert Westall\'s novel, \'Urn Burial\'. Ralph has been captured by an alien race...\nThis was the worst nightmare yet. He was standing with his back pressed against a smooth wall cold as ice. The cold nibbled at his buttocks and legs; it ran up and down the knobbles of his spine, making him shiver; it invaded his lungs so he could hardly breathe; he felt he had been shivering a long time.\nIn the extract, the writer intends to create a very creepy, sinister atmosphere. The way that he describes Ralph\'s imprisonment makes it sound very unpleasant. He is "pressed" against a wall that is "cold as ice" and the cold is creeping into every part of his body, making him shiver. Ralph also feels as if he can "hardly breathe" because of the cold.\n. The simile; "a smooth wall cold as ice", helps the reader relate to Ralph as they will know what ice feels like. The writer also uses personification; the cold "nibbled" at Ralph, it "ran up and down" his back and "invaded" his lungs. This makes the cold sound as if it were alive, running over and into Ralph, trying to eat away at him. This adds to the feeling that he has been overpowered and is in danger.\nWhat does it all mean? Find out with this activity.\nLove books? Get your reviews published on Student Life.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. While you will be able to view the content of this page in your current browser, you will not be able to get the full visual experience. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n', 'label': '4'}
{'text': "As well as having lots of ideas, you need to explain them clearly. One really effective way of doing this is to use\nSo if you're answering a question, state your point, back it up with a piece of evidence and then explain it.\nTry out the PEE method. Here's an extract from 'Holes' about Stanley and the prison work camp.\nFind two features of Stanley's character and explain how they are suggested. Write your answer down and then compare it to ours.\nStanley and his parents had tried to pretend that he was just going away to camp for a while, just like rich kids do. When Stanley was younger he used to play with stuffed animals, and pretend the animals were at camp. Camp Fun and Games he called it. Sometimes he'd have them play soccer with a marble. Other times they'd run an obstacle course, or go bungee jumping off a table, tied to broken rubber bands. Now Stanley tried to pretend he was going to Camp Fun and Games. Maybe he'd make some friends, he thought. At least he'd get to swim in the lake.\nCheck our ideas on the extract by clicking the button below.\nHe is willing to make the best of a bad situation.\nThe writer suggests that Stanley spent long periods, when younger, playing alone with stuffed toys.\nStanley thinks that he will have the chance to make friends and 'at least he'd get to swim in the lake'.\nThe writer lists the sort of games Stanley played with his stuffed toys at 'Camp Fun and Games' in a way that suggests he was playing on his own - the toys became his friends.\nHe is going to a boy's prison work camp, but, instead of thinking about the horrors he might face, he shows that he is hopeful and ready to make the best of things.\nWhack and zap mad professors and aliens!\nLove books? {'text': "> Diet, drugs and health - Drugs and health\nDiet, drugs and health - Drugs and health\nDrugs are substances that have effects on the body.\nare drugs that help people suffering from pain or disease.\n, such as tobacco, alcohol and caffeine. Most other recreational drugs are\n, such as cannabis, ecstasy and heroin.\nAll drugs can damage the liver, because it is the liver that breaks drugs down in the body. Any drug that is misused can cause damage to the body, as well as personal and social problems. Injecting any drug with a needle and syringe that someone else has used may lead to a number of diseases from infected blood, including HIV and hepatitis.\nDepressants slow down messages in the brain and along the nerves.\nis a depressant. It is found in beer, wines and spirits such as vodka.\nHere are some of the typical effects depressants have on the body:\na distorted view of the world, or hallucinations\nSome of the long-term effects of depressants on the body include damage to the liver, brain and heart. They can also have the following effects:\nsolvent abuse causes a rash around the nose and mouth\ncannabis causes loss of memory and concentration, as well as an increased risk of mental illness.\nStimulants speed up messages in the brain and along the nerves. This makes you feel more alert.\nis a stimulant and is found in cola drinks, coffee and tea. It makes you feel more energetic and alert, but it can also cause insomnia (difficulty in sleeping), headaches and nervousness.\nare all illegal stimulants. They make you feel more energetic and confident, but they can damage the liver and heart. They can also cause loss of memory and concentration, and bring an increased risk of mental illness.\nCan you match Viral Vinnie's appetite for English, Maths and Science?\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n", 'label': '4'}
{'text': '> Variation and classification - Continuous & discontinuous\nVariation and classification - Continuous & discontinuous\nSome of the features of the different organisms in a species show continuous variation, and some features show discontinuous variation.\nHuman height is an example of continuous variation. Height ranges from that of the shortest person in the world to that of the tallest person. Any height is possible between these values. So it is continuous variation.\nFor any species a characteristic that changes gradually over a range of values shows continuous variation. Examples of such characteristics are:\nIf you record the heights of a group of people and draw a graph of your results, it usually looks something like this:\nThe more people you measure, and the smaller the categories you use, the closer the results will be to the curved line. This shape of graph is typical of a feature with continuous variation. Weight and foot length would give graphs similar in shape to this.\nHuman blood group is an example of discontinuous variation. There are only 4 types of blood group. There are no other possibilities and there are no values in between. So this is discontinuous variation.\nA characteristic of any species with only a limited number of possible values shows discontinuous variation. Here are some examples:\nblood group (A, B, AB or O)\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n', 'label': '4'}
{'text': ". For example, when you push open a door you have to apply a force to the door. You also have to apply a force to pull open a drawer.\nYou cannot see a force but often you can see what it does. Forces can change the speed of something, the direction it is moving in or its shape. For example, an elastic band gets longer if you pull it.\nA force meter is used to measure forces.\n. Force meters contain a spring connected to a metal hook. The spring stretches when a force is applied to the hook. The bigger the force applied, the longer the spring stretches and the bigger the reading.\nThe unit of force is called the\n. So 100 N is a bigger force than 5 N.\nSomething is pulling your mouse towards this link.\nJoin Questionaut's quest to find his friend's hat.\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. This gives us algebraic terms, like 2x and 5y.\nWhen algebraic terms are put together by mathematical operations such as + and - we get an algebraic expression, like 2x + 5y +3z.\nWe can simplify algebraic expressions by collecting 'like terms'.\nTime to formulate a new revision plan!\nCan you match Viral Vinnie's appetite for English, Maths and Science?\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': '> Writer\'s tricks - Persuading the reader\nThe extract below is from a leaflet about passive smoking.\n. Passive smoking is breathing in other people\'s tobacco smoke. Other people\'s tobacco smoke is sometimes called environmental tobacco smoke.\n. Only 15% of the smoke from a cigarette is inhaled by the smoker - the rest goes into the surrounding air and other people can breathe it in. Breathing air which contains tobacco smoke can be bad for your health. This is because the tiny particles and gases in tobacco smoke contain over 4000 chemicals, many of which are harmful - at least 60 are known to cause cancer. The gases also contain carbon monoxide, the poisonous gas that comes out of car exhausts.\nQ. What is the effect on my health?\n. Breathing other people\'s smoke is uncomfortable and can cause:\nnose, throat and chest irritation and breathing difficulties\nFrom a Health Development Agency Passive Smoking Information Leaflet\nThe following questions will draw on all the skills you have revised so far. Note down your answers then compare them with ours.\nQ1. What, according to the leaflet, is "passive smoking"?\nQ2. How much of the smoke from one cigarette is inhaled by the smoker?\nQ3. Name one effect that passive smoking can have on our health, according to the extract.\nQ4. Who do you think is the target audience for the leaflet?\nQ5. Give one reason why you think this.\nQ6. Look at the second answer that the writer has given in the leaflet: the one beginning "Only 15% of the smoke...". Explain two ways in which the writer has used language to persuade the reader that passive smoking is dangerous.\nQ7. Why has the writer phrased each heading as a question?\nQ8. Explain two ways in which the writer has used layout to make the text more effective.\nA1. Passive smoking is \'breathing in other people\'s tobacco smoke\'.\nA2. 15% is inhaled by the smoker.\nA3. Coughing. (You could name any of the effects listed in the bullet points.)\nA4. The target audience could be teenagers, or a broad audience. It is the reason that you give in the next answer that is more important.\nA5. Reasons are: the language used is quite simple; sentences are mainly quite short and simple, many only contain one or two ideas; the information is broken up into short sections; the headings make the information easy to follow. All these would make the text accessible for many readers, including young people.\nA6. There are three main ways: the simple statement that it is \'bad for your health\'; the fact that tobacco smoke contains \'over 4000 chemicals\', many of which are harmful; the mention of carbon monoxide which is \'poisonous\'.\nA7. The headings are phrased as questions to draw the reader into the text.\nA8. Layout has been used in several different ways: the \'Q\' and \'A\' format is eyecatching; the short paragraphs are easy to follow; the bullet points at the end of the extract make the facts easy to read.\nUse your knowledge to help Spherox find his way home.\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "Antibiotics are medicines used by doctors when harmful microbes have made you ill. They are substances that harm bacteria. Some antibiotics stop the bacteria reproducing and others kill the bacteria directly.\nAntibiotics are helpful to treat diseases caused by bacteria, such as tuberculosis and food poisoning. They do not harm viruses, so antibiotics cannot treat diseases such as colds and flu, which are caused by viruses.\nAntibiotics only work against bacteria, not viruses\nWhen you are infected by a microbe, it takes time for your body to start fighting the infection. It does this by making enough white blood cells with the correct antibody. During this time, you continue to feel unwell.\nYou begin to recover when enough antibodies have been produced. After the microbes have been killed, the amount of antibodies goes down again. But some of the white blood cells that produce the correct antibody remain in your blood.\ninfection by the same microbe, your body makes the correct antibodies much faster, because of the white blood cells that remain from when you had the first infection. The microbe doesn't get a chance to make you ill this time, and we say that you are\nto the microbe and the disease it causes.\nCheck your understanding of this by studying the animation.\nImmunisation is a process that doctors use to make people immune from certain illnesses, even before they have been infected. It involves you receiving an injection containing a\nVaccines contain a dead or weak form of the disease-causing microbe, or some of its antigens. In response to the vaccine your immune system produces white blood cells with the correct antibody to kill the microbe, so you become immune without falling ill.\nYou are likely to have been immunised against several microbes, viruses and bacteria, including the ones that cause diphtheria, whooping cough, polio, tetanus, meningitis, measles, mumps and tuberculosis. Girls are also immunised against rubella.\nVaccination works against diseases caused by both bacteria and viruses.\nUse your knowledge to help Spherox find his way home.\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. Pure carbon can exist in two very different forms -\n. The table shows some differences between them.\nDiamond is the hardest natural substance on Earth, but it is also very brittle and will shatter if hit with a hammer.\nGraphite is unusual because it is a non-metal that conducts electricity.\nUse your knowledge to help Spherox find his way home.\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "> Energy transfer and storage - Heat and temperature\nEnergy transfer and storage - Heat and temperature\nare not the same thing, although both are concerned with thermal energy.\nThe heat an object contains is the\nThe temperature of an object is to do with\nit is, measured in degrees Celsius. Note that the unit of temperature is written as\nA thermometer is used to measure the temperature of an object\nA thermometer is used to measure the temperature of an object\nLet's look at two examples to see the difference between heat and temperature.\nA swimming pool at 30째C is at a lower temperature than a cup of tea at 80째C. But the swimming pool contains more water, so it stores more thermal energy than the cup of tea.\nTo boil water we must increase its temperature to 100째C. It takes longer to boil a large beaker of water than a small beaker because the large beaker contains more water and needs more thermal energy to reach 100째C.\nCan you match Viral Vinnie's appetite for English, Maths and Science?\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "> Romeo and Juliet Summary - The opening\nRomeo and Juliet Summary - The opening\nThe play starts by telling us what will happen at the end. A girl and a boy from two warring families will die. Their deaths will put an end to the violence. The action is set in Verona in Italy.\nThese equally rich and powerful families are:\nTwo of Capulet's servants pick a fight in the market place with one of Montague's servants. Benvolio tries to stop the fight. Tybalt attacks Benvolio. A riot starts. Prince Escalus stops the riot and warns that if the Montagues and the Capulets are involved in any more violence the punishment will be death.\nLuckily, Romeo wasn't involved, but his mother and father wonder where he is. Benvolio has seen him moodily wandering about by himself. He says he will try to find out what is wrong with Romeo.\nRomeo tells Benvolio that he is in love with a girl called Rosaline. He is in agony because she doesn't love him back. Benvolio's advice is to look at other attractive girls. Romeo says that no other girl could ever live up to Rosaline.\nRead the full text online and make your own notes.\nUp for a challenge? {'text': "The method for rounding to a given number of significant figures is almost identical to the method used for rounding to a given number of decimal places.\nYou look at the number after the one you're interested in, to see whether it is greater or less than 5. If it's less than 5, round down. If it's 5 or more, round up.\nQ1. Round 0.0724591 to 3 significant figures (s.f.)\nQ2. Round 0.2300105 to 4 significant figures (s.f.)\nTo round to three significant figures, look at the fourth significant figure. It's a 5, so round up.\nTo round to four significant figures, look at the fifth significant figure. It's a 1, so round down.\nEven though 0.2300 is the same as 0.23, include the zeros to show that you have rounded to 4 significant figures.\nRound up, round up and try this activity!\nMake sure your maths skills add up.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': '> Romeo and Juliet second key extract - What happens\nRomeo and Juliet second key extract - What happens\nIn this section you will see buttons at the end of some paragraphs. These will give you extra information. If you want this information, just mouse over the buttons as you read through.\nRomeo and his friends have left the Capulets\' party. Romeo has run away from his friends. Mercutio has been shouting rude jokes because he thinks that Romeo has gone off with Rosaline. Mercutio and Benvolio finally give up looking for him and go home.\nThe second set extract begins with Romeo hiding from Mercutio and Benvolio in Juliet\'s garden. Romeo thinks to himself that Mercutio can never understand how he feels because he has never been in love.\n"He jests at scars that never felt a wound"\nHe watches Juliet as she stands on her balcony thinking out loud. He thinks that she is like the sun\nRomeo uses lots of words and images that relate to light when he describes Juliet.: \'sun\', \'stars\' \'brightness\'.\nand that the moon is jealous of her because she is so beautiful. He says that her eyes are like two stars that are so bright that they would stop night-time from being dark if they were in heaven, and the birds would sing because they would think that night was day.\nRomeo uses more words and images to do with light to describe Juliet.\nHe idolises her and compares her to an angel.\nWhen Romeo says that Juliet is like an angel from heaven, on the one hand, he is saying how lovely she is. On the other hand, you could say that he doesn\'t really see her as a flesh and blood person. He idolises her. Do you believe that he can really love her when he doesn\'t actually know anything about her? Or do you believe in love at first sight?\nJuliet, not realising that Romeo is hiding in her garden, imagines what she would say to Romeo if he were there. She says out loud that she wishes he wasn\'t a Montague, but says that it doesn\'t really matter because she loves him anyway, and hopes that he loves her. After all, a name is just a word; it doesn\'t really mean that much.\nIf we used another word for a rose instead of the word \'rose\', eg \'poo\', the rose would still be a rose, it wouldn\'t smell like poo just because we used that word. In the same way, Romeo is still lovely even though his name is Montague.\nWhen Juliet is thinking these things aloud on her balcony, she doesn\'t know that anyone else is watching. Have you ever practiced saying something to someone, even though you know that you would never be brave enough to say it?\nWhat\'s in a name? That which we call a rose\nBy any other word would smell as sweet\nWhen Romeo replies, Juliet nearly jumps out of her skin.\n"My name, dear saint, is hateful to myself"\nWhen Romeo calls her \'dear saint\', Juliet realizes who he is. Romeo called her \'dear saint\' at the party.\nJuliet is very worried for Romeo\'s safety; he is a Montague on Capulet property. Romeo uses very poetic and exaggerated language to describe how he managed to climb over the walls.\nRomeo has been quite brave and perhaps foolish to break into Juliet\'s garden. He likes to takes risks and doesn\'t think clearly about the seriousness of his actions. He uses poetic language to exaggerate his bravery.\nHe declares that he\'d rather die than live never having the opportunity to love Juliet.\nJuliet admits that she is embarrassed that Romeo heard the things that she was saying about him. She asks him if he loves her too, but she doesn\'t give him the chance to answer.\nJuliet is worried that she has shown herself to be too keen on Romeo. In Shakespeare\'s day, nice girls weren\'t supposed to show that they were interested in boys.\nJuliet\'s speech is very long! Is she nervous or embarrassed? Is she a chatterbox? Is she so excited about her new love that she can\'t stop talking about it?\nRomeo begins to use poetic language about the moon to describe how much he loves her, but Juliet won\'t let him finish.\nTime - Juliet won\'t let Romeo finish his sentences! Poor Romeo! We already know how much he loves to speak! Juliet\'s mind is working very quickly. She is excited, but also worried about how suddenly they have fallen in love.\nShe says that if he swears by the moon, he might turn out to be just as changeable as the moon (the moon changes its shape throughout the month).\nShe worries that they have fallen in love so quickly.\nIt is too rash, too unadvised, too sudden.\nShe tries to say goodnight, but she is excited and passionate about her feelings for Romeo and can\'t seem to stop talking about it.\n"My bounty is as boundless as the sea.\nMy love as deep. The more I give to thee,\nThe more I have, for both are infinite"\nJuliet\'s use of imagery seems more heartfelt than Romeo\'s: her love is as deep as the sea, and the sea never runs out. That\'s passion!\nJuliet\'s Nurse shouts to her from inside the house. Juliet asks Romeo to wait. As she goes into her bedroom, Romeo thinks to himself that their love seems like a dream.\nLove - Is this true love? How could it have happened so quickly? Do you believe in \'love at first sight\'? Remember, that same evening that he met and fell in love with Juliet, Romeo was moping about saying that he would never love anyone as much as he loved Rosaline! Romeo might argue though that he didn\'t really know what true love was until he met Juliet.\nJuliet comes back out onto the balcony and tells Romeo that if he is serious about her, she will send a messenger out to him tomorrow to find out where and what time they will get married!\nTime - events happen very quickly in this play. In less than a week, Romeo and Juliet fall in love, get married and die.\nShe says goodnight to him as her Nurse impatiently tells her to come inside.\nRomeo finds it hard to say goodnight to her.\nRomeo said that he was in love with Rosaline in the first extract. Less than a day later, he claims to be in love with Juliet. Has he really thought about the consequences of marrying Juliet. Perhaps, when you are in love, nothing else matters. What do you think?\nRomeo uses lots of words and images that relate to light when he describes Juliet.: \'sun\', \'stars\' \'brightness\'.\nRomeo uses more words and images to do with light to describe Juliet.\nWhen Romeo says that Juliet is like an angel from heaven, on the one hand, he is saying how lovely she is. On the other hand, you could say that he doesn\'t really see her as a flesh and blood person. He idolises her. Do you believe that he can really love her when he doesn\'t actually know anything about her? Or do you believe in love at first sight?\nIf we used another word for a rose instead of the word \'rose\', eg \'poo\', the rose would still be a rose, it wouldn\'t smell like poo just because we used that word. In the same way, Romeo is still lovely even though his name is Montague.\nWhen Juliet is thinking these things aloud on her balcony, she doesn\'t know that anyone else is watching. Have you ever practiced saying something to someone, even though you know that you would never be brave enough to say it?\nWhen Romeo calls her \'dear saint\', Juliet realizes who he is. Romeo called her \'dear saint\' at the party.\nRomeo has been quite brave and perhaps foolish to break into Juliet\'s garden. He likes to takes risks and doesn\'t think clearly about the seriousness of his actions. He uses poetic language to exaggerate his bravery.\nJuliet is worried that she has shown herself to be too keen on Romeo. In Shakespeare\'s day, nice girls weren\'t supposed to show that they were interested in boys.\nJuliet\'s speech is very long! Is she nervous or embarrassed? Is she a chatterbox? Is she so excited about her new love that she can\'t stop talking about it?\nTime - Juliet won\'t let Romeo finish his sentences! Poor Romeo! We already know how much he loves to speak! She is excited, but also worried about how suddenly they have fallen in love.\nJuliet\'s use of imagery seems more heartfelt than Romeo\'s: her love is as deep as the sea, and the sea never runs out. Romeo might argue though that he didn\'t really know what true love was until he met Juliet.\nTime - events happen very quickly in this play. {'text': 'The millions of types of living things can be organised into categories, where we group together organisms with similar features. This is called the classification system.\nVariation between individuals in a species can be continuous or discontinuous, inherited or environmental.\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': '> Preparing, planning and checking - Spelling\nIt\'s important that you check the accuracy of your spelling in your written work. Here are some common errors to watch out for:\nNot dropping the final "e" before adding "-ing".\nErrors in forming plurals in words that end in "-y".\nHomophones (words that sound the same but are spelt differently and have different meanings), like "to", "two" and "too".\nProblems with two vowels in the middle of words, such as ea, ou and ie\nProblems with words that we sometimes shorten when we say them, like "probly" for "probably".\nCertain words could also cause trouble, so look for any ways of remembering them. Sometimes the oddest ideas are the easiest to remember, like Big Elephants Can Always Understand Small Elephants, which gives us \'because\'. {'text': '> Variation and classification - Genetic engineering\nVariation in living organisms can also be created by\nUsing laboratory techniques scientists can alter the genetic code within the DNA of a living organism. They can add genes from a different species to an organism\'s DNA\nFor example, GM can be used to alter the DNA in a bacterium so that it produces insulin. This is a human hormone and valuable to people with diabetes. Bacteria reproduce quickly, so a lot of insulin can be made quickly and used to help people suffering from diabetes.\nSome people are concerned that there may be negative aspects to GM.\nFor example, there are people that believe GM is unethical and should be banned.\nOther people are concerned that there may be unexpected long term problems of using GM, producing changes that could not be reversed. Such changes could create new pathogens or "superweeds" by the GM organisms breeding with other species. This could cause the natural balance of living organisms in the environment to be upset.\nScientists, society and individuals need to think about the advantages and disadvantages of genetic engineering.\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "> Romeo and Juliet Summary - The end\nRomeo and Juliet Summary - The end\nMeanwhile, in Mantua, Romeo waits for news. A servant called Balthasar arrives and tells Romeo that he has heard that Juliet has died. Romeo decides to buy some poison. He plans to go to see Juliet's body where he will take the poison and die next to her.\nMeanwhile, Friar John explains to Friar Lawrence that the letter he wanted him to take to Romeo explaining the truth about Juliet didn't get delivered. Friar Lawrence decides to go to the tomb and wait for Juliet to wake up while he sends another letter to Romeo.\nThat same evening, Paris goes to Juliet's tomb with some flowers. He hears a noise and decides to investigate.\nRomeo pays Balthasar off and breaks into the Capulet tomb. Paris tries to stop him. Romeo begs him to leave him alone, but Paris thinks he is vandalising the tomb. They fight. Romeo kills Paris. Just before Paris dies he asks Romeo to place him next to Juliet's body. Romeo is sad that he had to kill Paris and takes him into the tomb to be near Juliet.\nWhen Romeo sees Juliet lying in the tomb, he can't believe that she is dead because she looks so beautiful. He hugs her and kisses her. He takes the poison then kisses her again and dies.\nFriar Lawrence finds the bodies of Paris and Romeo just as Juliet is about to wake up. Juliet wakes up and asks the Friar where Romeo is. He hears a noise and begs Juliet to come away with him, but when she finds out that Romeo is dead, she refuses to go with him. Friar Lawrence runs away.\nJuliet tries to kiss the poison off Romeo's lips. His lips are still warm, but there is not enough poison left on them to kill her. She takes his dagger and stabs herself.\nSome watchmen discover the bodies outside the tomb. They also find the Friar who is crying and shaking. Prince Escalus and Juliet's mother and father arrive with Romeo's father. Friar Lawrence tells them all the truth about the wedding and their children's deaths. He feels so guilty that he asks the Prince to punish him, but Prince Escalus won't because the Friar is a holy man. Prince Escalus blames Montague and Capulet, but he also blames himself for not doing enough to stop the violence. Capulet and Montague decide to end their rift. Montague offers to have a statue of Juliet made. The play ends as the Prince says that this is the saddest story ever told.\nRead the full text online and make your own notes.\nUp for a challenge? {'text': "The environment, the Earth and the universe\n> Astronomy and space science - Gravitational forces\nAstronomy and space science - Gravitational forces\nAll objects are attracted towards each other by a force called\n. Gravity only becomes noticeable when there is a really massive object like a star, planet or moon. You can find out more about gravity in the Revision Bite called\nGravitational forces between the Sun and planets keep the planets in\naround the Sun. Without these forces, the planets would fly off into deep space.\nTheir orbits are slightly squashed circles called\n. Diagrams often show the orbits as very squashed, but this is just to get a sense of perspective and to fit the diagrams onto the page.\nThe planets furthest out are also the coldest because they receive the least heat energy from the Sun.\ntake more time to complete an orbit\nFor example, Mercury, the closest planet to the Sun, takes just 88 Earth days to complete an orbit. But Neptune, the furthest out, takes 164 Earth years to complete an orbit.\nThe graph shows the distances of the planets from the Sun and the time it takes them to orbit once around it. The shape of the curve shows that the further out a planet is the longer it takes to orbit the Sun.\nMore from The environment, the Earth and the universe\nTry an activity that's out of this world!\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': '> Measures of average - The mode\nThe mode is the only average that can have more than one value.\nWhen finding the mode, it helps to order the numbers first.\nFind the mode of each of the following sets of numbers:\na) 3, 7, 1, 3, 4, 8, 3\nb) 2, 7, 2, 1, 4, 7, 3\na) Start by placing the numbers in order:\n1, 3, 3, 3, 4, 7, 8\nThe number 3 occurs most often so the mode is\nb) Start by placing the numbers in order:\n1, 2, 2, 3, 4, 7, 7\nThe numbers 2 and 7 occur more often than all other numbers so the modes are\nIn this frequency table, the mode is the value with the highest frequency:\nIn this example the modal shoe size is 7, because more people take size 7 than any other size.\nHow mean are you? {'text': '> Explore, imagine and entertain - Original words\nExplore, imagine and entertain - Original words\nA sunny beach gives you all sorts of possibilities to use your senses. For instance:\nThe shouts of excited children mingled with the screams of seagulls and the soft roar of breakers on the sandy beach\n. I looked down the beach towards the blue sea criss-crossed by the white triangles of sails\n. The hot sun burned down onto my back and neck\n, and the air was heavy with the smells of suntan oil, sea salt and ice cream\n. I could taste the vinegary tang of chips even before I found the busy fish and chip shop\nYou don\'t want to overdo the senses, but they are a useful way of making your writing more interesting. Another way of doing this is to look for more original words and phrases to write something that is fresh, not stale.\nAvoid clichés. These are phrases that are used so much that they have lost their power. For instance, if you are "over the moon" about something, or "waiting until the cows come home", then you are using clichés. Look for original phrases instead.\nHow could you improve the following sentences?\n1) He was scared out of his skin.\n2) The trees danced in the breeze.\n3) She felt that her heart would break.\n1) He felt his fingers uncontrollably tighten and clench together so that his nails dug deep into his palms.\n2)The wind gradually got stronger and they could see the leaves on the top branches swirling rhythmically, rising and falling.\n3) She knew that she wouldn\'t be able to speak or even look at him, and she kept blinking back the tears.\nHopefully, you\'ll find these second versions more accurate, creative and involving. {'text': "> Number patterns - Exploring number patterns\n2, 6, 10,... is a number pattern that follows the rule 'add 4'.\nThe next number is 10 + 4 = 14\n81, 27, 9, .... is a number pattern that follows the rule 'divide by 3'.\nThe next number is 9 รท 3 = 3\n5, 8, 14, ... is a number pattern that follows the rule 'subtract 1, multiply by 2'.\nThe next number is (14 -1) ร\x97 2 = 26\nEach number in a number pattern is called a term. So in the number pattern 2, 6, 10 ... the first term is 2, the second term is 6 and the third term is 10.\nWrite down the rule and the next two terms in the number pattern: 2, 4, 8,... Then check your answer.\nThe rule is 'multiply by 2' and the next 2 terms are 16 and 32.\nLook at how patterns change from one term to another. See what rule gets you from the 1st term to the 2nd term, then check the same rule gets you from the 2nd term to the 3rd term.\nIf it doesn't, find a different rule to get to the 2nd number and then check that it gets you to the 3rd number.\nFollow the rules and try this activity!\nUse your knowledge to help Spherox find his way home.\nGo back to basics with KS2 Bitesize.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': '> Atmosphere and setting - Test Bite\nRay, the main character in this extract, has stolen a motorbike and caused an accident that killed someone. He has told nobody, but knows that he can\'t hide for much longer. He is about to get on a bus, but realises that the one person who can link him to the crime is the conductor of that very bus. Before he can run off, he bumps into Mrs Fitzroy, his best friend\'s mum.\nAnswer the question below and then check your ideas against ours. Write one paragraph for each bullet point.\nHe hung back, groping wildly for some excuse to prevent him getting on, but the bell rang and the engine increased its impatient rumble and his legs carried him upwards on to the platform, and he felt Mrs Fitzroy clamber on behind. The bus began to move. He turned towards the stairs, but she caught hold of his arm.\n"Let\'s go downstairs. I don\'t like the smoke." Again he felt her hand guide him, and he ducked his head and began to walk along the aisle. "Yeah".\n"This\'ll do," she said, and he turned back and sat beside her - the less fuss he made, the less obvious he was, the better. As he settled, he kept his face bent low, aware of the conductor walking towards them. He brushed past, and, noticing things with a total clarity, Ray saw the dark blue uniform that he was wearing and noted the heaviness and thickness of the material. He heard him clumping up the stairs, and he wondered, absurdly, if he was wearing heavy boots, too.\nMrs Fitzroy was opening the bag which she had on her lap, and Ray felt in his pocket for his fare. If he had the right change, he could just hand it to the conductor without looking up. Yes, he had a ten and two pence piece. He glanced at Mrs Fitzroy and saw to his dismay that she was taking out a pound-note from her purse. That would mean a delay while she got her change - plenty of chance for him to be recognised. Could he offer to pay her fare? It would seem strange, but anything was better than being seen.\nWhat kind of atmosphere does the writer create in this extract and how do they do it?\nRay\'s thoughts and actions as he gets on the bus\nhow the writer uses language to create the atmosphere.\nIn this text, the writer creates an atmosphere of fear and tension. Ray\'s thoughts and actions at the start of the passage show that he is under a lot of pressure. He tries to think of an excuse to \'prevent him getting on\' the bus, but knows that this will just make Mrs Fitzroy suspicious. When he tries to go upstairs, she insists they stay downstairs. Nothing seems to be going his way, and this leads us to believe he may well be spotted by the conductor.\nAs the conductor approaches, Ray\'s fears increase which creates more tension. He keeps his face \'bent low\' to avoid being recognised, and also notices things \'with a total clarity\'. This shows that he is very scared and alert, ready for something to go wrong. When he realises Mrs Fitzroy has no change, he feels \'dismay\'. The reader is kept on the edge of their seat waiting for the conductor to come along.\nThe writer uses language, as well as events, to create tension. The phrase \'groping wildly for some excuse\' shows Ray\'s panic and gives the impression that he feels he has no control over events. The way he notices the \'heaviness\' of the conductor\'s uniform, and wonders if he was \'wearing heavy boots as well\' might mean that he is afraid of the man. Ray asks himself \'Could he offer to pay her fare?\'. This shows he is tense; he is running through possibilities in his mind. The writer uses Ray\'s fears to create an atmosphere of tension for the reader.\nMore from Atmosphere and setting - Test Bite:\nWhat does it all mean? Find out with this activity.\nLove books? Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n', 'label': '4'}
{'text': "> Reproduction - The female reproductive system\nThe female reproductive system contains these parts:\nThe two ovaries contain hundreds of undeveloped female sex cells called\n. Women have these cells in their bodies from birth - whereas men produce new sperm continually.\n. The egg tube is lined with\n, which are tiny hairs on cells. Every month, an egg develops and becomes mature, and is released from an ovary. The cilia waft the egg along inside the egg tube and into the uterus.\n. It is a muscular bag with a soft lining. The uterus is where a baby develops until its birth.\nis a ring of muscle at the lower end of the uterus. It keeps the baby in place while the woman is pregnant.\nis a muscular tube that leads from the cervix to the outside of the woman's body. A man's penis goes into the woman's vagina during sexual intercourse. {'text': "> Energy transfer and storage - Thermal energy transfer\nEnergy transfer and storage - Thermal energy transfer\nWhen a substance is heated, its particles gain energy and vibrate more vigorously. The particles bump into nearby particles and make them vibrate more. This passes the thermal energy through the substance by\n, from the hot end to the cold end.\nThis is how the handle of a metal spoon soon gets hot when the spoon is put into a hot drink.\nSubstances that allow thermal energy to move easily through them are called conductors. Metals are good conductors of thermal energy.\nallow thermal energy to move through them easily are called\nThe particles in liquids and gases can move from place to place.\nhappens when particles with a lot of thermal energy in a liquid or gas move, and take the place of particles with less thermal energy. Thermal energy is transferred from hot places to cold places by convection.\nIn order to see this content you need to have both\n. The hotter an object is, the more infrared radiation it gives off.\nNo particles are involved in radiation, unlike conduction and convection. This means that thermal energy transfer by radiation can even work in space, but conduction and convection cannot.\nRadiation is how we can feel the heat of the Sun, even though it is millions of kilometres away in space.\nInfrared cameras give images even in the dark, because they are detecting heat, not visible light.\nConduction and convection need moving particles to transfer the thermal energy, but radiation does not.\nCan you match Viral Vinnie's appetite for English, Maths and Science?\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. While you will be able to view the content of this page in your current browser, you will not be able to get the full visual experience. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n", 'label': '4'}

{'text': "> The Tempest first key extract - Performance\nThe Tempest first key extract - Performance\nWhen you talk about the performance of a play, you should think about how people in the audience feel as they watch it. For instance, the beginning of the first extract is magical and romantic. The tone changes in the middle to one of conflict.\nProspero has lots of asides (thoughts spoken aloud) in the first extract. His role in this scene is made more complex because his character is pretending to be something he is not. The director has to decide whether he wants us to see Prospero as a good father who wants the best for his daughter or a manipulative control freak.\nProspero also speaks to Ariel who is invisible to the other characters on the stage.\nWhen Ariel appears, the director must decide how to present the 'illusion'. Ariel is invisible to the other characters. But it does not necessarily follow that he must be invisible to the audience, too. Try to imagine as many interesting and unusual ways to present Ariel - the 'invisible' sprite - as you can.\nWhen you write about performance, you need to mention the tone or feeling you get at a particular point in the play, and the effect it might have on the audience.\nYou can find evidence for your ideas in the four question areas:\nThe characters and how you respond to them\nThe language used - the detail about freedom and slavery, for example\nThe issues and ideas - like love, magic and power\nThe performance instructions, such as stage directions\nMore from The Tempest first key extract:\nUp for a challenge? Head to GCSE Bitesize.\nGet creative, go backstage and find drama tips and inspiration.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "> Number patterns - Number patterns in diagrams\nNumber patterns - Number patterns in diagrams\nA number pattern in a diagram often requires counting shapes to find the rule. Again, look at how the pattern grows from one term to the next.\nPattern 1 has 0 orange tiles and 3 blue tiles, so 3 tiles altogether\nPattern 2 has 1 orange tiles and 5 blue tiles, so 6 tiles altogether\nPattern 3 has 2 orange tiles and 7 blue tiles, so 9 tiles altogether\nQ1. Write the rule and the fourth terms for:\nPattern 4 has 3 orange tiles and 9 blue tiles, so 12 tiles altogether\na) The rule for the number pattern of orange tiles is 'add 1' and the 4th term is 3.\nb) The rule for the number pattern of blue tiles is 'add 2' and the 4th term is 9.\nc) The rule for the number pattern of all tiles is 'add 3' and the 4th term is 12.\nFollow the rules and try this activity!\nUse your knowledge to help Spherox find his way home.\nGo back to basics with KS2 Bitesize.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "> Food chains - Pyramids of numbers\nThe population of each organism in a food chain can be shown in a sort of bar chart called a pyramid of numbers. The more organisms there are, the wider the bar. The producer in the food chain always goes at the bottom of the pyramid of numbers.\nClover is a plant and it is the producer in this food chain. Its bar goes at the bottom of the pyramid:\nEnergy is lost to the surroundings as we go from one level to the next, so there are fewer organisms at each level in this food chain. A lot of clover is needed to support the snail population. A thrush eats lots of snails, and a hawk eats lots of thrushes, so the population of hawks is very small.\nSometimes the pyramid of numbers doesn't look like a pyramid at all. This could happen if the producer is a large plant such as a tree, or if one of the animals is very small. Remember, though, that whatever the situation, the producer still goes at the bottom of the pyramid.\nAn oak tree is very large so many insects can feed on it\nFleas are very small and lots of them can feed on a rabbit\nHungry for knowledge? {'text': '> Formal and informal writing - The writer\'s "voice"\nFormal and informal writing - The writer\'s "voice"\nWe all have different ways of expressing ourselves in our speech and in our writing. In writing, this is sometimes called voice.\nGood writers have a unique voice or style of writing.\nHere are two very different styles of writing:\nI suppose I could tell you all about where I was born, what it was like when Mum was still around, what happened when I was a little kid, all that kind of stuff, but it\'s not really relevant.\nMy father\'s family name being Pirrip, and my Christian name Philip, my infant tongue could make of both names nothing longer or more explicit than Pip.\nCan you guess which line is from Charles Dickens\'s novel Great Expectations and which one is from Kevin Brooks\'s novel Martyn Pig?\nCharles Dickens\'s voice is very different to Kevin Brooks\'s voice. {'text': "> Inequalities and Simultaneous Equations - Inequalities\nIn an equation the '=' sign means that the two sides are identical. But what happens when the two sides are not identical?\nIf this is the case you need to use inequalities to show the relationship between the two sides.\nFor example, if x > 2, then x = 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, ... (x is greater than, but not equal to 2, so don't include the 2).\nIf y is ≤ 4, then y = 4, 3, 2, 1, 0, -1, ... (y is less than or equal to 4, so do include the 4).\nIf z ≥ 3, what are the possible values of z?\n3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, ...\nz is greater than or equal to 3, so it can be 3 and any number greater than 3.\nUse your knowledge to help Spherox find his way home.\nUp for a challenge? {'text': "> Constructing triangles and bearings - Bearings\nSuppose you were in the middle of nowhere, and there were no signs or landmarks to help you find your way. Would you know how to find your way home? Someone might tell you via phone or radio to 'walk to your left', or 'turn through 60° and then start walking', but how would they know which way you were pointing in the first place?\nOne way of describing direction from a point is to use\nA compass always points north. Bearings are measured from the\nSo when someone tells you to walk on a bearing of 120°, you should face north, turn clockwise through 120° and start walking.\nThe angle between the north line and the flight path of the aeroplane is 30°. We say that the aeroplane is flying on a bearing of 030° from Heathrow Airport.\nClick 'Play' to see the direction change in the diagram below. Click 'Pause' to see the bearing.\nIn order to see this content you need to have both\nBearings are always described using three figures. So for less than 100° put an appropriate number of 0s in front. Eg 020°, 037°, 002°, 007°.\nJoin Questionaut's quest to find his friend's hat.\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "Liquids and gases do not have a fixed shape. They can flow and fill their containers, but solids cannot. The particle model explains why.\nSolids cannot flow because their particles are only able to vibrate and cannot move from place to place.\nLiquids can flow because their particles can move over each other. When water is poured into a glass, the particles of water move over each other and into the corners of the glass. The particles keep on moving over each other as the water takes the shape of the glass. The animation shows how this works.\nIn order to see this content you need to have both\nGases can flow because their particles can move in all directions. When a Bunsen burner is connected to a gas tap and turned on, natural gas flows through the rubber tubing. The particles of natural gas are free to move anywhere inside the tubing, and pressure forces them through the tubing into the Bunsen burner.\nHow strong is your bond with Bitesize?\nCan you match Viral Vinnie's appetite for English, Maths and Science?\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "> Compounds and mixtures - The reactivity series\nCompounds and mixtures - The reactivity series\nMagnesium burns very brightly when heated in air\nSome metals are very unreactive. That means they do not easily take part in chemical reactions. For example platinum does not react with oxygen in the air, even if it is heated in a Bunsen burner flame.\nSome metals are very reactive. They easily take part in chemical reactions to make new substances.\nMagnesium is like this. If it is heated in a Bunsen burner, it ignites and burns with a brilliant white flame.\nThe reactivity series for some common metals\nOther metals may be more reactive than magnesium, or in between magnesium and platinum. If we put the metals in order of their reactivity, from most reactive down to least reactive, we get a list called the\nIf you want to learn the reactivity series, you could try making up a mnemonic or silly sentence to help. Here's one - can you do better?\nHow will you react to this activity?\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "> Formal and informal writing - Formal Language\nFormal and informal writing - Formal Language\nUsing formal language doesn't mean that you have to sound boring, you can still use words imaginatively in formal writing. News reports use formal language, but the words are rich and stimulating to keep the audience interested.\nQ1. The two sentences below both use formal language to give us the same information. Which sentence do you think is best and why?\na) The bomb broke the windows of nearby buildings.\nb) The blast shattered the windows of nearby buildings.\nQ2. Which of the following should NOT use formal language?\nb) A letter to the local paper\nc) A speech to teachers or parents\nd) A newspaper article aimed at adults\nA1. Sentence b is better. Blast and shattered are far more descriptive than bomb and broke.\nA2. Example a) should not be written with formal language. You wouldn’t use formal language when writing to a close friend.\nTips for making your writing more formal\nMake your writing clear and to the point.\nInclude some complex sentences in your writing. Try using semi-colons if you feel confident about using them correctly.\nIt's good to use figurative language if you think it fits in with the purpose and audience of the task. Metaphors and similes work well in speeches.\nDon't use 'Well' or 'You know' or 'Anyway' or 'Like I just said' or any phrase that sounds like you are having a friendly chat.\nAvoid using: 'And', 'But', 'Because' or 'So' at the beginning of a sentence.\nWords like 'nice' and 'a lot' have no power. Try to think of more descriptive words eg 'delicious' or 'endless'.\nClichés are colourful phrases that people use all the time in speech. So often, in fact, that they seem worn out and boring in writing. Avoid phrases such as 'pretty as a picture', 'big as a house', 'skinny as a rake'.\nJoin Questionaut's quest to find his friend's hat.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "> Collecting and recording data - Continuous data\nCollecting and recording data - Continuous data\n. Examples include time, height and weight.\nBecause continuous data can take any value, there are an infinite number of possible outcomes. So\nbefore it can be represented in a frequency table or statistical diagram.\nWhen choosing groups for the data, make sure that each piece of data can be placed in one (and only one) of the groups.\nYou are investigating the length of time each member of a class spends on the internet per week. Look at the class groupings below - do you think they are right?\n, because the times of '10 hours' and '20 hours' can be entered into two different groups.\nFor example, the time 10 hours can be entered into 0 ≤ time ≤10 (where time is less than or equal to 10 hours), and also into 10 ≤ time ≤ 20 (where time is more than or equal to 10 hours).\n, because the times '10 hours' and '20 hours' cannot be entered into any of the groups.\nFor example, the time 10 hours can neither be entered into 0 < time < 10 (where time is less than 10 hours), nor can it be entered into 10 < time < 20 (where time is more than 10 hours).\n'10 hours' is included in the second group, but not the first and '20 hours' is included in the third group, but not the second.\nDoes everything tally up? {'text': "> Food chains - Respiration in plants\nAll living things get the energy they need to live from a chemical reaction called\n. This process needs glucose as a starting point. First we'll see how respiration works, and then look at how plants use respiration in combination with photosynthesis.\nis the chemical reaction used to release energy from glucose. It is called aerobic because oxygen from the air is also needed.\nHere is the word equation for aerobic respiration. Energy is put in brackets because it not a substance:\nNotice that the word equation for respiration is the reverse of the word equation for photosynthesis. Check back if you are not sure of this.\nPlant cells respire, just as animal cells do. If they stop respiring, they will die. Remember that respiration is not the same as breathing, so take care - plants do not breathe.\nAs we can see from the word equations respiration and photosynthesis are opposites. Respiration uses oxygen and produces carbon dioxide. Photosynthesis uses carbon dioxide and produces oxygen.\nSo what happens to a plant overall? This depends on whether it is in the dark or the light, and how bright the light is.\nPlants respire all the time, whether it is dark or light. They photosynthesise only when they are in the light.\nNeither gas is taken in or given out, as each cancels the other out\nPhotosynthesis usually results in a net food gain (net glucose gain), once respiration has been accounted for. This means that there is an increase in the biomass of the plant.\nPlants that lose their leaves in winter store food produced during the summer by photosynthesis. They store enough food to last them over winter, and to provide energy reserves for new growth in the spring.\nHungry for knowledge? Prey on this activity.\nWhack and zap mad professors and aliens!\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "> The Tempest Summary - Prospero revealed\nProspero has Alonso, Antonio and Sebastian in his power. He has them imprisoned, with other survivors (except Trinculo and Stephano who are still with Caliban) in a trance, by his cave.\nHe tells Ariel to fetch them to him. He says that although it would be understandable if he took revenge on them, he would forgive them if they were sorry for what they had done to him.\nHe also tells Ariel that he will soon be free, and tells him he will miss him.\nAriel leaves to fetch the group. Prospero, alone, declares that he will give up his magic, break his magic staff and throw his magic books into the sea as soon as this business is over.\nWhen Ariel brings the men back, Prospero places them in a magic circle. After telling them off for the wrong things they have done, he releases them from his spell, so they can now wake up. In order that they will recognise him as they awaken, Prospero sends Ariel to fetch his Duke's clothing and sword.\nThe men slowly start to come to their senses. They recognise Prospero, but are amazed to see him in such a strange place.\nAlonso is very ashamed of what he has done.\nUp for a challenge? {'text': 'The extract below is about zombies. Note down your answers to the questions that follow and then check them against ours.\n"The eyes were the worst. It was not my imagination. They were in truth like the eyes of a dead man, not blind, but staring, unfocused, unseeing. The whole face, for that matter, was bad enough. It was vacant, as if there was nothing behind it. It seemed not only expressionless, but incapable of expression. I had seen so much previously in Haiti that was outside the ordinary normal experience that for the flash of a second I had a sickening, almost panicky lapse in which I thought, or rather felt, "Great God, maybe this stuff really is true...".\nThis is how William Seabrook described his encounter with one of the most horrifying creatures ever to step from the realms of the supernatural. For Seabrook was face-to-face with a zombie - a walking corpse. And in that moment he was prepared to believe all that he had heard about zombies since he first arrived on the island of Haiti.\nThe zombie\'s fate is even worse than that of a vampire or werewolf. The vampire returns to his loved ones. He may be recognised and laid to rest. The werewolf may be wounded and regain human form. But the zombie is a mindless automaton (robot), doomed to live out a twilight existence of brutish toil (animal-like labour). A zombie can eat, move, hear, even speak, but he has no memory of his past or knowledge of his present condition. He may pass by his own home or gaze into the eyes of his loved ones without a glimmer of recognition.\nNeither ghost nor person, the zombie is said to be trapped, possibly forever, in that "misty zone that divides life from death". For while the vampire is the living dead, the zombie is merely the walking dead - a body without soul or mind raised from the grave and given a semblance (appearance) of life through sorcery. He is the creature of the sorcerer, who uses him as a slave or hires him out - usually to walk on the land.\nFrom \'The Book of Great Mysteries\' edited by Colin Wilson and Christopher Evans.\nQ1. The writer chooses to begin the extract with a story based on someone\'s actual experience. Why do you think he did this?\nQ2. What is the effect of the two short sentences which open the extract?\nQ3. In the third sentence, why does the speaker use a list of three adjectives to describe the zombie\'s eyes?\nQ4. Why did Seabrook believe for a moment that he had met a real zombie?\nQ5. Which words tell you he did not really believe this?\nQ6. In the second paragraph, how does the writer use language to convince us that the zombie is a terrifying creature?\nQ7. Which other creatures are compared to the zombie in the third paragraph?\nQ8. Give two reasons why the zombie\'s fate is described as "even worse".\nQ9. What is the purpose of this text?\nA1. They did this to make the whole text sound more believable, and to add lively detail to the factual section which follows it.\nA3. They help the reader to build up a picture of the zombie, making the writing more dramatic.\nA4. He had seen \'so much previously in Haiti that was outside normal experience\' that he thought it might be a real zombie.\nA5. The words which tell us he didn\'t really believe this are: \'for a flash of a second\', \'panicky lapse\' and \'maybe\'.\nA6. The writer uses the phrase \'one of the most horrifying creatures ever to step from the realms of the supernatural\'. You might also have picked out the phrase \'walking corpse\'.\nA7. Zombies are compared to vampires and werewolves.\nA8. The zombie\'s fate is worse because it can\'t think, it can\'t return to human form, it is doomed to slave labour and it has no memory of its home or loved ones.\nA9. The text has two purposes: firstly, to inform us about zombies, and secondly, to entertain.\nMore from Writer\'s tricks - Test Bite:\nUse your knowledge to help Spherox find his way home.\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. While you will be able to view the content of this page in your current browser, you will not be able to get the full visual experience. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n', 'label': '4'}
{'text': "> Magnets and electric current - Magnetic fields\nMagnets and electric current - Magnetic fields\nBefore we look at electromagnets let's recap\nThey fill the space around a magnet where the magnetic forces work, where they can attract or repel magnetic materials.\nAlthough we cannot see magnetic fields, we can detect them using\n. The tiny pieces of iron line up in a magnetic field.\nIt would be difficult to draw the results from the sort of experiment seen in the photograph, so we draw simple magnetic field lines instead.\nthe field lines have arrows on them\nthe field lines come out of N and go into S\nthe field lines are more concentrated at the poles.\nThe magnetic field is strongest at the poles, where the field lines are most concentrated.\nMagnets and effects of electric current activity\nUse your knowledge to help Spherox find his way home.\nMore than 3000 video clips from BBC programmes.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled.
