{'text': 'A life cycle assessment, or LCA, can be used to assess the environmental impact of the manufacture and use of different materials and products.\nThe articles that we use have three main life stages: manufacture, use and disposal. A life cycle assessment, or LCA, is a study of the stages in the life of a manufactured product.\nPolymers have recycling symbols like this one for PVC to show what they are\nThe key features of a life cycle assessment include the following factors:\nthe environmental impact and sustainability of making the materials from natural resources\nthe environmental impact of making the product from the material\nthe environmental impact of using the product\nthe environmental impact of disposing of the product by incineration, landfill or recycling\nIt is possible to make a product from different materials, for example, a window frame can be made from wood or uPVC. The life cycle assessment for a product will depend on the material that it is made from.\nIt is possible to use the same material to make different products, for example, polythene can be used to make food wrap (cling film) or a bucket. The life cycle assessment of different products will be different, even though they are made from the same material.\nA life cycle assessment can be used to compare and evaluate the impact of:\nthe use of different materials for the same job\nthe use of the same material for different jobs\nRead on if you are taking the\nIt is possible to make a life cycle assessment of a material. The outcome of this life cycle assessment will depend on:\na consideration of the factors involved in the production of the material\na consideration of the factors that involve each of the products that are made from this material\n', 'label': '5'}
{'text': "Comets are balls of ice and dust in orbit around the Sun. The orbits of comets are different from those of planets - they are elliptical. A comet's orbit takes it very close to the Sun and then far away again. The time to complete an orbit varies - some comets take a few years, while others take millions of years to complete an orbit.\nComets have a range of different orbital periods and all leave a trail of debris behind them\nComets are often visible from Earth when they get close to the Sun, because the Sun's heat vaporises material from their surface, and this vapour forms a tail.\nAsteroids are rocky objects, smaller than planets. Most of them are found in an 'asteroid belt', in orbit around the Sun between Mars and Jupiter. The minor planet Ceres is found here, too. Asteroids can crash into each other. When they do, they may break apart and their orbit may change.\nThe orbits of some asteroids cross the Earth's orbit. At various times during the Earth's history, asteroids have hit the Earth. When this happened, a tremendous amount of energy was released, throwing up billions of tonnes of dust. This blocked heat and light from the Sun, making the Earth very cold.\nIt is thought that it was the collision of an asteroid with the Earth that helped to drive the dinosaurs to extinction. Scientists worry that an asteroid could still hit the Earth and cause a global catastrophe.\nFor an activity that is out of this world!\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. While you will be able to view the content of this page in your current browser, you will not be able to get the full visual experience. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n", 'label': '5'}
{'text': 'Named after the main character in a piece of work.\nheroine of the novel and all of the other characters are seen through her eyes. Characters such as Bertha Mason who are not seen by Jane are not encountered by the reader either.\nJane is the main character, and the story is told through her eyes. She is a strong character with a well developed sense of what is right. When she is small, this is revealed as a strong sense of injustice, which leads to the fight with John Reed and the final breakdown of her relationship with Mrs Reed.\nBecause the story is told through her eyes, we are allowed to fully understand the development of her emotions. Probably one of the most powerful scenes in the book is when she is with the dying Helen Burns. Helen\'s resignation and acceptance, combined with her religious faith, and the admirable role model of Miss Temple, are the big positives of Jane\'s time in Lowood.\nPerhaps one of the most attractive things about Jane is that she is not a\nA person regarded as self-righteous and arrogant.\n. She allows her feelings full vent. She resents Blanche because she loves Rochester so much, although that does not stop her from behaving as she should. But there comes a moment when she simply responds to emotion, when she is close to accepting St John Rivers: "I had felt what it was to be loved; but, like him, I had now put love out of the question, and thought only of duty." (Chapter 35.) It is at that point that she hears Rochester calling her from far away. While at the point of accepting St John, she appealed to Heaven for guidance, and the outcome was to send her back to Rochester.\nOur close relationship with Jane is an important element of the book. Remember the opening of the last chapter. Possibly the most famous line in the book emphasises our close relationship with the heroine: "Reader, I married him." (Chapter 38.)\nWhy does Mr Rochester marry Bertha Mason? In part, it is because he believes he is marrying an attractive woman. In part, it is to oblige his family by making a good marriage financially speaking. And in part it is because his father and brother, and Bertha\'s relatives, kept the madness in her family from him. While Rochester blames himself for falling for Bertha\'s superficial charm, he cannot forgive the betrayal of the deception. Even after his brother and father die, he is still trapped by the situation.\nIt is clear that he tries to hide from the reality of it, but when he meets Jane he sees her as extraordinarily different and refreshing. He falls deeply in love, but does not have the courage to tell her. He admits, after Mason has stopped the wedding, that he wanted to have her "safe" first, knowing her moral stance as he does. The fact that he was prepared to deceive her, even after his own experience, might suggest he needs a period of\nbefore the happy ending. What is never in any doubt is how much he loves Jane:\n"Oh, Jane! my hope - my love - my life!" (Chapter 27.)\nThere are, of course, a lot of other characters in the book. The best way to deal with them, given that the story is told from Jane\'s point of view, is to look at what they mean to her. This would be a good starting point in any character study.\nAdmirable role models: Helen Burns, Miss Temple.\nCruel, negative, but ultimately to be resisted: John Reed, Mr Brocklehurst; or outgrown: Mrs Reed.\nPositive characters: Bessie, Mr Lloyd, Hannah, some of the students at the village school, the good-natured farmer who gave her food when starving.\nNegative or weak, but lesser figures: some of the teachers at Lowood, Abbot.\nNegative pictures of the wealthy: Blanche Ingram and her mother, Mr Brocklehurst\'s family, Georgiana Reed.\nWarm, positive characters: Diana and Mary Rivers, Rosamond and Mr Oliver.\nObsessive and emotionally restricted people, though with a certain charisma: Eliza Reed, St John Rivers.\nSome of these characters represent challenges in Jane\'s journey through life. Some may have little impact, others are a support.\n', 'label': '5'}

{'text': "Making decisions on moral issues is not easy. Religion helps followers to make decisions that are pleasing to God and create a society where people respect and care for each other\nPeople draw on a variety of sources of authority to help them make a decision. For example:\nreligious leaders and the official teaching of their religion\nThere are two types of morality that affect the decisions people make – absolute morality and relative moraility.\nIf you believe in absolute morality you will have faith that there is a right course of action to take in a moral dilemma, which is true in all situations regardless of culture, religious tradition, time or age.\nHow would a follower of this sort of morality respond to the commandment ‘Do not kill’? They would try to make sure that they were not involved in any killing, which would affect their views on issues such as war, abortion and euthanasia. They would say that these actions are wrong in all circumstances.\nIf you believe in relative morality you would agree that different courses of action might be needed in different situations.\nHow would a follower of this sort of morality respond to the commandment ‘Do not kill’? They would agree that killing is wrong, but would look at a range of other issues as well and say that sometimes killing might be necessary in a particular situation, such as abortion, if continuing the pregnancy would result in the birth of a very disabled child, or if the mother had been raped.\nContraception or ‘birth control’ is used for a variety of reasons:\nwhen pregnancy might harm the mental or physical condition of the mother\nto limit the number of children people have to ensure they don't damage living standards or affect other children\nto prevent pregnancy in people who do not want a child at this stage in their lives\nContraception, including artificial contraception, is permitted in Judaism in appropriate circumstances.\nReform and Liberal schools of Judaism allow birth control for a wide range of reasons. Orthodox Judaism is more restrictive.\nThe methods of contraception allowed under Jewish law are those that do not damage the sperm or stop it getting to its intended destination. These are the contraceptive pill and the IUD.\nJudaism teaches that life is a sacred gift from God:\nThen God said, ‘Let us make man in our image, in our likeness, and let them rule over the fish of the sea and the birds of the air, over the livestock, over all the earth, and over all the creatures that move along the ground.’ So God created man in his own image, in the image of God he created him; male and female he created them.”\nSexual intercourse is seen as an important part of marriage. It is part of a husband’s duty and a woman’s rights. Judaism is generally opposed to contraception because of teachings such as:\nHe who fashioned and made the earth… he did not create it to be empty, but formed it to be inhabited…\nGod blessed them and said to them, ‘Be fruitful and increase in number; fill the earth and subdue it.’\nContraceptives are also thought to interfere with the physical union between a man and a woman:\nFor this reason a man will leave his father and mother and be united to his wife, and they will become one flesh.\nOn the other hand any restriction on the use of contraceptives can be lifted if the mother’s life is at risk in any way.\nAbortion is the artificial ending of the life of a foetus in the womb (uterus). A natural abortion is called a miscarriage. Abortion has been legal in England, Scotland and Wales since 1967 when The Abortion Act was passed. A new upper time limit of 24 weeks was introduced in 1990 under The Human Fertilisation and Embryology Act.\nAn abortion may be carried out if one of the following conditions applies:\nthe life or physical health of the mother is at risk\nthe mental health of the mother is at risk\nthere is a reasonable chance that the child will be born seriously disabled\nWhere the mental health of the mother is at risk, or her family will suffer if the pregnancy continues, the latest termination date is 24 weeks. There is no upper limit if the life or physical health of the mother is at risk, or if there is a reasonable chance of a seriously disabled child being born.\nIn 1974 119,000 legal abortions were carried out in England and Wales, by 2006 this figure had risen to 193,700.\nIn Judaism, abortion is thought to be worse than\nBirth control; actions, devices or medication intended to prevent conception.\nbecause it interferes with a potential life. However there are instances when it is permitted, particularly when the life of the mother is at risk. The decision must be taken by the mother. The later in the pregnancy, the more difficult it is to approve of an abortion.\nIt is clear that the life of the mother is more important than that of an unborn child:\nIf men who are fighting hit a pregnant woman and she gives birth prematurely but there is no serious injury, the offender must be fined whatever the woman’s husband demands and the court allows. But if there is serious injury, you are to take life for life.\nYour web browser does not have JavaScript switched on at the moment. {'text': "There are two main ways to clone animals.\nthe developing human offspring inside the womb\nis removed from a pregnant animal at an early stage, before its cells have had time to become specialised. The cells are separated, grown for a while in a laboratory, then transplanted into host mothers.\nWhen the offspring are born, they are identical to each other, and to the original pregnant animal. They are not identical to their host mothers, because they contain different genetic information.\nControls what happens inside the cell. Chromosomes are structures found in the nucleus of most cells.\nof an unfertilised egg with one from a different cell. The replacement can come from an embryo. If it is from an adult cell, it is called\n'Dolly the sheep' was the first mammal to be cloned using adult cell cloning. She was born in the UK in 1996, and died in 2003. Here is how she was produced:\nAn egg cell was removed from the ovary of an adult female sheep, and its nucleus removed.\nThe nucleus from an udder cell of a donor sheep was inserted into the empty egg cell.\nThe fused cell then began to develop normally, using genetic information from the donated\nThe material inside the nucleus of cells, carrying genetic information. DNA stands for Deoxyribonucleic Acid.\nBefore the dividing cells became specialised, the embryo was implanted into the uterus of a foster mother sheep. The result was Dolly, who was genetically identical to the donor sheep.\nThe cloning process of 'Dolly the sheep'\nFed up of reading? {'text': "When chemicals react with each other, different chemicals are made. One of the best ways to describe what is happening is by writing a chemical equation.\nA chemical equation tells you which chemicals reacted together (the\n) and the new chemicals that were made in the reaction (the\nThe simplest equation is a word equation. For example:\nA symbol equation gives more information about what is happening in the reaction:\nEach of the reactants and products is shown as a formula. This formula shows how many atoms of each element are present.\nThe formula for sodium is Na - the same as its symbol.\n, because the halogens exist as molecules of two atoms (\nEach of the Group 1 halides has a formula with one symbol for the metal and one for the halogen. So, for sodium chloride the formula is NaCl.\nThe numbers in front of the formulae are there to\nthe equation. This gives the same number of atoms of each element on each side of the equation.\nFor the exam you will be expected to know the following formulae:\nHalides of Group 1 metals - for example:\nHydroxides of Group 1 metals - for example:\nSometimes it is useful to know whether the reactants and products in a chemical reaction are solids, gases, liquids or dissolved in water. We can add\nto a symbol equation to show this.\nSo for the reaction between sodium and water, this is the symbol equation with state symbols:\nRead on if you are taking the\nLet's look at the steps you need to take when writing a symbol equation. We will use the reaction between sodium and water as an example:\nThe first step is to write a\nsodium + water â†’ sodium hydroxide + hydrogen\nThe next step is to write down the\nThe formula of sodium (and all other metals) is the same as the symbol,\nThe formula for a water molecule is H\nEach of the hydroxides of Group 1 metals has a formula with the metal symbol and OH for hydroxide. So sodium hydroxide has the formula NaOH.\nHydrogen is an element that exists as diatomic molecules, so its formula is H\nWe can now begin to write the symbol equation:\nthe equation so that it has the same number of atoms of each element on each side. This can be done by putting the correct numbers in front of the formulae.\n", 'label': '5'}

{'text': "All products have a limited life both for the consumer and the producer.\nThis Revision Bite will help you understand what the product life-cycle is and why it is important in marketing.\nWhen we buy a product we need to know how long it will last. Perishable goods, like fruit and vegetables, have a short lifespan. Durables like a car have a longer lifespan. Different products last for different lengths of time but their life-cycles have elements in common and follow this curve:\nThe product is tested and developed before it is launched. Initial sales will be low until the consumer starts buying. At this point, production costs are much higher than the revenue from sales.\nAs sales increase production becomes more profitable. The early development costs can be recovered. The success of the product can lead to\nChoosing and continuing to buy your favourite brand.\nCustomers returning to buy from the same business.\nThe product reaches its peak of sale and is at its most profitable point for the company. Competitors have now entered the market which may reach\nWhen the market is full of similar products it becomes difficult for a product to make additional profits.\nAs new models and designs come out, or fashions change, a product may become\nA product that is outdated or one which has been replaced by another.\n. Sales fall, as does revenue. It is no longer profitable to produce it.\nApplying the product life cycle to the marketing mix\nMarketing teams watch for changes in the business environment and react to them. They respond to consumer needs, the actions of competitors or government and use the following strategies during each stage of the product life cycle.\nTo make the target market aware of the new product it is important to heavily\nuse advertising and publicity to increase the sales of a product\nThis is usually a one-off price which is used as a promotionary tactic to gain customers attention and so to increase sales. Later the price will rise.\nAs sales and profitability increase, the selling price may be reduced to make the product more attractive. Continued advertising around the brand name will help to sustain sales. The marketing team may consider expanding its distribution, to reach more consumers.\nCompetitors will usually have entered the market at this stage. If their products are as good but cheaper the company may lose some of its market share. The pricing strategy must be reviewed. Marketers may also put\nonto their product, by offering accessories or insurance, for example.\nMarketing cannot save a product at this stage, but targeting a different and smaller segment can prolong its life.\nHard PC, a computer engineering company, has developed a new processor that is ten times more powerful than existing ones. Their product has sold very well, but is now passing from its growth stage into its maturity stage. Competitors have already entered the market. As a member of their marketing team, suggest two promotional activities Hard PC might use. Give your reasons.\nWhen you have finished take a look at the sample answers on the next page.\nMost exam questions in this subject are based on a case study that provides a setting for business theory. Look carefully at your case study to see what information is given about the product life-cycle. Think about the different stages and the marketing strategies that can be used.\nWe need to promote our product. I would suggest that we offer free accessories to increase sales. We could also try advertising our new promotion.\nJill's answer shows the right kind of promotional activities for this situation but not the reasons for them. This kind of promotion would not necessarily be used to 'increase sales'. She has also only given one reason. This answer would probably get an 'E' grade.\nThere is a lot of competition so we need to promote our product. I would suggest that we offer free accessories. This would make our product more attractive than our competitors' products. We could also try advertising to remind consumers about our brand and the new promotion we have on offer. This might encourage more sales.\nLuke's answer showed he understood the subject, and his reasons were good. He could have been more thorough, and used business terms. This answer would probably get a 'C' grade.\nThe market will soon reach saturation point because of competition. We therefore need to promote our product to lengthen its life. I would suggest that we try to add value to our product by offering free accessories. This is because we want consumers to find our product more attractive than our competitors' products. We could also try advertising to remind consumers about the existence of our brand and the new promotion we will have on offer. We may already have developed some brand loyalty amongst our customers so this might encourage repeat sales.\nTess's answer was very detailed, and she was able to apply her knowledge of business to the case study. She was able to use the correct terms, like saturation point, add value, brand loyalty. This answer would probably get an 'A' grade.\n", 'label': '5'}
{'text': 'We use a decimal point to separate units from parts of a whole (tenths, hundredths, thousandths etc)\nIn the number 34.27, the value of the figure 2 is a tenth, and the value of the figure 7 is a hundredth.\nWhen ordering numbers, we should always compare the digits on the left first.\nFor example, which is greater: 2.701 or 2.71?\nBoth numbers have two units and seven tenths, but 2.701 has no hundredths, whereas 2.71 has one hundredth. Therefore, 2.71 is greater than 2.701.\nAnother way to look at it is to write a zero at the end of 2.71 to make it 2.710 (this does not change its value, because it is after the decimal point).\nThe two numbers are now 2.710 and 2.701. It is quite easy to see that 2.710 is bigger (just as 2710 is bigger than 2701).\nLearn about the dark side of numbers!\nMake sure your maths skills add up.\nBBC World Service - Figure it out\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "A 'tropism' is a growth in response to a stimulus. Plants grow towards sources of water and light, which they need to survive and grow.\nAuxin is a plant hormone produced in the stem tips and roots, which controls the direction of growth. Plant hormones are used in weedkillers, rooting powder and to control fruit ripening.\nto help make sure they grow towards sources of light and water.\n– growth in response to the direction of\n– growth in response to the direction of\nResponses of different parts of the plant\nis a plant hormone responsible for controlling the\nof root tips and stem tips in response to\nof stems and roots. It's thought that light and gravity can interfere with the transport of auxin causing it to be unevenly distributed.\n3 groups of seeds are grown in a cardboard box.\n- when the tips are removed, no auxin is made so the stems do not grow\n– when the tips are covered, auxin moves to all parts of the stem causing all parts to grow\n- when the tips are lit from one side only auxin accumulates on the shaded side causing it to grow more than the illuminated side\nGive your revision some visual style with a Bitesize revision map!\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "In general, both types of company must\nAn independent check on the accounts of a company.\ntheir accounts, and have them available for inspection. There are, however, exceptions to this rule for smaller private limited companies. Both types of company must indicate their status in their name, usually by using the abbreviation PLC or Ltd. This lets traders know that their liability is limited and that debts cannot be recovered from the personal funds of the company\nIndividual investors who own part of a limited company.\nLack of capital due to no share issue.\nOwnership and control are closely connected, eg Board of Directors are usually the main shareholders.\nEconomy of scale means that big companies can produce things cheaper than smaller companies. There are two reasons for this. First, they can buy in bulk, so can negotiate with suppliers to pay less. Second, the more a company produces the lower the average cost per product will be of overheads (fixed costs, such as buildings). Where similar companies locate together as an industry they can also experience economies of scale. They share the costs of building the necessary infrastructure (eg roads, telecommunications) and the cost of educating the workforce, between them. Also the combined demand from all these companies should mean that supplies are cheaper.\nProcedures that damage efficiency, involving too much paperwork or 'red tape'.\nthan PLCs, eg decisions can be taken more quickly.\nThe relationship between the workers and the management/owners.\nBenefit from economies of scale, eg bulk buying, cheaper borrowing.\nConflict of interest between shareholders and the Board of Directors.\nPossibility of takeover or merger because shares can be bought by anyone.\nThe exam will give you an opportunity to show your understanding of real-life businesssituations. The examiner will want to see you using business terms correctly in your answers.\nGet down to business and discuss Business Studies here.\nLosing your way? {'text': "and guilt are also strong themes in\n. Duncan clearly values loyalty - he has the first Thane of Cawdor executed and rewards Macbeth by making him the new Thane. Shakespeare cleverly uses loyalty as a dramatic device as well - Duncan is in the middle of talking about 'absolute trust' when Macbeth walks in - we know he's already thought about killing Duncan, but for the moment he talks about 'the loyalty I owe' and his 'duties' to Duncan.\nLoyalty is also very important to Banquo - he will not desert Duncan. Macbeth, however, has an odd idea of loyalty - he knows he is doing the wrong thing, but he still goes ahead. Early on in the play perhaps it is his wife who is manipulating him, but later on it is Macbeth who makes the decisions. And later on he also starts to show he hates disloyalty, threatening his messengers and servants.\n- he is unsure before the murder and regrets it immediately after. Lady Macbeth is the opposite - she seems to show no guilt at the time and even talks about how 'a little water' cleans away the blood. Her increasing madness later on is a sign of her guilt and she imagines her hands to be stained with blood.\nThere may be other topics you can spot, such as violence, destruction and tyranny. It's good to include something about the basic ideas within\nin your own work. This will help you understand what the play is about, how it all fits together and how Shakespeare used ideas to frighten, shock and entertain his audiences.\nRead the full text online and make your own notes.\nGet creative, get published and get expert writing advice at BBC Blast.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': 'is an idea that runs through a text. A\nAny piece of writing. More widely, a text can be anything that conveys meaning - eg, a film, tv programme, advert, website, or image.\nA central, unifying idea that runs through a text or performance.\nor many. Understanding the themes makes the text more than \'just\' a story - it becomes something more significant, because we\'re encouraged to think deeper about the story and work out what lies beyond the plot.\n. Together, they help us to learn about the characters and understand why they act as they do.\nThere are various types of love explored in the play. From which characters do we learn about the different sorts of love?\nLove in \'A View From the Bridge\'\nBeatrice, Eddie and Catherine are first seen as a loving family.\nMarco loves his family deeply. He has come to America to help them. He misses them a lot.\nIn the wider sense, Beatrice loves her family in Sicily enough to support her cousins. Family ties are very important.\nEddie and Catherine, although uncle and niece, have become more like a father and daughter. Eddie made a lot of sacrifices to provide Catherine with the best education he could.\nMarco and Rodolpho have a strong bond - great enough for Marco to lay down his life for his brother\'s cause.\nEddie and Beatrice\'s marriage is obviously not as strong as it used to be: Beatrice asks,\n"When am I gonna be a wife again, Eddie?"\nThey have not slept together for months.\nCatherine and Rodolpho quickly fall deeply in love.\nEddie\'s love for Catherine has become sexual, even though he refuses to admit it. This is the cause of the friction in his own marriage and the dispute with Rodolpho and Marco.\nThe play shows us that love is not always beautiful - it is responsible for all the\nbetween the characters. It is a deep passion that can create jealousy and cause pain both to the person who loves, the person who is loved and those around them. For Eddie, love also causes conflict within himself when he cannot admit to his illicit love for Catherine.\nWhat do you imagine happens to the lovers Catherine and Rodolpho at the end of the play? Do they go on to find happiness? What about Beatrice?\nA dramatic composition written for performance by actors on a stage.\nare going to be important in the play in his opening speech. He sets the story that he is going to tell us in the\nThe factors surrounding a text which help us to understand it; the background events which help to explain something.\n"In Sicily, from where their fathers came, the law has not been a friendly idea since the Greeks were beaten.."\n"I only came here when I was twenty-five. In those days, Al Capone, the greatest Carthaginian of all, was learning his trade on these pavements, and Frankie Yale himself was cut precisely in half by a machine-gun on the corner of Union Street, two blocks away."\nThe fact that Alfieri goes on to state that lawyers in ancient times, as well as he in modern times, were unable to prevent a\ncauses us to question the power and influence of the law. In other words, although justice is very important, often the law as it stands is incapable of delivering justice.\nAlfieri believes that it is best to\n: it is better to rely on written law as far as possible and accept it even when you are only \'half\' satisfied. The written law may not always act in favour of justice yet it is better to follow the law than to take it into your own hands. In the play we see that Eddie betrays Marco and Rodolpho, there is no law to punish Eddie so Marco takes the law into his own hands, the play ends with a fight to the death. Alfieri reiterates his beliefs at the end of the play:\n"Most of the time now we settle for half and I like it better."\nAlfieri values the law more than justice, he sees that when people go against the law to assert justice it can lead to\nThe play encourages us to ask what is justice? What makes justice? Both Eddie and Marco have strong ideas of what is \'just\' and are prepared to go to great lengths to achieve it. The characters often mistake their own desires for justice, they fail to look for a higher principle of justice seperate from their own feelings, this is what leads to conflict.\nHere are some more instances in the play when\nThe story of Vinny Bolzano is an example of how someone obeying the law (as Vinny technically was when he informed on his uncle) is actually doing something unjust. Do you think the treatment of Vinny by his relations was just?\nAlfieri tries to warn Eddie about his relationship with Catherine and argues with him to allow her to marry Rodolpho.\nWhen the law is wrong it\'s because it\'s unnatural, but in this case it is natural and a river will drown you if you buck it now.\nHe is suggesting that it is Eddie\'s feelings for Catherine that are \'unnatural\'.\nEddie makes recourse to the law that he spurned when he telephones the Immigration Bureau. Eddie has no fixed principle of justice, his feelings dictate what he believes to be \'just\'.\nAlfieri tries to make Marco realise who is the real \'judge\' of events - God.\nBoth Eddie and Marco allow their personal feelings to affect their idea of justice. They are not strong enough to take an objective view. We see that Alfieri is right, people are not strong enough to execute true justice, their desires and feeling always take a part. This is why it is better to rely on the law, which although flawed offers an objective view.\nin the play and decide what ideas they contribute to the\nA central, unifying idea that runs through a text or performance.\nCentral, unifying ideas that run through a text or performance.\n. Eddie and Beatrice\'s tale of Vinny Bolzano at the start of the play sets the\nThe mood or manner of a text or part of a text. The author\'s \'tone of voice\' or way in which they expect to be understood. The emotional load carried by a text.\n"The family had an uncle that they were hidin\' in the house, and he snitched to the Immigration."\n"He had five brothers and the old father. And they grabbed him in the kitchen and pulled him down the stairs - three flights his head was bouncin\' like a coconut. And they spit on him in the street, his own father and his brothers. The whole neighbourhood was crying."\nIt is clear that, in the eyes of Eddie and Beatrice, Vinny had done something very wrong and was justly punished. Eddie is clear that Vinny will never be seen in the neighbourhood again out of shame:\n"a guy do a thing like that? How\'s he gonna show his face?"\nFamily comes first. To betray one\'s family is a crime and should be punished - Vinny gets no sympathy despite the injuries inflicted upon him: it was seen that he got what he deserved. It is ironic that Eddie does just the same thing as Vinny - \'snitch to Immigration\' - to Marco and Rodolpho at the end of the play.\nis shown to be very important, especially to the male characters. It means far more to them than the law. To be honourable is to be respected. If you do anything dishonourable, you lose respect. That is why Marco and Eddie are so keen to protect their names and get a \'just\' conclusion. Codes of honour bind families and the whole neighbourhood with a sense of community. Everyone should look out for one another, to betray someone is the most dishonourable action imaginable.\nHere are some examples of how honour works in the play:\n"It\'s an honour, B. I mean it."\nwhen they discuss the imminent arrival of the cousins.\nPerhaps one of the reasons why Eddie finds it impossible to admit his love for Catherine is because he knows how dishonourable it is.\nAlfieri warns Eddie that he will lose the respect of the neighbourhood if he betrays the brothers.\n"You won\'t have a friend in the world, Eddie!"\nIt is significant that a lawyer (whom we would expect to uphold the law) is encouraging Eddie to do something illegal by continuing to keep the brothers hidden.\nMarco believes the only honourable course is to punish Eddie when Eddie betrayed the brothers. Alfieri tries to persuade him otherwise:\n"To promise not to kill is not dishonourable"\n- but Marco\'s sense of honour it too strong. (It is interesting that Marco had given Alfieri his word that he would not harm Eddie, yet then does so: clearly, Marco\'s need for revenge is stronger than any fear about breaking a promise.\nEddie, however, blindly refuses to believe that he has done anything wrong. He desperately wants to get back his good name after Marco\'s accusations caused the neighbourhood to turn away from him.\nMarco\'s got my name - and you run tell him, kid, that he\'s gonna give it back to me in front of this neighbourhood, or we have it out.\nDo you think that Eddie dies an \'honourable\' death? He does not try to escape his fate - in fact, he encourages it - perhaps because he realised that he had no option.\n', 'label': '5'}

{'text': "Along a coastline there are features created by erosion. These include cliffs, wave cut platforms and wave cut notches. There are also headlands and bays, caves, arches, stacks and stumps.\nSeven Sisters chalk cliffs on the East Sussex coast\nOne of the most common features of a coastline is a\n. Cliffs are shaped through a combination of erosion and weathering - the breakdown of rocks caused by weather conditions.\nto create gently sloping cliffs. Hard rock, eg chalk, is more resistant and\nWeather weakens the top of the cliff.\nThe sea attacks the base of the cliff forming a wave-cut notch.\nThe notch increases in size causing the cliff to collapse.\nThe backwash carries the rubble towards the sea forming a wave-cut platform.\nThe process repeats and the cliff continues to retreat.\nBack to Coastal landscapes and processes index\nDeliver key Geographic sound bites direct to your ear!\nExplore the UK's coastline with the BBC.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': 'You should be able to calculate the cost of using an electrical appliance when given enough information about it.\ntransferred to an appliance depends on its power and the length of time it is switched on. The amount of mains electrical energy transferred is measured in kilowatt-hours, kWh. One unit is 1kWh.\nThe equation below shows the relationship between energy transferred, power and time:\nenergy transferred (kWh) = power (kW) × time (h)\nNote that power is measured in kilowatts here instead of the more usual watts. To convert from W to kW you must divide by 1000.\nFor example, 2000W = 2000 ÷ 1000 = 2kW.\nAlso note that time is measured in hours here, instead of the more usual seconds. To convert from seconds to hours you must divide by 3600.\nFor example, 1800s = 1800 ÷ 3600 = 0.5 hours.\nElectricity meters measure the number of units of electricity used in a home or other building. The more units used, the greater the cost. The cost of the electricity used is calculated using this equation:\ntotal cost = number of units × cost per unit\nFor example, if 5 units of electricity are used at a cost of 8p per unit, the total cost will be 5 × 8 = 40p.\nCheck your understanding of working out the cost of electricity by having a go at this activity.\nYour web browser does not have JavaScript switched on at the moment. {'text': "The popularity of Much Ado About Nothing\nis one of Shakespeare's best-known plays. There are all sorts of reasons for this, but perhaps the main one is that the basic story still strikes a chord with modern audiences.\nThe play is all about relationships between the sexes, and we meet two very different couples. One is exactly as we would expect a couple to be: they fall in love almost at first sight and appear ideally suited to each other. However, the man appears to be quite shallow and believes his wife-to-be has cheated on him. He leaves her, but is tricked into marrying her later on.\nThe second couple are not together as a couple at all. They spend most of their time insulting each other, and both swear they will never marry. However, their friends trick them into falling in love, which they do, and they get ready to marry at the end. One of the most interesting ideas in the play is that the traditional couple are perhaps not really in love, but the odd couple are.\nThe play contains two basic ideas which have been used in all sorts of films and stories. The first is that a couple have to overcome numerous obstacles before they can find true love. The second is that two very different people who start off arguing later fall in love, and everything ends happily.\nhas been filmed a number of times and adapted for stage in all sorts of ways. For instance, there are versions set during the Second World War, one in India, and even a version with references to the mafia.\nBack to Much Ado About Nothing index\nRead the full text online and make your own notes.\nGet creative, get published and get expert writing advice at BBC Blast.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. While you will be able to view the content of this page in your current browser, you will not be able to get the full visual experience. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n", 'label': '5'}

{'text': "Scene ideas where the victim is present\nMegan and her friends stop a younger student from moving away from them by positioning themselves around her. They threaten her and ask for her money. They take the money and her bag, throwing it on the ground. They walk away laughing. Megan looks back and the scene freezes. She speaks to the audience with a direct address, saying she wishes she hadn't done it, that she feels ashamed, that her parents would be horrified, and that she wants to make amends. Looking at her friends, she realises she can't do that at the moment.\nMegan and her friends stop a younger student from moving away from them by positioning themselves around her. They threaten her and ask for her money. They take the money and her bag, throwing it on the ground. The young girl looks up at the bullies, asking why they want to do this to someone smaller than themselves. The older girls all laugh - freeze. Megan stops laughing and turns to the audience, serious now. She remembers how the same thing once happened to her, and how she felt. She's always felt angry about it since it happened. She realises how the girl feels, and is ashamed. She looks at the frozen image of her friends and their victim, and says that she's not going to do anything about it now, but later she'll give the money back and apologise. She knows that she'll get into trouble anyway, as the girl will tell a teacher.\nThese scenes will need at least a couple more actors. They focus on Megan's regret, and the guilt she feels about being a bully.\nGet creative, go backstage and find drama tips and inspiration.\nGeneral Theatre Links - Theatre Studies: Articles and Resources\nGreek Theatre - Wikipedia: Theatre of Ancient Greece\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "For the D201 project, you are likely to have to produce two of the three types of screen-based publications - websites, information points and presentations.\nYou will probably be familiar with websites and presentations, but you might have to do a bit more investigation to find examples of information points.\nSpend a bit of time investigating screen-based publications and note what makes them effective - or not!\nA woman using a public information point: You might be asked to produce an on-screen publication for an information point\nThe crucial thing is to make sure that each publication you make is suitable for the intended purpose and audience.\nAs with other publications in the D201 course, you don’t have to worry too much about using all the advanced features of the piece of software you are using. The exam board is much more keen to see that you have thought about what you are doing and have produced a suitable solution. This will involve careful planning, testing and modifying of each product you develop.\nPlanning is a crucial stage in the development of screen-based media. The exam board may ask you to include evidence of your plan in your eportfolio. Look carefully at the\nto see if the planning stage has a tick next to it. If it does, it means you must include it in your project and it is probably worth spending a bit more time on it.\nThe standard ways of planning screen-based media are storyboards and navigation charts.\nYou could do the storyboard or navigation chart on paper, or onto a computer using different types of software. If you do it on paper, you may need to scan it in to get it onto your eportfolio.\nOther things to think about as part of your planning:\nSize and file format of your publication.\nPresentations and websites can get quite big if you start including lots of graphic and media files. Check carefully to see how much memory you are allowed to use.\nWebpages (htm) and Powerpoint files are normally permitted file types.\nIf you are using another type of software, make sure you are able to convert it into one of the allowed file types.\nFiles types allowed are listed in the\nA storyboard shows each stage you want to have on screen, one after the other. You would normally use a storyboard if there is just a single pathway through your product – for example, a simple slideshow that starts at Slide 1 and goes through to the end.\nYou can include pictures, text and descriptions to explain what you are trying to achieve. For example, you might want to describe some sound or music that you want to have, or the transition you would like to have between slides.\nBelow is an example of a storyboard for a School Parents' Evening presentation.\nThe more detail you include, the easier you will find it when you come to make the actual product.\nYour finished version does not have to be exactly the same as your original design:\nSometimes you will find better ways of doing something. For example, you may not be able to find the precise image you intended to use.\nDon't worry about changes. The storyboard is just a plan to guide you through the process. You will not lose marks for changes.\nUse your evaluation section to explain the differences between the storyboard plan and final version. Don't forget to include reasons why changes were made.\nA navigation chart is used when there is potentially more than one way to navigate through your product. For example, on a website each user may want to visit pages in a different order and on an information point, the user may want to view some sections and not others.\nA navigation chart starts with the main welcome screen or home page at the top and then shows the different ways a user can access the various parts of the product. There is no compulsory way of doing this. What is important is that you show you have thought about the best way to structure your product and how you are making it suitable for the intended audience.\nIn general, a navigation chart will contain less detail than a storyboard. A storyboard shows what each screen will look like, but a navigation chart shows the possible pathways between the screens. For the products you are producing, it may be sensible to put a bit more detail on your navigation charts, so that you have a design for each page you hope to produce.\nAdd notes to your diagram to explain exactly what you are trying to achieve. Explain the reasons for the choices you have made.\nAn information point is a set of screens that provide information on a particularly topic. You've probably seen information points in stations, airports, museums and places or interest.\nMake sure your Index page has links to all content.\nWhen you're designing an information point, it must be possible for the user to navigate to the information they want without having to scroll through all the other information. There must be a menu that provides links to all information.\nThis can be done in a Powerpoint-type slide show or by making a set of webpages. What you choose to use is up to you. Which do feel most comfortable with? Which lets you do the job in the way that is most suitable for the purpose and audience?\n", 'label': '5'}

{'text': "Shifting cultivation is a traditional, sustainable method of agriculture which has been practised by indigenous tribes for centuries. It occurs in areas of the Amazon rainforest, Central and West Africa and Indonesia. Along with other aspects of their culture and traditional way of life, it is under threat from large-scale clearance of the forests.\nA burning section of the Amazon in Para State, Brazil\nA small area of land is cleared and the vegetation burned, providing a source of nutrients from the ash.\nFor a few years the soil remains sufficiently fertile for the tribe to grow crops.\nWhen the soil's fertility is exhausted, the tribe moves on and clears another small area of forest.\nThe original area is regenerated, as it receives nutrients and seeds from surrounding vegetation.\nAs no lasting damage occurs, this method of agriculture is sustainable.\nIt is sometimes called 'slash and burn' agriculture.\nDeliver key Geographic sound bites direct to your ear!\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. While you will be able to view the content of this page in your current browser, you will not be able to get the full visual experience. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n", 'label': '5'}
{'text': 'Additives may be added to food for a variety of reasons. Some additives come from natural sources such as plants, whereas synthetic additives are manufactured.\nManufacturers use food additives to create products that people want to buy. They may also increase how long the food will last.\nThere are several types of food additive, each used in food for a different purpose.\nThese may be used to replace the natural colours lost as the food was processed. They may also be used to add colour to make the food product look more attractive. People buy food that looks nice.\nThese may be used to give food a taste that was lost in processing. Or they may add a taste to food that has very little.\nSweeteners are used to make food taste sweeter. Sugars are natural sweeteners present in many foods, but extra sugar can be added to make these foods sweeter. Artificial sweeteners, such as saccharin and aspartame, are many times sweeter than sugar. Very small quantities of these are used to sweeten ‘diet’ foods such as cola and yoghurt.\nEmulsifiers help to mix together substances which do not easily mix, such as oil and water. Stabilisers stop these substances separating again after they have been mixed.\nThese prevent the growth of microbes such as\nSingle-celled micro-organisms, some of which are pathogenic in humans, animals and plants. Singular is bacterium.\nor moulds in foods during storage. They give food a longer ‘shelf life’. Examples are sulfur dioxide in dried fruit and nitrites in bacon.\nThese prevent the reaction of chemicals in the food with oxygen in the air, which makes foods go stale. These reactions make fats and oils go rancid, giving them an unpleasant taste. They may also cause food to change colour.\nA food additive that has passed safety tests to allow its legal use in the European Union (EU) is given an E number. This system is used for both synthetic and natural additives.\nThere are four series of E numbers:\nE400 and over are emulsifiers, stabilisers and other additives\nFlavourings do not have E numbers, but they are controlled by other laws.\nThere are health concerns about the use of some additives that are allowed to be added to food. In most cases there is enough evidence to cause concern, but not enough to provide sufficient support for the additive to be banned.\nHere are some of the health concerns about additives:\nInvestigations carried out by scientists on laboratory animals have shown that some additives, when fed in large doses, are carcinogenic. This means they can cause cancer. This has not been shown in humans.\nIt has been suggested that some additives may cause hyperactivity and behavioural problems in children.\nSome additives have been associated with the increase in the occurrence of asthma in children that has taken place during recent years.\nabout a proposed ban on certain food colourings.\n', 'label': '5'}

{'text': "Sikhism: beliefs about care of the planet\nThe relationship between human beings and the earth is increasingly complicated and urgent. Every day there are stories about pollution, global warming and animal species facing extinction. Religion is responding with views on the enviroment and our responsibility for it.\nAlthough human beings are seen as the most intelligent life form on earth, they are responsible for almost all the\ndone to the planet. If we imagined the earth is aged 46, all the damage done has taken place in the last 60 seconds of the earth's life.\nSikhism is very concerned with the relationship between humanity and the environment. They believe that\nA Punjabi term used in Sikhism to refer to God.\ncreated the world as a place where every type of plant and animal could live so that all life could have the chance to prove that it was good enough to reach\n(liberation from the cycle of birth and death, reincarnation).\nNature we observe with awe, wonder and joy\nNature in the soil of the earth\nAll nature is yours, O powerful Creator\nYou command it, observe it and pervade within it.\nThe lives of the Gurus are full of stories of their love for nature. Sikhs are forbidden to kill for the sake of killing or to eat to excess.\nIn Sikh hymns Waheguru is said to be the provider of all life. There is no difference between the world of humans and the world of nature. Both of these are equally important and must be treated with respect.\nThe Gurus have strongly made us aware of our responsibility towards this earth.\nSikhs believe that the environment can only be preserved if the balance created by Waheguru is maintained.\nIn 1986, HRH Prince Philip, then President of the WWF International invited five leaders of five of the major religions of the world -\n- to meet to discuss how their faiths could help\nThe meeting took place in Assisi in Italy, because it was the birth place of St Francis, the Catholic saint of ecology. From this meeting arose key statements by the five faiths outlining their own distinctive traditions and approach to the care for nature.\nIn the Assisi Declarations on Nature the Sikh statement was:\nSince the beginning of the Sikh religion in the late fifteenth century, the faith has been built upon the message of the ‘oneness of Creation’. Sikhism believes an almighty God created the universe. He himself is the creator and master of all forms of the universe, responsible for all modes of nature and all elements of the world. Sikhism firmly believes God to be the source of the birth, life and death of all things.\nSikhism teaches that the natural environment and the survival of all life forms are closely linked in the rhythm of nature. The history of the Gurus is full of stories of their love and special relationship with the natural environment-, with animals, birds, vegetation, earth, rivers, mountains and the sky. There is also a very strong vegetation tradition.\nIt is for this reason that in Sikhism those who kill for lust of hunting, eating or to make sacrifices are condemned. In Sikh hymns God is often referred to as the provider for all life which God loves and is loved by. God as both father and mother guarantees equality to man and woman in faith and compassion towards all beings and nature.\nExplain Sikh teaching about caring for the environment.\nIn your essay you should have dealt with all the following:\nthe origin of Sikh teaching in the Guru Granth Sahib\nthe teachings found in the Sikh Declaration at Assisi\nYour web browser does not have JavaScript switched on at the moment. For information on how to enable JavaScript please go to the\nYou will not be able to see this content until you have JavaScript switched on.\n", 'label': '5'}
{'text': 'Discussing themes in your work shows that you are no longer just thinking about Hamlet as if it was a true story. Instead you are looking at the play and thinking about Shakespeare\'s choices. The four main themes in Hamlet are revenge, madness, deception and family and sexuality.\nLaertes challenges Hamlet to a duel to avenge his father\'s death\nis the initial motivation for Hamlet\'s transformation into anger and madness.\nIn Shakespeare\'s time, "Revenge Tragedies" were a popular form of entertainment for theatre goers. The Bible explicitly\nrevenge but human instinct often wants it.\nHamlet strongly desires revenge for his father\'s murder, but other concerns cloud the issue. For example, Hamlet has the chance to kill Claudius when he finds him apparently knelt in prayer. Hamlet hesitates because he fears that if Claudius dies while he is praying, he might go to heaven. Hamlet is determined that Claudius should go to hell for his betrayal and deception.\nabout the nature of the old King\'s death also confuses the matter. Hamlet feels unable to take revenge unless he is absolutely sure of Claudius\' guilt. Hamlet fears that the Ghost is not his father but an evil spirit sent to tempt him to Hell.\nLaertes\' sense of revenge is much stronger than Hamlet\'s and Shakespeare\nthe two. Laertes does not need to be convinced of Hamlet\'s guilt to take revenge. On hearing Hamlet\'s explanation for Polonius\' death, Laertes declares that he is\n. By this he means that he understands Hamlet\'s actions, but it does not stop him from fighting Hamlet in a duel with a poisoned and sharpened sword.\nAfter speaking to the Ghost, Hamlet decides to\n, meaning he is going to feign\nHamlet hopes that by pretending to be mad, he will be able to study the King\'s behaviour without arousing suspicion. Ironically, Claudius declares that\n"madness in great ones must not unwatched go"\nand Hamlet ends up being more closely watched than ever.\nHamlet\'s apparent madness also has the effect of\nhimself. Ophelia, in particular, suffers from this. She was once loved by Hamlet, but in his madness he frightens her and claims not to have ever loved her. There are different reasons why Hamlet may have done this:\nHis mother\'s unfaithfulness and incest could have caused him to lose trust in all relationships. His treatment of Ophelia is perhaps a sincere attempt to persuade her against marriage (\nOr perhaps Hamlet wants to remove any love from his own life to be in the right frame of mind to kill Claudius.\nOphelia is driven mad during the play\n. As a loyal daughter and would-be wife, the loss of her father and lover prove too much and she descends into madness. Perhaps Shakespeare wants to show the effects of a corrupt, disordered world on a pure and innocent soul. Some critics suggest that Ophelia\'s madness is a result of the pressure on a woman in a male-dominated world.\nboth have been apparently spurned by a loved one.\nOphelia, however, doesn\'t have the intellectual capacity to understand the corruption around her and she suffers terribly as a result.\nHamlet decides to pretend he is mad\nDeception causes many of the play\'s events. Claudius claims the throne from the old King by\nHis position is therefore false and this is what spurs Hamlet to seek revenge. However, the audience\'s knowledge of this murder comes from the spirit of the old King - and it is possible that the Ghost is\nof deception. He secretly desires revenge, and plots and schemes behind others\' backs. He feigns madness and puts on a play for the purpose of trapping Claudius.\nAs well as hiding his murder of the old King, Claudius is deceitful on other occasions:\nHe sends for Hamlet\'s friends, Rosencrantz and Guildenstern, to spy on his stepson and discover what he knows about the murder of the old King.\nAlso, he sends a letter to the English court to ask them to execute Hamlet.\nFinally, he plots with Laertes to poison Hamlet.\nNone of these acts of deception result in what the characters intend.\nHamlet\'s madness causes his beloved Ophelia\'s suicide.\nClaudius\' poison ends up killing Laertes, Gertrude and himself.\nHamlet is disgusted with his mother\'s marriage to his uncle and sees it as an act of\n. His revenge is motivated by the loss of\nOphelia is dominated by her father and brother\nwith his mother\'s infidelity. He insults her crudely and basely and fails to properly account for Claudius\' role in events. His cruel treatment of Ophelia seems to be the result of this loss of faith in his mother, rather than due to any fault on Ophelia\'s part.\nOphelia also suffers because of her family. She is\nby her brother and father, neither of whom show any interest in her true feelings.\nBoth Hamlet and Ophelia feel duty-bound to carry out their father\'s wishes and this bears heavily on them both.\n', 'label': '5'}

{'text': "Dickens also explores social class in Victorian England.\nPip starts off as a blacksmith's apprentice (honest working class), rises to be a gentleman, but ends up middle class - a partner in a trading company.\nMagwitch is a career criminal - a member of the lowest underclass - but makes a fortune in Australia.\nMiss Havisham is rich, but her father made his money as a businessman, brewing beer.\nJoe is a skilled craftsman (honest upper working class).\nOrlick works in the forge. He is a member of the lower working class, surly and dangerous.\nHerbert Pocket longs to be a middle class 'capitalist'.\nBelinda Pocket is 'out of her class'. She married beneath herself and is incompetent in her new role as mistress of a schoolteacher's house.\nPip sees that many of the people of 'high' social class have significant character flaws, and that people from other social classes are 'better' human beings. On the other hand, violent and surly lower working class people are to be feared and distrusted.\nDickens' message is that the middle class values of godliness, hard work, temperance and the gentleness of a 'gentleman' are - with sufficient income - the way to happiness. This message would appeal to his middle class/upper working class readership.\nRead the full text online and make your own notes.\nGet creative, get published and get expert writing advice at BBC Blast.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n", 'label': '5'}
{'text': 'When reading a non-fiction text, you need to be able to assess whether the information in the text is\n. You will also need to be able to comment on the writer\'s line of thought or their\n. This Revision Bite will help you to learn the difference between fact and opinion and how to follow an argument through a non-fiction text.\nOne useful question to ask yourself when you start reading a non-fiction text is how much use the author has made of\nSomething that is known or believed to be true or real; or something whose existence can be proved.\nA belief or judgement that is held by a person as the truth, but cannot be proved as true.\n. It\'s a basic difference, but one that examiners are interested in because it tells you whether a writer is trying to\nRecognising a fact from an opinion is not that difficult. But it isn\'t so much telling them apart that will get you the marks - it\'s whether you can say how the author has\nHave a look at this leaflet from the Vegan Society. As you read through it, try to find examples of\nThe views expressed in this leaflet do not represent the views of the BBC.\nLook at the example exam question below:\nHow is a mixture of fact and opinion used to influence your reaction to the first page of the Vegan Society\'s "Poor Calf/Poor Cow" leaflet?\nTo tackle this question, you need to identify\nin the leaflet and explain how the writer tries to\nyou towards a particular point of view.\nTo begin, it is important to make sure you know the\nBeing able to spot the difference between fact and opinion isn\'t always as easy as it sounds. It is important to be able to distinguish between them so you can make an accurate judgement on what you are reading.\nOn the front page of the leaflet, there are only two statements apart from the title - "Poor Calf\'.\n"Every year, hundreds of thousands of calves like this one are separated from their mothers within four days of birth."\n"Why? To satisfy our unnatural and unhealthy taste for cow\'s milk."\n, and the other is probably an\nDon\'t make it too difficult for yourself - just think: which statement could be proved to be true, and which could not?\n"Every year, hundreds of thousands of calves like this one are separated from their mothers within four days of birth"\nWhy? Because, even though the numbers are not supported by evidence, they\nbe. Even if they are not absolutely accurate (\nis a bit vague), it is certainly true that large numbers of very young calves are taken from their mothers.\n"Why? To satisfy our unnatural and unhealthy taste for cow\'s milk"\nwhether or not a taste for cow\'s milk is either unnatural or unhealthy. It\'s just a matter of\n, however strong people\'s feelings may be.\nof the reader initially is very important. Think how you might do this when writing a leaflet.\nNotice how, in the Vegan Society\'s leaflet, the fact comes first:\n"Every year, hundreds of thousands of calves like this one are separated from their mothers within four days of birth."\nNotice how the reader\'s attention is caught by the\nand then is led into and through the article. In this way, you won\'t be put off reading any further by immediately meeting an opinion you don\'t hold, but you\'ll probably be interested enough to read on.\nHow the reader responds to a non-fiction text is very important. The following techniques illustrate how the Vegan Society\'s leaflet has been designed to affect the reader\'s response.\nFacts are usually presented to readers in cold and objective language, but use of vivid or\nabout the information being given to you. This is\nDesigned to make the reader feel something strongly.\nThe fact in the first statement begins to work on your emotions.\nThis sounds an awfully big and uncomfortable number.\nUsing facts emotively softens you up for the emotive words in the opinion that come next in the article.\n"to satisfy our unnatural and unhealthy taste"\nThe use of the words \'unnatural\' and \'unhealthy\' is the\nof the author. There is no proof given in the article to back this statement up as fact.\nThe use of pictures is always important in getting a message across. Think about how effectively you may have seen them used in other campaign leaflets.\nYou can\'t really call a photograph a fact or an opinion - but the camera can sometimes lie, or at least put forward a particular point of view. Pictures are a very powerful way of stirring emotions and selling a product - just take a look at the covers of magazines next time you are in a newsagent.\nThe photo of the calf on the leaflet is\nin that it\'s of a real calf, but it\'s also\nbecause it looks sweet, appealing and frightened, and seems to be trapped in a grim little pen.\nNow that you know the power of fact and opinion separately, think about how and why you might use fact and opinion together.\nMixing fact and opinion is a very skillful way to present information to achieve a particular purpose. Think about the following statement.\n"The modern dairy cow is nothing more than a milk machine...milked 2-3 times a day."\n"The modern dairy cow is nothing more than a milk machine"\nA cow is clearly not a machine. This is an opinion expressed through very emotive language.\nThis is an uncontroversial fact and is used to support the opinion previously stated.\nNow that you know the difference between fact and opinion, we are going to look at how they can be used to form an argument.\n(leaving you to make up your own mind)\nRead the excerpt below, written by a journalist, from an article about the war on drugs. Can you spot the one sentence - the\n- which sums up what the paragraph is about?\nDrugs must be tackled at source. But what happens when a subculture becomes mainstream? People who talk about a "war on drugs" treat drug use as an alien, private minority activity that must be stamped out. Their war strategy aims to mobilise all possible social pressures and an array of agencies to isolate and destroy. Politicians, who want to appear tough on crime, are in the forefront of this process. They encourage police and schools to treat drug use - which in the majority of instances means possession of soft drugs - in a draconian, inflexibly judgmental manner. Police chiefs who advise against prosecution and teachers with doubts about expulsion are increasingly overridden.\nTopic sentences are the sentences in a non-fiction text that express the main ideas - or\n- of the text. They form the\nThe article about the war on drugs contains four core themes. Did you correctly identify the topic sentence in the paragraph that you read? It is:\n"People who talk about a \'war on drugs\' treat drug use as an alien, private, minority activity that must be stamped out."\nThe other three topic sentences from the rest of the text are:\n"The adequacy of this strategy can now be judged from yesterday\'s Institute for the Study of Drug Dependency report, Drugs Futures."\n"As the report says, what were once drug subcultures are now a mainstream part of the democratic market economy society. They have become the norm."\n"That does not make drug use right any more than the availability of tobacco or alcohol makes consumption of these substances right. But it certainly requires policymakers and enforcement agencies to adopt a more realistic approach to the changed drug experience of the modern age."\nSo what\'s left? Why not just write four sentences and leave it at that?\nWell, what\'s left are important elements of making a good argument -\nThe following techniques have been employed by the writer of the war on drugs article to form a sound argument.\nEach topic sentence is reinforced with a mixture of clarification and repetition of the main ideas. These add force to the argument to make it more powerful. This is the reinforcement in the first paragraph:\nTheir war strategy aims to mobilise all possible social pressures and an array of agencies to isolate and destroy. Politicians, who want to appear tough on crime, are in the forefront of this process. They encourage police and schools to treat drug use - which in the majority of instances means possession of soft drugs - in a draconian, inflexibly judgmental manner. Police chiefs who advise against prosecution and teachers with doubts about expulsion are increasingly overridden.\nIf you take clarification and repetition away, what\'s left is a big chunk of illustrative facts around which the whole argument is constructed - in this case, the findings of the special report, dealt with in the second paragraph:\nBased on a survey of 700 teenagers in north-west England aged from 14 to 16, it shows that for this age group the availability of drugs is a normal part of what the report calls "the leisure-pleasure landscape". The report finds that, by the age of 16, 76 per cent of the young people have been in situations where drugs were available or offered, and that 51 per cent had tried a drug at least once.\nWhen you remove the facts, all you have left is the conclusion - in this case, one that throws the argument open to debate:\nThe fact that Labour, though claiming to be modern, should adopt the completely opposite approach in its by-election propaganda in the north-west this week only goes to show how far we still have to go.\nIf you want to check how a writer makes a convincing argument:\nLook for sentences that illustrate or give facts.\nIn essay writing, the conclusion is the final paragraph(s) where an argument is summed up and the essay is brought to a suitable ending to leave a final impression on the reader.\nThere are four paragraphs in the article - corresponding to the four main stages of the argument.\nThat\'s not a coincidence. Paragraphs are there to guide you through to the main points of the argument. Use the divisions between them to divide your notes up when you do your first read-through.\nFinally, do make sure you look at the ending. This is a really useful way of helping you establish what the author\'s argument is if you find yourself getting lost in the body of the text. Here it\'s an open-ended,\n', 'label': '5'}
{'text': "Arguments about drugs are important because they can concern possible physical harm, or even the end of life, by human hands rather than by Godâ€™s will. Most religious teachings have something to say about using drugs.\nAll drugs are classed as either legal or illegal (illicit).\n'Illegal drugs' include heroin, cocaine, ecstasy, LSD and cannabis (these are divided into Class A, B or C depending on how addictive they are).\n'Recreational drugs' are drugs that people use for pleasure or relaxation. Most recreational drugs are illegal. However, alcohol and tobacco are legal recreational drugs. (Some religious people would include caffeine as a 'recreational' drug and would avoid its use.)\n'Prescription drugs' are those prescribed by a doctor to treat a medical condition, and are legal.\nAccording to National Health Service (NHS) reports (2007):\nIn 2005/06, 10.5% of adults aged 16 to 59 living in England and Wales had used one or more illicit (illegal) drug in the last year, a decrease from 12.1% in 1998.\n6.3% had used an illicit (illegal) drug in the last month, a fall from 7.1% in 1998.\nThe use of any Class A drug (like heroine) in the last year has increased, from 2.7% in 1998 to 3.4% in 2005/06, mainly due to a rise in the use of cocaine powder.\nMen are more likely to take illicit (illegal) drugs than women: 13.7% of men compared with 7.4% of women took illegal drugs in the last year.\nFor Class A drugs, the highest levels were found among those living in London.\nFor younger adults aged 16 to 24, drug use in the last year fell between 1998 and 2005/06, from 31.8% to 25.2%, whilst the use of Class A drug use has remained stable.\nPost ideas and discuss Religious Studies here.\nGet some direction with a Bitesize revision map\nUnderstand the beliefs of others and develop your own opinion.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': 'You need to be able to calculate the force involved in changing the momentum of an object. Here is the equation you need:\nThe force is measured in newtons, N. The time is measured in seconds, s.\nA 25 kg bicycle is travelling at 12 m/s. What force is needed to bring it to a halt in 5 s?\nMomentum at start = 25 × 12 = 300 kg m/s\nMomentum at end = 0 × 12 = 0 kg m/s\nChange in momentum = 300 - 0 kg m/s\nSo a force of 60N is needed.\nYou should see that, for a given change in momentum, the longer the time taken, the smaller the force needed. This is the idea behind many car safety features. It also explains why it takes a long time to stop a super-tanker at sea, or to change its direction.\nWatch this illustrated podcast on momentum to get a summary of how momentum and motion are related.\nIn order to see this content you need to have both\nGet some direction with a Bitesize revision map\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. While you will be able to view the content of this page in your current browser, you will not be able to get the full visual experience. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n', 'label': '5'}

{'text': 'We can also deal with language in\nby looking at the techniques Shakespeare used. Some of these techniques (and names) might seem difficult at first. If that\'s the case, just think about what the play would sound like if the technique was not used. For instance, when we meet the witches at the start, imagine that they said:\n"Thing\'s aren\'t what they seem, you know"\nWell, yes, it is easy to understand but it is not something unusual or interesting, and it doesn\'t seem to be something a witch might want to say anyway. So instead, they say:\n"Fair is foul, and foul is fair"\nSuddenly it\'s not so obvious what Shakespeare is getting at. This is also a lot more complex and interesting - opposing ideas are put together and the actual meaning seems to be a paradox - how can something fair be foul, and something foul be fair? Let\'s have a look at this next.\nRead the full text online and make your own notes.\nGet creative, get published and get expert writing advice at BBC Blast.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled.
