{'text': 'Not many people had real friends in the American West in the 1930s - it was a case of every man for himself. That is one of the reasons why the story of George and Lennie\'s unusual friendship is so poignant. They have each other. No one else in the novel is so lucky.\nHe is a small man, but has brains and a quick wit.\nHe has been a good friend to Lennie, ever since he promised Lennie\'s Aunt Clara that he would care for him. He looks after all Lennie\'s affairs, such as carrying his work card, and tries to steer him out of potential trouble.\nHe needs Lennie as a friend, not only because Lennie\'s strength helps to get them both jobs, but so as not to be lonely. His threats to leave Lennie are not really serious. He is genuinely proud of Lennie.\nHe shares a dream with Lennie to own a piece of land and is prepared to work hard to build up the money needed to buy it.\n"...with us it ain\'t like that. We got a future. We got somebody to talk to that gives a damn about us. We don\'t have to sit in no bar room blowin\' in our jack \'jus because we got no place else to go. If them other guys gets in jail they can rot for all anybody gives a damn. But not us."\nHe is honest with people he trusts. For example, he tells Slim that he used to play tricks on Lennie when they were young, but now feels guilty about it as Lennie nearly drowned.\nHe is a big man, in contrast to his name.\nHe has limited intelligence, so he relies on George to look after him. He copies George in everything George does and trusts George completely.\n"Behind him (George) walked his opposite, a huge man, shapeless of face, with large, pale eyes, with wide, sloping shoulders; and he walked heavily, dragging his feet a little, the way a bear drags his paws. His arms did not swing at his sides, but hung loosely."\nHe shares a dream with George to own a piece of land. Lennie\'s special job would be to tend the rabbits\nHe likes to pet soft things, like puppies and dead mice. We know this got him into trouble in Weed when he tried to feel a girl\'s soft red dress: she thought he was going to attack her.\nHe can be forgetful - George continually has to remind him about important things.\nHe is very gentle and kind, and would never harm anyone or anything deliberately.\nHe is extremely strong: he can work as well as two men at bucking barley.\nHe is often described as a child or an animal - he drinks from the pool like a horse and his huge hands are described as paws.\n(lead mule-team driver) at the ranch. He is excellent at his job.\nHe is the natural leader at the ranch. Everyone respects his views and looks up to him.\nHe has a quiet dignity: he doesn\'t need to assert himself to have authority.\n"there was a gravity in his manner and a quiet so profound that all talked stopped when he spoke. His authority was so great that his word was taken on any subject, be it politics or love."\nHe understands the relationship between George and Lennie. He helps George at the end and reassures George that he did the right thing.\nWe know little else about him, which gives him a slightly mysterious quality. Do you think he is too good to be true?\nCurley is the boss\'s son, so he doesn\'t need to work like the ordinary ranch hands, and he has time to kill.\nHe\'s little - so he hates big guys.\nHe is a prize-fighter and looks for opportunities for a fight.\n"He glanced coldly at George and then at Lennie. His arms gradually bent at the elbows and his hands closed into fists. He stiffened and went into a slight crouch. His glance was at once calculating and pugnacious."\nHe is newly- married and is very possessive of his wife - but he still visits brothels.\nThere is a rumour that he wears a glove filled with Vaseline to keep his hand soft for his wife.\nWe never know her name - she is merely Curley\'s \'property\' with no individual identity.\nShe is young, pretty, wears attractive clothes and curls her hair.\nShe seems flirtatious and is always hanging around the bunk-house.\nShe is lonely - there are no other women to talk to and Curley is not really interested in her.\n"What kinda harm am I doin\' to you? Seems like they ain\'t none of them cares how I gotta live. I tell you I ain\'t used to livin\' like this. I coulda made somethin\' of myself."\nShe doesn\'t like Curley - she tells Lennie that she only married him when she didn\'t receive a letter she\'d been promised to get into Hollywood.\nCrooks is the black stable hand or\nHe is the only permanent employee at the ranch, since he injured his back in an accident. His back gives him constant pain.\nHe is the only black man around and is made to be isolated by his colour - he can\'t go into the bunk-house or socialise with the men.\nHe is always called the \'nigger\' by the men, which shows how racism is taken for granted. The men don\'t mean to insult Crooks every time they call him this, but they never think to use his name\nAll this has made him proud and aloof.\n"S\'pose you didn\'t have nobody. S\'pose you couldn\'t go into the bunk house and play rummy \'cause you were black...A guy needs somebody-to be near him....I tell ya a guy gets too lonely an\' he gets sick."\nThe only time he mixes with the ranch hands socially is when they pitch horseshoes - and then he beats everyone!\nHe has his own room near the stables and has a few possessions. He has books, which show he is intelligent and an old copy of the California Civil Code, which suggests he is concerned about his rights.\nHe has seen many men come and go, all dreaming of buying a piece of land, but is now cynical, as no one has ever achieved it.\nCandy is the oldest ranch hand. He lost his right hand in an accident at work.\nHe is the \'swamper\' - the man who cleans the bunkhouse. He knows he will be thrown out and put \'on the county\' when he is too old to work.\nBecause of this, he accepts what goes on and doesn\'t challenge anything: he can\'t afford to lose his job.\nHe has a very old dog, which he has had from a pup. It is his only friend and companion.\n"The old man came slowly into the room. He had his broom in his hand. And at his heels there walked a drag-footed sheep dog, gray of muzzle, and with pale, blind old eyes."\nCarlson insists on shooting the dog because he claims it is too old and ill to be of any use. Candy is devastated.\nHe is lonely and isolated, but makes friends with George and Lennie and offers his compensation money to help them all to buy a ranch together and achieve their dream.\nWhen he finds Curley\'s wife dead, he is furious, as he knows instantly that Lennie was involved and that they have lost their chance of achieving their dream.\n', 'label': '5'}

{'text': ", which is when the audience knows something which characters in the play do not. For instance, Duncan greets Macbeth without suspecting a thing and Duncan thinks the castle (where he is to be murdered) is 'pleasant' and 'sweetly recommends itself'. Dramatic irony is used here to bring the audience into the play - we know what is happening but feel powerless to do anything\nThe key to understanding dramatic effect is to think about the feelings being created in the audience. It's not about reading the play but experiencing it. And the feelings we have are not accidental, but created by putting certain events together, or by explaining a character's thoughts and motivations, or by suggesting what will happen next. We might feel anger, disbelief, sympathy or fear. Try to include something about dramatic effect in your work, as it shows you understand how the play works.\nRead the full text online and make your own notes.\nGet creative, get published and get expert writing advice at BBC Blast.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "Sujata Bhatt: from Search For My Tongue\nSujata Bhatt: from Search For My Tongue\nThe poem is written in three sections:\nThe poet expresses how hard it is for her to know two languages, but neglect the one she feels most belongs to her.\nShe then translates her thoughts for us into English (so lines 31-38 mean something similar to lines 17-30), showing that although her 'mother tongue' dies during the day, it 'grows back' in her dreams at night, becoming strong and producing 'blossoms'.\nHow many meanings does the word 'tongue' have in the poem? Consider these:\nIt is a part of the body - the part you speak with.\nIt has also come to mean the language that you speak.\nThe phrase 'lost my tongue' (line 2) is used in a\nsense to mean that someone is tongue-tied and does not know what to say.\nBack to Poems from different cultures index\nGet some direction with a Bitesize revision map\nGet creative, get published and get expert writing advice at BBC Blast.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "What you must be able to do\nIn role-plays, the most important thing is to get your message across, so that a French-speaking person would understand. Of course, you should try to be as accurate as possible, but small mistakes will not always lose marks.\nYou will also need to ask questions, as well as give answers.\nlevel, you will need to to be accurate and fluent. You will also have to deal with the unexpected, give explanations and communicate opinions, ideas and feelings. You will also be expected to use different verb tenses and have a wide range of vocabulary.\nMake sure that you have a vocabulary book/record that covers each topic in the syllabus. Use this to build up your personal vocabulary of words (eg\n). You should revise a small number of new words and phrases every day.\nAs well as topic-based vocabulary you must be sure that you are confident with your general vocabulary that can be applied to all sorts of situations, for example:\nYou also need to learn the phrases that keep turning up in role plays, for example:\n'j'aime', 'je n'aime pas' 'est-ce que je peux...?' 'est-ce qu'il y a...?' 'je voudrais...' 'tu veux / vous voulez...?' 'c'est combien?' 'pour aller...?'\nMake a list of these phrases and keep practising them.\nyou will need plenty of practice with more demanding situations, such as those that might require you to tell a story, give an opinion or use a verb in the future. You also need to work at different situations with a view to using a key phrase you have learnt by heart (eg\n) or a structure you have been practising (eg\nYou will probably find that your role play card will contain some English, such as 'You are at the grocer's to buy food for a picnic' to set the scene.\nYou will also have some short notes to prompt you, such as\nor a visual prompt - an 'icon' or small picture.\nIf you need more information concerning your exam board and format of the role play, check with your teacher.\nThere could be more than one way of interpreting a question. For example, if somebody asks you where you would like to go this evening, you could say\nIn the same way, if you were asked to say that something was free, but you did not know how to say\nIn one of the foundation tier role plays, and in both of the higher tier role plays, you will have to respond to 'the unexpected'. This means that you will not be told what to say on your role play card - often there will be a symbol such as '!' in place of an instruction. Here you will have to respond to something that the examiner has just said.\nOne way that you can prepare for the unexpected is to think through how you might deal with situations where you have asked for something that it is not available. For example, think about what you might say in reply to statements such as:\n'Il n'y a pas de chambres de libre.' 'L'hÃ´tel est complet.' 'Je regrette, mais il n'y a plus de pain.'\nDecide whether you need to use the\nform of address, and then keep to it.\nWhen talking to strangers, remember to greet and leave them politely.\nAsk your teacher to prepare a tape of important role play phrases to practise with, alongside typical role-play exam cards, or prepare it yourself and get your teacher to check it for you.\nYour teacher could also provide a tape containing some model answers that will demonstrate, for example, what a grade 'C' performance sounds like.\n", 'label': '5'}
{'text': 'Dust from volcanoes reflects heat radiation from the Sun, leading to cooling. But dust from factories reflects heat radiation from cities, stopping it from escaping. This leads to warming in urban areas.\n. It absorbs heat energy that is radiated from the Earthâ€™s surface and prevents it from escaping into space. This keeps the Earth warmer than it would otherwise be. But human activities are increasing the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere. This increases the\nCarbon dioxide in the atmosphere has risen at a higher rate since the 19th century\nThe temperature of the earth has risen over the years\nHuman activities leading to global warming include:\nMost of the energy we use comes from burning fossil fuels. These release carbon dioxide when they burn. So the increasing use of energy is leading to increasing amounts of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere.\nWhen land is cleared for timber and farms, there are fewer trees to remove carbon dioxide from the atmosphere by photosynthesis. Also, if the fallen trees are burned or left to rot, additional carbon dioxide is released into the atmosphere.\nBack to Energy for the home index\nWireless signals are all around us, learn more in this activity!\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "There are two opposing historic images of the Depression in 1930s Britain:\n- lines of broken, unemployed men, rows of shabby housing - and\n- new washing machines, automobiles, electricity and cinemas.\nIn 1929, the Wall Street Crash plunged the USA into economic depression. The Americans were alarmed, so they called in their loans to other countries and put up customs barriers to stop imports of foreign goods. This created a depression across the rest of the world.\nUnemployment in Britain rose to 2.5 million (25 per cent of the workforce) in 1933. Worst hit were the areas of heavy industry (eg coal, iron, steel, shipbuilding) in Northern Ireland, Scotland, Wales and the north of England. These industries were already struggling because they had not modernised after the war and had been badly affected by competition from other countries. The Depression meant that now these industries crumbled. For example, when the coal mine, the steel works and Palmer's shipyard closed down in Jarrow in the north-east of England, every single man in the town was made\nlaid off from work because they are no longer needed\nThe people of Jarrow organised a march to London - a crusade to seek help from the government, but they were told to go home and work out their own salvation'. In fact,\nthe government did not have a clue how to cope with the Depression\n, and the policies it did put into action were either useless, or made matters worse.\nKey industries closed in Jarrow sparking the Jarrow Crusade.\nIn the south-east of England where new\nsuch as chemicals, electrical goods and automobiles had been developed,\n. In fact, people with jobs benefited from the Depression because prices fell and they could buy more!\nBack to Britain 1905 - 1951 index\nFed up with reading? {'text': "Nuclear fission is the splitting of an atom's nucleus to release heat. Nuclear power stations use the fission of uranium-235 to heat water. Fossil fuel power stations burn their fuel (coal, oil or gas) to heat their water.\nDangerous radioactive waste is sealed in glass-like blocks and buried in rocks.\nof a large nucleus. When this happens energy is released in the form of\n. Nuclear reactors use the heat released by the fission of uranium. If 1kg of uranium-235 undergoes nuclear fission it can release about the same amount of energy as 2 million kg of coal.\nThe fission of uranium can set up a chain reaction that will keep on releasing energy as long as there are uranium nuclei present. If this chain reaction is allowed to get out of control, energy is released very\n. Nuclear power stations are designed so that this cannot happen.\nUranium-235 is a naturally occurring element which has a special property. When a neutron is absorbed by the nucleus, the new heavier nucleus becomes unstable. It is unable to hold itself together so splits into two smaller nuclei and gives out three neutrons and a burst of energy.\n. Fossil fuel (coal, oil and gas) power stations and nuclear (uranium) power stations both use the same processes to make electricity. These are:\nfuel produces heat and heat is used to boil water and is turned into steam\nturbine turns a generator and the generator makes electricity\nelectricity goes to the transformers to produce the correct voltage\nThe only difference between fossil fuel and nuclear power stations is how the water is heated. Fossil fuel power stations\ntheir fuel while a nuclear power station uses the\n. At present the most dangerous waste is sealed in glass-like blocks which are buried deep within rocks. Careless disposal of waste in the past has led to\nAs well as producing heat the nuclear reactor can be used to make other materials radioactive. The chain reaction inside the reactor releases\n. If a material is put into the reactor some of these neutrons may be absorbed by the nuclei of its atoms. This will make an atom's nucleus\nwhich means it has become radioactive. These man-made radioisotopes are often then used as\nin hospitals to diagnose and treat patients or in industry to detect leaks in pipes.\nThe nuclear reactor is designed to allow a\nto take place. Each time a uranium nucleus splits up it releases energy and three neutrons. If all the neutrons are allowed to be absorbed by other uranium nuclei the chain reaction will spiral out of control causing an\n. {'text': "Resistors are components which restrict or resist the flow of current. The ability of a material or component to resist current flow is measured in\nunits of electrical resistance, usually shown by the symbol R. 1 volt will force a current of 1 amp through a resistance of 1 ohm.\n. There are three main types of resistor:\nSpecial resistors, such as thermistors and light-dependant resistors (LDRs)\nThese are the most common type of resistor. They are found in nearly every electronic circuit. Their three most important uses are:\nA light-emitting diode (LED) protected by a fixed resistor\nProtecting other components (such as an LED) from damage by too much current.\nA circuit diagram for a temperature detector\ncomponents which split a circuit's voltage into two. Potential dividers consist of two resistors in series.\n(or voltage dividers). A fixed resistor is used to split voltage between different parts of the circuit. Potential dividers are used, for example, with LDRs in circuits which detect changes in light.\nA circuit diagram for a timing application\nIn timing applications. In this role a fixed resistor is used with a capacitor in series.\nThere are two types of variable resistor:\nThe first type of variable resistor can be altered continually as they work. For example the volume control in a radio.\nThe second type is called a pre-set potentiometer. It has a resistance control that is adjusted and then fixed. These resistors would normally be adjusted once only.\nThe main difference between the two types of Potentiometers is their size. The pre-set potentiometers tend to be smaller and are usually adjusted with a screwdriver. A variable resistor is generally provided with a long spindle onto which an operating knob is attached.\nchange resistance as temperatures change. Most thermistors have a negative temperature coefficient - meaning their resistance falls as temperature increases. Thermistors are used in temperature-sensing circuits.\nhave a resistance which changes in response to changes in light levels, as detected by a photo-sensitive plate on the resistor. Most LDRs have a negative light coefficient - meaning that their resistance falls as the amount of light falling on them increases. LDRs are used in light-detection circuits.\nPost ideas and discuss Design and Technology here.\nGive your revision some visual style with a Bitesize revision map!\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': 'The elements in Group 1 of the Periodic Table are called the alkali metals. They include lithium (Li), sodium (Na) and potassium (K).\nmetals that are easily cut with a scalpel or knife. The freshly cut surface is a shiny, silver colour, but this\nquickly to a dull grey as the metal reacts with oxygen and water in the air. Pieces of such metals are stored in oil to prevent these reactions.\nThe shiny surface of sodium tarnishes more quickly than that of lithium. And potassium tarnishes more quickly than sodium. This shows the\nof the metals as we go down the group.\n, care has to be taken when using them. They must not be touched because they will react with the water in sweat on the skin. Gloves may be used, and goggles should be worn.\nThe alkali metals show trends in physical properties down the group.\ncompared to most other metals. Apart from the other alkali metals, only three metals (indium, gallium and mercury) have lower melting points than lithium. You can see from the graph that lithium, at the top of Group 1, has the\nin the group. The melting points then decrease as you go down the group.\nThe boiling points of these alkali metals show a similar pattern to the melting points.\nThe density of a substance is a measure of how much\n. It is measured in grams/cubic centimetre. For example gold and lead are very dense metals - even a small lump of either of them can still feel heavy. The alkali metals have\ncompared to most other metals. (They feel lighter.) You can see from the graph that lithium, at the top of Group 1, has the lowest density in the group. The densities then generally increase as you go down the group.\n. Lithium is the hardest alkali metal and they become softer as you go down the group.\nAll the alkali metals react vigorously with cold water. In each reaction,\nis produced. The speed and violence of the reaction\nas you go down the group. This shows that the reactivity of the alkali metals increases as you go down Group 1.\nWhen lithium is added to water, lithium floats. It fizzes steadily and becomes smaller, until it eventually disappears.\nlithium + water → lithium hydroxide + hydrogen\nWhen sodium is added to water, the sodium melts to form a ball that moves around on the surface. It fizzes rapidly, and the hydrogen produced may burn with an orange flame before the sodium disappears.\nsodium + water → sodium hydroxide + hydrogen\nWhen potassium is added to water, the metal melts and floats. It moves around very quickly on the surface of the water. The hydrogen ignites instantly. The metal is also set on fire, with sparks and a lilac flame. There is sometimes a small explosion at the end of the reaction.\npotassium + water → potassium hydroxide + hydrogen\nThe hydroxides formed in all of these reactions dissolve in water to form alkaline solutions. These solutions turn universal indicator purple, showing they are strongly\n. Strong alkalis are corrosive, so care must be taken when they are used - for example, by using goggles and gloves.\nAll of the alkali metals react vigorously with chlorine gas. Each reaction produces a white crystalline salt. The reaction gets more violent as you move down Group 1, showing how reactivity increases down the group.\nIf a piece of hot lithium is lowered into a jar of chlorine, white powder is produced and settles on the sides of the jar. This is the salt\nIf a piece of hot sodium is lowered into a jar of chlorine, the sodium burns with a bright yellow flame. Clouds of white powder are produced and settle on the sides of the jar. This is the salt\nThe reaction of sodium with chlorine is similar to the reaction with lithium, but more vigorous.\nPotassium reacts more violently with chlorine than sodium does.\n', 'label': '5'}
{'text': 'People with diabetes cannot control blood glucose concentration properly. Type 1 diabetes is treated using insulin injections, and type 2 diabetes is controlled through diet and exercise.\nIt is important that the concentration of\na simple sugar made by the body from food, which is used by cells to make energy in respiration\n, which is a type of sugar, in the blood stays at a near constant level. There are serious consequences if blood sugar concentration goes outside a narrow range.\ntoo little glucose causes confusion, unconsciousness, even coma\ntoo much glucose causes exhaustion and blurred vision\nProcessed foods often contain a lot of sugar. This is absorbed easily in the digestive system, causing a rapid increase in the\nchemical messengers produced in glands and carried by the blood to specific organs in the body\nproduced by the pancreas that reduces the blood glucose level, ensuring that it remains within narrow limits.\nYour web browser does not have JavaScript switched on at the moment. {'text': "You should understand what is meant by the amplitude, wavelength and frequency of a wave.\nAs waves travel, they set up patterns of disturbance. The amplitude of a wave is its maximum disturbance from its undisturbed position. Take care: the amplitude is not the distance between the top and bottom of a wave.\nThe wavelength of a wave is the distance between a point on one wave and the same point on the next wave. It is often easiest to measure this from the crest of one wave to the crest of the next wave, but it doesn't matter where as long as it is the same point in each wave.\nThe frequency of a wave is the number of waves produced by a source each second. It is also the number of waves that pass a certain point each second. The unit of frequency is the hertz (Hz). It is common for kilohertz (kHz), megahertz (MHz) and gigahertz (GHz) to be used when waves have very high frequencies. For example, most people cannot hear a high-pitched sound above 20kHz, radio stations broadcast\nLow frequency electromagnetic radiation used to transmit information such as television and radio programmes.\nwith frequencies of about 100MHz, while most wireless computer networks operate at 2.4GHz.\nCheck your understanding of this section by having a go at this activity.\nYour web browser does not have JavaScript switched on at the moment. {'text': "in industry and hospitals. They're used to find out what is happening\nIn industry they can be used to:\nfind leaks or blockages in underground pipes\nTo locate a leak in an underground pipe a very small amount of radioactive material that gives off gamma rays is put into the pipe. A detector is moved along the ground above the pipe. The leak is located where there's an increase in activity and little or no activity after that point.\nOne type of smoke detector uses Americium-241, an alpha source, to detect smoke.\nThe alpha particles pass between the two charged metal plates, causing air particles to ionise (split into positive and negative ions). The ions are attracted to the oppositely charged metal plates causing a current to flow.\nGive your revision some visual style with a Bitesize revision map!\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': 'An electronics product can be thought of as a\nwith inputs, processes and outputs. The most common method of manufacturing electronic products is the batch method - though one-off production and continuous-flow production are also important.\nICT is used extensively in electronics manufacturing. The use of machines that are controlled by computers is called computer-aided manufacture or CAM.\nElectronics systems diagrams are used to show how the parts of a product work together. Many electronic products are made up of a number of standard system circuits (circuits that are common to many different products), such as sensors, amplifiers, timers, counters and output devices.\nSystem diagrams usually take the form of a\nin which each part of the electronic system is represented by an input, a process or an output.\nThe block diagrams below shows two types of system.\nhas no feedback mechanism, so the accuracy depends on how well the system was set up before hand.\nelectronic systems use sensors to provide feedback. This means that if the output is not satisfactory, the inputs or processes can be altered.\nPost ideas and discuss Design and Technology here.\nGive your revision some visual style with a Bitesize revision map!\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': 'Hungary had been controlled by Russia since 1945. The death of Stalin brought people in many Eastern European countries the\nof freedom and change, but as the 1956 uprising in Hungary proved, this was not to be the case.\n1. The death of Stalin led many Hungarians to hope that Hungary also would be \'de-Stalinised\'. In July 1956, the \'Stalinist\' Secretary of the Hungarian Communist Party, Rakosi, fell from power.\n2. During October 1956, students, workers and soldiers in Hungary attacked the AVH (the secret police) and Russian soldiers, and smashed a statue of Stalin.\n3. On 24 October 1956 Imre Nagy - a moderate and a westerniser - took over as prime minister.\n4. Nagy asked Khrushchev to move the Russian troops out. Khrushchev agreed and on 28 October 1956, the Russian army pulled out of Budapest.\n5. For five days, there was freedom in Hungary. The new Hungarian government introduced democracy, freedom of speech, and freedom of religion. Cardinal Mindzenty, the leader of the Catholic Church, was freed from prison.\n6. Then, on 3 November 1956, Nagy announced that Hungary was going to leave the Warsaw Pact. However, Khrushchev was not going to allow this. He claimed he had received a letter from Hungarian Communist leaders asking for his help.\n7. At dawn on 4 November 1956, 1,000 Russian tanks rolled into Budapest. They destroyed the Hungarian army and captured Hungarian Radio the last words broadcast were "Help! Help! Help!".\n8. Hungarian people - even children - fought the Russian troops with machine guns. Some 4,000 Hungarians were killed.\n9. Khrushchev put in Russian supporter, Janos Kadar, as prime minister.\nBack to International relations 1945 - 1991 index\nFed up with reading? Give your ears a treat and listen to some History audio.\nAll things historic - from ancient to modern.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': 'Our Sun is a star. It seems much bigger than other stars in the sky because it is much closer to Earth. Stars form immense groups called galaxies. A\nA cluster of billions of stars, held together by gravity.\ncan contain many millions of stars, held together by the force of gravity.\nOur Sun is in a spiral galaxy called the Milky Way. The Sun is about half-way from the centre of the galaxy, on one of the arms.\nThe Milky Way galaxy is home to planet Earth\nThe distances involved in galaxies are huge. The distance from one star and another in a galaxy is millions of times more than the distance between the planets in the solar system. Meanwhile, the distance from one galaxy to another is millions of times more than the distance between the stars in a galaxy. The universe contains at least one billion galaxies.\nFor an activity that is out of this world!\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "Integrated circuits are the basic component of modern\ntechnology dealing with the building of electronic circuits and devices using microchips (large numbers of extremely small integrated circuits)\nYou need to know about three types of integrated circuit that are important in controlling electronic systems. These are:\n(a circuit) having two states, one of which is stable. A monostable circuit needs to be pushed into the unstable state by a control input, and will jump back after a set time to the stable state - giving a single, timed output signal.\n(a circuit) having two states, neither of which is stable. An astable circuit therefore oscillates between the two states, giving a constant on/off digital output. Used, for example, to make LEDs flash continuously.\nIntegrated circuits are the basic component of microelectronics. ICs are complete, self-contained circuits, with dozens, hundreds or even thousands of separate components such as transistors, diodes, resistors and capacitors etched into a tiny silicon chip.\nICs have three big advantages over conventional circuits with discrete components:\nThe chip inside an IC is usually packaged inside a piece of black plastic with tiny pins protruding to allow connections to the circuit. In ICs the pins are arranged in a 'dual-in-line' (DIL) configuration, or as a surface mount chip with either eight, 14 or 16 pins. The surface mount chip is much smaller and is designed for machines to build the circuits.\nA Surface Mount package integrated circuit - far smaller than a finger-tip\nTimer circuits are used to control sequences of events in electronic systems by changing the circuit from one state to another at preset times.\nOne of the commonest integrated timer circuits is the\n, which is produced as an eight-pin DIL package containing 25 transistors, 2 diodes and 16 resistors. The 555 can be used as either an\n(a circuit) having two states, neither of which is stable. An astable circuit therefore oscillates between the two states, giving a constant on/off digital output. Used, for example, to make LEDs flash continuously.\n(a circuit) having two states, one of which is stable. A monostable circuit needs to be pushed into the unstable state by a control input, and will jump back after a set time to the stable state - giving a single, timed output signal.\nWhen the astable timer is switched on it will give a constant on/off digital output. So the timer will make an LED flash, at a rate determined by a capacitor in the circuit.\nYour web browser does not have JavaScript switched on at the moment. For information on how to enable JavaScript please go to the\nYou will not be able to see this content until you have JavaScript switched on.\nThe period when the timer/LED is on is called the\nand the period when the timer/LED is off is called the\n. You can calculate the duration of the mark and the space using the following formulae:\nMark (time on) = 0.7 x (R1 + R2) x C1\nSpace (time off) = 0.7 x R1 x C1\n- where R1 is the value of resistor R1 (in Ohms), R2 is value of resistor R2 (in Ohms) and C1 is the value of the capacitor (in microFarads)\nMonostable timers are often called one-shot timers. When the timer is switched on it will stay on for a certain length of time and then stay off until it is switched on again.\nNotice how you only need to press the switch once. The switch makes contact, then the timing process begins. The time period depends on the value of resistor R1 and capacitor C1.\nThe duration of the period is calculated using the formula:\nTime on (seconds) = 1.1 x R1 x C1\n- where R1 is the value of resistor R1 (in Ohms) and C1 is the value of the capacitor (in microFarads)\nAn astable 555 timer has the following external component values: R1 = 100 kOhms; R2 = 47 kOhms; C1 = 10 microFarads:\nMark (time on) = 0.7 x (100,000 + 47,000) x 0.00001 =\nSpace (time off) = 0.7 x 100,000 x 0.00001 =\nA monostable 555 timer has the following component values: R1 is 100 kiloOhms and C1 is 100 microFarads. Calculate the length of time that the timer will stay on.\nTime on = 1.1 x 100 000 x 0.0001 =\nAmplifiers are devices which takes a relatively weak signal as an input and produce a much stronger signal as an output.\nis a special kind of amplifier used in equipment such as stereo equipment and medical cardiographs (which amplify the heart beat). They have a voltage\nthe amount of amplification of the input voltage - ie how much bigger the output voltage is compared to the input voltage\nOp-amps are integrated circuits that cram the equivalent of many transistors, resistors and capacitor into a small silicon chip. They are represented in circuit diagrams as follows:\nAn op-amp has two separate inputs - the inverting input and the non-inverting input. The op-amp most commonly used in schools is the\n, an eight-pin DIL package which apart from its code number is identical in appearance to the 555 timer. The graphic shows a pin-out diagram for a 741.\nThe 3 most important pins are pin 2 (inverting input), pin 3 (non-inverting input) and pin 6 (output)\nThe operating conditions for the 741 are as follows:\n- that is, devices which compare two inputs (the inverting input and the non-inverting input).\nA common comparator is the temperature controller or thermostat. Using a temperature sensor as part of the circuitry, the op-amp is set at a particular temperature - say 20 degrees centigrade. The op-amp compares this reference temperature to the actual environmental temperature of the room, measured by a\ntype of resistor that changes resistance with temperature - also called a Temperature-Dependent Resistor. Usually the resistance decreases with an increase in temperature (and vice versa)\n. If the voltage at the non-inverting input is greater than the voltage at the inverting input the op-amp switches on the heating system. The diagram shows an op-amp used as a temperature controller with a thermistor providing the non-inverting input.\na circuit diagram for a temperature control system, with an op-amp acting as a comparator\nCounter circuits record the number of times an event takes place.\nThe counter circuit you are most likely to come across is the\n, which can be set to count to any value between one and 10 , over and over again. The 4017 is a complementary metal oxide semiconductor (CMOS) integrated circuit.\nA decade counter has ten outputs. When it is turned on, the counter switches from one output to the next. The speed at which each output turns on or 'goes high' is determined by a timer connected to an input. The counter is switched on and off using either a manual switch or with an astable 555 timer (using pin 3 on the 555 as the output).\nshowing the arrangement of pins in a 4017 counter chip, and a guide to what each pin does.\nPin-out diagram for a 4017 decade counter\nPins 1 to 7 and pin 9 and pin 11 are outputs for the counter.\nPin 8 is the negative power supply.\nPin 12 is the carry-out pin (this could be connected to another 4017).\nPin 13 is the enable pin. It can be used to stop the count.\nPin 14 is the clock pin. This will be connected to a manual switch or to an astable 555 timer.\nPin 15 is the reset pin. This returns counter to zero.\nPin 16 is the positive power supply pin. It runs at a voltage between 3V and 16V.\nThe circuit below shows a decade counter being used as a random number generator or electronic dice. The input 14 can be connected to a 555 timer to operate the dice. A switch has been connected to pin 13, which will stop the dice when pressed.\n", 'label': '5'}

{'text': "Noël en France - in this exercise you will read about how some young French people spend Christmas. Take careful note of the seasonal vocabulary.\nHere is a typical reading question that you might get in your French exam. Read through the question and fill in your answers. Have a look at how this one works - you have to work out which person each phrase is referring to. This question should take you about 15 minutes.\nCinq étudiantes parlent de la fête de Noël.\nPour moi, Noël est entouré de magie en quelque sorte. Petite, j'étais captivée par tout ce qui se passait autour de ce jour, les préparatifs du sapin, la crèche, les cadeaux. A présent, je participe à la mise en scène de Noël pour les petits de la famille.\nJe suis généralement très occupée et très énervée toute la journée. Je suis vite fatiguée. Les visiteurs sont souvent très ennuyeux, et le repas trop lourd à digérer. Ce qui m'énerve le plus, c'est la messe de minuit.\nNoël pour moi est un jour comme les autres. Je vis seule avec ma mère et le soir de Noël nous allons en général au restaurant ou chez des amis. Noël n'est pas particulièrement drôle quand la famille est petite.\nA Noël j'ai décidé que cette année je ne resterai pas à la maison pour fêter Noël dans la tradition. J'ai économisé de l'argent pour aller rendre visite à une amie qui habite en Hollande, à la Haye.\nLes fêtes de Noël, je trouve ça génial. Tout le monde se dépêche pour acheter les derniers cadeaux, toutes les rues sont illuminées et c'est merveilleux. Nous faisons de grands repas pour le réveillon de Noël et pour le jour de Noël également.\nPour chaque phrase ci-dessous, écris le nom de la personne qui correspond.\nElle n'a pas l'habitude de fêter Noël à la maison.\nPour elle Noël a toujours un sens religieux.\nElle va faire quelque chose de différent cette année.\nElle a horreur d'aller à l'église la veille de Noël.\nElle n'a pas l'habitude de fêter Noël à la maison.\nSimone and her mother don't usually celebrate Christmas at home. She loves the nativity and helping with the preparations.\nElle va faire quelque chose de différent cette année.\nThis year Amina is not staying at home for a traditional Christmas. She is going to see a friend in Holland.\nElle a horreur d'aller à l'église la veille de Noël.\nFrancine does not like the midnight mass service.\nElisabeth enjoys the traditional way of spending Christmas with shopping, bright lights and good food.\nRead the full text at least twice. Unicellular organisms only have one cell. Multicellular organisms have many cells.\n, and waste products away from them. {'text': 'Corrosive substances which have a pH lower than 7. Acidity is caused by a high concentration of hydrogen ions.\nhave a pH of less than 7.\nSubstances with a pH higher than 7, and which have a high concentration of hydroxyl ions. Bases react with acids to form a salt and water (called neutralisation). Metal hydroxides, oxides and carbonates are all bases.\nhave a pH of more than 7. When bases are dissolved in water, they are known as\nclass of chemical compounds, mostly metallic oxides. Examples are sodium chloride, potassium chloride, and magnesium sulphate\nare made when an acid reacts with a base, carbonate or metal. The name of the salt formed depends on the metal in the base and the acid used. For example, salts made using hydrochloric acid are called chlorides.\nYou will have already learnt quite a lot about acids and bases in Key Stage 3 Science. If you feel a bit rusty on this topic, have a quick look at\n. Here are the bare bones of what you need to know:\nSubstances with a pH of less than 7 are acids. The stronger the acid, the lower the pH number. Acids turn blue litmus paper red. They turn universal indicator red if they are strong, and orange or yellow if they are weak.\nSubstances that can react with acids and neutralise them to make a salt and water are called bases. They are usually metal oxides or metal hydroxides. For example, copper oxide and sodium hydroxide are bases.\nBases that dissolve in water are called alkalis. Copper oxide is not an alkali because it does not dissolve in water. Sodium hydroxide is an alkali because it does dissolve in water.\nAlkaline solutions have a pH of more than 7. The stronger the alkali, the higher the pH number. Alkalis turn red litmus paper blue. They turn universal indicator dark blue or purple if they are strong, and blue-green if they are weak.\nNeutral solutions have a pH of 7. They do not change the colour of litmus paper, but they turn universal indicator green. Water is neutral.\nGive your revision some visual style with a Bitesize revision map!\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. While you will be able to view the content of this page in your current browser, you will not be able to get the full visual experience. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n', 'label': '5'}

{'text': "'Percent' means 'out of 100'. If 90 per cent of the population owns a mobile phone, this means 90 out of every 100 people have one. The symbol '%' means per cent.\nA percentage is a fraction of 100.\n(30 in each 100) as a fraction is\nOften, in real life - and maths exams - you must find a percentage of a quantity. First, write the percentage as a fraction or a decimal, then multiply by the quantity.\nFirst, write 40% as a fraction: 40% =\nPractise converting percentages to fractions. Then try the questions below.\nYour web browser does not have JavaScript switched on at the moment. For information on how to enable JavaScript please go to the\nYou will not be able to see this content until you have JavaScript switched on.\nSarah is buying a pair of jeans. The original price was £75, but there is a discount of 30%. How much will the discount be?\n(Note that if the question asked for the discount price, you would subtract the discount from the original price : £75 - £22.50 = £52.50.)\nSometimes both the percentage and amount of money will not be whole numbers.\nA car costs £9,999.90 before VAT (value added tax). Work out the cost of the VAT if it is charged at 17.5%.\nSince the answer is a price, it must be rounded to two decimal places.\nPeople often buy something at one price, and sell it on for another - eg, when they are selling things at a car boot sale.\nIf the selling price is greater than the buying price, a\nIf the selling price is less than the buying price, there is a\nPeople pay tax on the income they earn. The basic rate of income tax is 22%.\nValue Added Tax is added to the cost of most things you buy. It is charged at 17.5%.\nIn some questions you are given the cost price and the selling prices and have to find the percentage increase or decrease. This means you need to find one amount as a percentage of another. You form a fraction from the two amounts and multiply this by 100. Try these questions.\nAjay is dealing in electrical goods. He buys a radio for £45 and sells it for £63. What is his percentage profit?\nHere the cost price is £45 and the selling price £63.\nThe profit is £63 - £45 = £18\nTo calculate the percentage profit you have to find what the profit is as a percentage of the original price. So divide the profit by the original price and multiply by 100.\nCharlotte buys a coat in a sale for £60. The original cost of the coat was £80. What is the percentage decrease?\nThe coat was bought for £60, and the original price was £80.\nThe decrease is £80 - £60 = £20.\nTo calculate the percentage decrease, divide the actual decrease by the original price and multiply by 100.\nSometimes a question will ask you to work\nand find the original price after an increase.\nIn Question 1 you were told the original price (the cost price) and the selling price. You were asked to find the percentage profit.\nInstead imagine you were given the selling price (£63) and the percentage profit (40%), and told to find the original price.\nto find 40% of £63 and take it away. The 40% is a percentage of the original price, not of the selling price. (40% of £63 happens to be £25.20 which is no help at all.)\nThe method for questions like this is in\n. If you are given a quantity\na percentage increase or decrease, and you need to find the original amount, use this method.\n", 'label': '5'}

{'text': "Although Victor selects the Monster's body parts so that it will be beautiful, when it is given life it looks hideously ugly. This leads ordinary people to be scared of the Monster and mistreat it.\nThe Monster is of good character, and does many kind things (for example, helping the De Laceys to harvest their crops and saving the peasant girl from drowning).\nIt is turned bad through Victor's and other's mistreatment.\nThe Monster lacks company and only ever wants friendship. This is why it asks Victor to build it a wife.\nIt is very clever, learning to speak and read by secretly watching the De Laceys. Its speech is sophisticated and persuasive, helping us to have sympathy for it.\nUnlike Victor, the Monster regrets its bad actions at the end of the book.\nIt also shows love for Victor at the end. {'text': 'Hydrogen is often seen as an environmentally friendly alternative to fossil fuels and biofuels. When hydrogen burns, the only product formed is water:\nhydrogen\xa0\xa0\xa0 + \xa0\xa0\xa0oxygen \xa0\xa0\xa0 → \xa0\xa0\xa0 water\nSome hydrogen powered vehicles have already been made and are on the road, but there are few of them because there are difficulties in making and in handling hydrogen.\nAt the moment, most hydrogen is made by reacting steam with coal or natural gas, which are non-renewable resources.\nHydrogen can also be made by passing electricity through water. Unfortunately, most electricity is generated using coal and other fossil fuels: any pollution from burning these fuels just happens at the power station instead of at the vehicle itself.\nfrom 2006 about using solar energy to obtain hydrogen from water.\nHydrogen gas is very flammable and may explode if handled incorrectly. It must be compressed and chilled, then stored in tough, insulated tanks. It is not as convenient as petrol and diesel.\nBack to Fuels, air, seawater and pollution index\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "CAM is essentially the use of automated machines that are controlled by computers. Some of the advantages of using computer-aided manufacturing are that\nmachines can be quickly reprogrammed for each new batch of products\nspecifications can be transmitted quickly from design to manufacturing, and from one machine to another\nmachines can work continuously for long periods\nwork can be carried out in conditions which would be hazardous to humans\nWhen computers are used to carry out bespoke precision tasks, such as soldering circuit boards, this is called\nor CNC. {'text': "Assess how bad the injury is by the signs and symptoms displayed by the individual. Treatment for injuries differs according to the type of damage.\nThis Revision Bite covers several treatment types, including the dressing of open wounds, the DRABC checklist for concussion, and Mouth-to-Mouth Ventilation (MMV) for resuscitation. For reducing swelling, pain and bleeding in injuries to soft tissues, remember the acronym RICE: Rest, Ice, Compression and Elevation.\nFractures and dislocations are serious injuries. In all cases where a fracture or dislocation is suspected move the sufferer as little as possible, support the injured part and seek medical advice.\ntreatment is used for strains, sprains and bruises.\n. Stop activity to prevent further injury.\n. Apply an ice pack to reduce blood flow, pain and swelling.\n. Wrap a bandage tightly around the area to reduce internal bleeding and swelling.\n. Raise the injury above heart level to reduce swelling and throbbing.\ntreatment lessens the pain and helps to reduce injury recovery time.\nGrazes should be cleaned and covered with a non-stick dressing. Photo courtesy of BBC Sport\nAll skin damage should be cleaned to prevent infection.\n– dry the skin around the cut and cover with a clean dressing.\n– check for dirt within the graze. Cover with a specialist non-stick dressing.\n– do not break the blister. Cover it with a specialist plaster that stays in place until it falls off naturally. This eases pain and protects the area from further damage.\nDehydration, hypothermia and unconsciousness are emergency situations. You should always send for medical help before treating the sufferer.\nThe body does not have as much fluids and water as it should. Severe dehydration can be life-threatening.\nlie the sufferer down in a cool place\nCaused by excessive cold. The internal body temperature drops leading to shivering, cold pale skin, shallow breathing, feeling confused and tired.\nmove sufferer to a warmer, sheltered area\nprovide extra clothing or a survival bag\n: Check that you and the sufferer are not in danger. Make sure everyone is safe.\n: Shake and shout - is the person unconscious?\n: Check that the airway is clear.\n: Check that the sufferer is breathing.\nWith the casualty lying on his back:\nTilt the head back to clear the airway.\nPinch their nose and seal your lips around their mouth to seal the system\nBlow into the mouth and watch the chest rise.\nTake your mouth away and watch the chest fall.\nContinue with 10 breaths per minute until breathing starts.\nTilt the head back to clear the airway\nPinch their nose and seal your lips around their mouth to seal the system\nBlow into the mouth and watch the chest rise.\nTake your mouth away and watch the chest fall\nContinue with 10 breaths per minute until breathing starts\nWhen there is no pulse, with the casualty on his back:\nInterlock your fingers with the heel of your hand in the centre of his sternum (breastbone). Ensure that pressure is not applied over the ribs.\nPosition yourself vertically above the casualty’s chest and, with your arms straight and press the sternum down 4-5cm.\nRock backwards to release the pressure, and allow the chest come back up completely after each compression.\n30 chest compressions at a rate of 100 per minute followed by two mouth-to-mouth ventilations.\nStop to recheck the casualty only if he starts breathing normally; otherwise do not interrupt resuscitation. Continue resuscitation until qualified help arrives and takes over, or the casualty starts breathing normally, or you become exhausted.\nUse the recovery position for an unconscious person who is breathing. Roll their body towards you and onto their side. Then:\nTilt the head back to keep the airway clear.\nEnsure that the head and neck are in a straight line.\nKeep the hip and knee bent at 90º to keep body stable and comfortable.\nUse the casualty's hand to support the head, but it should remain lower than the body to allow fluids to drain from the mouth.\n", 'label': '5'}
{'text': "Environmentalists work towards or advocate the protection of the environment from destruction and pollution.\nTrade unionists are workers who belong to an organised association that protects their interests when negotiating hours, wages, conditions etc. May also be known as labour unions.\nGlobalisation operates mostly in the interests of the richest countries, which continue to dominate world trade at the expense of developing countries. The role of LEDCs in the world market is mostly to provide the North and West with cheap labour and raw materials.\nThere are no guarantees that the wealth from inward investment will benefit the local community. Often, profits are sent back to the MEDC where the TNC is based. Transnational companies, with their massive\nEconomy of scale means that big companies can produce things cheaper than smaller companies. There are two reasons for this. First, they can buy in bulk, so can negotiate with suppliers to pay less. Second, the more a company produces the lower the average cost per product will be of overheads (fixed costs, such as buildings). Where similar companies locate together as an industry they can also experience economies of scale. They share the costs of building the necessary infrastructure (eg roads, telecommunications) and the cost of educating the workforce, between them. Also the combined demand from all these companies should mean that supplies are cheaper.\n, may drive local companies out of business. If it becomes cheaper to operate in another country, the TNC might close down the factory and make local people redundant.\nAn absence of strictly enforced international laws means that TNCs may operate in LEDCs in a way that would not be allowed in an MEDC. They may pollute the environment, run risks with safety or impose poor working conditions and low wages on local workers.\nGlobalisation is viewed by many as a threat to the world's cultural diversity. It is feared it might drown out local economies, traditions and languages and simply re-cast the whole world in the mould of the capitalist North and West. An example of this is that a Hollywood film is far more likely to be successful worldwide than one made in India or China, which also have thriving film industries.\nIndustry may begin to thrive in LEDCs at the expense of jobs in manufacturing in the UK and other MEDCs, especially in textiles.\nAnti-globalisation campaigners sometimes try to draw people's attention to these points by demonstrating against the\n. The World Trade Organisation is an inter-government organisation that promotes the free-flow of trade around the world.\nDeliver key Geographic sound bites direct to your ear!\nLatest news from the world of business and industry.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "You should remember from your Key Stage 3 studies that white light can be split up into a spectrum of many different colours. You should know that visible light is just part of a continuous spectrum of electromagnetic radiation.\nWhite light can be split up to form a spectrum using a\n. This is a block of glass with a triangular cross-section. The light waves are\nas they enter and leave the prism. The shorter the\nThe length of a single wave, measured from one wave crest to the next.\nof the light the more it is\nThere is refraction when waves change direction as they move from one transparent substance to another.\n. As a result, red light is refracted the least and violet light is refracted the most, causing the coloured light to spread out to form a spectrum.\nVisible light is just one type of\n. There are various types of electromagnetic radiation with longer wavelengths of light than red light and with shorter wavelengths than violet light. All the different types of electromagnetic waves travel at the same speed through the vacuum of empty space.\nYou should know the different types of\nThe table summarises the main types of electromagnetic radiation and a typical use for each of them.\nUnlike sound waves, electromagnetic waves do not need a substance to travel through. They can travel through the\nof empty space. In a vacuum, they all travel with the same very high speed: 300 000 000 m/s.\nA beam of electromagnetic radiation delivers energy in ‘packets’ called photons.\nThe energy delivered by each photon increases with the\nof the electromagnetic waves. This means that gamma photons have the most energy, and radio photons the least.\nof a beam of electromagnetic radiation is the energy it delivers to a surface each second. This depends on how much energy each photon delivers, and on how many photons per second arrive at that surface.\nDifferent frequencies of electromagnetic radiation are used for different purposes due to their varying characteristics in reflection, absorption and transmission by various materials.\n. X-rays mostly pass through skin and soft tissue, but they do not easily pass through bone or metal. X-rays are used to produce shadow photographs of bones to check for damage such as fractures. They are also used in industry to check metal components and welds for cracks or other damage, and can detect objects hidden in the luggage of aircraft passengers.\nEven low doses of X-rays can cause cells to become cancerous, so precautions are taken in hospitals to limit the dose received by patients and staff when X-ray photographs are taken.\nBecause these can travel long distances through glass without becoming significantly weaker, these are used in\nA fine glass fibre, through which light travels by total internal reflection, from one end to the other.\nMicrowave radiation has lower frequencies and longer\nThe length of a single wave, measured from one wave crest to the next.\nthan visible light. Microwaves with certain wavelengths are absorbed by water molecules and can be used for\n. Water in the food absorbs the microwave radiation, which causes the water to heat up and cook the food. The water in living cells can also absorb microwave radiation. As a result, they can be killed or damaged by the heat released.\nA mobile phone mast - an example of a microwave transmitter\nMicrowave radiation can also be used to\nsuch as mobile phone calls. Microwave transmitters and receivers on buildings and masts communicate with the mobile telephones in their range.\nCertain microwave radiation wavelengths pass through the Earth's atmosphere and can be used to transmit information to and from\nmicrowaves well. For this reason, satellite dishes are made from metal, and so are the cases of microwave ovens.\nstrongly absorbed by the atmosphere so can be used to carry information for radio and TV programmes.\nMicrowaves and radio waves in the atmosphere\n", 'label': '5'}
{'text': "Darwin’s theory of evolution explains how species of living things have changed over geological time. The theory is supported by evidence from fossils, and by the rapid changes that can be seen to occur in microorganisms such as antibiotic-resistant bacteria. Many species have become extinct in the past and the extinction of species continues to happen.\nCharles Darwin was an English naturalist. He studied variation in plants and animals during a five-year voyage around the world in the 19th century. He explained his ideas about evolution in a book called\nDarwin’s ideas caused a lot of controversy, and this continues to this day, because the ideas can be seen as\nabout the creation of the world and creatures in it.\nDarwin studied the wildlife on the Galápagos Islands - a group of islands on the equator almost 1,000 kilometres west of Ecuador. He noticed that the finches - songbirds - on the different islands there were fundamentally similar to each other, but showed wide variations in their size, beaks and claws from island to island. For example, their beaks were different depending on the local food source. Darwin concluded that, because the islands are so distant from the mainland, the finches that had arrived there in the past had changed over time.\nDarwinâ\x80\x99s drawings of the different heads and beaks he found among the finches on the GalÃ¡pagos Islands\nDarwin studied hundreds more animal and plant species. After nearly 30 years of research, in 1858 he proposed his\nThe basic idea behind the theory of evolution is that all the different species have evolved from simple life forms. These simple life forms first developed more than three billion years ago - the Earth is about 4.5 billion years old. The timeline below shows some of the key events in the evolution of life forms on Earth, from the first bacteria to the first modern humans.\nYour web browser does not have JavaScript switched on at the moment. For information on how to enable JavaScript please go to the\nYou will not be able to see this content until you have JavaScript switched on.\nThe theory of evolution states that evolution happens by natural selection. Here are the key points:\nThe basic units of genetic material inherited from our parents. A gene is a section of DNA which controls part of a cell's chemistry - particularly protein production.\nare more likely to survive and reproduce.\nThe genes that allowed the individuals to be successful are\nIndividuals that are poorly adapted to their environment are less likely to survive and reproduce. This means that their genes are less likely to be passed to the next generation. Given enough time, a species will gradually evolve.\nFossils of ammonites - sea creatures that became extinct about 65 million years ago\nMost of the evidence for evolution comes from the fossil record. Fossils show how much, or how little, organisms have changed over time. One of the problems with the fossil record is that it contains gaps. Not all organisms fossilise well, and there will be many fossils that have been destroyed by the movements of the Earth, or simply not yet been discovered.\nOne of the few animals for which we have a fairly complete evolutionary record is the horse because all the main stages of the evolution of the horse have been preserved in fossil form. Over 60 million years,\nthe horse evolved from a dog-sized creature\nthat lived in rainforests into an animal adapted to living on the plains and standing up to 2 metres high.\nfrom 2006 about the first fish to live on land.\nIn the process its multi-toed feet, that were adapted for walking across the forest floor, evolved into single-toed hooves more suited for running over open country.\nEvolution is difficult to observe because it usually takes many years to happen. This is one reason why\nthe theory of evolution is still a theory\n, not a law. Since no-one was around millions of years ago to make observations, take notes and carry out experiments,\nevolution cannot be proved in the usual scientific sense\n. However, rapid changes in species have been observed that support the theory.\nBefore the industrial revolution in Britain, most peppered moths were of the pale variety. This meant that they were camouflaged against the pale birch trees that they rest on. Moths with a mutant black colouring were easily spotted and eaten by birds. This gave the white variety an advantage, and they were more likely to survive to reproduce.\nAirborne pollution in industrial areas blackened the birch tree bark with soot. This meant that the mutant black moths were now camouflaged, while the white variety became more vulnerable to predators. This gave the black variety an advantage, and they were more likely to survive and reproduce. Over time, the black peppered moths became far more numerous in urban areas than the pale variety.\nThe pale peppered moths camouflage well against the pale birch tree\nThe darker mutant peppered moths camouflage well against the blackened birch tree\nE. coli bacteria (Photo from Rocky Mountain Laboratories, NIAID, NIH)\nMicroorganisms such as bacteria and viruses reproduce very rapidly and can evolve in a relatively short time. One example is the bacterium\nThe material inside the nucleus of cells, carrying genetic information. DNA stands for Deoxyribonucleic Acid.\ncan be damaged or changed during replication, and most of the time this causes the death of the cell. But occasionally, the mutation is beneficial - for the bacteria. For example, it may allow resistance to an antibiotic. When that antibiotic is present, the resistant bacteria have an advantage over the bacteria that are not resistant. Antibiotic-resistant strains of bacteria are an increasing problem in hospitals.\nIndividuals that are poorly adapted to their environment are less likely to survive and reproduce than those that are well adapted. Similarly, it is possible that a species that is poorly adapted to its environment will not survive and will become extinct.\nHere are some of the factors that can cause a species to become extinct:\nchanges to the environment, such as a change in climate\nmany species have become extinct since life on Earth began\n. Extinction is still happening and a lot of it occurs because of human activities. We compete with other living things for space, food and water, and we are very successful predators.\nThe dodo was a large flightless bird that lived on Mauritius, an island in the Indian Ocean. The island was uninhabited and the dodo had no natural predators. Then Mauritius was colonised by the Dutch in 1638.\nDodos were hunted for food and easy to catch\nbecause they were not afraid of people. New competitors were brought onto the island, including pigs, cats and rats, which ate the dodos' eggs and their young.\nWithin 80 years, the dodo was extinct\n", 'label': '5'}
{'text': "Native American society seemed to lack order and regulation to the new settlers of the Great Plains, but they were looking for the wrong things. There was plenty of\namong the first people on the land, fostered by a range of customs and rituals.\nThe Native Americans were not one people, but many\n. The most famous tribes were the Apache, Sioux, Blackfeet and Cheyenne, each one led by its own Council of Elders.\nThe Native American way of government led new settlers on the Great Plains to think that the earliest inhabitants of the land had no government at all. This was not true, but their government was based on principles that the newcomers had difficulty in understanding.\nA Comanche tipi village by George Catlin\nFor example, a Native American chief had\nover his people, although he did have great\nfrom them, based on his bravery in war. And the only 'police' in Native American society were warriors called\n, who selected and broke camp, fed the old and the weak, stopped buffalo being scared away, and controlled the hunt.\nIn fact, the hunt was the only occasion when everybody had to obey. The Native American tribes did not need strict laws, because the harsh environment forced them to work together. Consequently, most tribes had\n, and the worst punishment was banishment (which meant death, given the harsh Plains environment). The only duty that members of the tribe had was to pray.\nBecause there was a need to take care of the women and children of the tribe,\n. At 17 a youth paid a dowry of horses and took his bride (aged 12-15). The Native Americans practiced polygamy (they had more than one wife), because many men died in the struggle to survive, so there was an excess of women to be cared for.\nto feed the old and the weak.\n(wandered off to die), as the tribe couldn't afford hangers-on.\nto be not looking after one's parents, hurting people who were sick, or harming the religion.\nand skill (eg stealing a tied horse).\nNo one was forced to go to war - individual warriors\nto follow the chief to war or not, as they felt best.\nThe bravest act of war was to score a\nTouching an enemy with a stick in warfare, instead of killing him.\n(where a warrior tapped his enemy with a stick and escaped).\nNative Americans scalped their enemy to stop him going to an afterworld they called the\nThe main aim in war was to stay alive, in order to care for the family (\nin this section and find examples of how Native American society was influenced by, or adapted to:\nthe harsh environment of the Great Plains\nAnswers to questions about how the environment of the Great Plains affected the way of life of Native Americans might include:\nThe dog-soldiers fed the old and the weak - it was an honour to feed them and the worst crime not to do so.\nMarriage was easy and involved polygamy .\nHorses were essential for survival - horse stealing (from other tribes) was admired.\nThe men had to try to stay alive, so no one was forced to go to war. The bravest act of war was a 'coup', and a main aim in war was to stay alive.\nOld people voluntarily exposed themselves to the elements, so they would die and not be a burden to the tribe.\nAnswers to questions about how the Native American religion affected the way of life of Native Americans might include:\nThey scalped their enemy to stop him going to the Happy Hunting Ground.\nthe Native Americans were able to live on the Plains.\ndifferent tribes lived on the Great Plains.\n", 'label': '5'}
{'text': 'The Earth has a layered structure made up of the core, mantle and crust. The lithosphere - the crust and upper part of the mantle - is broken into large pieces called tectonic plates. These move slowly over the mantle.\nVolcanoes occur when molten rock pushes up through weaknesses in the crust. The molten rock cools and solidifies to form igneous rocks, such as basalt, gabbro, rhyolite and granite.\nCross section showing structure of the Earth\nThe Earth is almost a sphere. These are its main layers, starting with the outermost:\n- has the properties of a solid, but can flow very slowly\n- made from liquid nickel and iron\n- made from solid nickel and iron\nconsists of the crust and outer part of the mantle. It is the relatively cold outer part of the Earth’s structure.\nThe Earth’s lithosphere is broken into large pieces called\ncontinental plates form the continents - land\nTectonic plates are less dense than the mantle, so they are found on top of it. The plates are moving constantly, at a rate of a few centimetres each year.\nWhere tectonic plates meet, the Earth’s crust becomes unstable as the plates push against each other, or ride under or over one another. Earthquakes and volcanic eruptions happen at the boundaries between plates.\nMagma - molten rock - is less dense than the crust. It can rise to the surface through weaknesses in the crust, forming a volcano.\nGeologists study volcanoes to try to predict future eruptions. Volcanoes can be very destructive, but some people choose to live near them because volcanic soil is very fertile. It contains minerals needed by plants for healthy growth.\nLava is the molten rock that erupts from a volcano. Some eruptions produce runny lava, while others produce thick lava that escapes violently. Igneous rocks are made when molten rock cools down and solidifies.\nIgneous rocks contain interlocking crystals. The size of the crystals depends on how quickly the molten rock cooled:\nif it cooled quickly, the crystals are small\nif it cooled slowly, the crystals are large\nThe slower the molten rock cools, the larger the crystals in the igneous rock.\nA summary of the properties of four igneous rocks and how they were formed\nBasalt is rich in iron, and rhyolite is rich in silica.\nThe mantle is the zone between the Earth’s crust and its core. It is relatively cold and rigid just below the crust. At greater depths, the mantle is able to flow because it is hot and non-rigid.\nThe theory of plate tectonics was proposed at the beginning of the last century by a German scientist named Alfred Wegener. It took more than 50 years for Wegener’s theory to be accepted. This was because it was difficult to work out the mechanism that could make whole continents move. It was not until the 1960s that enough evidence was discovered to fully support the theory.\nTectonic plates move because of convection currents in the Earth’s mantle. These are driven by the heat produced by the decay of radioactive elements inside the Earth.\nOceanic plates are denser than continental plates. Where they meet, the oceanic plate goes under the continental plate. This is called\n. The oceanic plate is partially re-melted. Check your understanding of this using the animation below.\nYour web browser does not have JavaScript switched on at the moment. For information on how to enable JavaScript please go to the\nYou will not be able to see this content until you have JavaScript switched on.\n', 'label': '5'}
{'text': 'Systems need to be controlled if they are to continue functioning the way they were designed to do.\nControls can be simple visual aids for the designer. Two examples are\ncorrect aligning of colour blocks in a printed product\nare used to make sure that colour printing lines up, because the various colours must line up with each other. Registration marks are usually shown in a cross shape. Sometimes work that is to be printed has\n, where the artwork for each colour is on a separate sheet.\nare standard bars of colour with blocks of each colour printed. This is done to show the strength and evenness of the ink used and that the registration of the colours is correct.\nThe table lists mechanical or electronic equipment used for control and feedback in graphic production.\nSpeed of movement of cutting blade; cutting fence can be set to required distance, which allows repetition\nPaper cut is ragged: blade may need sharpening/replacing; cut fewer sheets Wrong size: reset fence\nNumber of copies; paper type; quality of printout Repetition through repeat copies\nNumber of copies wrong: reset on computer Quality of print poor: change paper or ink cartridge\nSize of copy/enlarge/reduce; number of copies made; type of paper or other materials; quality of printout; copy too dark/light\nSize is wrong: reset size Number of copies wrong: reset number required Quality of print poor: change paper or toner cartridge Contrast wrong: adjust contrast control\nSpeed/depth of cut; pressure on cutter; order of cutting Repetition though repeating process\nCutting incorrect: adjust speed/depth and/or pressure through software or hardware controls Order wrong: reset though software controls\nSpeed/depth of cut; rotational speed of cutter; type/size of cutting tool; order of cuttingRepetition though repeating process\nCutting incorrect: adjust speed/depth, through software or hardware controlsOrder wrong: reset though software controls\nPost ideas and discuss Design and Technology here.\nGive your revision some visual style with a Bitesize revision map!\nGet creative!
