{'text': "Euthanasia is not suicide but the assisted ending of someone's life who is suffering. Most religions offer teaching on euthanasia and the end of life.\nEuthanasia is illegal in the United Kingdom but it was legalised in certain circumstances in the Netherlands in 2002 and assisted suicide was legalised in the State of Oregon (USA) in 1997.\n- the person concerned asks someone to help them die, perhaps by asking for help to take an overdose of painkillers\n- euthanasia is carried out without the patientâ€™s consent, for example, if they are in a persistent vegetative state and no longer able to live without a lifesupport machine, which is then switched off\nRemember that a person's decision to take their own life is known as 'suicide'.\nOld age and wisdom command the greatest respect in Hinduism and it is considered to be part of\n(duty) to honour, respect and care for elderly relatives.\nA man commands respect through his education, religious action, age, friends and wealth.\nPeople must be cared for until they die. Although Hindus have no religious objection to life-support machines, death is seen as a door into the next rebirth.\nAnd as a goldsmith takes the gold from an old piece of jewellery and shapes it into a more modern piece, so the Self forgets the old body, takes hold of another body, whether like that of the fathers, or of the celestial singers, or of the gods, or of the begetter, or of any other creature.\nHindus believe that all of life is sacred so they\n(respect for life) means that it's always considered wrong to take life even if someone is ill or in pain. Suffering is seen as the result of bad\n(actions, and the consequences of actions). The suffering has to be endured or the bad\nwill be carried forward into the next life.\nA Hindu who is very old or very ill may decide for themselves that the right time has come for death by choosing to stop eating or drinking. This act of renouncing the world shows that the Hindu realises that the world is not as important as it appears. This method of choosing death is often admired as a sign of great holiness.\nThe suicide of people who take their own lives because they are depressed or feel hopeless is not acceptable to Hindus, unless they took their lives as self-sacrifice or because they cannot live without someone who has just died.\n", 'label': '5'}

{'text': "Scientists, politicians and industrialists continue to debate the causes of global warming, with some arguing that it is a natural process that's been going on for centuries. However, the\n- established by the United Nations in 1988 - has stated the evidence suggests that human activity\naffect global warming, in particular through the release of greenhouses gases and the use of\nAerosol sprays contain pressurised liquids which are released as a fine spray by the use of gas. Before 1989 they used chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) which were found to damage the Earth's ozone layer.\nThere is also debate over how quickly the earth is warming up. Some scientists estimate that atmospheric temperatures could rise by 1.4° - 5.8°C in the next 100 years. Others believe that they will rise more slowly.\nThe map above shows which countries are responsible for the most emissions. LEDCs want to develop and to catch up with MEDCs and this normally means using more energy and burning more fuel. So global warming could threaten development.\nGlobal warming could melt the world's ice caps and glaciers, leading to an increase in sea levels. Some scientists estimate that over the next hundred years sea levels could rise by between 10cm and 90cm - making many coastal areas around the world uninhabitable.\nGlobal warming could also affect the weather patterns, leading to more droughts, flooding and extreme weather, such as\nHurricanes, typhoons and tropical cyclones are the same thing, but in different parts of the world. They are the strongest level of tropical storm with circling winds of more than 117km/h. They have a distinctive eye in the middle of the swirling clouds when seen from above.\nIn Britain we are largely unaffected by the dangerous weather of the\nThe Tropic of Cancer is the northern boundary of the tropics. It is found at a latitude of 23.5 degrees North, to the north of the equator. The southern boundary of the tropics is the Tropic of Capricorn 23.5 degrees South. Everything between these two lines is said to be tropical.\n, such as hurricanes or severe droughts. {'text': "The work you do as you prepare to make your art, craft or design object needs to be recorded in a work journal, log or sketchbook.\n. To satisfy our unnatural and unhealthy taste for cow\'s milk."\n, and the other is probably an\nDon\'t make it too difficult for yourself - just think: which statement could be proved to be true, and which could not?\nLosing your way? Es-tu déjà allé(e) en France ou en Belgique?\nHave you ever been to France or to Belgium?\nIf you haven't been to either country say so, and talk about another holiday instead.\n2. {'text': 'Light is one of the family of radiations called the electromagnetic spectrum. Some types of electromagnetic radiation are used to transmit information such as computer data, telephone calls and TV signals.\nThe pattern produced when white light shines through a prism is called the visible\nA series of similar waves, arranged in order of wavelength or frequency.\nThe prism separates the mixture of colours in white light into the different colours red, orange, yellow, green, indigo and violet.\nIn fact, visible light is only part of the\nThe different types of electromagnetic radiation, arranged in order of frequency or wavelength.\n. It’s the part we can see.\nElectromagnetic radiation comes in tiny ‘packets’ called photons.\nThe photons deliver different quantities of energy, with radio photons delivering the smallest amount, and gamma photons delivering the greatest amount of energy.\nIf the photons have enough energy, they can break molecules into bits called ions. This is called ionisation. These types of radiation are called\nThe different types of electromagnetic radiation, arranged in order of frequency or wavelength.\nonly the three types of radiation, which have the photons with most energy, are ionising. These are\nThe ions produced when ionising radiation breaks up molecules can take part in other chemical reactions. If these chemical reactions are in cells of your body, the cells can die or become cancerous. This is the reason that ionising radiation can be damaging to health.\nThe intensity of electromagnetic radiation is the energy arriving each second. This depends on two things: the energy in each photon, and the number of photons arriving each second.\nTo have the same intensity, a beam of red light would need ten times as many photons as a beam of ultraviolet, and a beam of microwaves would need a million times as many.\nEnergy of 1 ultraviolet photon\xa0\xa0\xa0=\xa0\xa0\xa0Energy of 10 red photons\xa0\xa0\xa0=\xa0\xa0\xa0Energy of 1 000 000 microwave photons\nAll forms of electromagnetic radiation deliver energy. This will heat the material that absorbs the radiation. The amount of heating depends on the intensity of the radiation, and also the\nAn object which gives out electromagnetic radiation is called a\nSomething which is affected by the radiation is a\nFurther from the source, the detector receives a lower intensity of radiation.\nAs the photons spread out from the source, they are more thinly spread out when they reach the detector.\nIonising radiation can break molecules into smaller fragments. These charged particles are called\n. As a result, ionising radiation damages substances and materials, including those in the cells of living things. The ions themselves can take part in chemical reactions, spreading the damage.\nultraviolet radiation, which is found in sunlight\nX-rays, which are used in medical imaging machines\ngamma rays, which are produced by some radioactive materials\nNot all types of electromagnetic radiation are ionising. Radio waves, light and microwaves are among them.\nMicrowaves are used to heat materials such as food. The molecules in the material absorb the energy delivered by the microwaves. This makes them vibrate faster, so the material heats up.\nthe intensity of the microwave beam is increased\nthe microwave beam is directed onto the material for longer\nSo you need to cook food for longer in a less powerful microwave oven. This is why they have power ratings, and food labels recommend different cooking times depending on this.\nElectromagnetic radiation emitted from a hot object.\nElectromagnetic radiation with a frequency between that of visible light and radio waves.\nLow frequency electromagnetic radiation used to transmit information such as television and radio programmes.\nare all used to transmit information such as computer data, telephone calls and TV signals.\nInformation such as computer data and telephone calls can be converted into infrared signals and transmitted by\n. Optical fibres are able to carry more information than an ordinary cable of the same thickness. In addition the signals they carry do not weaken so much over long distances. Television remote controls use infrared light to transmit coded signals to the television set in order to, for example, change channels or adjust the volume.\nMicrowave radiation can be used to transmit signals such as mobile phone calls. Microwave transmitters and receivers on buildings and masts communicate with the mobile telephones which are in their range.\nCertain microwave radiation wavelengths pass through the Earth’s atmosphere and can be used to transmit information to and from satellites in orbit.\nRadio waves are used to transmit television and radio programmes. Longer wavelength radio waves are reflected from an electrically charged layer of the upper atmosphere. This means they can reach receivers that are not in the line of sight because of the curvature of the Earth’s surface.\nMicrowaves and radio waves in the atmosphere\n', 'label': '5'}
{'text': 'Carol Ann Duffy was born in Glasgow in 1955. She moved to Staffordshire as a child with her family. After graduating in philosophy from Liverpool University, she became a full-time writer. Although her first works were published when she was 16, her first full poetry collection, Standing Female Nude, did not appear until 1985. She has since written five other collections that include poems about love, women, memory, desire and loss. She often writes dramatic monologues (poems from the point of view of a character) using the voice of an outsider or someone who is often ignored by others. She has been awarded both the OBE and the CBE.\nShe now lives in Manchester, where she teaches creative writing at the Metropolitan University and lives with her daughter, Ella (born in 1995).\nListen to the poem and watch the slideshow\nNobody hurt you. Nobody turned off the light and argued\nwith somebody else all night. The bad man on the moors\nwas only a movie you saw. Nobody locked the door.\nYour questions were answered fully. No. That didn\'t occur.\nYou couldn\'t sing anyway, cared less. The moment\'s a blur, a Film Fun\nlaughing itself to death in the coal fire. Anyone\'s guess.\nNobody forced you. You wanted to go that day. Begged. You chose\nthe dress. Here are the pictures, look at you. Look at us all,\nsmiling and waving, younger. The whole thing is inside your head.\nWhat you recall are impressions; we have the facts. We called the tune.\nThe secret police of your childhood were older and wiser than you, bigger\nthan you. Call back the sound of their voices. Boom. Boom. Boom.\nNobody sent you away. That was an extra holiday, with people\nyou seemed to like. They were firm, there was nothing to fear.\nThere was none but yourself to blame if it ended in tears.\nWhat does it matter now? No, no, nobody left the skidmarks of sin\non your soul and laid you wide open for Hell. You were loved.\nAlways. We did what was best. We remember your childhood well.\nAn extended speech performed by one person only\n: an angry parent (or parents) is talking to a grown-up child. The parent denies that the child was ever hurt or mistreated in any way, although it\'s clear that the child remembers things very differently...\nThe speaker sounds very much on the defensive: clearly the grown-up child has complained about something or asked an awkward question. The parent insists that the child was brought up well and was loved, and suggests that if the child thinks otherwise, they must be imagining it -\n"The whole thing is inside your head"\nLines of poetry that make up a unit; verses.\nof three lines, each of roughly the same length.\nThink about how the language the poet uses helps to convey her ideas. Here are some points to consider:\nThink about the title. We may often hear adults saying \'I remember my childhood well\', so it is significant that Duffy has deliberately twisted this to \'We Remember Your Childhood Well\'. The grown-ups definitely present themselves as in control.\nThe poem is written mainly in the past\nThe verb formation which describes the time at which the action occurred, eg past, present or future.\nhowever, reminding us that it is dealing with memories. As readers, we cannot be sure whose memory is more accurate - the parents\' or the child\'s. Is the child exaggerating about the horrors that appear to have taken place? Or are the parents guiltily trying to convince themselves that they didn\'t happen?\nWe don\'t know if it is a mother or a father talking. The pronoun \'We\' is used frequently, so whoever is speaking seems to be conveying the thoughts of them both. They could even be talking together (try reading the poem imagining that the mother and father speak alternate stanzas). We also don\'t know whether they are speaking to a son or a daughter: there is nothing to indicate the gender. Perhaps the vagueness is deliberate, to suggest that any parent/child relationship may end up with such tensions like this at some point.\nWe never hear the voice of the person being spoken to, the \'You\' of the poem. We only know their viewpoint through what the parent says. Imagine the reaction of the grown-up child to such vehement denials. How do you think they would feel?\nA group of lines of poetry that make up a unit - like a paragraph in a piece of prose; a verse.\nbegins with a statement that denies what the child believes to have happened - \'Nobody hurt you\' (line 1), \'Nobody sent you away\' (line 13), as if trying to crush the child\'s view of events. There is an apparent contrast between the parent\'s view and the child\'s. \'Nobody forced you. You wanted to go\' (line 7) suggests the parents saw things in one way while the child saw things completely differently. However, sometimes the parent seems to change tack mid-stream, \'You couldn\'t sing anyway, cared less\' (line 5), which could hint that their position is less clear than the child\'s.\nA feeling of potential conflict between a group of people. In an audience or reader, a sense of potential conflict, or a feeling of anxiety due to what may be about to happen.\nbetween the speaker and listener. We get the impression that the listener is not given much chance to speak - or, if they do, that it is ignored. The parents\' repeated denials are so dominant that the child doesn\'t get a word in edgeways.\nTo some extent, the poem raises more questions than it answers. It is\nA text written by a person of unknown name or identity.\nand so we know little about the speaker (or speakers) or the child they are addressing. The events being denied are left deliberately vague. We wonder what \'didn\'t occur\' (line 4); where did the family \'go that day\' (line 7)? The lack of detail both pulls us into the poem - we really want to know what happened! - and shuts us out. Since the parent doesn\'t need to spell out what they are talking about to their child, the closeness of the family - and the fact that we are outsiders - is emphasised.\nThe parent-child relationship has obviously broken down. Whichever version of events is right, any love and trust between the parents and child has been destroyed. Have the parents \'won\'? The last sentence, a repeat of the title, \'We remember your childhood well\', is their final, decisive word.\nThere are many frightening ideas in the poem that are suggested but not developed:\n(line 2), a door being locked (line 3), the child being\n(line 13). It is left to us to imagine exactly what happened on those occasions, but there is a definite sense of fear on the part of the child. Again, we wonder exactly what took place - who do we believe?\nThere are a number of violent verbs - \'hurt, argued, forced, begged\' - which add to the sense of danger.\n(line 11) brings in an even darker\nA central, unifying idea that runs through a text or performance.\n, once more creating questions for the reader. Who are these secret police, described as\n- the parents themselves, assuming a role of authority and power, or some other dictatorial group?\nWords that express the sound they stand for, eg \'crunch\', \'pop\'.\n(line 12), which would have drowned out any attempt by the child to put their own point of view. We associate a booming sound with explosions and bombs, so did the voices have the same sort of effect on the child as a bomb attack would have done? It is ironic that the parent uses the\nA description of one thing in terms of another - implicitly comparing the two, but without using \'as\' or \'like\'. \'Sea of troubles\', and \'drowning in debt\' are metaphors. Something that represents another thing.\n(line 10) to indicate the control they had over the child, when the \'music\' produced was so violent.\nA group of lines of poetry that make up a unit - like a paragraph in a piece of prose; a verse.\n(line 16) are and what is meant by\n(line 17). What hellish situation is the grown-up child now in? There is a sense of bitterness. It is clear that in the child\'s view at least their current awful situation is the result of what happened in their childhood.\nWhere a phrase or word is repeated several times to emphasise or make a particular point.\nin the poem. Nobody and No are heard constantly, so the negative ideas are hammered home.\nThe pattern of stressed and unstressed syllables in a line of poetry.\ncreated by the short sentences within the lines. This gives a feeling of awkwardness, perhaps mirroring the relationship between the parents and child. Nothing is smooth or easy.\nIn poetry, the use of words which have the same or a similar sound - eg \'flow\' and \'bow\' - to form a pattern of sound.\n, but not regular. Sometimes rhymes occur at the ends of lines (moors / door and tune / Boom), sometimes there is internal rhyme (Hell / well). This creates an uneven echo, adding to the\nA feeling of potential conflict between a group of people. In an audience or reader, a sense of potential conflict, or a feeling of anxiety due to what may be about to happen.\nMuch of the meaning of a poem is conveyed by the\nit expresses toward its subject matter. \'Attitude\' can be thought of as a combination of the poet\'s\nhe or she is trying to get across to the reader.\nA good way to decide on the\nThe mood or manner of a text or part of a text. The author\'s \'tone of voice\' or way in which they expect to be understood. The emotional load carried by a text.\nof a poem is to work out how you would read it aloud.\nin a harsh, firm way - the parents not only treated the child badly, but now deny that they did, which emphasises their coldness and lack of feeling.\nin a guilty way - the parents realise that they did not really do what was best (line 18) and are now sorry for it.\nwith genuine urgency, as if the parents love the child still and desperately want to be believed. Perhaps the child really did have an over-active imagination and has fabricated everything ...\nWell, there are certainly elements of both harshness and guilt in the tone of this poem. But genuine love? Perhaps it would be\nto read it this way, but for most readers there is too much evidence of the parents\' guilt to make this interpretation convincing!\nThe central idea in this poem is the extent to which people can deceive themselves about how they have behaved. This is shown by the yawning gap between\nwhat the reader can hear being said\nbetween the lines. The parents present themselves as blameless: but as the poem progresses it becomes clearer and clearer to the reader that this is far from the case.\nHere are some examples of this discrepancy between what the parents\ntheir words to mean, and what they\nWhat you recall are impressions; we have the facts.\nYour childhood memories are not accurate; we remember things as they really were.\nThe parents are discounting the child\'s view of events - even though it was the child who actually experienced these things - and arrogantly assume that adults always \'know better\'.\nThat was an extra holiday, with people you seemed to like.\nThe child was positively lucky to get an extra holiday, and with nice people too!\nThe parents were eager to send their child away, and not too fussy about whether the child really did like these people.\nThere was none but yourself to blame if it ended in tears.\nThe child was on holiday in the care of nice people, so it must be the child\'s fault if they didn\'t enjoy themselves.\nSomething obviously went badly wrong on this holiday. The people \'were firm\': does this mean \'brutal\'?The parents seem shockingly unconcerned about the child\'s tears...\nThis was a normal childhood in a normal, loving family.\nThe verb formation which describes the time at which the action occurred, eg past, present or future.\nis used: it does not say You are loved - suggesting the child is no longer loved, even if it once was.\nIn the exam, you will be required to write about several poems, some pre-1914 and some post-1914. To which poems would you compare\n? There will be a number of ways in which the poems can be compared, and you may well be able to think of ones which we have not!\nWhat to look for in your comparison\nBoth poems look at the power the older generation have over the younger but \'We Remember\' is from the older generation\'s point of view, Kid from that of the younger generation.\nRobin in Kid has broken free from Batman and now has the upper hand; the child in the Duffy poem still feels downtrodden.\nA feeling of potential conflict between a group of people. In an audience or reader, a sense of potential conflict, or a feeling of anxiety due to what may be about to happen.\nbetween generations, both from the point of view of the older generation.\nThe young people in the Yeats poem seem to have a pleasant time of it; the child in We Remember seems very unhappy.\nBoth poems about the distance between parent and child, both from the point of view of the older generation.\nMargaret\'s love for her child is clearly genuine - the parents \'love\' in the Duffy poem rings hollow.\nIn the exam you\'ll be asked to write about four poems, two pre-1914 and two post-1914 (Heaney and Clarke or Duffy and Armitage), comparing and contrasting them with each other. The poems will usually have something in common - such as their subject matter, or an aspect of their language, or the ideas expressed - but also important differences. In comparing them, you may be able to notice things about the way the poems convey their meanings which you might not have noticed before.\nWhen you are asked to compare poems, it\'s a good idea to run through in your mind each of the headings under which we have looked at the poems in the revision bite:\nsubject matter, structure, language and imagery, sound, ideas, and attitudes and tone\nCompare We Remember Your Childhood Well with one other post-1914 poem and two pre-1914 poems of your choice that focus on the relationship between two generations.\nThree poems suitable for this comparison would be Simon Armitage\'s Kid, W B Yeats\'s Song of the Old Mother, and William Wordsworth\'s The Affliction of Margaret.\nWhat would you want to include in your comparison? On a piece of paper, note down some points to make in comparing We Remember Your Childhood Well with each of these three poems.\nIn answering this question you might comment on:\nNow have a go at answer the question, just as you would do in the exam.\nto look at some sample answers to this question...\nWe Remember Your Childhood Well: Test (answer hints)\nBoth poems look at the influence of those in a position of power over young people\n... but in Kid, the child breaks free, whereas in We Remember the parents still seem to have a hold.\nKid is from the point of view of the younger character, whereas We Remember is the voice of the older.\nKid contains humour, yet We Remember is more threatening.\nYeats: The Song of the Old Mother\nBoth poems see tension between two generations.\nBoth are from the point of view of the older generation.\nIn neither poem are the young able to put their own point of view\n... but it does seem that the young people in Yeats\'s poem are satisfied with life - in contrast to the child in Duffy\'s.\nBoth poems are from the point of view of the older generation.\n... and both seem subtly to complain about the younger generation. Margaret complains that she has not heard from her son, while in We Remember, the speaker seems on the defensive with the insistent Nobody...\nMargaret\'s love of her son appears true and genuine (she states I have no other earthly friend), while the speaker in Duffy\'s poem leaves this ambiguous - You were loved.\nBoth poems are about the distance between parents and a child, yet in Margaret\'s case it is an enforced separation, whereas in We Remember we feel that the separation is the fault of the parents.\nOf course, these suggestions do not contain everything there is to say! You may have thought of other relevant points, and there may be other poems you have read which you could use in your comparison. The important thing is to be able to write two or three sentences pointing out similarities and differences between the poems.\n', 'label': '5'}
{'text': "Benidorm ha cambiado mucho en las últimas décadas. En el pasado era un pueblo pesquero típico español, pero hoy se ha convertido es un centro turístico de mucha importancia para el comercio Español. {'text': "- Russia was too big to rule. In 1913, it stretched 4,000 miles from Europe to Alaska, and comprised 125 million people.\n- Russia was backward. It had few roads and limited industrialisation. Most people were still peasants.\n- Russia was militarily weak. It had lost a war with Japan in 1904.\n- Russia had many different nationalities, languages and religions.\n- the government of Russia, which Nicholas ruled over alone, was far too much work for one man.\n- Russia was industrialising and the workers, eg in St Petersburg, were poor and oppressed. On Bloody Sunday 1905, they went on a peaceful march to ask the tsar to help them, but the Cossacks attacked them.\n- the representatives of the new middle class industrialists. They called themselves the Kadets and wanted Russia to have a constitution like England's. In 1905, there was a revolution and they managed to force Nicholas to create a Duma (parliament), but it had no real power.\n- for instance, the Social Revolutionaries and the Marxists - split into the Mensheviks who wanted peaceful change and the Bolsheviks who wanted a revolution - committed acts of terrorism such as the murder of Prime Minister Stolypin in 1911.\nBack to Russia/USSR 1905 - 1941 index\nFed up with reading? {'text': 'The main reasons people objected to the construction of railways were:\nParliament did not like passing Acts of Parliament for railways\nbecause they were worried that the new fast speeds of trains would cause health problems for passengers.\nFarmers and landowners did not like the idea of new railway tracks passing through their farm land\nbecause they believed that the smoke would destroy crops and scare their animals into giving birth prematurely or dying.\nat the idea of new railway tracks because they believed that it would hinder fox-hunting.\nSome people did not like the idea of\nmen and women travelling in the same train carriage\nby railway companies, but failed to do everything they could to try to prevent them from stealing their businesses.\nBack to Transport 1700 - 1900 index\nAll things historic - from ancient to modern.\nMaking the Modern World - The Growth of the Railways\nInstitute of Railways Studies and Transport History\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': 'In Section B of Paper Two you will be asked to write in order to\n. The writing might be linked to a theme or idea from the Poetry from Different Cultures, but this is not always the case. This Revision Bite will help you learn the difference between informing, explaining and describing.\nYou feel ill and go to see a doctor.\nWhich of the following is informing, explaining or describing?\nDescribing - you are telling the doctor how you feel.\nInforming - the doctor gives you the facts.\nExplaining - the doctor explains what a cold is and tells you a little bit more about it.\nThese areas do tend to overlap, but you should keep in mind that:\nExplanation is factual, but with more detail.\nDescription is usually about how something makes you feel.\nTo inform means to give facts to another person.\n, eg what is involved in this job.\nGive the readers a bit more information, eg what is interesting about the job and what you enjoy about it.\nRemember you are giving information. Imagine that someone asked about your job because they are thinking they might like a similar one.\nWrite informatively about a job you have now, you have had in the past, or are interested in.\nTo explain means to make clear, show the meaning or to account for.\nyou are writing to. This question does not give you a specific audience so you must assume you are writing for anyone who might be interested, eg parents and children.\nyou are writing to them, eg "being fair is a good quality in a carer because...".\nBeing a parent or guardian is never easy. Explain what you think makes a good parent or guardian.\nTo describe is to give a description of what something or someone is like.\nare important in this sort of writing, eg how does this place make you feel and why?\nTry and think about using the sorts of devices you have seen in poetry and literature, eg\nA description of one thing in terms of another - implicitly comparing the two, but without using \'as\' or \'like\'. \'Sea of troubles\', and \'drowning in debt\' are metaphors. Something that represents another thing.\nAn explicit comparison of one thing to another, using the words \'like\' or \'as\'. \'Sleeping like a log\' and \'bright as a button\' are similes.\nPlaces can seem different at different times of the day. Choose a place you know well and describe it at two different times of the day.\nAs with any piece of writing in English, you can organise and improve your writing by:\nUsing your own knowledge, experiences and observations.\nBeing precise in your choice of words.\nPlanning your answers in the exam carefully.\nHere’s a question that tests all the skills described in this section:\nWrite a letter from the headteacher of your school to parents of Year 11 students, informing them about a planned trip, explaining why the trip will be useful and describing the activities that will take place.\nHave a look at the following letter written in response to the exam question\nWe are having a trip to Newtown Outdoor Pursuits Centre on 10 December for all Year 11 students. We shall leave at about 9 o\'clock and will be back during the evening.\nAt the Centre, students will be able to do whatever they want, eg rock climbing, orienteering, abseiling and canoeing. They will need a packed lunch but no special clothes.\nWe think they will have fun there, and the cost will be £10 each which you should send in to school as soon as you can.\nPlease let me know if your child does not want to go.\nNow that you know the kind of skills needed to make a letter\n, think about how this answer can be improved.\nThe examiner\'s verdict demonstrates how the student could have answered the question better. These are some of the faults in the original letter, with suggestions about how you could improve it.\nA title to the letter would be helpful, so that readers know what to expect and what information to look for.\nThe information given is too vague, eg parents need to know the exact times and places of departure and arrival.\nIt\'s also helpful to state the day as well as the date of the trip, and to give more details of special arrangements, eg about safety, what will happen if the return is delayed, etc.\nThe description of what takes place at the Centre is too brief, eg there is no information about supervision of the students, or what specific clothing is needed for the activities.\nThe explanation of why the trip is taking place is vague and is also mixed up with information about the cost.\nInformation about paying is vague, eg who should the money be sent to? Should it be cash or a cheque?\nThere is no explanation about what will be done with students who don\'t go on the trip, or what will happen if not enough want to go.\nParents are not given information about how to find out more about the trip.\nThe language is too simple, eg \'child\'. Although the letter is polite, it should be more detailed and informative.\nNow read the second answer to the exam question and see how the examiner\'s comments have been incorporated into the answer.\nCHANGED A title to the letter would be helpful, so readers know what to expect and what information to look for.\n) Visit to Newtown Outdoor Pursuits Centre\nWe are planning to take all Year 11 students on a visit to Newtown Outdoor Pursuits Centre on Thursday 10 December (\nThe information given is too vague, eg parents need to know the exact times and places of departure and arrival.\n). We shall leave school immediately after registration in the morning, and we intend to be back at the main school entrance by 7 o\'clock in the evening. We shall be travelling by Brown\'s Executive Coaches, which are fitted with seat belts and speed limiters. If our return is delayed for any reason, you may contact the company for information on 01234-567890. (\nIt\'s also helpful to state the day as well as the date of the trip, and to give more details of special arrangements, eg about safety, what will happen if the return is delayed, etc.\nSix teachers and several parent volunteers will accompany the students, who will be in groups of no more than ten throughout the day, always with at least one adult. (\nThe description of what takes place at the Centre is too brief, eg there is no information about supervision of the students, or what specific clothing is needed for the activities.\nIf your son/daughter comes on the trip, s/he will need to bring a packed lunch, and sufficient drinks for an energetic day! No spending money is necessary, as there are no shops at the Centre. Although the letter is polite, it should be more detailed and informative.\nConvey your meaning simply and accurately to readers.\nUse language that is right for the particular audience.\nSet out your writing clearly and helpfully.\nUnderstand exactly what your readers need to know.\nUse a wide range of words to give precise instructions, explanations or descriptions.\nUse suitable presentational devices to help convey your meaning.\n', 'label': '5'}

{'text': "Germany's allies during the war also received treaties dealing with their punishment. These treaties were drawn up by officials and followed the principles set out in the Treaty of Versailles.\nFour other treaties were made with the countries that had helped Germany during the war.\nThe Treaty of Versailles, however, was the template for these treaties, which were drawn up by officials (not by the big three) and which simply\nHere are the main provisions of each treaty - showing 1) terms of disarmament, 2) amount of reparation, 3) land lost, 4) new countries formed - starting with the Treaty of Versailles.\nGermany: Treaty of Versailles (28 June 1919)\n132 billion gold marks to be paid in reparations\nAfterwards: The Dawes and Young Plans re-scheduled Germany's payments.\nAustria: Treaty of Saint Germain (10 Sept 1919)\nthe Austro-Hungarian empire was dismantled, Tyrol lost to Italy\nAfterwards: Austria went bankrupt before the amount of reparations could be set.\nHungary: Treaty of Trianon (4 June 1920)\nAfterwards: Hungary could not pay the reparations, so its payments were suspended.\nBulgaria: Treaty of Neuilly (27 Nov 1919)\n20,000 volunteers, four torpedo boats, no air force\nTurkey: Treaty of SÃ¨vres (10 Aug 1920)\n50,000 soldiers, seven sailboats and six torpedo boats\nSmyrna and East Thrace to Greece, Rhodes to Italy\nKurdistan, Armenia, Hejaz (Arabia). Iraq and Palestine became British mandates. Syria became a French mandate\nAfterwards: Turkish nationalists, led by Kemel Attaturk, rebelled and rejected the treaty.\nTo help you remember, copy or print out the terms of the treaties, cut them up, shuffle them, then see if you can put them back together again correctly.\nAs part of your revision, think about the\nthe treaty-makers of 1919-1923 treated the defeated countries.\nthe main features of Eastern Europe were as decided by the peace-makers of 1919-1923.\n", 'label': '5'}
{'text': "A group of lines of poetry that make up a unit - like a paragraph in a piece of prose; a verse.\nof 24 lines. The lines are pentameters (they have 10 syllables each).\nThink about how the language the poet uses helps to convey his ideas. Here are some points to consider:\nThink about the title. It does not tell us anything about Batman and Robin - it's only when we begin to read the poem that the identity of the 'kid' becomes clear. However, if we go back to the title having read the poem, it may remind us of other young people who are caught up in the shadow (line 20) of someone they admire, and their need to forge their own identity.\nBatman is at first presented as a real superhero: he is described at the start in the alliterative phrase Batman, big shot, as someone who gives orders to Robin. Yet as we read on, his status is diminished. We hear that he\n(line 4) Robin and had an affair with a married woman (line 10). We see him at the end all alone, cooking an unappealing meal for himself (\n(line 21), with next to nothing (line 22) in the house to eat. Can it be that he cannot manage by himself, without Robin around? He is shown as anxious to get going,\n(line 23) with boredom, but unable to do anything.\nThis poem contains various examples of slang, for example naval slang -\n(line 2), British slang - the ordinary word motor (line 11) for the amazing Batmobile, and American slang -\n(line 24). The mixture of styles adds humour and perhaps helps to illustrate the growing-up process: Robin is trying out a mixture of things.\nThere is a serious message behind the comedy - we are encouraged to consider whether heroes and hero-worship can really sustain young people growing up. However marvellous the admired person may be, a young person has to learn to be independent -\n(line 18) and to live their own life.\nGive your revision some visual style with a Bitesize revision map!\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. While you will be able to view the content of this page in your current browser, you will not be able to get the full visual experience. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n", 'label': '5'}
{'text': "There are four main stages in setting up a new computer system: Analysis - studying the problem; design - designing a solution; implementation - putting the solution into effect and testing it; evaluation - checking that the solution is working as intended. This process is often called systems analysis.\nDeveloping and activating a new computer system is a long process. It is important to break the process down into smaller stages, each one requiring a different set of professional skills.\nAn important part of this process is the first stage -\n. During this stage the systems analyst will investigate how the current system works and what needs to be improved. This involves finding out whether a new computer system is needed at all and exactly what it will be used for.\nAnalysis is all about looking at how a job is done at present and seeing if the job could be done better or more efficiently by upgrading or developing a new system.\nWith this goal in mind, the systems analyst might:\na step by step guide, eg a guide to using a piece of software including instructions, example scenarios and screenshots\nand any printouts the current system creates\nHaving investigated the present system, the systems analyst will produce a\n. This will look at whether the new system is:\n- is the new system technically possible to implement in the time available?\n- will the cost of the new system be offset by savings once it is implemented, ie will it save the organisation time, money or increase its performance?\nThe project will only continue to the next stage if the answer to both of these questions is yes. At this point the decision makers in the organisation, eg the board of directors, decide whether or not to go ahead.\nThe next step is to draw up a\nthat outlines exactly what the new system will do. For example, it will mention:\na general term used to describe an application or a program\nthe term denoting either an entrance or changes which are inserted into a system and which activate/modify a process\nthe term denoting either an exit or changes which exit a system and which activate/modify a process\nA test plan will be included in the design phase to explain exactly how the new system will be tested and the expected outcomes for each test.\na general term used to describe an application or a program\nis usually very complex. Any mistakes made by the designers or programmer can have a dramatic effect depending on what the software is used for.\nUsually software is tested with three distinct types of\ninformation without context, eg a list of students with numbers beside their names is data, when it's made clear that those numbers represent their placing in a 100 metre race, the data becomes information\n– this is normal data the system should be working with.\n– this is data at the boundary between typical data and invalid data.\nInvalid data (sometimes known as erroneous data)\n– this is data that should cause the system to tell the user that there is a problem with data entered into the system.\nTesting helps to ensure that the system always acts as expected.\nImplementation is the next stage of developing a new system, after design. This is where the new system is created and installed.\na list of instructions written in a programming language\na general term used to describe an application or a program\na resource - for example, a collection of documents containing all the information a user needs to know about using and getting support with a piece of software\ntesting the system using the test plan\nIf the tests are not satisfactory then any problems will need to be corrected and the system tested again.\nUser documentation will be written to help staff become familiar with the new system. It will include:\na step by step guide, eg a guide to using a piece of software including instructions, example scenarios and screenshots\nthe term denoting either an entrance or changes which are inserted into a system and which activate/modify a process\nthe term denoting either an exit or changes which exit a system and which activate/modify a process\ntaking a screen shot of what's displayed on screen and saving it in an image file, eg as a *.jpg, *.bmp or *.gif\ndetails of what error messages mean, ie troubleshooting advice\nWhen the system is ready to go on-line there are different ways of moving from the old to the new system:\nRunning both the old and new system until you are certain the new system is working correctly. Parallel running is likely to be the most expensive as it involves doing the work twice for a period of time. However, it is the safest. If there are any bugs in the new system, you can always go back to the old system while the problems are corrected.\nChanging over in a small part of the company to start with. Only when the system is deemed satisfactory will it be rolled out to the rest of the organisation. A supermarket introducing a new 'self-scanning' system might choose to introduce it in two or three stores at first. This is a pilot changeover.\nThe old system is scrapped and immediately replaced by the new system. With this option there is a danger that there may still be problems with the new system. Even though it is the most risky type of changeover, many companies use this method.\nThe change over is split into phases or stages. Each stage is introduced one at a time and the old system is kept running to do the remainder of the tasks that have not yet been changed.\nOnce the system has been installed it will be monitored to check whether it is working correctly. Sometimes problems with a system will not be found until it is being used by a large number of people or an unusual situation occurs.\nEvaluation is really re-analysing - starting the same systems analysis process all over again. Many of the same techniques can be used, such as interviewing staff or sending out questionnaires.\nOnce a system is running correctly it can still need maintenance. This may be because a bug is found or because the company needs a new feature.\n", 'label': '5'}
{'text': "You will also need to know about the\nThe 1936 Constitution changed the name of the Central Executive Committee to the Supreme Soviet.\nThe Supreme Soviet was empowered to set up Commissions, which administered most of the government.\nThe leader of the Presidium was declared to be the Head of State.\nThe 1936 Constitution thus focussed power in Stalin's hands.\nIt also gave everyone some good things such as rights to vote (but only for the Communist Party), to work, to rest and leisure, to health protection, to care in old age and sickness, to housing and education.\nBack to Russia/USSR 1905 - 1941 index\nFed up with reading? {'text': "Public health is about avoiding the spread of disease within a particular society - often through providing water to help people keep themselves, their animals and their surroundings clean. Is there any\nPrehistoric people would not have had any concept of public health - they did not settle in one place, so would have seen no need to build things like\nPrehistoric family leaving cave, and its accumulated dirt and litter, on way to their next resting place\nIt's unlikely that they had any idea of personal health either. The Australian aborigines of recent times did have some practices that seem 'healthy' - for instance, they buried their excrement far from the camp - but they did so for\n(to stop an enemy finding it and stealing their spirit) rather than for\n. {'text': "The opening lines of the poem are dark. The 'greyness' (line 1) is heightened by the heavy alliteration 'in drizzle of one despondent dawn' (line 2) and even the approaching 'sunbreak' (line 4) does not lift the atmosphere.\nThere are metaphors of horror and death: the 'dead tree' (line 6) branch on which the vultures are roosting is described as a 'broken bone' (line 5), while the male vulture's bashed-in head is a 'pebble on a stem' (line 9) and its body is a 'dump of gross feathers' (line 11).\nIn the second section, the vultures' affection leads the poet on to muse about the nature of love. Love is personified as a woman finding a place to sleep. She is 'in other ways so particular' (line 23) and hard to please, yet, strangely, she chooses to sleep with the vultures, 'that charnel house' (line 26). Yet why does love sleep with 'her face turned to the wall' (line 28)?\nWe see the 'Belsen Commandant' - a mass murderer - as Daddy. Why does Achebe use a child's name for him rather than 'father'?\nIn the fourth section, the poet again uses metaphors: the evil Commandant is 'an ogre' (line 43) with merely a spark of love - 'a tiny glow-worm tenderness' (line 44) in the 'icy caverns of a cruel heart' (line 46). These are fairly clichÃ©d images, perhaps because Achebe wanted to suggest that what he is describing is nothing new: there will always be love and evil in the world.\nThe 'germ' (line 48) of love does not seem to grow as a normal seed would because the 'perpetuity of evil' (line 50) is bound up with it and prevents it from developing. (Think of wheat germ rather than disease-carrying germs.)\nThere is some alliteration in the poem, but, otherwise, Achebe concentrates on visual images rather than sound effects to present his ideas.\nBack to Poems from different cultures index\nGet some direction with a Bitesize revision map\nGet creative, get published and get expert writing advice at BBC Blast.\nContemporary Postcolonial and Postimperial Literature in English\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "Charles Darwin was an English naturalist who studied variation in plants and animals during a five-year voyage around the world in the 19th century. He explained his ideas on evolution in a book called, 'On the Origin of Species', published in 1859.\nDarwin’s ideas caused a lot of controversy, and this continues today, because they can be seen as\nabout the creation of the world and the creatures in it.\nThe basic idea behind the theory of evolution is that all the different species have evolved from simple life forms. These simple life forms first developed more than 3 billion years ago (the Earth is about 4.5 billion years old). The timeline below shows some of the key events in the evolution of life on Earth, from the first\nSingle-celled micro-organisms, some of which are pathogenic in humans, animals and plants. Singular is bacterium.\nYour web browser does not have JavaScript switched on at the moment. For information on how to enable JavaScript please go to the\nYou will not be able to see this content until you have JavaScript switched on.\nThe theory of evolution states that evolution happens by natural selection. The key points are that:\nindividuals in a species show a wide range of variation\nthis variation is because of differences in their\nThe basic units of genetic material inherited from our parents. A gene is a section of DNA which controls part of a cell's chemistry - particularly protein production.\nindividuals with characteristics most suited to the environment are more likely to survive and reproduce\nthe genes that allow these individuals to be successful are passed to their offspring\nIndividuals that are poorly adapted to their environment are less likely to survive and reproduce. This means that their genes are less likely to be passed to the next generation. Given enough time, a species will gradually evolve.\ncan be caused by both genes and the environment. But it is only variation caused by genes that can be passed on to the next generation.\nLife on Earth today exists because of the conditions that were present when life was evolving. If, in the past, conditions had been different eg hotter, colder, or the Earth more or less massive, then evolution by natural selection could have produced some very different results. Our bodies would have changed to suit the Earth’s conditions.\nBack to Evolution, nerves and hormones index\nAn activity that would make Darwin proud!\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': ", which is when the audience knows something which characters in the play do not. For instance, we know that Iago wants the handkerchief as evidence of Desdemona having an affair. However, even Emilia, who has picked up the handkerchief, has no idea he is using it for this reason. We also know that the conversation between Cassio and Iago about a woman is designed to enrage Othello, but Cassio has no idea about this. And even when Desdemona goes to speak to Othello towards the end of the play, we know he intends to kill her, but she is unaware. Dramatic irony is often used to make the audience more involved - we know what is happening but feel powerless to do anything (and that is why we are the audience, not the actors).\nThe key to understanding dramatic effect is to think about the feelings being created in the audience. It's not about reading the play but experiencing it. And the feelings we have are not accidental, but created by putting certain events together, or by explaining a character's thoughts and motivations, or by suggesting what will happen next. We might feel anger, disbelief or sympathy. Try to include something about dramatic effect in your work, as it shows you understand how the play works.\nRead the full text online and make your own notes.\nGet creative, get published and get expert writing advice at BBC Blast.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n", 'label': '5'}

{'text': "Timing and rhythm are vital to all forms of music. Without this the sound becomes unformulated and the musicians cannot play in unison.\nThe tempo of music is measured in BPM, or\ninute. 60 BPM is 1 beat a second.\nSometimes this is written at the beginning of the music and is called a Metronome marking.\nTempo and stylistic feel is often indicated in classical music by Italian terminology\nThis diagram shows the different durations of different types of note.\nThe Semibreve lasts for 4 crotchet beats.\nThe Minim lasts for 2 crotchet beats.\nThe Quaver lasts for half a crotchet beat (so there are two to the time of a crotchet).\nThe Semiquaver lasts for a quarter of a crotchet beat (so there are 4 to the time of a crotchet).\nYour web browser does not have JavaScript switched on at the moment. For information on how to enable JavaScript please go to the\nYou will not be able to see this content until you have JavaScript switched on.\nThe top number indicates the number of beats in each bar.\nThe bottom number is a code for what the beat is measured in.\nThe common codes for the bottom number are:\nThis means there are 4 crotchet beats in each bar.\nThis means there are 6 quaver beats in each bar.\nThis means there are 2 minim beats in each bar.\nA dot after a note increases its value by half again. So:\nA dotted crotchet lasts for 1 and a half crotchets.\nA dotted quaver lasts for 1 and a half quavers.\nTo understand this properly, it's best to listen to some examples of dotted rhythms and get the 'feel' of them.\nYour web browser does not have JavaScript switched on at the moment. {'text': 'A system is a set of components arranged to carry out a particular function. All systems have\nSystems for manufacturing graphics products require planning; system flowcharts are useful for this. They also need to be controlled, and these system controls can be visual, mechanical or electronic devices. Production systems also need to be checked for quality - a procedure called\n, depending on the scale of production. Computer-aided manufacture (CAM) is widespread in all kinds of graphics production.\nA system is a set of components arranged to carry out a particular function. Systems may include mechanical, electrical or electronic components. The block diagram below represents a system for producing a batch of leaflets.\nis what goes into the system - the raw materials. In a music system the input usually comes from a CD player or radio tuner.\nis the shaping and forming of the materials, or the exchange of information needed to effect the output. In a music system it is the amplifier that does the processing.\nis what comes out of the system - the finished product. In a music system, the speakers take care of the output.\nMost systems have a fourth element -\n- which is simply a way of changing the input or process as a result of what happens at the output. In a music system, feedback is a human response to the output from the speakers: if the music is too loud, or the radio tuned to the wrong station, the user will reduce the volume or retune the radio. In a system diagram feedback is shown like this:\nAn example of feedback in a production system is checking that the product meets the specification, and adjusting the process to make sure it does. Many systems have an automatic type of feedback, where feedback from one part of the system switches another part of the system on or off. This sort of system is called a\nWhen planning a production system you need to work out how the different elements of the system fit together, with each part in the right order. A flow chart is a good way of doing this. The one below shows how to organise the production of a school newsletter.\nAny large-scale production system of the kind you would find in manufacturing is likely to include the following processes:\nof raw materials, bought-in components, sub-assemblies and part finished products.\nof bought-in components to make sure they are of the required quality; Inspection of part-finished products to ensure they meet specifications; artwork. Inspection has to be done at all the crucial points in the production process.\nof raw materials, part-finished products and complete products.\nUse these symbols when drawing a flowchart for large-scale production system\nSystems need to be controlled if they are to continue functioning the way they were designed to do.\nControls can be simple visual aids for the designer. Two examples are\ncorrect aligning of colour blocks in a printed product\nare used to make sure that colour printing lines up, because the various colours must line up with each other. Registration marks are usually shown in a cross shape. Sometimes work that is to be printed has\n, where the artwork for each colour is on a separate sheet.\nare standard bars of colour with blocks of each colour printed. This is done to show the strength and evenness of the ink used and that the registration of the colours is correct.\nThe table lists mechanical or electronic equipment used for control and feedback in graphic production.\nSpeed of movement of cutting blade; cutting fence can be set to required distance, which allows repetition\nPaper cut is ragged: blade may need sharpening/replacing; cut fewer sheets Wrong size: reset fence\nNumber of copies; paper type; quality of printout Repetition through repeat copies\nNumber of copies wrong: reset on computer Quality of print poor: change paper or ink cartridge\nSize of copy/enlarge/reduce; number of copies made; type of paper or other materials; quality of printout; copy too dark/light\nSize is wrong: reset size Number of copies wrong: reset number required Quality of print poor: change paper or toner cartridge Contrast wrong: adjust contrast control\nSpeed/depth of cut; pressure on cutter; order of cutting Repetition though repeating process\nCutting incorrect: adjust speed/depth and/or pressure through software or hardware controls Order wrong: reset though software controls\nSpeed/depth of cut; rotational speed of cutter; type/size of cutting tool; order of cuttingRepetition though repeating process\nCutting incorrect: adjust speed/depth, through software or hardware controlsOrder wrong: reset though software controls\nQuality control is a specialised type of system control designed to check that a product meets the design specification and is of the prescribed quality. Before making a product, the designer should decide what quality checks need to be done, and at what stage in the making process they should be carried out.\ndo what it is supposed to do\ncheck against the specification: does the product meet all aspects of the specification?\nis the text accurate, spelt correctly, with correct grammar and layout?\nhave the correct shades of colours been used?\nare the registration marks correct and do they line up?\nhave correct desktop publishing (DTP) layout templates been used?\ncheck measurements: are they within the tolerances specified?\nfor products such as pop-up books, check the cut and fit of different parts: do they fit accurately and neatly without gaps?\nfor products such as pop-up books and cards, check to see if the product works properly and as intended: do parts move as required?\nThere are four main types of production system used in manufacturing graphic products, each one suitable for a different scale of production.\nis when only one of the product is made. It is labour-intensive, because every product is different. One-off graphic products might include a presentation book as a souvenir of a special event, or a model of a theatre set.\nis when a set quantity of the product is made. It may also use a lot of labour, but jigs and templates are used to aid production. Often the machines can be easily changed to produce a batch of a different product. Batch-produced graphic products include programmes for a play or concert, or posters to advertise a play or concert.\nis when a very large number of the product is made, usually on a production line - but the process cannot be continuous because the product regularly changes. Examples of mass-produced graphic products are newspapers and magazines.\nproduction is when many thousands of products are made. The difference between this and mass production is that the production line is kept running 24 hours a day, seven days a week, to eliminate the expense of stopping and restarting the production process. The process is often automated and few workers are required. Continuous-flow production is used for graphics products which sell very large numbers throughout the year, and do not need to be frequently changed - such as cereal packaging.\nInformation and communications technology is widely used in manufacturing graphics products. Its benefits are that:\nit makes it easy to produce accurate, complex, standardised drawings\nIt allows complex shapes to be made with ease and precision\nit enables changes to be made quickly and easily, and\nit greatly simplifies batch or mass production\nCAM machines are good for batch or mass production, and they are also useful for one-off products that are complicated to make. There are two types of CAM machine:\nPlotter/cutters can be used either for cutting of card and vinyl, or (by replacing the blade with a pen) to produce drawings and lettering prior to cutting. Cutter/printers are more complex CAM machines which allow full-colour printing before cutting is done.\nThese are mainly used for cutting plastics, hard wax, soft metals and wood-based materials such as MDF. They are particularly useful for making prototype models and moulds for vacuum-forming. Some of these machines can have a scanner head fitted in place of the cutting tool, allowing 3D scanning to be done.\n', 'label': '5'}
{'text': "When an aircraft carrying British children who are being evacuated from a war zone crashes on a remote island, killing all adults, the children realise that they will have to survive on their own and no one knows where they are.\nThey begin life on the island full of excitement, but gradually the order they tried to create breaks down. The civilised schoolboys become savages.\nChapter 1 - Sound of the Shell\nRalph and Piggy meet on the beach, having survived the crash. They introduce themselves, then enjoy swimming in a lagoon. {'text': 'Linkages are mechanisms which allow force or motion to be directed where it is needed. Linkages can be used to change:\nA linkage consists of a system of rods or other rigid materials connected by joints or pivots. The ability of each rod to move will be limited by moving and fixed pivots. The input at one end of the mechanical linkages will be different from the output, in place, speed, direction and other ways.\nA reverse-motion linkage changes the direction of motion. In the diagram below, note how the linkage looks a little like a "\n". See how the central rod moves around a central fixed pivot. By pulling (or pushing) the linkage in one direction, it creates an exact opposite motion in the other direction. If the fixed pivot was not central, it would create a larger or smaller motion in the opposite direction.\nYour web browser does not have JavaScript switched on at the moment. For information on how to enable JavaScript please go to the\nYou will not be able to see this content until you have JavaScript switched on.\nA parallel-motion linkage creates an identical parallel motion. In the diagram below, note how the linkage looks a little like an "\n". This time, it is the two side rods that move around two central fixed pivots, while the top of the "\n" moves freely. By pulling (or pushing) the linkage in one direction, it creates an identical parallel motion at the other end of the linkage.\nYour web browser does not have JavaScript switched on at the moment. {'text': 'is deliberately vague about many aspects of the plot, but as you will see the characters in the story give plenty of scope for investigation.\nstarts with an old man looking after his pigeons. He has a favourite - a young, healthy bird that he is holding carefully. The man looks out happily across the countryside, until he sees his granddaughter swinging on a gate in the distance. The old man suddenly appears annoyed. He almost allows the young pigeon to fly off, then grabs it and locks it away in the small box.\nHe calls to his granddaughter, Alice, who comes over to speak to him, even though it is clear she is waiting to meet her boyfriend, Steven. The grandfather criticises her and threatens to tell her mother about the relationship. The girl simply laughs and says: \'Tell away!\' She then wanders off singing a love song to annoy him.\nThe old man thinks about how the house was once full of grandchildren and full of life, but as the children grew up it became empty and he would soon be alone. He wants to apologise to Alice, but only mutters it - she cannot hear what he starts to say. He then becomes angry when he sees her meet her boyfriend and walk around the garden with him.\n\'Can\'t we keep her a bit longer?\'\nThe old man talks to his daughter\nThe grandfather goes into the house feeling confused and angry, thinking all the time about his granddaughter and believing she has made a mistake by falling in love with Steven. He speaks to his daughter, Lucy, who does not seem at all concerned about Alice and Steven.\nLucy tries to calm her father down, but he gets more and more angry. He thinks about how all his granddaughters changed as soon as they got married. Lucy in turn blames her father for upsetting her girls - then announces Alice is to get married in a month\'s time. The old man says nothing. He walks out into the garden crying.\n"He lifted the bird on his wrist, and watched it soar."\nThe grandfather and Steven watch the pigeons fly away\nThe grandfather meets Alice and Steven almost immediately. Steven has a gift for him - a young pigeon - and the couple both fuss around the grandfather and lead him over to where the other pigeons are kept. They then move away to chat in private while the old man looks after the new bird, then locks it away in a box.\nThe old man takes out his favourite bird - the one he would not release at the start of the story. He knows it is too young to return to him, but lets it go anyway. Alice, Steven and Lucy all see the pigeon fly up, and the old man gets the impression that everything has stopped - even the wind - to watch this bird escape.\nThe older pigeons have also flown up, and they return. The young bird, the man\'s favourite, has disappeared. He smiles proudly at his granddaughter. She seems astonished by his actions and stares at him, crying.\nis a very short story. We do not know many facts about the four main characters, and the events take place over perhaps just an hour in the man\'s life. We learn very little of what took place before this, and nothing of what happens after.\nThe story is deliberately unclear, especially when you look for reasons why someone does something. For instance, we cannot be sure why the old man lets his favourite bird leave. And we can only guess why Alice is crying at the end.\nWe do, however, get a clear picture of the different characters and their relationships with one another. This is what you need to concentrate on in your answers. The next section looks in detail at how you should write about the characters, and what part they play in the story.\n', 'label': '5'}

{'text': 'Power stations fuelled by fossil fuels or nuclear fuels are reliable sources of energy. This means they can provide power whenever it is needed. However, their start-up times vary according to the type of fuel used.\nNuclear power stations and coal-fired power stations usually provide ‘base load’ electricity - they are run all of the time because they take the longest time to start up. Oil-fired and gas-fired power stations are often used to provide extra electricity at peak times, because they take the least time to start up.\nThe fuel for nuclear power stations is relatively cheap, but the power stations themselves are expensive to build. It is also very expensive to dismantle old nuclear power stations, and to store their radioactive waste, which is a dangerous health hazard.\nRenewable fuel resources do not cost anything, but the equipment used to generate the power may be expensive to build. Certain resources are reliable, including tidal barrages and hydroelectric power. Others are less reliable, including wind and solar energy.\nBack to Living for the future index\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. While you will be able to view the content of this page in your current browser, you will not be able to get the full visual experience. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n', 'label': '5'}
{'text': "William Blake: The Little Boy Lost / The Little Boy Found\nThe poem is extremely simple, and does not use effects like\nWords strung together with repeated (often initial) consonants, eg Max made many men mad.\nWords that express the sound they stand for, eg 'crunch', 'pop'.\n. Instead, Blake used short words - mostly of only one syllable - and a simple\nFather, father, where are you going? Oh do not walk so fast! {'text': "In the exam you'll be asked to write about four poems, two pre-1914 and two post-1914 (Heaney and Clarke or Duffy and Armitage), comparing and contrasting them with each other.\nThe poems will usually have something in common - such as their subject matter, or an aspect of their language, or the ideas expressed - but also important differences. In comparing them, you may be able to notice things about the way the poems convey their meanings which you might not have noticed before.\nWhen you are asked to compare poems, it's a good idea to run through in your mind each of the headings under which we have looked at the poems in the revision bite:\nsubject matter, structure, language and imagery, sound, ideas and attitudes and tone.\nHomecoming shows how anger may be followed by reconciliation. Compare Homecoming with one other post-1914 poem and two pre-1914 poems of your choice that examine conflict within a relationship.\nThree poems suitable for this comparison would be Duffy's We Remember Your Childhood Well, Blake's Little Boy Lost/Little Boy Found, and Browning's My Last Duchess.\nWhat would you want to include in your comparison? {'text': "When scientific data has been collected, it is important that this data and any conclusions are reviewed by other scientists. This is called 'peer review'.\nUsing the example of how lifestyle factors can affect the risk of heart disease, you need to be able to:\nDescribe the peer review process. For instance, state that other scientists repeat the experiment to see if they get similar results and conclusions.\nUnderstand that new scientific claims are less reliable if they have not yet been evaluated by peer review. For example, remarkable claims are being made for 'superfoods', such as that they prevent heart disease and increase longevity. However, many of the claims have not yet been peer reviewed, so they should not be treated as totally reliable.\nUnderstand that if the results of an investigation have not been replicated by other scientists, they should be treated with suspicion.\nUsing the example of how lifestyle factors can affect the risk of heart disease, you need to be able to explain why scientists think it is important that a claim by one scientist should be replicated by other scientists. This is because the first set of results may contain errors. When scientific research is being paid for by a company with a vested interest, such a food company producing a food that is claimed to lower cholesterol, the results that support the claim need to be examined and replicated to make sure that they are correct.\nAn activity that will get blood to your brain!\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': 'Forum theatre is a technique you can use while acting out a scene. The group watching is encouraged to\n. At other times, the actors themselves can stop the action, and ask for help. Sometimes someone else can step in and take over a role - or even introduce a new one.\nWhy use forum theatre? What can it add to a drama?\nSometimes it is hard, when devising drama, to imagine what a character might\nat a particular moment. {'text': 'Michèle Roberts had a troubled relationship with her mother, a major theme of\n, it is useful to know something about the author and what may have inspired her story.\nMichèle Roberts was born in 1949 in London. She had a strict Catholic upbringing and, as she grew up, came to disagree with the way her religion viewed women. In an interview with the BBC World Service, she said:\n"We had to be forgiven for being women before we even began to try to be good, we had to get over having the bodies we had. This really pushed me into wanting to write as a way of opposing what was very constricting, and actually painful, in my life."\nHer family disapproved of her writing. In particular, she had a troubled relationship with her mother, although in recent years she has become close to her again. Roberts explores mother/daughter relationships in much of her writing.\n', 'label': '5'}

{'text': "Explaining what you want to achieve and getting other people to join in are very important skills.
