{'text': "Work done and energy transferred are measured in joules (J). The work done on an object can be calculated if the force and distance moved are known.\nA change in momentum happens when a force is applied to an object that is moving or is able to move. The total momentum in an explosion or collision stays the same.\nYou should know, and be able to use, the relationship between work done, force applied and distance moved.\nWork and energy are measured in the same unit, the joule (J). When an object is moved by a force, energy is transferred and work is done. But work is not a form of energy - it is one of the ways in which energy can be transferred.\nThis equation shows the relationship between work done, force applied and distance moved:\nwork done (joule, J) = force (newton, N) × distance (metre, m)\nThe distance involved is the distance moved in the direction of the applied force.\nA force of 10N is applied to a box to move it 2m along the floor. What is the work done on the box?\nThe work done is 10 × 2 = 20J.\nCheck your understanding of this by having a go at the activity.\nYour web browser does not have JavaScript switched on at the moment. For information on how to enable JavaScript please go to the\nYou will not be able to see this content until you have JavaScript switched on.\nAny object that is raised against the force of gravity stores\n. For example, if you lift a book up onto a shelf, you have to do work against the force of gravity. The book has gained gravitational potential energy.\nElastic objects such as elastic bands and squash balls can change their shape. They can be stretched or squashed, but energy is needed to change their shape. This energy is stored in the stretched or squashed object as\n(sometimes called movement energy). The more mass an object has, and the faster it is moving, the more kinetic energy it has. You should be able to discuss the transformation of kinetic energy to other forms of energy.\nSeveral energy transfers happen when a squash ball is dropped onto a table and bounces up again.\nWhen the ball is stationary above the table, its gravitational potential energy (GPE) is at a maximum. It has no kinetic energy (KE), or elastic potential energy (EPE).\nAs the ball falls, its GPE is transferred to KE and the ball accelerates towards the table.\nWhen the ball hits the table, the KE is transferred to EPE as the ball squashes. As the ball regains its shape, the EPE is transferred to KE and it bounces upwards.\nWhen the ball reaches the top of its travel, all the KE has been transferred to GPE again. Note that the ball will be lower than it was when it was first dropped, because some energy is also transferred as heat and sound to the surroundings.\nThe pendulum is a simple machine for transferring gravitational potential energy to kinetic energy, and back again.\nWhen the bob is at the highest point of its swing, it has no kinetic energy, but its gravitational potential energy is at a maximum. As the bob swings downwards, gravitational potential energy is transferred to kinetic energy, and the bob accelerates.\nAt the bottom of its swing, the bob’s kinetic energy is at a maximum and its gravitational potential energy is at a minimum.\nAs the bob swings upwards, its kinetic energy is transferred to gravitational potential energy again. At the top of its swing, it once again has no kinetic energy, but its gravitational potential energy is at a maximum.\nNote that the bob’s swing will become lower with each swing, because some energy is also transferred as heat to the surroundings.\nHere is a version of the 'Work and Energy' podcast with drawings to help explain things.\nIn order to see this content you need to have both\n. This is the tendency of the object to keep moving in the same direction. It is difficult to change the direction of movement of an object with a lot of momentum.\nYou can calculate momentum using this equation:\nmomentum (kg m/s) = mass (kg) × velocity (m/s)\nmagnitude - an amount because it depends on the object’s mass\ndirection - because it depends on the velocity of the object\nWhat is the momentum of a 5 kg object moving at 2 m/s?\nSo long as no external forces are acting on the objects involved, the total momentum stays the same in explosions and collisions. We say that momentum is conserved. You can use this idea to work out the mass, velocity or momentum of an object in an explosion or collision.\nA bullet with a mass of 0.03 kg leaves a gun at 1000 m/s. If the gun’s mass is 1.5 kg, what is the velocity of the recoil on the gun?\nmomentum of bullet = mass × velocity\nRearrange the equation: velocity = momentum ÷ mass\nvelocity of recoil on gun = 30 kg m/s ÷ 1.5 kg\nWhen there is a car crash, the car, its contents, and the passengers, decelerate rapidly. They experience great forces because of the change in momentum, which can cause injury. If the time taken for the change in momentum on the body is increased, the forces on the body are reduced too. Seat belts and crumple zones are designed to reduce the forces on the body if there is a collision.\nSeat belts stop you tumbling around inside the car if there is a collision. However, they are designed to stretch a bit in a collision. This increases the time taken for the body’s momentum to reach zero, so reduces the forces on it.\nAir bags increase the time taken for the head’s momentum to reach zero, so reduce the forces on it. They also act a soft cushion and prevent cuts.\nCrumple zones are another safety feature in cars\nYou should know, and be able to use, the relationship between kinetic energy, mass and speed.\nThis equation shows the relationship between kinetic energy (J), mass (kg) and speed (m/s):\nWhat is the kinetic energy of a 1,000kg car travelling at 10m/s?\n× 1,000 × 100 = 50,000J (or 50kJ)\nCheck your understanding of this section by having a go at the activity.\nYour web browser does not have JavaScript switched on at the moment. For information on how to enable JavaScript please go to the\nYou will not be able to see this content until you have JavaScript switched on.\nYou need to be able to calculate the force involved in changing the momentum of an object. Here is the equation you need:\nThe force is measured in newtons, N. The time is measured in seconds, s.\nA 25 kg bicycle is travelling at 12 m/s. What force is needed to bring it to a halt in 5 s?\nMomentum at start = 25 × 12 = 300 kg m/s\nMomentum at end = 0 × 12 = 0 kg m/s\nChange in momentum = 300 - 0 kg m/s\nSo a force of 60N is needed.\nYou should see that, for a given change in momentum, the longer the time taken, the smaller the force needed. This is the idea behind many car safety features. It also explains why it takes a long time to stop a super-tanker at sea, or to change its direction.\nWatch this illustrated podcast on momentum to get a summary of how momentum and motion are related.\nIn order to see this content you need to have both\n", 'label': '5'}
{'text': 'Ideas about science - values - higher\nSome people believe employers should have access to our genetic profile when we apply for a job. In the future, they may be able to use this information to determine how much time we are likely to take off due to illness, and use this information to help decide whether or not to offer us a job.\nInsurance companies may also want access to our genetic profile. They could use this information to see how long we are expected to live, and maybe either refuse to give us insurance or only provide it at an increased cost.\nfrom 2007 about a company offering genetic testing for around £1,000.\nBoth of these are examples of values that science cannot address. Genetic testing is an example of what is\n, ie what can be done. But the decisions we take on how to use this information are an example of\n, and cannot be ‘answered’ by science.\nSociety is going to have to decide who has access to our genetic profile. For example, should we all be on a\nThe material inside the nucleus of cells, carrying genetic information. DNA stands for Deoxyribonucleic Acid.\ndatabase to help the police to catch criminals? Or is this a step too far, because in the future it could allow employers and insurance companies access to data we would rather they did not see?\nScientific data does not change according to who is reading it. But values can change, especially in different environmental and social contexts. For instance, many Roman Catholics think abortion is a sin, but many other people do not and decide to have an abortion because they think it is the right thing to do.\nFed up of reading? {'text': "This exercise will help you answer questions in an examination as well as possible.\nIf you worked through the Revision and Test Bites, you will have spotted lots of advice about how to answer questions. Can you remember what was said? Doing well in examinations is not just about learning the subject, it's also about making sure that you understand the questions and write good answers. So what should you do if you are going to do as well as possible in an examination? Here are some tips:\nMake sure that you arrive in good time for the examination. Get everything that you need ready in advance. There's nothing worse than having to rush.\nCheck the starting time and how long the exam will last. Do not get taken by surprise. You can get this information from your teacher at school.\nMake sure you know how many questions you have to answer and how long you can afford to spend on each.\nMake sure that your watch is working. Put it on your desk where you can see it, rather than wearing it on your wrist where you will have to stop and look at it.\nAlways have at least two pens and make sure that they are working. They must be blue or black - but check this with your teacher first.\nIf you like to draw diagrams, have a pencil handy and sharpen it.\nMake sure that you have everything else that you need. A picture of your pet or something that makes you laugh will help you feel positive in your exam.\nMake sure that you understand where you have a choice of questions. You usually do on history papers. Check back through some Revision Bites to see some example questions if you are not sure what they will be like.\nAlways read the question carefully and spot the key words,\n, etc. Usually the two papers will have different types of questions. One will be\n. Make sure you know which is which.\nPlan your answer before you start writing. It helps just to jot down a list of points and then cross them off when you write your answer. This is really important in order to make sure you do not forget to include all your points.\nMake sure that you are answering the\nand not the question which you hoped would be on the paper! This is the commonest mistake made in examinations.\nIt counts for half the marks lost by candidates in examinations\nIf the question is made up of sub-questions, read through all of them first. This will help you to decide if you can answer the question. It will also help you to work out how long to spend on each question.\nSometimes one sub-question will lead on to another. Try to make sure that you do not put the two answers together.\nCheck the number of marks for each sub-question. The more marks available, the longer the answer should be normally.\nSPG stands for Spelling, Punctuation and Grammar. How neat your handwriting is does not count but it helps if you try to keep it in order.\nThere are an extra five marks available for correct SPG. To get five marks you will need to spell accurately and express yourself clearly. You will need to use correct historical terms. Here are a couple of examples:\nThe Prime Minister of Germany is called the Chancellor.\nWhen talking about after 1924 Russia should be called the Soviet Union.\nMake sure that you use capital letters for all names of people, countries, cities, towns etc.\nCopy words carefully from the question paper, particularly names like Czechoslovakia.\nPut full stops after every sentence and make sure that each sentence makes sense.\nCheck through your answers if you have time.\nRemember that your answers will be marked by someone who does not know you.\nThe examiner will not be able to understand your answer if you do not explain things properly.\nMake your answers as clear as possible. Do not try to be funny.\nThe examiner will have four hundred scripts to mark. Try to make sure that yours is easy to mark. Do exactly what the questions ask you to do.\n", 'label': '5'}
{'text': "In a bid to improve roads, the first Turnpike Trusts were set up in 1663. These organisations introduced tolls on roads and aimed to use the money raised to maintain the roads. However, the Turnpike Trust scheme still had its problems.\nThe first attempt in Britain to improve roads started in 1663. This was when the Turnpike Trust was set up. The trusts had one simple aim:\nto charge people to use newly improved roads\nand then the money raised from the tolls was used to pay for the upkeep of the roads.\nwho were sometimes more interested in making a profit than maintaining the good condition of roads for their customers. The businessmen had to get an Act of Parliament passed to build their turnpike and had to employ professional road surveyors, treasurers and reputable road engineers.\nA carriage passes through the toll gate while engineers survey the road\nAs you can see from the illustration, the road engineers built\ngates across the entrance of the roads\nand then toll keepers collected tolls from people using the roads. People were charged different tolls depending on the method of transport they were using. This money was then meant to be used to maintain the roads.\nSome trusts did maintain their roads and\n(such as Thomas Telford) to build straighter and better roads. However, people who had always used local roads did not like suddenly having to now pay for the same route. For example, during the Rebecca Riots in Wales (1842-44) rioters dressed as women burned down toll keepers' cottages and tollgates in protest at road tolls.\nBack to Transport 1700 - 1900 index\nAll things historic - from ancient to modern.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "Christianity: beliefs about care of the planet\nChristianity: beliefs about care of the planet\nThe relationship between human beings and the earth is increasingly complicated and urgent. {'text': "of carbon (it has two extra neutrons in its nucleus making it unstable).\nThere's a small amount of radioactive carbon-14 in all living organisms. When they die no new carbon-14 is taken in by the dead organism. The carbon-14 it contained at the time of death decays over a long period of time. By measuring the amount of carbon-14 left in dead organic material the approximate time since it died can be worked out.\nSome people believe the Turin shroud is almost 2000 years old and the burial cloth of Jesus Christ.\nIt was carbon dated in 1988, and scientists found the shroud to be from the 13th of 14th century.\n. Uranium has a very long half-life and so by measuring how much uranium is left in a rock its approximate age can be worked out.\nGive your revision some visual style with a Bitesize revision map!\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "information without context, eg a list of students with numbers beside their names is data, when it's made clear that those numbers represent their placing in a 100 metre race, the data becomes information\nneeds to be backed up for many reasons:\na user may delete an important file\na device used to store vast amounts of data, the data is stored on a disk\na small program written to cause harm to a computer\na fire may destroy the building where the data was being stored (businesses will often store their\nto copy data onto a separate storage device in case the original device should fail, be damaged or the data stored on it get corrupted\nIf the data wasn’t backed up then the consequences could be disastrous depending on what data was lost. If a business lost details of all the payments it had yet to receive the business could go bankrupt as they wouldn’t know what was owed to them or by who.\nBusinesses typically use magnetic tape to backup important data. Your average home user is unlikely to backup their data but those who do will most likely use an external hard disk.\nSome data is more valuable than other data and some data is changed more frequently than other data. These are the kind of issues that must be taken into account when deciding how often to backup data.\nThe value of the data should determine how frequently it is backed up.\nIf the data doesn’t change often then it doesn’t need to be backed up as often, maybe just after each change. If the data changes frequently then it should be backed up frequently (maybe every evening).\nSome data may not be being used very often but it may still be useful or needed in the future. In this case data can be archived. Archived data is copied to a suitable storage medium (perhaps\nused to store data, eg a movie\nor magnetic tape) then it is stored safely and securely. The original data is then deleted from the computer system. This is done to free up storage space for new data.\nPost ideas and discuss ICT and DiDA here.\nICT Dictionaries and Encyclopaedias - Webopedia: Online Computer Dictionary for Internet Terms\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "You'll need to show your use of some of these elements in your portfolios for\nTeen pregnancy theme in popular soap 'Eastenders'\nof the drama is shown in the 'through-line' of the drama - its beginning, middle and end - although it doesn't have to be presented in a\nTo follow a series of events in real-time without the use of flash-backs or flash-forwards\nstructure. The characters in a play are also part of the plot.\nof the drama consists in the events that the characters take part in as they act the play.\nof the drama lies in the themes it deals with, eg bullying, the responsibilities of power, the bravery of ordinary people etc.\nThe form of a drama is the way that the story is told, the way the characters play their parts, and/or the way the themes are explored.\nThere are various dramatic forms, for example:\nA mime technique in which actors use their bodies to create props or part of the set\nYou'll need to choose the best way to communicate your drama.\nThe use of climax and anti-climax (the building and releasing of tension) in a drama is crucial, as it creates a sense of\nin the audience. We can become incredibly tense as we wait to see what's going to happen in a play, and then we're\nwhen things turn out well. It all adds to an interesting experience.\nFor example, will the guard notice that the escape tunnel entrance is partly uncovered? If the action is slowed down - perhaps because he sits down and talks for a while - the tension rises as we watch him. If the guard leaves without noticing the tunnel, the tension releases and we sigh with relief. It's up to the\nof a drama to create the climax and anti-climax that make sure this happens.\nThe use of contrast in drama productions - eg\n, or silence contrasted with noise - is a useful way to focus the audience's attention. A drama being played with no change of pace or rhythm doesn't usually hold our interest, but most can be\nwith the use of contrasting sights and sounds.\nAn example of such contrast could be in a courtroom drama. At first there's the\nof bringing in the prisoner, with everyone scurrying around trying to see and hear the judge's pronouncement. Then there's the sound of the gavel banging on his desk - and the resulting\nbefore he pronounces the sentence. The audience can't fail to be interested!\nThe way an actor plays a role, using his/her acting skills to create a character in a drama, is known as characterisation.\nThink about how we describe someone. Of course everyone looks a bit different, but a person's character can be shown in many ways, and this is where the actor's skill comes in. You can show a character in the way they walk and move (\nThe non-verbal way in which a person communicates their physical and mental state through using facial expressions, gesture and posture\n), in the way they speak (vocal qualities) and in their reaction to events in the drama.\nWhen creating a character we may use techniques such as\nTo question an individual while they remain in character\nto develop the role, but we also need to think about these other aspects of presenting the character so they can 'come alive' within the drama.\nWatch the video example by clicking on the link.\nNote: this link will open in a new browser window.\nThere's a range of dramatic conventions (techniques) that have been used to create dramatic effects in plays and spectacles for centuries. Among these are:\nA speech performed by an individual, often depicting that person thinking or talking aloud\nestablishing one part of the space as one location, and a different part of the space as another location\nProp - torn wedding photograph - what could it represent?\nDramas are produced to a great extent through the use of symbols - or representations - standing in for real things. Many of the following can be understood as symbols.\nprops (eg a torn wedding photograph to represent a divorce)\ngestures (eg finger on lips as a symbol of silence)\nexpressions (eg open mouth to represent surprise)\ncostume (a white costume as a symbol of innocence)\nlighting (eg blue lighting to represent night-time)\nsetting (dry ice vapour to represent a snowy wood)\n", 'label': '5'}
{'text': "You should know some of the properties and uses of gamma radiation and X-rays.\nThe number of repetitions per second of a wave. The unit of frequency is the hertz, 'Hz'.\n. Gamma radiation cannot be seen or felt. It mostly passes through skin and soft tissue, but some of it is absorbed by cells.\nGamma radiation is used, among other things, for the following purposes.\nto kill cancer cells (note that lower doses of gamma radiation could lead to cells becoming cancerous)\nX-rays have a lower frequency than gamma radiation. Like gamma rays, they cannot be seen or felt. X-rays mostly pass through skin and soft tissue, but they do not easily pass through bone or metal.\nX-rays are used to produce photographs of bones to check for damage such as fractures. They are also used in industry to check metal components and welds for cracks or other damage.\nLower doses of X-rays can cause cells to become cancerous, so precautions are taken in hospitals to limit the dose received by patients and staff when X-ray photographs are taken.\nFor more information about gamma radiation, visit\nBack to Waves, radiation and space index\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "To recap, the cost (C) of hiring this taxi to travel ‘n’ miles, when a taxi firm charges 50p per mile plus a fixed charge of £2.00 is:-\nC = £2 + (n x 50p)\nTo find the cost of the taxi for a journey of 20 miles, replace 'n' with 20.\nC = £2 + (20 x 50p)\nWhat is the cost of hiring this taxi for 16 miles?\nRemember that C = £2 + (16 x 50p)\nSee if you can do it better than Einstein!\nMake sure your maths skills add up.\nBBC World Service - Figure it out\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': 'When an unbalanced force is applied to an object, the object will accelerate. The size of the acceleration depends upon the force applied and the mass of the object. There is a relationship between force, mass and acceleration (force = mass × acceleration).\nGravity is a force that attracts objects with mass towards each other. The weight of an object is the force on it due to gravity. There is a relationship between weight, mass and acceleration of free-fall (weight = mass × acceleration of free-fall). The gravitational field strength of the Earth is 10 N/kg and its acceleration of free-fall is 10 m/s\nAll objects have mass. It is a measure of how much material the object contains, and it is measured in kilograms (kg). When a force is applied to an object it will accelerate. The size of this acceleration depends on the size of the force and the mass of the object.\nWhen an unbalanced force is applied to an object, the object will accelerate. The bigger the force, the greater the acceleration.\nDoubling the size of the unbalanced force doubles the acceleration.\nAn object will accelerate in the direction of an unbalanced force. The bigger the mass of the object, the smaller the acceleration.\nFor an activity that is out of this world!\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': 'You should know how stars are formed.\nStars form from massive clouds of dust and gas in space\nGravity pulls the dust and gas together\nAs the mass falls together it gets hot. A star is formed when it is hot enough for a\nto start - the hydrogen nuclei fuse together to make helium. This releases energy which keeps the core of the star hot.\nDuring this stable phase in the life of a star, the force of gravity holding the star together is balanced by the high pressure due to the high temperatures. Our Sun is at this stable phase in its life.\nThe Sun is halfway through its 10 billion year stable phase\nFor an activity that is out of this world!\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "All animal and plant cells have a nucleus, cytoplasm and a cell membrane. Plant cells also have a cell wall, chloroplasts and a vacuole. Different parts of the cell are adapted to perform different functions.\nHumans grow at different rates at different stages in their lives. Gestation and infancy are the times of fastest growth.\nAll animals and plants are made of\n. Animal cells and plant cells have features in common, such as a\nalso have a cell wall, chloroplasts and a large vacuole.\nContains enzymes and other chemicals â€“ it's the site of most cell\nof material into and out of the cell\nAbsorbs light energy and uses it to produce sugars in photosynthesis. Chloroplasts mainly found in leaf cells.\nProvides support by exerting pressure on the cell contents. Contains a solution of minerals and other nutrients.\nGrowth in plants and animals - higher only\nPlants and animals grow and differentiate their tissues in different ways. The main differences are outlined in the table below.\nMainly at shoot and root tips and in special growth zones like buds\nNew cells can be made by most tissues\nSize increase often caused by increasing the size of cells by absorbing water into the vacuole\nSize increase is brought about by increasing the number of cells\nMost plant cells can differentiate into different cell types\nOnly stem cells can differentiate into different cell types. Other animal cell functions remain fixed.\nfound in animals, that have the ability to grow into different tissues. They offer a possible\nfor many diseases caused by cell damage. Some people\nto research using stem cells that have been taken from\n. Other sources of stem cells are umbilical cords and bone marrow.\nHumans grow at different rates at different stages in their lives. Growth is very rapid in the womb and in the first two years of life. Puberty is another stage when growth and development is rapid.\nDependent on others for food and care\nPeak health and fitness but no increase in height\nHuman gestation is around 40 weeks although infants can survive if born earlier than this. Other mammals have different gestation times depending on their size, the number of offspring and how independent they are when born. Large animals with a small number of independent offspring have the longest gestation.\nWhen humans are born, their heads are relatively large, and their legs relatively short. Through childhood their bodies grow faster than their heads until they reach maturity. To check that development is happening at normal rates, infants regularly have their mass and head circumference measured.\n", 'label': '5'}

{'text': 'Antibiotics are drugs that kill bacteria, but not viruses. Certain antibiotics can be used to treat fungal infections, such as thrush.\nDrugs are substances that cause changes to the body. Some can help the body, others can harm it. Certain drugs can be\nand their existence has been known of for a long time. For example, willow bark was used by the ancient Greeks to help cure fevers and pains. It was later discovered that the active ingredient was salicylic acid. This was modified by chemists into the substance we call aspirin, which is less irritating to the stomach than salicylic acid.\nNew medical drugs have to be tested to ensure they work and are safe before they can be prescribed. There are three main stages:\nThe drugs are tested using computer models and human cells grown in the laboratory. Many substances fail this test because they damage cells or do not seem to work.\nDrugs that pass the first stage are tested on animals. In the UK, new medicines have to be. But it is illegal to test cosmetics and tobacco products on them. A typical test involves giving a known amount of the substance to the animals, then monitoring them carefully for any side-effects.\nDrugs that have passed animal tests are used in clinical trials. They are tested on healthy volunteers to check they are safe. The substances are then tested on people with the illness to ensure they are safe and work.\nYou may wish to view this BBC News item from 2006 about a drugs trial that left six volunteers very ill.\nMost substances do not pass all the tests and trials, so drug development is expensive and takes a long time.\nMedical drug trials are not without risk. Sometimes severe and unexpected side-effects occur.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': 'Magma is the hot molten rock found beneath the surface of the Earth. It reaches the surface through volcanic activity and forms the basis of igneous rocks.\nfrom the molten interior of the Earth. When magma erupts it cools to form volcanic landforms. When it cools inside the Earth it forms\nIntrusive rock is formed when hot molten magma is forced into small cracks between layers of other already existing rock types.\nrock, which may later be exposed by erosion and weathering.\nExamples of igneous rocks include basalt and granite.\nBack to Rock landscapes and processes index\nDeliver key Geographic sound bites direct to your ear!\nNews, issues and opinions from all around the UK.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': 'The new factories were met with mixed reactions. Some people hated the factory system and resorted to sabotage to hold back change, while others welcomed factories and relocated to find work.\nThere is evidence that many workers hated the factory system.\nHandloom weavers continued to work in competition against the machines\n, even though they were reduced to poverty – a sign of how much they hated the new ways.\nthe woolcombers and handloom weavers of Bradford staged a four-month strike\nto try to resist the changes in the woollen industry.\n, particularly in 1811-1812 by a group calling themselves the\nA group of English workers who formed in the early 19th Century. They opposed and destroyed new textile machines which threatened their traditional jobs.\nLuddites smashing a textile machine in 1812\nMany families moved from Norfolk and Suffolk, where there was high unemployment, to get work in the mills of Yorkshire and Lancashire.\nMany saw the new factories as an opportunity\n, not a curse (for example, Samuel Smiles’ book Self Help, 1859).\nThe majority of workers accepted factory discipline\npeacefully. Trade unions were slow to develop in the factories.\nThere were many attacks on the factories, for instance:\nIn 1753, an angry mob of weavers broke into Kay’s house and wrecked his looms.\nIn 1768, a group of local spinners broke into James Hargreaves’s house and destroyed his Spinning Jenny machines.\nIn 1779, workers in Lancashire smashed up Arkwright’s mill at Chorley.\nIn 1779, local spinners forced Samuel Crompton to dismantle his spinning mule.\nIn 1799, a Manchester weaving factory, which had bought some Cartwright power-looms, was burned by local hand-loom weavers.\nIn 1811-1812, there was a spate of attacks on mills and machinery by groups of workers who called themselves the Luddites.\nIn 1826, the handloom weavers of Haslingden in Lancashire attacked local factories.\nWhile reading in the paper to DAY on shorter houers of Labour I was Reminded of A cercomstance that came under my hone notis ....\nI was Minding a masheen with 30 threds in it I was then maid to mind 2 of 30 treds each and with improved mecheens in A few years I was minding tow mecheens with tow 100 treds each and Dubel speed so that in our improved condation we went as if the Devel was After us for 10 houers per day and the feemals have often Been carred out fainting what with the heat and hard work and all this is Done in Christian England and then we are tould to Be content in the station of Life to wich the Lord as places us But I say the Lord never Did place us there so we have no Right to Be content...\nSource A - a letter of complaint - was written by a woman, clearly uneducated, who nevertheless had something to say about the factories. List her complaints about the factory system?\nThere had been no commensurate increase in wages.\nReligion was used to keep the workers in their place.\nShe was content with the current system.\nNote the sarcasm in the phrase "improved condition".\nTo help you revise this section, draw a pair of weighing scales. On one side, write all the evidence that proves the workers hated and rejected the factory system. On the other side, write all the evidence that proves the workers accepted the factory system peacefully and even positively. Does the fact that there were a large number of riots against the system outweigh the millions of workers who accepted eagerly sought work in the factories without question?\nAs part of your revision, think about the\nworkers responded to changes in the textile industry.\nthe Luddites did to oppose the changes in the textile industry.\n', 'label': '5'}
{'text': 'A fugue is a special type of polyphonic texture. Fugues always begin with a tune that is played on a solo instrument/voice or by instruments/voices in unison. This tune is then played by all the other instruments or voices in turn but not necessarily at the same pitch.\nHere is an example of a fugue. Notice how the solo starts the fugue tune and then the other voices join in one at a time.\nLosing your way? {'text': "Tectonic plates are large areas of the Earth's crust that move slowly on the upper part of the mantle, often colliding and moving away from each other.\nare moving apart. The plates move apart due to\nRadioactive decay in the core of the Earth causes hot circular convection currents to rise and cold currents to fall. These currents cause the motion of tectonic plates.\nThe Helgafjell volcano on Westman Island, Iceland\nAs the plates move apart (very slowly),\nMagma is the hot molten rock found beneath the surface of the Earth. It reaches the surface through volcanic activity and forms the basis of igneous rocks.\nrises from the mantle. The magma erupts to the surface of the Earth. This is also accompanied by earthquakes.\nWhen the magma reaches the surface, it cools and solidifies to form a new crust of\n. This process is repeated many times, over a long period of time.\nEventually the new rock builds up to form a volcano.\ntend to be found under the sea, eg the Mid-Atlantic Ridge. Here, chains of underwater volcanoes have formed along the\nA plate boundary is the region where two or more tectonic plates meet. It is a zone of intense seismic activity.\n. One of these volcanoes may become so large that it erupts out of the sea to form a volcanic island, eg Surtsey and the Westman Islands near Iceland.\nThe diagram below to see how magma pushes up between the two plates, causing a chain of volcanoes along the constructive plate boundary.\nYour web browser does not have JavaScript switched on at the moment. {'text': 'We can explain the properties of metals by taking a more detailed look at their structure. Metal crystals are made up of positive metal ions surrounded by a sea of negative electrons.\nbetween positive ions and negative electrons means that a lot of\nis needed to separate these particles from the crystal lattice. This means that metals are strong and have high melting and boiling points.\nMuch less energy is needed to slide one layer of positive metal ions over another layer. This means that metals are easy to beat or press into shape.\nThe sea of electrons in a metal crystal is mobile. If a\nis applied across a piece of metal, the electrons will move, carrying an electrical current. {'text': 'The important part of an enzyme is called the\n. {'text': "Light and sound travel as waves. There are two types of wave - transverse and longitudinal. Waves can be described by their amplitude, wavelength and frequency. The speed of a wave can be calculated from its frequency and wavelength.\nfrom place to place without matter (solid, liquid or gas) being transferred. Think of a Mexican wave in a football crowd. The wave moves around the stadium, while each spectator stays in their seat only moving up then down when it's their turn.\nYour web browser does not have JavaScript switched on at the moment. For information on how to enable JavaScript please go to the\nYou will not be able to see this content until you have JavaScript switched on.\nSome waves must travel through a substance. The substance is known as the\n, and it can be solid, liquid or gas. Sound waves and seismic waves are like this. They must travel through a medium. It is the medium that vibrates as the waves travel through.\nOther waves do not need to travel through a substance. They may be able to travel through a medium, but they do not have to. Visible light, infrared rays, microwaves and other types of electromagnetic radiation are like this. They can travel through empty space. Electrical or magnetic fields vibrate as the waves travel through.\nBack to Wave model of radiation index\nPut down that pen and listen to some additional Science audio.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': 'is part of a line which has two end points (ie, it is not infinite). Each end of a line segment is usually labelled with letters.\nIf A is the point (1, 1) and B is the point (4, 5), what is the length of the line segment AB?\nIt is not easy to picture this without drawing a sketch. Have a look at the diagram below:\nA has an x-coordinate of 1. B has an x-coordinate of 4. So, to get from A to B, we move along 3 units.\nA has a y-coordinate of 1. B has a y-coordinate of 5. So, to get from A to B, we move up 4 units.\nWe have created a right-angled triangle. So to find the length of AB we use Pythagorasâ€™ theorem.\nIf P is the point (1, 5) and Q is the point (5, 1), what is the length of the line segment PQ? Give your answer correct to 1 decimal point (d.p.).\nIf you get a question like this, it is fine to draw a sketch or diagram. If you get really confident, you might be able to answer the question without using a diagram.\nBack to Shape, space and measures index\nNo robots in disguise, but this activity will transform your revision!\nMake sure your maths skills add up.\nBBC World Service - Figure it out\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "Some exam questions may ask you to give the answer in a simplified form. Rounding and estimating are two ways to make numbers easier to manage.\nGiving the complete number for something is sometimes unnecessary. For instance, the attendance at a football match might be\n. But for most people who want to know the attendance figure, an answer of '\nWe can round off large numbers like these to the nearest thousand, nearest hundred, nearest ten, nearest whole number, or any other specified number.\nFirst, look at the digit in the thousands place. It is 3. This means the number lies between 23000 and 24000. Look at the digit to the right of the 3. It is 7. That means 23745 is closer to\nThe rule is, if the next digit is:\nWhat is 23745 rounded to the nearest ten?\nIf so, well done! You saw that 23745 lies between 23740 and 23750, but is closer to 23750.\nIf you did not get the correct answer, remember that the tens digit is 4. This means that the number lies between 23740 and 23750. The next digit is 5, so we round up: 23745 = 23750 to the nearest ten.\nSometimes, rather than rounding off to the nearest whole number, you might need to be a little more accurate. You might need to include some of the digits after the decimal point.\nIn these cases, we can round off the number up to a certain number of decimal places.\nDo not confuse this with rounding off using significant figures (intermediate), as this is slightly different!\nThe same rules for rounding up apply here:\nWrite 2.6470588 to 2 decimal places (dp).\n? You needed to round up. We want 2 decimal places.\ndecimal digit is 4. So the number lies between 2.64 and 2.65\nThe next digit is 7, so we have to round up. So the answer is\n, giving your answer correct to one decimal place.\nWe need one decimal place. That means one number after the decimal point. The 1\nnumber after the decimal point is 8.\nThis means the answer lies between 7.8 and 7.9\nThe next digit is 7. This means we have to round up.\nRound off the number 3.9762645 to 1 dp.\nThe number lies between 3.9 and 4.0. The 7 after the 9 means you have to round up. So the answer is\nSometimes we do not always need to give detailed answers to problems - we just want a rough idea. When we are faced with a long number, we could round it off to the nearest thousand, or nearest million. And when we get a long decimal answer on a calculator, we could round it off to a certain number of decimal places.\nAnother method of giving an approximated answer is to round off using\nmeans important. The closer a digit is to the beginning of a number, the more important - or significant - it is.\nis the most significant digit, because it tells us that the number is\nand something. It follows that the 6 is the next most significant, and so on.\nis the most significant digit, because it tells us that the number is\n. The 8 is the next most significant, and so on.\nWe round off a number using a certain number of significant figures. The most common are 1, 2 or 3 significant figures.\nRemember the rules for rounding up are the same as before:\nWhat would you get if you wrote the number 368249 correct to 1 significant figure?\n3 is the first significant figure, and the digit after it is a 5, so you round up.\nWhat would you get if you wrote the number 0.00245 correct to 1 significant figure?\n2 is the first significant figure and the digit after this is less than 5, so you do not round up.\nWhat would you get if you wrote 0.0000058763 correct to 2 significant figures?\nYou had to round up the 8 to 9.\nIf you had problems, remember that the 2 most significant figures are 5 and 8. The digit after 8 is 7, so we have to round up 8 to 9.\nWe can use significant figures to get an approximate answer to a problem.\nWe can round off all the numbers in a maths problem to 1 significant figure to make 'easier' numbers. It is often possible to do this in your head.\nWe first round off both numbers to 1 significant figure (s.f.):\nSo we now need to make the denominator a whole number. We can do this by multiplying both 20 and 0.04 by 100.\nThe real answer to 19.4 รท 0.0437 = 443.9359... So this was a good estimate.\nTry this one. Remember, the working you do is just as important as the answer.\nHow would you get an approximate answer for 386062 ร\x97 0.007243?\nIf so, well done! {'text': "Acceleration is the rate at which an object changes its speed. It's calulated using the equation: acceleration = change in speed / time taken.\nSpeed-time graphs illustrate how the speed of an object changes over time. The steeper the gradient of the line, the greater the acceleration.\nIn everyday language we use 'accelerate' to mean speeding up and 'decelerate' to mean slowing down. In scientific terms 'acceleration' is the rate at which something\nacceleration = change in speed / time taken\nA bus accelerates from 5 m/s to 25 m/s in 10s\nTo calculate its acceleration, first find the change in speed.\nThis is 25m/s - 5m/s = 20m/s\nAcceleration = 20m/s ÷ 10s = 2m/s\nUse this triangle to help you rearrange the equation to:\nchange in speed = acceleration x time taken\ntime taken = change in speed / acceleration\nA speed-time graph tells us how the\nthe gradient of the line, the greater the\n(a bigger change in speed in the same time).\nAcceleration from a speed-time graph - higher tier only\nAcceleration = change in speed / time taken\nThe gradient of the line = acceleration\nFor the above diagram the acceleration shown by the blue line is:\nCheck your understanding of this by having a go at the following activity.\nYour web browser does not have JavaScript switched on at the moment. {'text': 'The properties of a metal are changed by including other elements, such as carbon. A mixture of two or more elements, where at least one element is a metal, is called an alloy. Alloys contain atoms of different sizes, which distort the regular arrangements of atoms. This makes it more difficult for the layers to slide over each other, so alloys are harder than the pure metal.\nIt is more difficult for layers of atoms to slide over each other in alloys\nCopper, gold and aluminium are too soft for many uses. They are mixed with other metals to make them harder for everyday use. For example:\n, used in electrical fittings, is 70 per cent copper and 30 per cent zinc.\n, used in jewellery, is 75 per cent gold and 25 per cent copper and other metals.\n, used in aircraft manufacture, is 96 per cent aluminium and 4 per cent copper and other metals.\nSmart alloys can return to their original shape after being bent. They are useful for spectacle frames and dental braces.\nBack to Atoms, metals, rocks and fuel index\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. The starting point is chosen at random.\nIf we want to test a 100-strong sample from a population of 2000, we test every\nmember. We use random numbers to determine the starting point.\nFor example, if we obtained the random number 7, we would test 7, 27, 47, 67...\nYou will have to make sure that each member of the population is arranged randomly. {'text': 'The radiation that distant stars and galaxies produce gives us information about the distances to stars, and about how they are changing. In the future, this may allow us to find out if life exists on planets around some of these stars.\nA large object that produces its own heat and light using nuclear fusion reactions.\nA cluster of billions of stars, held together by gravity.\nhas come from the light, and other radiations, that they give out. This has become more difficult to see from the Earthâ€™s surface, as light pollution from towns and cities interferes with observations of the night sky.\nLooking at the sky with the naked eye shows the Sun, Moon, stars, planets and a few cloudy patches called\n. When telescopes were invented and developed, astronomers could see that some of the nebulae were in fact groups of millions of stars. These are galaxies.\nPowerful telescopes allowed astronomers to answer a question which had baffled scientists since Copernicus first suggested that the Earth moved around the Sun. If the Earth moves, you would expect to see a different view of the stars at different times of the year, in the same way as the room you are in looks slightly different if you move your head to one side. That is to say everything seems to move in the opposite direction to your head, but the objects close to you seem to move more. This effect is called\n. So if the Earth was moving, why did the stars always look the same?\nThe answer to the question was revealed by more powerful telescopes. These showed that nearby stars do seem to move from side to side and back every year when compared with very distant stars, but that the amount of movement is tiny.\nFinding the distance of a star using parallax\nThe second nearest star to us is Proxima Centauri. The Sun is the nearest.\nIt seems to move through an angle of 1.5 seconds between January and June. As one second = 1/60 of a minute, and one minute = 1/60 of a degree, this tiny movement, which is less than a thousandth of the diameter of the Moon, needed powerful telescopes and accurate measurement to observe.\nIn the last 200 years, it has become very difficult to make astronomical observations in industrialised countries such as Britain. This is not just because of cloudy weather or air pollution. It is due to the bright lights found in cities and towns, and on roads. This light pollution means that it is hard for many people to see more than a few of the very brightest stars at night.\nTelescopes are now placed in the few remote, dark places left on our planet, or out in orbit around the Earth.\nThe Very Large Telescope is part of the Paranal Observatory which is built on top of the Cerro Paranal mountain, which is 2635 metres high, in the Atacama Desert in Chile.\nHubble Space Telescope - image courtesy of NASA\nTelescopes in space, such as the Hubble Space Telescope, can observe the whole sky. They are above light pollution, and dust and clouds in the atmosphere. However, they are difficult and expensive to launch and maintain. If anything goes wrong, only astronauts can fix them.\nBack to The Earth and space index\nFor an activity that is out of this world!\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': 'The revolution in the textiles industry where there was a move from home-based work to factories was at the heart of the Industrial Revolution. This Revision Bite will look at some of the changes in the textiles industry.\nMany historians believe that the Industrial Revolution would not have happened without the revolution in the textiles industry.\nBefore 1750, a lot of woollen cloth was produced, but\nthe textiles industry was a low-tech, labour-intensive cottage industry\n. British workers were unable to spin a cotton thread strong enough to make cotton cloth, so they had to use wool thread for the warp, which\nproduced a half-wool, half-cotton cloth called fustian\nAfter 1750, however, there was a revolution in the textiles industry. This involved:\n, probably as a result of the growth in population, but also because of the opening up of the export market.\nand innovation - the use of machinery.\n, away from East Anglia and the West Country. The first factories were situated in the hills of Lancashire and Yorkshire near to fast-flowing streams, which could power the water-wheels. {'text': "Contraception or ‘birth control’ is used for a variety of reasons:\nwhen pregnancy might harm the mental or physical condition of the mother\nto limit the number of children people have to ensure they don't damage living standards or affect other children\nto prevent pregnancy in people who do not want a child at this stage in their lives\nContraception, including artificial contraception, is permitted in Judaism in appropriate circumstances.\nReform and Liberal schools of Judaism allow birth control for a wide range of reasons. Orthodox Judaism is more restrictive.\nThe methods of contraception allowed under Jewish law are those that do not damage the sperm or stop it getting to its intended destination. These are the contraceptive pill and the IUD.\nJudaism teaches that life is a sacred gift from God:\nThen God said, ‘Let us make man in our image, in our likeness, and let them rule over the fish of the sea and the birds of the air, over the livestock, over all the earth, and over all the creatures that move along the ground.’ So God created man in his own image, in the image of God he created him; male and female he created them.”\nSexual intercourse is seen as an important part of marriage. It is part of a husband’s duty and a woman’s rights. Judaism is generally opposed to contraception because of teachings such as:\nHe who fashioned and made the earth… he did not create it to be empty, but formed it to be inhabited…\nGod blessed them and said to them, ‘Be fruitful and increase in number; fill the earth and subdue it.’\nContraceptives are also thought to interfere with the physical union between a man and a woman:\nFor this reason a man will leave his father and mother and be united to his wife, and they will become one flesh.\nOn the other hand any restriction on the use of contraceptives can be lifted if the mother’s life is at risk in any way.\nPost ideas and discuss Religious Studies here.\nGet some direction with a Bitesize revision map\nUnderstand the beliefs of others and develop your own opinion.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "Stalin's Five-year Plans dealt with industrial production, but something needed to be done about the food supply so Stalin introduced collectivisation. After years of resistance and\nStalin eventually executed those who resisted, or sent them to labour camps.\nBy the end of the 1920s, it was clear that Russian agriculture was inadequate. Although the\nWealthy Russian farming peasants, who strongly opposed collectivisation - Stalin killed many.\nwere relatively wealthy and successful, the thousands of tiny, backward peasant farms were not producing enough to feed the population.\nIn 1927, Stalin declared that the way forward was for people in each village to voluntarily unite their farms into one collective farm. This\nwould be able to afford machinery, be more efficient, and be able to create a surplus to send to the towns.\nAfter two years, when everyone had ignored his idea\nthere had been a famine, Stalin made collectivisation compulsory.\nthe idea, so they burned their crops and killed their animals rather than hand them over to the state. There was another famine in 1930.\nStalin relaxed the rules for a while, but in 1931 he again tried to enforce collectivisation.\nAgain there was the same resistance and another, worse famine.\nStalin blamed the kulaks, and declared war on them. They were executed or sent to the\nby 1939, 99 per cent of land had been collectivised\nof land had been collectivised 90% of the peasants lived on one of the 250,000 kolkhoz. Farming was run by government officials. The government took 90 per cent of production and left the rest for the people to live on.\nBack to Russia/USSR 1905 - 1941 index\nFed up with reading? {'text': 'Isambard Kingdom Brunel is one of the three main engineers responsible for the development of the railways. This Revision Bite will look at his contribution to the railway network.\nThe development of railways during the 19th century happened because of the work of three main engineers. We have already mentioned Richard Trevithick and George Stephenson, but Isambard Kingdom Brunel also played a key role.\nwho designed steam trains, oversaw the construction of new railway tracks and built some amazing and breathtaking bridges and tunnels along his railway routes.\nthe chief engineer of the Great Western Railway\n(GWR) in 1833. The railway line linked the towns of London and Bristol and was often referred to as "God\'s Wonderful Railway" because the route was so smooth and it was a perfect example of railway engineering.\nThe line was so successful that it was later extended to connect to Plymouth and Cornwall. Brunel used his considerable skills on the route and\nbuilt the Tamar Bridge and Box Tunnel\nOne of the reasons why Brunel\'s railway routes and tracks were so smooth is because, unlike George Stephenson,\nhe used a gauge of 7 feet 3 inches\n. He believed that this gauge was not only the safest, but would allow trains to travel faster and give the passengers more comfort. Unfortunately, 92 per cent of the railway tracks in Britain had already been built at Stephenson\'s gauge of 4 feet 8.5 inches. This led to\nthe Gauge Act being passed in 1846\n, which stated that all train tracks had to be built to George Stephenson\'s gauge width. Isambard Kingdom Brunel had\n. This made it easier for trains to run on all tracks across the country and not just in the local area.\nBack to Transport 1700 - 1900 index\nAll things historic - from ancient to modern.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. While you will be able to view the content of this page in your current browser, you will not be able to get the full visual experience. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n', 'label': '5'}
{'text': "Electric motors transfer electrical energy into kinetic energy, using magnets and coils of wire. There is a relationship between electrical power, voltage and current (power = voltage × current).\nWhenever useful energy is transferred, some energy that is not useful is also transferred – we say such energy is 'wasted'. When you measure the efficiency of a device, you measure how much of the energy supplied is useful.\nThe cost of electricity depends upon the amount of electrical power used, the amount of time it is used for, and the charge made for each unit of electricity. It is possible to reduce heat losses from homes using insulation, and this saves money, but some methods of insulation are more cost-effective than others.\nIf you are given information such as a diagram, you should be able to explain how an electric motor works.\nA simple electric motor can be built using a coil of wire that is free to rotate between two opposite magnetic poles. When an electric current flows through the coil, the coil experiences a force and moves.\nThe direction of the current must be reversed every half turn, otherwise the coil comes to a halt again. This is achieved using a conducting ring split in two, called a\n. A coil of wire is used with lots of turns to increase the effect of the magnetic field.\nThe animation shows a simple electric motor, with the arrow heads showing the direction of the current.\nYour web browser does not have JavaScript switched on at the moment. {'text': 'Indonesian music does not have the same scales as Western music, and is rarely written down. Here are some other key points:\nGamelan music often consists of tunes that are played over and over again (cyclic melodies).\nTypically, a fast interlocking pattern (played on the pemade and the kantil) is layed over the melodic patterns played on the ugal.\nWestern musicians who wish to perform Gamelan use a number notation system instead of the Western staff notation.\nTwo different tuning systems are used in Javanese Gamelan:\nSlendro is a 5-note system of whole tone and minor third\nThe distance between two pitches or notes. {'text': "It is not practical to generate large amounts of electricity by passing a magnet in and out of a coil of wire. Instead, generators induce a current by spinning a coil of wire inside a magnetic field, or by spinning a magnet inside a coil of wire. As this happens, a potential difference - voltage - is produced between the ends of the coil, which causes a current to flow.\nOne simple example of a generator is the bicycle dynamo. The dynamo has a wheel that touches the back tyre. As the bicycle moves, the wheel turns a magnet inside a coil. This induces enough electricity to run the bicycle's lights.\nYour web browser does not have JavaScript switched on at the moment. For information on how to enable JavaScript please go to the\nYou will not be able to see this content until you have JavaScript switched on.\nThe faster the bicycle moves, the greater the induced current and the brighter the lights.\nDon't lick a battery, try this activity!\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "Fabrics usually need to be washed, bleached and dyed, before they are suitable for making into textile products. Often they need to be printed as well, using either block-printing or screen-printing techniques. Garments are assembled using various joining techniques including sewing, fusing and heat-sealing. Finishing is a process which improves the appearance, handle and performance of fabrics; while pressing is used to shape and stabilise fabrics.\nDyed cloth in a souk in Marrakesh\nBefore dyeing and printing the fabric is prepared by washing, bleaching and\ntreating cotton yarn with an alkali to improve its strength, lustre and receptivity to dye.\nIn industrial production fabric is dyed by continuous or batch dyeing:\n, the fabric passes through a dye bath. The fabric is then squeezed between rollers to spread the dye evenly and remove excess dye. Continuous dyeing is used for colours that do not need to change too quickly with fashion.\n, fabrics are produced without dye. They are then dyed to order in large batches according to the colours required. Batch dyeing is used for colours that need to change frequently with fashion.\nFabrics are printed by block or screen printing:\nis done using metal or wooden blocks, one for each colour. The background shapes are cut away to leave a raised design on the block. Dye is applied and stamped onto the fabric. This is a very slow process used by specialised craft industries.\na pattern is printed onto fabric through a\na sheet of paper, celluloid, or other material in which a design has been cut, so that when ink is passed over the sheet the design is reproduced on the surface below\nheld in place by a screen. Each screen prints one part of the design in one colour. After printing the dyestuff must be fixed using steam or dry heat.\nThe graphics show three different types of screen printing.\nis a slow process used by designer-makers for complicated fabric designs.\nautomates this process, with the fabric moved through the machine on a conveyor belt and the print repeating rapidly.\nComputer Aided Design - a system which helps the user produce accurate drawings.\nand roller squeegees - one roller for each colour; this is a very fast process used in the continuous printing of furnishing and clothing fabrics.\ntwo fabrics together produces an unfinished seam. Finishing the seam prevents fraying and produces a hard-wearing, neat finish.\nis used to permanently join two fabrics together using an\na substance which bonds the surfaces of materials together\nresin. Fusing is sometimes done by hand, sometimes by machine.\nFusing by hand is used to join Vilene to fabric to make it stable and strong. It is also used to reinforce and strengthen fabrics for garments, bags and accessories; and allows hems to be turned up without stitching.\nIn a factory there are two types of machine used for fusing: a flat-bed press is used to join short fabric lengths for batch production; a conveyor press is used for fusing long fabric lengths for mass production.\nis used for synthetic fibres made from thermoplastics, such as polyester or nylon. Heat-sealing is used to set a material into a shape, eg pleats. It is also use to seal the seams on all-weather gear and tents to make them waterproof.\nIn industry a range of different sewing machines are used for stitching seams, embroidery, buttonholes etc. The main ones are listed in the table below:\nStitches, cuts and finishes seams in one process\nFinishing is done to improve a product's appearance, properties and quality. It covers many different processes, some mechanical and some chemical.\nMechanical finishing uses heat, pressure and rollers to improve the appearance of the fabric.\ncotton or nylon fabrics makes them fluffy and warm, with a soft\nhow a textile feels when touched such as soft, rough, smooth, warm or cool\n. The fabrics pass through rollers with wire brushes that lift the fibres to form a\na soft surface created by brushing the fabric, aligning the ends of the fibres\nis the industrial equivalent of ironing. It smoothes the fabric and improves its\nthe sheen of a fabric, e.g. silk is bright and shiny\nEngraved calendar rollers are used to emboss\nRelief is the height of the ground above sea level.\nis used for thermoplastic fabrics (polyester and nylon). The fabrics are set in permanent shapes or pleats.\nChemical finishing involves the application of chemical solutions or\nsubstances (eg acrylics and urethanes) which, applied to a fabric's surface, evaporate to leave a film upon it\nhow a textile performs in use - eg water proof or hardwearing.\nbefore dyeing. This makes it easier to dye pastel shades.\ntreated with an alkali to improve strength, lustre and receptivity to dye (of cotton)\nusing caustic soda. Mercerised fabrics are stronger, dye well and have improved lustre.\nWool can be given a shrink-resist finish using silicone or Teflon. This results in soft, smooth, lustrous yarns and fabrics that are machine-washable.\nCotton and viscose fabrics are given a crease-resistant finish using\n'raw' plastic, especially when in semi-liquid form (Resistant materials). Substances (eg acrylics and urethanes) which, applied to a fabric's surface, evaporate to leave a film upon it (Textiles technology).\n. This makes them easy-care. They dry fast and smooth and need little ironing.\nChildren's nightwear and cotton/viscose furnishings must by law be given a\na flame-resistant fabric has been treated with a chemical finish which makes it hard to catch fire\nfinish. This often makes the fabric stiffer and weaker.\nThese are new, high-tech methods for finishing products.\nare applied to the fabric surface to slow down the growth of bacteria. They control odours in sports shoes and reduce infection in medical products.\ninvolves applying a layer of polymer to the surface of the fabric. Teflon coating makes fabrics\ntreated with a chemical finish to stop the absorption of water-based or oil-based liquids.\nthe ability to shed water; non-wetting or water proof\nallowing perspiration to evaporate, making sports or work clothes more comfortable to wear\nproteins which catalyse or speed up chemical reactions inside our bodies\ngives a stone-washed finish to denim fabrics.\ntextile materials using dry heat or steam. {'text': "You should know how a transformer works and how to calculate the\nThe potential difference of a cell, electrical supply or electric component. It is measured in volts, 'V'.\nAlso called 'ac'. This is an electric current that regularly changes its direction and size.\n. A changing magnetic field also induces a changing voltage in a coil. This is the basis of how a transformer works:\nThe primary coil is connected to an AC supply.\nAn alternating current passes through a primary coil wrapped around a soft iron core.\nThe changing current produces a changing magnetic field.\nThis induces an alternating voltage in the secondary coil.\nThis induces an alternating current (AC) in the circuit connected to the secondary coil.\nThere is no electrical connection between the primary and the secondary coils.\nTransformers only work if AC is supplied to the primary coil. If DC was supplied, there would be no current in the secondary coil.\nAs the current in the primary coil increases steadily or decreases steadily, there is a constant voltage induced in the secondary coil.\nAs the voltage in the primary coil reaches maximum strength the voltage induced in the secondary coil is at its weakest (zero volts).\nThe ratio between the voltages in the coils is the same as the ratio of the number of turns in the coils.\nprimary voltage / secondary voltage = turns on primary / turns on secondary\non the secondary coil than they do on the primary coil.\non the secondary coil than they do on the primary coil.\nA transformer has 20 turns on the primary and 400 on the secondary. What is the output voltage if the input voltage is 500V?\nCheck your understanding of this by having a go at the activity.\nYour web browser does not have JavaScript switched on at the moment. For information on how to enable JavaScript please go to the\nYou will not be able to see this content until you have JavaScript switched on.\nPut down that pen and listen to some additional Science audio.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': 'Making decisions on moral issues is not easy. Religion helps followers to make decisions that are pleasing to God and create a society where people respect and care for each other\nPeople draw on a variety of sources of authority to help them make a decision. For example:\nreligious leaders and the official teaching of their religion\nThere are two types of morality that affect the decisions people make – absolute morality and relative moraility.\nIf you believe in absolute morality you will have faith that there is a right course of action to take in a moral dilemma, which is true in all situations regardless of culture, religious tradition, time or age.\nHow would a follower of this sort of morality respond to the commandment ‘Do not kill’? They would try to make sure that they were not involved in any killing, which would affect their views on issues such as war, abortion and euthanasia. They would say that these actions are wrong in all circumstances.\nIf you believe in relative morality you would agree that different courses of action might be needed in different situations.\nHow would a follower of this sort of morality respond to the commandment ‘Do not kill’? They would agree that killing is wrong, but would look at a range of other issues as well and say that sometimes killing might be necessary in a particular situation, such as abortion, if continuing the pregnancy would result in the birth of a very disabled child, or if the mother had been raped.\nPost ideas and discuss Religious Studies here.\nGet some direction with a Bitesize revision map\nUnderstand the beliefs of others and develop your own opinion.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "Personal and social life: A life story\nPersonal and social life: A life story\nIn your German exam you will need to show you can read and understand a story in different tenses, including the imperfect tense. This Revision Bite will help you practise this.\nLies Ottos Lebenslauf und suche für jede Frage die Antwort heraus, die am besten passt.\nIch bin im Frühling, am 23 April 1928, in Hannover geboren. Ich hatte braune Augen und große Ohren. Ich wurde Otto Kaufmann genannt. Als Kind fand ich die Schule ziemlich langweilig und ich schlief oft ein. Nur Erdkunde hatte ich gern. Ich war ein typischer Teenager und probierte Alkohol und Zigaretten. Mit neunzehn habe ich mich zum ersten Mal verliebt. Sie hatte schwarze Haare und dunkle Augen. Sie hieß Liselotte und schaute mich nie an, weil ich kein Geld hatte. Ich war drei Jahre arbeitslos! Eines Tages spazierte ich mit dem Hund und ich fand eine Halskette. Was sollte ich machen? Die Halskette zur Polizei bringen oder sie verkaufen? So ein Dilemma! Ich war brav und ging zur Polizei. Die Belohnung dafür war 10,000 Mark!! Ich wettete das Geld auf ein Pferd namens Stampfer und gewann tausend Mark. Ich habe das Pferd gekauft und bin jetzt einer der reichsten Männer in Deutschland. Ich wohne in einem großen Haus in Hannover. Ich habe meine alte Liebe, Liselotte, geheiratet und habe vier Kinder und zwölf Enkel. Ich wette, dass ich einer der glücklichsten Großväter der Welt bin!\n= season. April is in the spring).\n(Otto didn't enjoy school - it was boring!)\nEr fand eine Halskette und musste es ...\n(Otto gave the necklace to the police).\n10,000 Mark (die Belohnung dafür war 10,000 Mark)\nIn einem groß Haus (Ich wohne in einem groß Haus)\nsehr glücklich (... einer der glücklichsten Großväter ...)\nUse your language skills in this sinister game of intrigue and detection.\nLearn to sprechen like a native with the BBC.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "Table salt is sodium chloride. Too much salt in the diet can lead to\n, which in turn leads to an increased risk of heart disease and strokes.\nfound naturally in many kinds of food\n, but more is added by food manufacturers - and many people add even more when they are eating. Processed foods often have a high proportion of salt and fat. Salt added to food during processing accounts for about two-thirds of the average salt intake.\nOn average, men in the UK eat about 10g of salt a day and women about 8g a day. However, food scientists recommend no more than\nin the diet. Reducing the amount of salt in the diet will help to reduce the risk of heart disease, and to a greater extent the risk of suffering a stroke.\nfrom 2006 about the governments salt guidelines.\nThere is some evidence that the food industry has persuaded government bodies to set higher targets for the recommended amount of dietary salt in our food than doctors might wish.\nLet's see how you respond to this activity!\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "Before setting to work on your questions, check the list below of things to avoid. Questions should not be too:\nPersonal, eg how much money do you have in the bank?\nEmbarrassing or upsetting, eg how often do you shower?\nguiding a question which can interfere with the response given\n, eg you like ------------ don't you? Do not attempt to influence people's answers in any way.\nin several different ways. Quantifiers such as ‘few’, ‘some’, ‘many’ and ‘usually’ can be interpreted differently by different respondents. {'text': 'Isambard Kingdom Brunel is one of the three main engineers responsible for the development of the railways. This Revision Bite will look at his contribution to the railway network.\nThe development of railways during the 19th century happened because of the work of three main engineers. We have already mentioned Richard Trevithick and George Stephenson, but Isambard Kingdom Brunel also played a key role.\nwho designed steam trains, oversaw the construction of new railway tracks and built some amazing and breathtaking bridges and tunnels along his railway routes.\nthe chief engineer of the Great Western Railway\n(GWR) in 1833. The railway line linked the towns of London and Bristol and was often referred to as "God\'s Wonderful Railway" because the route was so smooth and it was a perfect example of railway engineering.\nThe line was so successful that it was later extended to connect to Plymouth and Cornwall. Brunel used his considerable skills on the route and\nbuilt the Tamar Bridge and Box Tunnel\nOne of the reasons why Brunel\'s railway routes and tracks were so smooth is because, unlike George Stephenson,\nhe used a gauge of 7 feet 3 inches\n. He believed that this gauge was not only the safest, but would allow trains to travel faster and give the passengers more comfort. Unfortunately, 92 per cent of the railway tracks in Britain had already been built at Stephenson\'s gauge of 4 feet 8.5 inches. This led to\nthe Gauge Act being passed in 1846\n, which stated that all train tracks had to be built to George Stephenson\'s gauge width. Isambard Kingdom Brunel had\n. This made it easier for trains to run on all tracks across the country and not just in the local area.\nUse a side of A4 paper to create a profile of Isambard Kingdom Brunel that highlights his key achievements in the development of railways.\nAs part of your revision, think about the\nrole Isambard Kingdom Brunel played in the development of railways.\nthe GWR deserved the title "God\'s Wonderful Railway".\nit was important to establish a uniform gauge for British railway tracks.\n', 'label': '5'}

{'text': "There are, of course, a lot of other characters in the book. The best way to deal with them, given that the story is told from Jane's point of view, is to look at what they mean to her.
