{'text': 'The characters we see as the curtain rises are not the same as those at the plays conclusion. The events of the evening change everyone, as well as their expectations of the future. Inspector Goole is instrumental in disturbing the harmony; a purposeful, mysterious character who forces the characters to confront each other\'s social responsibility, snobbery and guilt. But is the inspector as genuine as he seems?\nAll these changes take place because of the visit of Inspector Goole. But who is Inspector Goole? And who is the girl whose suicide he is apparently investigating?\nHe is described at the start as a\n"heavy-looking, rather portentous man in his middle fifties but rather provincial in his speech."\nHe has worked his way up in the world and is\nof his achievements. He boasts about having been Mayor and tries (and fails) to impress the Inspector with his local standing and his influential friends.\nHowever, he is aware of people who are his social superiors, which is why he shows off about the port to Gerald,\n"it\'s exactly the same port your father gets."\nHe is proud that he is likely to be knighted, as that would move him even higher in social circles.\n"is one of the happiest nights of my life."\nThis is not only because Sheila will be happy, but because a merger with Crofts Limited will be good for his business.\nfor the future and confident that there will not be a war. As the audience knows there\nbe a war, we begin to doubt Mr Birling\'s judgement. (If he is wrong about the war, what else will he be wrong about?)\nHe wants to protect himself and his family. He believes that socialist ideas that stress the importance of the community are\n"a man has to make his own way."\nHe wants to protect Birling and Co. He cannot see that he did anything wrong when he fired Eva Smith - he was just looking after his business interests.\nHe wants to protect his reputation. As the Inspector\'s investigations continue, his selfishness gets the better of him: he is worried about how the press will view the story in Act II, and accuses Sheila of disloyalty at the start of Act III. He wants to hide the fact that Eric stole money:\n"I\'ve got to cover this up as soon as I can."\nAt the end of the play, he knows he has lost the chance of his knighthood, his reputation in Brumley and the chance of Birling and Co. merging with their rivals. Yet he hasn\'t learnt the lesson of the play: he is unable to admit his responsibility for his part in Eva\'s death.\nShe is described at the start as\n"about fifty, a rather cold woman and her husband\'s social superior."\n, very aware of the differences between social classes. She is irritated when Mr Birling makes the social gaffe of praising the cook in front of Gerald and later is very dismissive of Eva, saying\nShe has the least respect for the Inspector of all the characters. She tries - unsuccessfully - to intimidate him and force him to leave, then lies to him when she claims that she does not recognise the photograph that he shows her.\nShe sees Sheila and Eric still as\nthat she doesn\'t want to believe: Eric\'s drinking, Gerald\'s affair with Eva, and the fact that a working class girl would refuse money even if it was stolen, claiming\nagainst the girl who applied to her committee for help and saw it as her\nto refuse to help her. Her narrow sense of morality dictates that the father of a child should be responsible for its welfare, regardless of circumstances.\nAt the end of the play, she has had to come to terms that her son is a heavy drinker who got a girl pregnant and stole money to support her, her daughter will not marry a good social \'catch\' and that her own reputation within the town will be sullied. Yet, like her husband, she refuses to believe that she did anything wrong and doesn\'t accept responsibility for her part in Eva\'s death.\nShe is described at the start as\n"a pretty girl in her early twenties, very pleased with life and rather excited."\nEven though she seems very playful at the opening, we know that she has had suspicions about Gerald when she mentions\n"last summer, when you never came near me."\nDoes this suggest that she is not as naive and shallow as she first appears?\nAlthough she has probably never in her life before considered the conditions of the workers, she shows her\nimmediately she hears of her father\'s treatment of Eva Smith:\n"But these girls aren\'t cheap labour - they\'re people."\nShe is horrified by her own part in Eva\'s story. She feels full of\nfor her jealous actions and blames herself as\n: she realises that Gerald knew Daisy Renton from his reaction, the moment the Inspector mentioned her name. At the end of Act II, she is the first to realise Eric\'s part in the story. Significantly, she is the first to wonder who the Inspector really is, saying to him, \'wonderingly\',\n"he\'s giving us the rope - so that we\'ll hang ourselves"\n(Act II) and, near the end, is the first to consider whether the Inspector may not be real.\nShe genuinely wants to know about Gerald\'s part in the story. It\'s interesting that she is not angry with him when she hears about the affair: she says that she respects his honesty. She is becoming\nwith her parents in Act 3 for trying to\n"It frightens me the way you talk:"\nshe cannot understand how they cannot have learnt from the evening in the same way that she has. She is seeing her parents in a new, unfavourable light.\nAt the end of the play, Sheila is much\nShe can now judge her parents and Gerald from a new perspective, but the greatest change has been in herself: her social conscience has been awakened and she is aware of her responsibilities. The Sheila who had a girl dismissed from her job for a trivial reason has vanished forever.\nHe is described at the start as\n"in his early twenties, not quite at ease, half shy, half assertive."\nright from the start. He cries,\n"Oh - my God! - how stupid it all is!"\nas he tells his story. He is horrified that his thoughtless actions had such consequences.\n, though, because although he got a woman pregnant, he was concerned enough to give her money. He was obviously less worried about stealing (or \'borrowing\' from his father\'s office) than he was about the girl\'s future. So, was Eric, initially, the most socially aware member of the Birling family?\nHe is appalled by his parents\' inability to admit their own responsibility. He tells them forcefully,\nWhen Birling tries to threaten him in Act III, Eric is aggressive in return:\nDo you think Eric has ever stood up to his father in this way before?\nAt the end of the play, like Sheila, he is fully aware of his social responsibility. Is he a bit like Mr Birling, wanting to protect his own interests?\nHe did have some genuine feeling for Daisy Renton, however: he is very moved when he hears of her death. He tells Inspector Goole that he arranged for her to live in his friend\'s flat\n"She was young and pretty and warm-hearted - and intensely grateful."\nDespite this, in Act 3 he tries to come up with as much evidence as possible to prove that the Inspector is a fake - because that would get him off the hook. He leaves the family with the message\nthat will result if they do not pay attention to what he has taught them.\nsuggests that the Inspector is not a \'real\' person. So, what is he?\nIs he a ghost? Try to stick to black text on a white or light-coloured background.\nArial size 12 is easy to read on websites. Try not to use a smaller sized font.\nRemember the intended audience. Always test your website on users.\nDo not use underlining on webpages. Users will think it is a hyperlink and get confused when it doesn't link to another website.\nKeep it simple. {'text': 'The Home Front during the First World War\nThe Home Front during the First World War\nThe First World War was the first \'total war\' - the whole nation had to be mobilised to fight. Men joined the army while women took over their jobs, but was this change lasting or a temporary effect of total war?\nThe population at home - the basics\nPeople in Britain were affected by six main ways:\n- there was a huge poster campaign to get people to join up, and the government had to introduce\nPeople who refused to fight in the two world wars, because of strong personal beliefs against war.\ncould be imprisoned. Women were recruited into the armed forces as nurses, drivers, cooks and telephonists.\nThe Defence of the Realm Act (DORA)\n- this was passed in August 1914. DORA allowed the government to take over the coal mines, railways and shipping. Lloyd George became Minister of Munitions and set up state-run\nfactories. The government worked with the trade unions to prevent strikes.\n- there were fewer workers because so many men left to join the army.\n- a fixed allowance for sugar, meat, butter, jam and tea was introduced in 1918. British Summer Time was also introduced to give more daylight working hours.\n- newspaper and soldiers\' letters were censored. "The Tribunal" (a\nA person who believes in peace and not violence, and opposes all wars - for either moral or religious reasons.\nnewspaper) was shut down, and lies were made up about German atrocities. Posters encouraged morale. The film "The Somme" was a semi-successful attempt at using film for propaganda because the graphic nature of actually seeing the men die upset many viewers.\nbombing raids after 1915, and the German navy shelled Hartlepool, Whitby and Scarborough.\nRead on to learn more about propaganda and the role women played in the war effort.\nBack to Britain 1905 - 1951 index\nFed up with reading? {'text': 'A half-equation shows you what happens at one of the electrodes during electrolysis. Electrons are shown as e\n. A half-equation is balanced by adding, or taking away, a number of electrons equal to the total number of charges on the ions in the equation.\nPositive ions gain electrons at the negative electrode, so are reduced.\nNegative ions or neutral atoms lose electrons at the positive electrode and are oxidised. For example, chlorine is produced during the electrolysis of sodium chloride solution:\nThis half-equation can be rewritten as 2Cl\nThe simulation below shows what happens during the purification of copper by electrolysis.\nYour web browser does not have JavaScript switched on at the moment. What you set out to find out, and how you carried out the research.\n- A brief description of what you found out.\n- Details of what you found – this could be\ndata, such as 'on average, young people received £6.72 pocket money per week', or data represented on graphs (eg a pie chart showing the different things children spend their pocket money on), or descriptive text ( eg 'in general girls received more pocket money than boys, but boys were more likely to have part-time jobs').\n- A bulleted list saying what action could be taken based on the findings of your report.\nThis publication is probably best dealt with using a word processor.\nThe SPB will tell you exactly what the purpose of the report is and exactly what audience you are writing for. {'text': "Where no profit or loss is made ie where total revenue = total costs.\npoint is when a firm begins to make a profit. It will make a loss if it produces and sells output below this level.\nThe breakeven point for a firm is when total costs equals total revenue. Expenditure and income are the same and the firm makes neither a profit or a loss. If the firm can sell at production levels above this point, it will be making a profit. If sales fall below this point, it will be making a loss. Establishing the breakeven point helps a firm to plan the levels of production it needs to be profitable.\nBefore you can calculate the breakeven point, you need to identify the firm's costs. These include:\nRenting an office block is part of a company's fixed costs\nThese do not change as output changes, eg rent.\nare constant and do not change however many goods are produced. They include rent and insurance.\nWages paid to employees are part of a company's variable costs\nThese change according to output eg raw materials.\ninclude raw materials and wages. You need to calculate the variable costs per unit. These costs increase in direct proportion to the number of units produced.\nBy adding the firm's variable costs and fixed costs you can work out the\nFixed costs plus variable costs make total costs.\nThe firm's variable costs are added to the fixed costs and these make the total costs.\nYou need to establish how many units are to be produced.\nYou need to know the selling price of the units.\nOnce you have the above information, you can begin to calculate the breakeven point. You do this either by using a chart or an equation.\nThese do not change as output changes, eg rent.\nThese change according to output eg raw materials.\nYou may find it helpful to work through the\nHere is how to work out the breakeven point, using the example of a firm manufacturing compact discs. You can assume the firm has the following costs:\nYou first construct a chart with output (units) on the horizontal (x) axis, and costs and revenue on the vertical (y) axis. On to this, you plot a horizontal fixed costs line (it is horizontal because fixed costs don't changewith output).\nThen you plot a variable cost line from this point, which will, in effect, be the total costs line. This is because the fixed cost added to the variable cost gives the total cost. To do this, you multiply:\nvariable cost per unit × number of units\nIn this example of the CD manufacturing firm, you can assume that the variable cost per unit is £2 and there are 2 000 units = £4,000\nOnce you have done this, you are ready to plot the\nThe value of sales at a given output ie sales price multiplied by output.\nsales price × number of units (output)\nIf the sales price is £6.00 and 2.000 items were to be manufactured, the calculation is:\n£6.00 × 2,000 = £12,000 total revenue\nWhere the total revenue line crosses the total costs line is the breakeven point (ie costs and revenue are the same). Everything below this point is produced at a loss, and everything above it is produced at a profit.\nFixed costs: £10,000, Variable costs: £2 per unit, Sales price: £6 per unit\nIf you read downwards, it tells you how many units you need to produce and sell at this price to breakeven: 2,500 CDs\nIf you read across, it tells you how much money you must spend before you recover your outlay: £15,000\nAs with any calculation, it is easy to make a mistake. There are two simple equations you can use to double-check your answer. You can calculate the breakeven point in:\nEither way, the result should be the same.\nFor the breakeven point in costs/revenue, you then multiply the breakeven point in units, which you have just calculated, by the sales price.\nIf you look at the breakeven chart, you will see this is the correct answer.\nBreakeven analysis is a favourite exam topic. In an exam, you could be asked to complete a breakeven chart. With these two equations, you'll be able to double check your calculations, get them right and improve your marks.\nUse the example of the CD manufacturer above and plot your own chart with the same costs, but this time with a different total revenue line:\nYou should have calculated a breakeven point of 2,000 units and a costs revenue of £14,000.\nIf you have made a mistake, calculate the breakeven point in units, and then in costs/revenue again and double check your calculations again.\n", 'label': '5'}
{'text': "The locus of a point which moves so that it is an equal distance from two points, A and B, is the perpendicular bisector of the line joining A and B.\nTo construct this locus, you do the following (try this yourself on a piece of paper):\nPractise this construction until you can do it without looking at the instructions. You don't need to label the points with letters each time - they are just there as a guide.\nTo bisect an angle, you do the following:\nV is the vertex of the angle we want to bisect.\n(Try this yourself on a piece of paper.)\nRemember: if you are asked to do a construction in an exam,\ndo not rub out your construction lines\nThe loci of a point which moves so that it is the same distance from lines AOB and COD, are the lines which bisect angles AOC, AOD, DOB and BOC:\nBack to Shape, space and measures index\nNow to take a different angle on revision with this activity!\nMake sure your maths skills add up.\nBBC World Service - Figure it out\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': 'Changes in the iron and steel industry\nChanges in the iron and steel industry\nIron and steel was arguably the most important industry in the Industrial Revolution, and the Industrial Revolution could not have happened without a massive increase in the production and quality of iron and steel. It was essential for mechanical and civil engineering, domestic and military uses.\nand centred on the Weald in Sussex and the Forest of Dean in Gloucestershire – places where there were plenty of woodlands to provide the charcoal needed in the smelting process. But the charcoal was running out, and half of\nBritain’s iron had to be imported from Sweden and Russia\n. The steel industry, which used Benjamin Huntsman’s "crucible" process, was also small-scale and centred on Sheffield.\nIn the 18th century, there was a revolution in the production of iron, and in the 19th century, a revolution in the production of steel.\nThe growth of the iron and steel industry involved:\nChanges in location - to South Wales, the Midlands and Scotland.\nImprovements in transport - canals and waterways.\nBack to Industry 1700 - 1900 index\nAll things historic - from ancient to modern.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': 'In this Revision Bite we are going to look at:\nof a number are any numbers that divide into it exactly. This includes 1 and the number itself.\nFor example, the factors of 6 are 1, 2, 3 and 6. The factors of 8 are 1, 2, 4 and 8.\nFor larger numbers it is sometimes easier to ‘pair’ the factors by writing them as multiplications.\nFor example, 24 = 1 x 24 = 2 x 12 = 3 x 8 = 4 x 6\nSo the factors of 24 are 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 12 and 24.\nThe factors of 40 are 1, 2, 4, 5, 8, 10, 20 and 40.\nMake sure that you got all of them. {'text': 'Making decisions on moral issues is not easy. Religion helps followers to make decisions that are pleasing to God and create a society where people respect and care for each other\nPeople draw on a variety of sources of authority to help them make a decision. For example:\nreligious leaders and the official teaching of their religion\nThere are two types of morality that affect the decisions people make – absolute morality and relative moraility.\nIf you believe in absolute morality you will have faith that there is a right course of action to take in a moral dilemma, which is true in all situations regardless of culture, religious tradition, time or age.\nHow would a follower of this sort of morality respond to the commandment ‘Do not kill’? They would try to make sure that they were not involved in any killing, which would affect their views on issues such as war, abortion and euthanasia. They would say that these actions are wrong in all circumstances.\nIf you believe in relative morality you would agree that different courses of action might be needed in different situations.\nHow would a follower of this sort of morality respond to the commandment ‘Do not kill’? They would agree that killing is wrong, but would look at a range of other issues as well and say that sometimes killing might be necessary in a particular situation, such as abortion, if continuing the pregnancy would result in the birth of a very disabled child, or if the mother had been raped.\nPost ideas and discuss Religious Studies here.\nGet some direction with a Bitesize revision map\nUnderstand the beliefs of others and develop your own opinion.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "The space between planets is called interplanetary space. These are some of the conditions there:\nthe temperature varies from very cold - away from the Sun - to very hot - in sunshine\nthe gravitational field strength is close to zero, so objects are effectively weightless\nthere is a lot of cosmic radiation - radiation from the Sun and distant objects in space\nIf astronauts are to explore space, scientists and engineers must design systems to protect them from these conditions.\nSpacecraft provide the conditions needed for astronauts to survive in space. They provide:\nan atmosphere (and equipment to remove waste gases such as carbon dioxide)\ninsulation and heating to provide a suitable temperature for life\nexercise equipment to reduce the effects of weightlessness (bones become weaker the longer an astronaut is in space, and exercise helps to slow this process down).\nThe walls and windows of spacecraft are designed to withstand the impact of 'micrometeorites' (tiny pieces of fast-moving rock). But they cannot protect astronauts from all the cosmic radiation in space, which can cause cancer. The Earth's atmosphere and magnetic field shield life forms on Earth from most of this, but scientists are not sure how they can protect astronauts in space. This limits how long a mission can last without damaging the health of the astronauts.\nFor an activity that is out of this world!\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "Alfred, Lord Tennyson: The Charge of the Light Brigade\nMany other poets have written poems about war and its effects and it is interesting to compare their work to Tennyson's treatment of the subject.\nPicture courtesy of The National Army Museum\nAlthough this poem offers graphic descriptions of the difficulties faced by the Light Brigade, Tennyson makes the final message one of glory and bravery, with sacrifice for one's country a noble and desirable end. Wilfred Owen's poem\ngives an even more graphic depiction of war, and is a strong reaction against the sort of ideas presented by Tennyson. Owen experienced war, and so his poems are more closely reflective of the views of the serving soldiers. Men like Tennyson may view it as honourable to die for one's country, but that is perhaps easy to say from a distance.\nBack to Alfred, Lord Tennyson: The Charge of the Light Brigade index\nRead the full text online and make your own notes.\nGet creative, get published and get expert writing advice at BBC Blast.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "The opposition in an electrical component to the flow of electricity through it. Resistance is measured in ohms.\nin a series circuit, and also how to\nWhen components are connected in series, their total resistance is the sum of their individual resistances. For example, if a 2\nresistor are connected side by side, their total resistance is 2 + 1 + 3 = 6\nIf you increase the number of lamps in a series circuit, the total resistance will increase and less current will flow. {'text': 'If this poem is considered alongside William Blake\'s\n, the differing attitudes are striking. Whilst this poem is positive, Blake is concerned with the negatives of life in London. Wordsworth here is focusing on the city in the morning, and does not mention seeing people. Blake\'s poem is about the effects of the city on its inhabitants.\n"The river glideth at his own sweet will\' is arguably a conscious rejection of Blake"\n. Unlike Blake\'s speaker, the speaker in this poem seems to believe in the power of nature to persist alongside the man-made city, even that it is perfected by the city.\n', 'label': '5'}
{'text': "W B Yeats: Song of the Old Mother\nMuch of the meaning of a poem is conveyed by the\nit expresses toward its subject matter. 'Attitude' can be thought of as a combination of the poet's\nhe or she is trying to get across to the reader.\nA good way to decide on the\nThe mood or manner of a text or part of a text. The author's 'tone of voice' or way in which they expect to be understood. The emotional load carried by a text.\nof a poem is to work out how you would read it aloud.\nWistfully, as if the old woman wishes she could be like the young women?\nBitterly, as if the old woman is angry that her life has been so hard compared to the lives of the young women?\nSadly and resignedly, as if the old woman regrets that her life has been like this but knows she never had the option of changing it?\n'Till stars are beginning to blink and peep;\nAnd the young lie long and dream in their bed\nOf the matching of ribbons for bosom and head,\nAnd their day goes over in idleness,'\nThe mood or manner of a text or part of a text. {'text': 'Coal was one of the vital elements that contributed to the Industrial Revolution. The mining of coal changed from being a small-scalle operation to become a large-scale operation helped by major technological advances.\nThe Industrial Revolution would not have happened without coal.\nIt is sometimes suggested that the key to the increase in coal production was an increase in scale, not a technological revolution. Certainly,\nthe organisation of the industry changed hugely\n, from small-scale adit or bell pits employing about 20 miners, to deep-shaft mines run by wealthy coal magnates such as Lord Londonderry.\nHowever, the reason that coal mining had been restricted to small surface mining was because\nworking deeper mines had encountered technological difficulties\nsuch as flooding, explosions, chokedamp, roof-falls, and lifting and transporting the coal. By the 19th century, these problems had been overcome by technological changes.\nkey to the increase in production was the use of the steam engine\n. The steam engine was powered by coal, so as the steam engine improved and was used in more industries, this led to an increased demand for coal.\nA similar example of industries interacting to cause the Industrial Revolution is between coal and the railways. The first steam trains in the world and the first railway in the world - the Stockton and Darlington Railway 1825 - were built to transport coal to the docks. However,\nrailways proved so popular and grew so big that they became a major user of coal\nin the 19th century, and this increased the demand for coal.\nBack to Industry 1700 - 1900 index\nAll things historic - from ancient to modern.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. While you will be able to view the content of this page in your current browser, you will not be able to get the full visual experience. {'text': "This Revision Bite will give you practise in structuring a presentation about a famous person into five key sections: intro, past, present, future and concluding opinion.\nIn your presentation exam you should speak for about one minute in Spanish on a topic you have prepared, then you will be asked questions in Spanish about what you have said. The biggest companies are no longer national firms but\nor transnational corporations (TNCs) with subsidiaries in many countries.\nGlobalisation is the process by which the world is becoming increasingly interconnected as a result of massively increased trade and cultural exchange.\nGlobalisation has been taking place for hundreds of years, but has speeded up enormously over the last half-century.\n. TV, telephony and the internet have allowed information and ideas to travel quickly. UK businesses can have a call centre in India answering calls from UK customers.\nhas become cheap and quick. UK people now holiday all over the world. People from other countries can travel to the UK to seek better-paid jobs. Businesses can ship products and raw materials all over the world more easily - making products and services from all over the globe available to UK customers.\n. Laws restricting trade and foreign investment have been relaxed. Some governments even offer grants and tax incentives to persuade foreign companies to invest in their country. {'text': "All matter is made of atoms. There are over a hundred different types of atom, called elements, and each one has a symbol. The atoms of a particular element are identical to each other.\nWhen atoms of different elements join together they make a compound. Compounds are represented by formulae that show how many atoms of each element are in the compound. Formulae can be worked out from the charge of the ions that make up the compound.\nChemical reactions can be written down as balanced chemical equations.\nAll matter is made from atoms. Atoms are very, very small. A molecule is formed when atoms join together by chemical bonds.\nThere are over a hundred different types of atom, called elements. The atoms of a particular element are identical to each other. They cannot be changed chemically into any different element. For example a piece of pure sulfur consists only of sulfur atoms. No chemical process can break it down into a different substance.\nCompounds are substances that contain atoms of at least\nchemically combined. For example: magnesium oxide consists of magnesium atoms and oxygen atoms chemically bonded together.\nNotice how the name sometimes suggests whether a substance is an element or a compound. If you can see the names of two or more elements it's almost certainly a compound but beware – many substances with only one name are actually compounds – water and methane for example.\nElements are represented by one or two\n. The first letter is always a capital and the second is always lower case.\n. Symbols and numbers show the atoms in the compound.\nOne zinc atom (Zn) and one carbon atom (C) are chemically bonded with three oxygen atoms (O\n). Notice that we don't need to write a 1 next to the Zn or C.\nIron(III) hydroxide consists of one iron atom joined with three oxygen and three hydrogen atoms. The formula is written like this because the oxygen and hydrogen atom often act together.\nThe formula of a compound can usually be deduced if the\nin it are known. For example, the compound formed from Na\nion so that the compound is neutral overall. The formula is therefore Na\nIt's helpful to remember some of the common ions so that the formula of most compounds can be deduced.\nWhen the atoms in elements or compounds rearrange themselves to form new substances it's called a\n. The atoms are rearranged but no atoms are lost or made.\nChemical reactions are written down as chemical\nWhen copper is heated in the air it reacts with the oxygen to form a new substance, called\nThis is not the whole story. A chemical equation needs to show where all the atoms in the products have come from. It also needs to account for all the atoms in all of the reactants. To\nthe equation, adjust the number of atoms or molecules until there are the same numbers of each type of atom on both sides of the equation. Don't be tempted to change the formulae of any of the substances involved.\nWhat is the equation for the above reaction? The substances involved are copper atoms (Cu), oxygen molecules in the air (O\n) and molecules of copper oxide (CuO). If we use them to write the equation it might not be balanced. It would look like this:\nBut that is not a balanced equation. This cannot be completely correct because there are two atoms of oxygen on the left and only one on the right. One atom of oxygen is\nWe balance it by thinking about the atoms and molecules involved. Two atoms of copper are needed for every molecule of oxygen.\nTwo atoms of copper react with two atoms of oxygen to form two molecules of copper oxide\n", 'label': '5'}

The 2nd note of the tie is not actually played.\nClick play to hear the rhythm played, first without any syncopation, and then with a syncopation added.\nYour web browser does not have JavaScript switched on at the moment. {'text': "I think Furry Fabrics should use Batch production for their new line of products. They do not know how big their market will be, so it would be more sensible to produce their hats in batches. This means they will not make too many unpopular hats that they can't sell.\nPaula's answer shows that she understands some of the basics of this topic. She has not explained in any detail why she would choose this method of production, or that she has considered any other methods. This answer would probably get an 'E' grade.\nI think Furry Fabrics should use batch production for their new line of products. They are not making something for one customer, so job production is not appropriate. They do not know how big their market will be, so mass production would also be inappropriate. It would therefore be more sensible to produce their hats in batches. This means they will not make too many unpopular hats that they can't sell, and they can produce more of the models that are selling well.\nDean has answered the question quite well, and given good reasons. He has shown that he understands the topic. He could have given more detail, and used more business terms to get a higher grade. This answer would probably get a 'C' grade.\nI think Furry Fabrics should use batch production for their new line of products. They are not producing a\ngood, so job production is not appropriate. They do not know how big their market will be, or what the demand will be for particular designs, colours or sizes, so mass production would also be inappropriate. It would therefore be more sensible to produce their hats in batches, and monitor the sales for each of the models. This means they will reduce wastage and costs, by not making unpopular hats they can't sell. At the same time, they can increase the frequency of the runs on the models that are selling well.\nRose has given an excellent answer. She has shown that she understands the topic well and has given good detailed reasons. She has also shown that she can used business terms like a customised good or batch production correctly. This answer would probably get an 'A' grade.\nGet down to business and discuss Business Studies here.\nLosing your way? {'text': "'I've made out a will; I've left myself'\n'I've made out a will; I've left myself'\nI've made out a will: Test (answer hints)\nCompare your answer with the hints below:\nThe sonnet's short length and tight structure make it suitable for intimate thoughts, single, simple ideas, and extended metaphors. Traditionally it has often been used for epitaphs - ie, reflections on what persists after a person's death.\nThese poems contain extended metaphors - one describing the body in terms of food or a clock, the other describing the couple's relationship in terms of a bed.\nBoth poems are quite intimate: one describes the writer's attitude towards his own body parts, the other Anne Hathaway's memories of love-making with her remarkable husband.\nBoth poems focus on one all-important thing that is seen as persisting, despite death: Armitage's heart, - his 'pendulum, the ticker' - and Anne Hathaway's 'living, laughing love - I hold him in the casket of my widow's head'.\nSonnets have traditionally been used to express intimate, personal feelings and thoughts about big subjects like love and death. They often make heavy use of metaphor.\nBoth these poems talk about death - about what goes and what might live on in some way. Both poems could be seen as a kind of epitaph.\nThe Armitage sonnet uses a series of metaphors of the body as food, or a clock. The Jonson sonnet has two metaphors: that of the debt - 'Seven years tho'wert lent to me, and I thee pay' - and the child as a poem - 'Ben Jonson his best piece of poetrie'.\nThe mood of the two poems is very different: one looking humourously forward to the writer's own death, the other looking back at someone else's death with grief and a kind of resignation.\nSonnets are compact, tightly structured poems. They are ideal for describing a single scene or idea, or capturing a moment of intense feeling.\nThese poems both do just that. Armitage's expresses the kind of wry thought that might strike you while you sit in a hospital waiting room; Whitman's describes a momentary wild thought while walking in a storm\nBoth poems are densely descriptive, with images tumbling confusedly over each other.\nBoth sonnets are fairly free: Whitman's poem has 6 beats/line instead of the usual 5, and a single half-rhyme echoing through the whole poem. Armitage's uses a mixture of 4 or 5 beats/line and rhymes erratically. They also both also seem to tail off at the end with extra short lines.\nOf course, these suggestions do not contain everything there is to say! You may have thought of other relevant points, and there may be other poems you have read which you could use in your comparison. The important thing is to be able to write two or three sentences pointing out similarities and differences between the poems.\nGet some direction with a Bitesize revision map\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. While you will be able to view the content of this page in your current browser, you will not be able to get the full visual experience. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n", 'label': '5'}
{'text': 'When the boys first gather on the island they appear a very varied group, yet by the end they all seem very similar. So, what happens to them to cause this transformation?\nLet\'s look at the most important characters in more detail. If you\'ve time, jot down the key points you\'ve noticed about the characters featured here - then compare your notes with ours.\n"You could see he might make a boxer, as far as width and heaviness in the shoulders went, but there was a mildness about his mouth and eyes that proclaimed no devil."\n"there was a stillness about Ralph as he sat that marked him out: there was his size and attractive appearance"\nHe is twelve years and a few months old. He has an attractive appearance, which suggests that he has an attractive character too.\nHe is sensible: it was Ralph\'s idea to have a chief, establish rules and build a signal fire so they can be rescued. He speaks wisely.\nHe is a good leader. He knows that it\'s important to keep Jack on his side and speaks to Piggy with the directness of genuine leadership. Later on he feels the weight of being chief as a personal hell - but he doesn\'t give up.\nHe wants to hang on to civilised values. When he realises that their lives are full of dirt and decay, he feels a\n. In the discussions about the beast, he feels\n"the understandable and lawful world... slipping away"\nHe uses civilised language. Even when he is pleading with Jack for the return of Piggy\'s glasses, he speaks like a school boy:\nHe is brave. He led the search for the beast at the fort alone:\nIt is Ralph who approaches the dead airman at the top of the mountain, with leaden steps, while Jack and Roger stay back.\nYet even Ralph sometimes gets carried away with the hunt. Ralph starts the game where they pretend Robert is a pig:\n"The desire to squeeze and hurt was over-mastering"\n. Later on, he becomes part of the \'dance\' that kills Simon. Near the end, he breaks the pig\'s skull on the stick with a sick fear and rage.\nRalph finally becomes an outcast. He tells himself this is\nWhen he meets the naval officer, he is seen as a little scarecrow, but Ralph is still able to assert himself as the leader. Then he cries, for the first time on the island.\n"he was tall, thin and bony; and his hair was red.. His face was crumpled and freckled, and ugly without silliness. Out of this face stared two blue eyes, frustrated now, and turning, or ready to turn to anger."\nJack is the leader of the choir. He was the chapter chorister, can sing C sharp, and was the head boy at school.\nHe has red hair and is tall, thin and bony.\n"His face was crumpled and freckled, and ugly without silliness"\n. His fiery hair and his ugly appearance give us clues to his fiery, ugly character.\nHe is hungry for power. When we first meet him he bosses the choir around; later he undermines Ralph\'s leadership and sets up his own tribe against Ralph, even though he loses a vote. He gradually becomes a dictator. When he orders the tribe to tie up Samneric her boasts to Ralph\nHe knows as soon as Ralph asks him that the choir should be hunters. Hunting then pre-occupies him more and more through the novel.\nHe can\'t kill the first pig he sees because of\n"the enormity of the knife descending and cutting into living flesh; because of the unbearable blood"\n. Yet he quickly puts aside any doubts.\n"All you can talk about is pig, pig, pig!"\nJack paints on a mask to help him hunt better. The paint gives him a liberation into savagery: he is able to do savage things now he looks more like a savage.\nHe is so moved by having killed a pig that he isn\'t anxious about the ship that went by while the fire was out. All he thinks about is the knowledge that\n"they had outwitted a living thing, imposed their will on it, taken away its life"\nBy the end, Jack has moved on even further. His prey has gone beyond pigs - he is keen to hunt Ralph.\nHe commits the first act of violence towards another boy on the island when he thumps Piggy.\n. He gets gradually more violent towards other boys: he has no thought for Piggy when he steals his glasses and later he ties up and beats Wilfred.\nHe pretends not to be frightened of the beast - but is shivering and croaking when he sees the \'beast\' on the mountain. Does this suggest that he\'s not really as brave as he\'d like to think he is?\n, it\'s soon clear he doesn\'t care about the rules or being civilised:\n" Bollocks to the rules! We\'re strong - we hunt! "\nHe rejects the order that had been established on the island:\n"We don\'t need the conch any more"\nAt the end, he has no remorse for Piggy\'s death. He declares himself Chief. He has lost the name Jack, which suggests he has lost all.\n"a slight, furtive boy whom no one knew, who kept to himself with an inner intensity of avoidance and secrecy."\n"the shock of black hair, down his nape and low on his forehead, seemed to suit his gloomy face and make what had seemed at first unsociable remoteness in to something foreboding."\nWhen he is first seen, he is described as\nHe is a loner and uncommunicative by nature.\nHe is cruel. He deliberately spoils the littluns\' games. Later, he relishes sharpening a stick at both ends with which to kill Ralph.\nHe volunteers to go up the mountain with Ralph and Jack to find the beast.\nHe becomes Jack\'s right hand man: they torture Samneric together to find out Ralph\'s hiding place. Yet he is capable of acting independently: he levers the rock that kills Piggy on his own initiative.\nHe is an executioner. He kills Piggy and, in the final hunt, Ralph fears Roger because he\n"What intelligence had been shown was traceable to Piggy."\n"Piggy was an outsider, not only by accent, which did not matter, but by fat, and ass-mar, and specs, and a certain disinclination to manual labour."\nHe has physical disadvantages because he is fat and asthmatic and is short sighted. Without his glasses, everything becomes a blur.\nHe is very intelligent - in Chapter 1 it is his idea to make a list of names, and it is he who realises that no adult knows the boys are on the island. Later he suggests making a sundial and hats. Ralph recognises Piggy could think:\n"Piggy, for all his ludicrous body, had brains"\nHowever, he does not speak as grammatically accurately as the others:\n" How can you expect to be rescues if you don\'t put first things first and act proper"\n. Perhaps this is to suggest he wasn\'t as well educated as the others and that he is not from the right class of people to be a successful leader. At the time the novel was written most power was still in the hands of the middle and upper classes.\nHe is embarrassed by his nickname, and he behaves with dignity when Ralph betrays the name to the others. We never know his real name.\nHe is kind and considerate to the littluns. He helps the boy with the birthmark talk about the \'snake-thing\' and helps Percival talk about the beast. He is later often left to care for them when the others are exploring and hunting.\nHe has the most mature attitude of any boy on the island. He scornfully sees the other boys\nHe is pragmatic. When Simon dies, Piggy tries to convince Ralph there was nothing they could have done:\n"It was an accident... and that\'s that"\nLike Ralph, he believes in civilised values and clings to what creates order:\n" I just take the conch to say this. I can\'t see no more and I got to get my glasses back"\n. When they go to the fort to confront Jack, he shouts\nto try to show Jack that he has a right to be heard.\nPiggy and the conch are destroyed together by the rock Roger levers. Thus both intelligence and the symbol of authority are dead, so we know that there is nothing left to stop Jack gaining full control.\nAt the end, Ralph mourns the fall through the air of\n"he was a skinny, vivid little boy, with a glance coming up from under a hut of straight hair that hung down, black and course"\n"He walked with an accustomed tread through the fruit trees"\nThe first time we meet Simon, he is in his choir robes. He faints on the beach because of the heat and Jack mocks him. We know he is delicate. He has epilepsy.\n"a skinny, vivid little boy, with a glance coming up from under a hut of straight hair that hung down, black and course"\n. His hair hides his face, which hints to us he is secretive.\nHe is imaginative: he sees the buds on the bushes as\nHe is helpful and works for the good of others; he is the only one to stick with Ralph to make the shelters. He is kind to the littluns and finds fruit for them.\nThe others recognise he is \'different\' to them in some way. Ralph says\n"a secret place in a clearing full of flowers and butterflies"\n, and is sufficiently at one with the jungle to walk in it alone at night. He is at one with nature and he has no fear.\nHe seems able to prophesy - he is the first to suggest that\n"You\'ll get back to where you came from"\nHe is the most perceptive about the beast. He says\n"maybe there is a beast... What I mean is... maybe it\'s only us"\n. He is the only one to see that the problems on the island stem from the boys\' relationships with each other, not from an outside force. Yet nobody understands what he\'s trying to say.\nWhen the Lord of the Flies \'speaks\' to him this idea is reiterated: the voice in Simon\'s head says\n"Fancy thinking the Beast was something you could hunt and kill!... You knew, didn\'t you? I\'m part of you?"\nHe is killed just as he is about to reveal the truth. It is ironic that he is the only one who finds out that the \'beast\' was a dead parachutist, but is denied passing on the message because the group of boys think, in their frenzy, he is the beast.\nSimon\'s close relationship with nature seems to carry on even after he is dead:\n" The waves turned the corpse gently in the water. ... Softly, surrounded by a fringe of bright inquisitive creatures, itself a silver shape beneath the steadfast constellations, Simon\'s dead body moved out towards the open sea"\n"They were twins and the eye was shocked and incredulous at such cheery duplication. They breathed together, they grinned together, they were chunky and vital. They raised wet lips at Ralph, for they seemed provided with not quite enough skin, so that their profiles were blurred and their mouths pulled open."\nThe twins gradually lost their individual names on the island and become Samneric. They depend upon each other and do everything together.\nThey are the first to see the parachutist (while they are tending the fire at night) and think it is a beast.\nThey share Ralph and Piggy\'s dismay at the death of Simon.\nThey are involved in the first successful pig hunt with Jack, but more and more they grow to support Ralph. They join the fight against Jack when Jack raids the shelters at night to get Piggy\'s glasses. Finally, only Samneric and Piggy are left on Ralph\'s side. Yet they are not strong enough to withstand a lot of pressure, and ultimately reveal Ralph\'s hiding place to Roger and Jack. In the end evil triumphs over good.\n', 'label': '5'}

{'text': "Gregor Mendel (1822-1884) studied the inheritance of different characteristics in pea plants. He found that when he bred red-flowered plants with white-flowered plants, all the offspring produced red flowers. If he bred these plants with each other, most of the offspring had red flowers, but some had white. This was because the allele for red flowers is dominant, and the allele for white flowers is recessive. Genetic diagrams help to show how this works.\nIn a genetic diagram, you show all of the possible alleles for a particular characteristic. There will be two alleles from one parent, and two from the other parent, making four altogether. You then draw lines to show all the possible ways that these alleles could be paired in the offspring. There will be four possible ways, but some or all of them could be repeated.\nA genetic diagram showing the outcome of Mendelâ\x80\x99s first cross. All the offspring have red flowers, even though they carry the recessive allele for white flowers\nIn genetic diagrams, the dominant allele is shown as a capital letter, while the recessive allele is shown as a lower-case letter.\nA genetic diagram showing the outcome of Mendel's second cross. Three-quarters of the offspring have red flowers and a quarter have white flowers\nBack to Cell division and inheritance index\nLosing your way? Make a Bitesize revision map!\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. While you will be able to view the content of this page in your current browser, you will not be able to get the full visual experience. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n", 'label': '5'}
{'text': 'Curves, texture from natural forms, criss cross lines, natural colours.\nThe joy of fertility and the natural world.\nClick \'Next\' for some background information on this artist.\nfor over 30 years. She remains fascinated with the creative process and likens the way clay can be transformed to a spirited, colourful and glazed vessel through firing to the growth of a tree from a seed.\nHer passion for ceramics was strengthened at high school, and experimentation with other art mediums strengthened her conviction that pottery was her natural vocation.\nThe work Kate creates ranges in size from intricate palm-sized pieces to exuberant, bold pots large enough for children to sit in. She also creates a variety of work from public fountains to gallery installation pieces.\nKate has become well known for her use of\non her work. The crystalline glazes produce crystal growth on the surface (as seen on \'Queen Pineapple\').\nThe glazes can almost be bad taste as they are so glitzy and clever, like 80s disco wallpaper or jazzy wrapping paper. I myself enjoy kitsch and aim to sometimes offset crystal bad taste with kitsch â€“ thus marrying form and surface. At other times crystals can be gentle and extraordinarily delicate making them a fabulously versatile friend to have in the often difficult glaze department.\nKey influences on Kate\'s work are the\nnatural world, fertility and the magic of growth\n, which she refers to as the "life force". Positive symbolism, fun and humour are also key to her work.\nAlthough most of Kate\'s pieces are based on\n, such as fruit and vegetables, she cites fashion designers\nas inspirations for the way she "dresses up" her pots.\nKate on the creative processes involved in ceramics:\nI prepare my clay very soft. I use T Material which usually arrives pretty hard, so I slice up a bag, make rows of wells in each slice, fill those with water, wait a few days and then wedge.\nI adore coiling. I think it is my favourite part of the whole of making ceramics ... except the anticipation and excitement of opening the kiln door. The slow process of the evolution of a form suits the way I work and think. When I have a concept for a pot I usually start a few pieces, making one of them follow my original idea, the others started are then free to change during the coiling of the form. It is these pieces that are so full of surprises and unsure excitement.\nI roll coils using both hands. I concentrate by closing my eyes and feeling the coil and reacting to it through touch alone. When I meet students who admit to not being able to roll a prefect coil I tell them to do it blindfold and get good reports back. You can not really see anything below your hands so you do really have to rely on touch alone to roll a coil. I adore rolling perfect soft long coils.\nThe artist on the subject of glazes:\nI mix [glaze] very thick. I apply using a variety of brushes. I try to create forms that will work with the fluidity of the glaze, create pools for crystals to grow in, and shoulders and round rims and gulleys and valleys for them to slide off and show their trail of movement.\nI often use three to six different glazes on one surface and blob and layer them together in a series of patches. These overlap in areas and create other effects. I keep a record of the order in which I apply the different recipes as effects change if the order changes.\n', 'label': '5'}
{'text': "Fractions, decimals and percentages can all represent the same information. But can you convert between them?\nTo change a fraction to a decimal, you divide the top number by the bottom number. (Divide the numerator by the denominator.)\nto a decimal, we calculate 3 ÷ 8\nSome decimals will terminate (end) like the example above, but many will not.\nThere are some fraction/decimal equivalents that you should be familiar with:\nIf the decimal terminates (ends), the denominator will be 10, or 100, or 1000 or… (depending on the number of decimal places).\n0.5 means 'five tenths’, so 0.5 =\n0.45 means '45 hundredths', so 0.45 =\n0.240 means ‘240 thousandths’, so 0.240 =\nIf the decimal repeats with a single digit, the denominator will be 9:\nIf the decimal repeats with two digits, the denominator will be 99:\nIf the decimal does not repeat at all it is known as an irrational number, and you cannot write it as a fraction.\nDenominator? {'text': "Success in geography coursework depends on the effective use of geography skills. The most important of these skills are being able to collect, select and represent data as well as analyse and interpret the evidence.\nCollect and record data in ways that are appropriate for your project.\nUndertake your own research - even if you are doing your coursework through a teacher-led investigation. This will improve your results, and make the work more interesting!\nFor example, if you are doing a shopping survey - make sure you understand the geographical issues related to local population structure, economic activity, transport patterns and urban planning. If you can find case studies on the issues you are looking into, make sure you refer to these and link them to what you have found in your own research.\nUse a range of graphs, tables and charts to represent your data. {'text': 'Urbanisation can cause problems such as transport congestion, lack of sufficient housing, over-rapid growth and environmental degradation. Many cities display particularly sharp inequalities in housing provision, health and employment.\nSome people try to escape these problems by moving away from the city - a process called\n. Long term, however, the solution must be to make cities more\nSustainable means using something or doing something in a way that minimises damage to the environment and which avoids using up natural resources, eg by using renewable rather than scarce resources.\nmeans an increase in the proportion of people living in urban areas compared to rural areas. An\nis a built-up area such as a town or city. A\nAs a country industrialises, the number of people living in urban areas tends to increase. The UK and many other MEDCs urbanised during the 18th and 19th centuries. People migrated from rural areas (due to the mechanisation in farming) to urban areas where there was employment in the new factories. The area of cities known as the inner city developed during this time as rows of terraced housing were built for workers.\nToday the UK is a mostly urban society, with 90% of the population living in towns or cities.\nOn a global scale, urbanisation is taking place rapidly, particularly in LEDCs\nAlthough the UK is an urban society, more and more people are choosing to live on the edge of urban areas - with many relocating to the countryside. {'text': 'Prop - torn wedding photograph - what could it represent?\nDramas are produced to a great extent through the use of symbols - or representations - standing in for real things. Many of the following can be understood as symbols.\nprops (eg a torn wedding photograph to represent a divorce)\ngestures (eg finger on lips as a symbol of silence)\nexpressions (eg open mouth to represent surprise)\ncostume (a white costume as a symbol of innocence)\nlighting (eg blue lighting to represent night-time)\nsetting (dry ice vapour to represent a snowy wood)\nLearn how to thought track in this activity!\nGet creative, go backstage and find drama tips and inspiration.\nGeneral Theatre Links - Theatre Studies: Articles and Resources\nGreek Theatre - Wikipedia: Theatre of Ancient Greece\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "Steps can be taken to manage flooding. Often these steps involve trying to lengthen the amount of time it takes for water to reach the river channel, thereby increasing the lag time. Flood management techniques can be divided into\n'Hard' options tend to be more expensive and have a greater impact on the river and the surrounding landscape.\n'Soft' options are more ecologically sensitive. The tables summarise the main flood management techniques.\nDams are often built along the course of a river in order to control the amount of discharge. Water is held back by the dam and released in a controlled way. This controls flooding.\nWater is usually stored in a reservoir behind the dam. This water can then be used to generate hydroelectric power or for recreation purposes.\nBuilding a dam can be very expensive.\nSediment is often trapped behind the wall of the dam, leading to erosion further downstream.\nSettlements and agricultural land may be lost when the river valley is flooded to form a reservoir.\nThe river channel may be widened or deepened allowing it to carry more water. A river channel may be straightened so that water can travel faster along the course. The channel course of the river can also be altered, diverting floodwaters away from settlements.\nAltering the river channel may lead to a greater risk of flooding downstream, as the water is carried there faster.\nTrees are planted near to the river. This means greater interception of rainwater and lower river discharge. This is a relatively low cost option, which enhances the environmental quality of the drainage basin.\nThe river is allowed to flood naturally in places, to prevent flooding in other areas - for example, near settlements.\nLocal authorities and the national government introduce policies to control urban development close to or on the floodplain. This reduces the chance of flooding and the risk of damage to property.\nThere can be resistance to development restrictions in areas where there is a shortage of housing. Enforcing planning regulations and controls may be harder in LEDCs.\nDifferent interest groups have different views about flood management techniques:\nGovernments and developers often favour large hard engineering options, such as dam building. Building a dam and a reservoir can generate income. Profits can be made from generating electric or leisure revenue.\nEnvironmental groups and local residents often prefer softer options, such as planting trees. Soft options cause little damage to the environment and do not involve the resettlement of communities.\nEffective flood management strategies should be economically, environmentally and socially sustainable. Sustainable strategies allow management without compromising the needs of future generations.\nBack to River landscapes and processes index\nDeliver key Geographic sound bites direct to your ear!\nNews, issues and opinions from all around the UK.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n", 'label': '5'}
{'text': "was the next-to-last novel of one of the greatest writers of the 19th century, Charles Dickens. It was published when Dickens was at his prime, and after all the experiences that developed his style and skills. It is a brilliant, intricate and perfectly crafted novel.\nThe factors surrounding a text which help us to understand it; the background events which help to explain something.\n, you need to know about Dickens, 19th-century novels, and his writing style.\nThese facts about Dickens will help you to better understand\nWhen he was 12, his father was imprisoned for debt.\nWhile his father was in prison, Dickens was sent to work in a boot-blacking factory.\nEven when his father came out of prison, Dickens' mother made him continue working in the factory - for which he never forgave her.\nIn 1830, he fell in love with Maria Beadnell, but she rejected him.\nIn 1857, Dickens, now 45, fell in love with an actress - the 18-year-old Ellen Ternan - although he never dared tell the public about her.\nIn 1858, Dickens set up his own weekly magazine -\n. In 1860, sales were falling because the novel the magazine was running did not have enough action to keep people interested.\nIt is possible that the elements of\nwere influenced by events in Dickens' life (listed above). {'text': 'How is information added to a wave?\nHow is information added to a wave?\nSignals are encoded and sent from a transmitter to a receiver, where they are decoded.\nOptical fibres can carry more information than an ordinary cable of the same diameter.\nSignals can be either analogue or digital. Digital signals maintain their quality over longer distances than analogue signals.\nSignals are sent from a transmitter to a receiver. This can be done in many ways: using\nElectromagnetic radiation with a frequency between that of visible light and radio waves.\nLow frequency electromagnetic radiation used to transmit information such as television and radio programmes.\nthrough the Earthâ€™s atmosphere and through space, or through cables using\nA fine glass fibre, through which light travels by total internal reflection, from one end to the other.\nAll signals, as they travel, decrease in\nThe maximum height of a wave, measured from the mid-point of its vibration.\n. This means that if they are transmitted over long distances they must be amplified (made bigger) along the way.\nBefore a sound or piece of information is transmitted, it is encoded in the transmitter in one of the ways described below - analogue or digital. The receiver must then decode the signal to produce a copy of the original information or sound.\ncontinuous data, eg the second hand on an analogue watch displays each second and the space in-between\nsignals vary continuously in amplitude, frequency or both.\ndata measured at discrete intervals, eg a digital watch typically moves from displaying one second to the next without displaying the values in-between\nsignals are a series of pulses with two states - on or off. Digital signals carry more information per second than analogue signals and they maintain their quality better over long distances.\nBack to Wave model of radiation index\nPut down that pen and listen to some additional Science audio.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "It is best way to start answering your question straight away. It will help you to focus on what is really important, and to decide what extra ideas you need as you develop your answer. So let's look at version two of 'What is the role of the Nurse in\n?' and see if we can tackle the question directly, without any waffle.\nWe first meet the Nurse in Act 1, Scene 3, as she talks to Lady Capulet and Juliet. The Nurse is quite different to the other characters: she seems very talkative and appears to ramble on. Her first topic of conversation is really Juliet's age - the Nurse explains in several different ways that Juliet is not quite 14 years old. Perhaps Shakespeare uses the Nurse here to show the audience just how innocent and young Juliet is. We also learn how close the Nurse is to Juliet. She remembers everything about Juliet's childhood and compares her to her dead daughter, Susan, who was born at the same time.\nThis might be your first attempt at starting the answer, but already it has a good focus on the question. The only time Shakespeare is mentioned is when we guess what he uses the character of the Nurse for, and this is an important point. Working like this allows you to plan your answer around the question, which is far better than just writing everything you know about the play.\nRemember, there is nothing wrong with including extra detail, but you only get marks for what is relevant.\nRead the full text online and make your own notes.\nGet creative, get published and get expert writing advice at BBC Blast.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': 'Mobile phones communicate with their base stations using low-intensity microwave radiation. Microwaves can be used to transmit information over large distances, although some areas have poor signals. The use of mobile phones means people are exposed to microwave radiation in two ways:\nto the head from the aerial in the phone\nto the body from transmitters in base station masts\nThere are limits to the amount of microwave radiation that can be emitted by mobile phones. This Specific Absorption Rate - SAR - should not be more than 2 watts per kilogram.\nMicrowaves from the phone can penetrate body tissues to a depth of a few centimetres. They are absorbed, and give up their energy to body tissues. This can cause a small amount of heating, about 0.1Â°C - much less than if you were standing in sunshine.\nThere is no conclusive evidence that mobile phones and masts can damage your health. But because millions of people use mobiles, many local authorities believe it is sensible to advise the public to take precautions, just in case.\nfrom 2007 about campaigners winning a two-year battle to get a mobile phone mast moved away from a primary school.\nBack to Energy for the home index\nWireless signals are all around us, learn more in this activity!\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': 'There were two types of water transport available in Britain before the 18th century - coastal shipping and navigable rivers. However, although both these methods were useful, they still had their problems, so something new was needed...\nBad weather was a risk of coastal shipping\n, but ships could be affected by tides, winds and pirates.\nHeavy goods such as coal and iron could only be transported by coastal shipping and not by roads.\nSome rivers had to be widened and deepened for large ships\nRivers that were large enough and deep enough to link towns and cities in Britain were called navigable rivers.\nThe main navigable rivers in Britain were the Thames, Severn, Humber, Trent and Mersey.\nrivers were widened and deepened by local communities\nWhile coastal shipping and navigable rivers were useful, there needed to be a more effective form of transport than roads and the existing water transport. The main reasons for change were:\nduring winter and dry up during summer months.\ndid not always link the major towns\nA rapidly growing population also needed a more efficient method of transport because\ncanals would be the next step forward\nRead this Revision Bite and then attempt to write down the information that you consider to be\nfor revising the early problems with pre-18th century water transport.\nAs part of your revision, think carefully about the\nthe benefits were of early water transport.\ncoastal shipping and navigable rivers needed to change.\n', 'label': '5'}
{'text': "For the political movement to have succeeded, it needed one leader who focused the attention of all the supporters and led them to victory. Chartism had two main leaders - Lovett and O'Connor - and they disagreed over Chartist tactics. This caused Chartism to fail.\nChartist groups were spread out in small groups all over the country. This made it difficult to successfully co-ordinate communication and meetings on a national level.\nThe Chartists did not always agree about what they wanted from Parliament. They all supported the Six Points, but some also wanted improved education, sobriety laws and improved working conditions.\nThe Chartists did not all belong to the same class and this meant that many middle-class supporters withdrew their support after Chartism became linked to violence. When the middle-class members left, there was less money to fund the movement and it started to fail.\nAll things historic - from ancient to modern.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "Thalidomide is a drug that was prescribed during the late 1950s and early 1960s. It was developed as a sleeping pill, but it was also thought to be useful for easing morning sickness in pregnant women. Unfortunately, it had not been tested for use in this way.\nA boy with stunted growth to the arms and legs due to the effects of thalidomide\nBy 1960, thalidomide was found to damage the development of unborn babies, especially if it had been taken in the first four to eight weeks of pregnancy. The drug led to the arms or legs of the babies being very short or incompletely formed. More than 10,000 babies were affected around the world. As a result of this disaster, thalidomide was banned.\nThalidomide is now used as a treatment for leprosy and bone cancer. Its use is heavily regulated, however, to prevent a repeat of the problems it caused in the last century.\nLet's see how you respond to this activity!\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled.
