{'text': "Evolution has taken place over millions of years and is responsible for all the living things on Earth today. There are different views and theories about the origin of life and the evolutionary process.\nIt is not possible to be certain how life on Earth began. We do know that:\nthe Earth is about 4,500 million years old\nthere is evidence that living things existed on Earth at least 3,500 million years ago\nno one was there to record how life began\nearly Earth was hotter and the atmosphere consisted mostly of\n(with other gases such as ammonia and methane)\nThrough the study of simple organisms and the chemistry of living things, we can develop scientific theories about how life on Earth began. The main theory is that living things developed from molecules that could\nThe material inside the nucleus of cells, carrying genetic information. DNA stands for Deoxyribonucleic Acid.\nThere are two possible origins for these replicating molecules:\nthey were produced by the conditions on Earth at the time\nthey came from somewhere else, such as another planet in our Solar System, or further out in space\nOver many millions of years these molecules joined with other molecules, becoming gradually more complex and dependent on each other. The process of evolution by\neventually led to all of the different living things that we see on Earth today.\nCharles Darwin was an English naturalist who studied variation in plants and animals during a five-year voyage around the world in the 19th century. He explained his ideas on evolution in a book called, 'On the Origin of Species', published in 1859.\nDarwin’s ideas caused a lot of controversy, and this continues today, because they can be seen as\nabout the creation of the world and the creatures in it.\nThe basic idea behind the theory of evolution is that all the different species have evolved from simple life forms. These simple life forms first developed more than 3 billion years ago (the Earth is about 4.5 billion years old). The timeline below shows some of the key events in the evolution of life on Earth, from the first\nSingle-celled micro-organisms, some of which are pathogenic in humans, animals and plants. Singular is bacterium.\nYour web browser does not have JavaScript switched on at the moment. For information on how to enable JavaScript please go to the\nYou will not be able to see this content until you have JavaScript switched on.\nThe theory of evolution states that evolution happens by natural selection. The key points are that:\nindividuals in a species show a wide range of variation\nthis variation is because of differences in their\nThe basic units of genetic material inherited from our parents. A gene is a section of DNA which controls part of a cell's chemistry - particularly protein production.\nindividuals with characteristics most suited to the environment are more likely to survive and reproduce\nthe genes that allow these individuals to be successful are passed to their offspring\nIndividuals that are poorly adapted to their environment are less likely to survive and reproduce. This means that their genes are less likely to be passed to the next generation. Given enough time, a species will gradually evolve.\ncan be caused by both genes and the environment. But it is only variation caused by genes that can be passed on to the next generation.\nLife on Earth today exists because of the conditions that were present when life was evolving. If, in the past, conditions had been different eg hotter, colder, or the Earth more or less massive, then evolution by natural selection could have produced some very different results. Our bodies would have changed to suit the Earth’s conditions.\nNatural selection and selective breeding can both produce changes in animals and plants. The difference between the two is that natural selection occurs in nature, but selective breeding only occurs when humans intervene.\nSelective breeding is a process where we choose the\nwe want in an animal. We then breed together a male and female that show some of those characteristics. From the offspring produced we select those that show the characteristic the most, and breed them together.\nThis process is repeated over many generations, each time selecting and breeding together those animals that have the characteristics we are looking for. Over a large number of generations, this can produce some surprising results.\nAll of these dogs were selectively bred from a common ancestor\nFarmers have used selective breeding for centuries to increase milk yield in cattle, produce larger eggs from chickens and obtain more grain from wheat.\nMutations are changes that can occur in\nThe basic units of genetic material inherited from our parents. A gene is a section of DNA which controls part of a cell's chemistry - particularly protein production.\n. These changes are random and can be caused by background radiation and chemicals that we come into contact with, for example the chemicals in cigarette smoke.\nSometimes these changes can be so severe that the\nBasic unit of life. Unicellular organisms only have one cell. Multicellular organisms have many cells.\ndies, sometimes the cell can divide uncontrollably and become cancerous, and sometimes the changes are small and the cell survives. Very rarely the changes may even be beneficial to us and produce new and useful characteristics.\nIf these changes occur in normal body cells, the changes are lost when we die. But if the changes occur in our\nsuch as sperm and ova, there is the possibility that the changes in the gene will be passed onto the next generation.\nIt is when these changes are passed on to the next generation that\ncan either ensure that they are selected if they are useful, or disappear from the gene pool if they are not.\nThe combined effect of these mutations, environmental changes, and natural selection, can sometimes produce changes in the organism that are so great that a new species is produced. This does not happen very often and only occurs when the mutated organism can no longer breed with the original species and is capable of producing fertile offspring.\nLiving organisms on Earth today, and the chemicals which work together to keep them alive, are extremely complex, even in single-celled micro-organisms. Some people find it hard to accept that such complexity could have evolved through natural selection. Some religious people believe that all living things on Earth were made by God, or that life was begun by God but then evolved through natural selection. We will probably never be absolutely certain about how life began, as no one was there to observe it. But scientists must base their theories on evidence.\nDarwin was not the only person to develop a theory of evolution. Jean-Baptiste Lamarck was a French scientist who developed an alternative theory at the beginning of the 19th century. His theory involved two ideas. These are:\nthe law of inheritance of acquired characteristics\nHis theory stated that a characteristic which is used more and more by an organism becomes bigger and stronger, and one that is not used eventually disappears. Any feature of an organism that is improved through use is passed to its offspring.\nThis table summarises the two different explanations for giraffes having long necks.\nSummary of explanations for giraffes having long necks\nA giraffe stretches its neck to reach food high up\nA giraffe with a longer neck can reach food high up\nThe giraffe’s neck gets longer because it is used a lot\nThe giraffe is more likely to get enough food to survive and to reproduce\nThe giraffe’s offspring inherit its long neck\nThe giraffe’s offspring inherit its long neck\nfor all the observations made about life on Earth. For instance, his theory would predict that all organisms gradually become complex, and simple organisms disappear.\nDarwin’s theory can account for the continued presence of simple organisms.\nJust like Darwin and Lamarck, when presented with information about alternative views about the origin of life and the evolutionary process, you need to be able to:\nIdentify statements that are data and statements that offer an explanation. For example, data is produced from an investigation and often but not always includes numbers. However, an explanation is a hypothesis that can be used to explain the data. If a scientist grows a micro-organism and counts the number of micro-organisms present every thirty minutes, the numbers he or she collects is\n. If the scientist notices that the number doubles every thirty minutes, he or she can use the data to produce an explanation, eg that\nSingle-celled micro-organisms, some of which are pathogenic in humans, animals and plants. Singular is bacterium.\ndivide every thirty minutes and the numbers increase exponentially.\nRecognise data or observations that are accounted for, or conflict with, an\nhardened remains or impressions of an organism that existed in the geological past\ncan be dated by looking at the age of the rock in which they are found. The fossil record shows how organisms have changed over a period of time. The data supports the explanation of the theory of evolution. However, when the fossil data is compared with the theory that all life on Earth started just a few thousand years ago, the data does not support the explanation.\nin an explanation. For example, sometimes the data collected from an investigation does not immediately lead to an explanation. When Alexander Fleming noticed that bacteria were not growing next to the penicillium mould it took imagination and creativity for him to think that maybe the mould was producing a chemical that was killing the bacteria. That is how antibiotics were discovered.\nIdentify a scientific question for which there is not an agreed answer. For example, did life evolve on planet Earth or did it arrive on a meteorite from outer space? Because no one was there at the time it is impossible to give an exact answer.\nSuggest why scientists involved in the same research sometimes disagree with each other. For example, many years ago, when scientists were first trying to date how old a fossil was, they sometimes disagreed. It was only when more evidence became available that they began to agree on the fossil’s age.\nYou will also need to be able to suggest why some scientists are reluctant to change their minds and explanations, even when new evidence is found that contradicts them. This is often due to the fact that scientists devote their lives to their research. To realise that, after all the years they have spent on it, their theory was wrong, is very difficult to accept.\nFossils of ammonites - sea creatures that became extinct about 65 million years ago\nMost of the evidence for evolution comes from the\n. Fossils show how much, or how little, organisms have changed over time.\nOne of the problems with the fossil record is that it contains gaps. Not all organisms fossilise well. And many fossils are destroyed by the movements of the Earth, or have simply not been discovered.\nEvolution is difficult to observe because it usually occurs over many years. This is one reason why the theory of evolution is\n, not a law. Since no one was around millions of years ago to make observations, take notes or carry out experiments, evolution cannot be proven in the usual scientific sense. However, rapid changes in species have been observed that support the theory.\nBefore the Industrial Revolution in Britain, most peppered moths were of the pale variety. They were camouflaged against the pale birch trees they rested on. Moths with a mutant black colouring were spotted easily by birds and eaten. This gave the white variety an advantage, making them more likely to survive and reproduce.\nAirborne pollution in industrial areas blackened the birch tree bark with soot. This meant the mutant black moths were now camouflaged, while the white variety became more vulnerable to predators. It gave the black variety an advantage. They were then more likely to survive and reproduce. Over time, the black peppered moths became far more numerous in urban areas than the pale variety.\nThe pale peppered moths camouflage well against the pale birch tree\nThe darker mutant peppered moths camouflage well against the blackened birch tree\nE. coli bacteria (Photo from Rocky Mountain Laboratories, NIAID, NIH)\nSingle-celled micro-organisms, some of which are pathogenic in humans, animals and plants. Singular is bacterium.\nultramicroscopic non-cellular organisms that replicate themselves inside the cells of living hosts\nreproduce rapidly and can evolve in a relatively short time. One example is the bacterium E. coli. Its\nThe material inside the nucleus of cells, carrying genetic information. DNA stands for Deoxyribonucleic Acid.\ncan be damaged or changed during replication, and most of the time this causes the death of the cell. But occasionally the mutation is beneficial (to the bacteria). For example, it may allow resistance to certain\nSubstances that kill bacteria and fungal infections.\n. When those antibiotics are present, the resistant bacteria have an advantage over the bacteria that are not resistant. Antibiotic-resistant strains of bacteria are an increasing problem in hospitals.\nScientists can now examine the DNA from different species of organism and use the data produced to see how closely related the two species are to each other. By collecting a lot of this data, scientists can compare the results with conventional ideas about how organisms have evolved. What they found was that DNA data supported the conventional theory of evolution.\nYou need to be able to provide an explanation that links together things that were previously thought to be unrelated. For example, DNA data being used to support the theory of evolution. Also people had noticed that there was a wide variety of different things living on the planet. Darwin noticed that different islands in the Galapagos had different types of finches adapted to eating the type of food found on each island. It was only when Darwin produced his theory of evolution by natural selection that these two unrelated facts were linked together.\nLiving organisms are dependent on the environment and other species for their survival. When the environment changes, organisms are not as well adapted to it.\nIndividuals that are poorly adapted to their environment are less likely to survive and reproduce than those that are well adapted. Similarly, it is possible that a species that is poorly adapted to its environment will become\nspecies of organism that is no longer living\nHere are some factors that can cause a species to become extinct:\nrapid changes to the environment, such as the climate\nBecause we are all part of a\n, changes in one part of the web can have a big impact on other parts of the web. When one food source disappears, a predator will have to find another food source in order to survive.\nThe fossil record shows that since life on Earth began many species have become\n. Extinction is still occurring, a lot of it because of human activity. We compete with other living things for space, food and water, and are very successful predators.\nSome animals such as the quagga are extinct because of the\nThe last quagga alive in the wild was shot in the late 1870s.\nThe quagga was the first extinct species to have its\nThe material inside the nucleus of cells, carrying genetic information. DNA stands for Deoxyribonucleic Acid.\nstudied. The DNA showed that the quagga was not a separate species as had been previously thought, but was a type of zebra.\nThe DNA result from the quagga is a good example of where new data is in conflict with a previous explanation.\nOther animals such as the dodo are extinct because of the\n. The dodo was a large flightless bird that lived in the Mauritius, a group of islands in the Indian Ocean. These islands were uninhabited, and the dodo had no natural predators. Then Mauritius were colonised by the Dutch in 1638. Dodos were hunted for food and easy to catch, because they were not afraid of people. However, it was new competitors brought to the islands, such as pigs, cats and rats, which ate the dodos' eggs and young, that were finally responsible for the extinction of the dodo.\nBiodiversity means having as wide a range of different species as possible. Maintaining biodiversity is an important part of using the environment in a\nway. Indiscriminate use of the environment, for example cutting down large areas of the rain forest to grow crops such as soya, results in a large number of species becoming extinct and reduces biodiversity.\nIt is only now that we are beginning to realise the potential medicines and crops that we can obtain from a wide range of different organisms. Only by maintaining biodiversity can we be sure that these benefits will be available for future generations.\n", 'label': '5'}
{'text': "Light travels as waves. Waves can be described by their\n. The speed of a wave can be calculated from its frequency and wavelength.\nvibrations that transfer energy from place to place\nwithout matter (solid, liquid or gas) being transferred. Think of a Mexican wave in a football crowd. The wave moves around the stadium, while each spectator stays in their seat only moving up then down when it's their turn.\nYour web browser does not have JavaScript switched on at the moment. The substance is known as\n, and it can be solid, liquid or gas. Sound waves and\nare like this. They must travel through a medium. It is the medium that vibrates as the waves travel through.\nOther waves do not need to travel through a substance. They may be able to travel through a medium, but they do not have to. Visible light, infrared rays, microwaves and other types of\nEnergy travelling as waves in the form of changing electrical and magnetic fields.\nare like this. They can travel through empty space. {'text': "Fractions, decimals and percentages can all represent the same information. But can you convert between them?\nTo change a fraction to a decimal, you divide the top number by the bottom number. (Divide the numerator by the denominator.)\nto a decimal, we calculate 3 ÷ 8\nSome decimals will terminate (end) like the example above, but many will not.\nThere are some fraction/decimal equivalents that you should be familiar with:\nIf the decimal terminates (ends), the denominator will be 10, or 100, or 1000 or… (depending on the number of decimal places).\n0.5 means 'five tenths’, so 0.5 =\n0.45 means '45 hundredths', so 0.45 =\n0.240 means ‘240 thousandths’, so 0.240 =\nIf the decimal repeats with a single digit, the denominator will be 9:\nIf the decimal repeats with two digits, the denominator will be 99:\nIf the decimal does not repeat at all it is known as an irrational number, and you cannot write it as a fraction.\nHow do we know whether a fraction will give a terminating decimal? The rule is to find the prime factors of the denominator.\nIf the prime factors are only 2 and/or 5 the decimal will terminate.\n28 = 2 x 2 x 7\nso the decimal will not terminate. It will be a recurring decimal.\n40 = 2 x 2 x 2 x 5\nThe prime factors of 40 consist of 2s and 5s, so the decimal will terminate.\n125 = 5 x 5 x 5\n120 = 2 x 2 x 2 x 3 x 5\nThere is a 3 in there, so the decimal will recur.\nTo change a fraction to a percentage multiply it by 100.\nRemember: you might find it easier to convert the fraction to a decimal before you multiply by 100.\nTo change a percentage to a fraction divide by 100.\nTo change a decimal to a percentage multiply it by 100.\n0.4 becomes 0.4 x 100 = 40%.\n2.01 becomes 2.01 x 100 = 201%.\nTo change a percentage to a decimal divide by 100.\n", 'label': '5'}
{'text': 'You can use information about reacting masses to calculate the formula of a\nA compound is a substance formed by the chemical union (involving bond formation) of two or more elements.\nSuppose 3.2g of sulfur reacts with oxygen to produce 6.4g of sulfur oxide. What is the formula of the oxide?\nof sulfur is 32 and the A\nFind the mass of each element. Conservation of mass tells us that the mass of oxygen = the mass of sulfur oxide - the mass of sulfur.\nThe mass of oxygen reacted = 6.4 - 3.2 = 3.2g\nSo we have 3.2g of sulfur and 3.2g of oxygen.\nNow divide the mass of each element by its A\nFinally, find the ratio of the elements.\nYou can do this by dividing the results by the smallest of the numbers to give you the number of atoms of each element in the compound.\nIn this case the smallest value is 0.1, so divide both results by that.\nS = 0.1 รท 0.1 = 1\nO = 0.2 รท 0.1 = 2\n(If one of the numbers ends in 0.5, multiply all the numbers by 2 - this is because you cannot have half-atoms in a compound.)\nSo the ratio of sulfur to oxygen is 1:2\nThe number of atoms tells you that the formula for sulfur oxide is SO\nHere is the calculation again in tabular form to help you remember the steps:\nSteps to calculation the formula of a compound\nResult: the formula for the oxide = SO\nGet some direction with a Bitesize revision map\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "Before You Were Mine: Test (sample answers)\nBelow are some sample answers which examiners would mark at different grades.\nThe ballroom with the thousand eyes sets a very romantic scene and we can understand how the poet's mother would have been excited to go there and risk staying out late.\nAs well as illustrating how the light played on the mirrorball, sending light across the dancefloor, the thousand eyes could refer to the eyes of five hundred potential suitors (real or imaginary) standing round watching, which would have enhanced the excitement even more.\nThroughout, the poet is very possessive of her mother. References to her appear constantly (I'm ten years away... I'm not here yet... I remember...). The word Mine appears in the title and the poem actually concludes with the same words as the title, as if the poet is locking her mother in a firm embrace of words.\nThis answer would be of a Grade A standard.\nThe line I see you, clear as scent is difficult to understand, because you can't see scent. I think it means that the poet has imagined what her mum must have looked like, waiting by the tree, so clearly that she can almost smell the scene. Also, scent is quite a romantic word - maybe her mum wore scent when she met her boyfriend.\nThe fact that the poet names her mother's friends, Maggie McGeeney and Jean Duff (which sound like typical names from those times) help us believe in what she is writing. It is more personal - we feel we can get to know her mother's pals too.\nThis answer would be of a Grade C standard.\nThe poet's mum used to imagine herself having as a perfect life, as if she was in a film - fizzy, movie tomorrows, if she met the right boy.\nThe poet says that her mother looked a bit like Marilyn Monroe in her polka-dot dress, which is interesting because her mother probably dreamed of being like Marilyn.\nThis answer made points which would be of a Grade E standard.\nIf your answer was closest to Answer 1 - well done! If not, it might be a good idea to look back over the Revision Bite.\nGet some direction with a Bitesize revision map\nGet creative, get published and get expert writing advice at BBC Blast.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': 'The end of the Native American way of life\nThe end of the Native American way of life\nWhy did the white Americans win the West?\nWhite Americans won the West because everything was on their side. The Native Americans fought bravely, but the odds were completely against them.\nA contemporary painting of the Wounded Knee Creek massacre, where troops attacked the Ghost Dancers, 29 December 1890\n- the massacre of Custer\'s regiment caused thousands of \'Custer\'s Avengers\' to join up, and it made the US Army determined to hunt down and destroy the Native American warriors.\n- the US government made promises which it later broke.\n- the US government had unlimited men and money. After the Little Bighorn, the Sioux had to disband their army because the land could not support so large a group for long.\n- the US Army had access to repeating rifles, machine guns, cannons and the telegraph. The Native Americans had to buy rifles, and used smoke signals to communicate.\n- thousands of white Americans and US soldiers could travel to the West in hours by railroad.\n- after the 1870s, white hunters destroyed the buffalo, not only for their hides, but partly to destroy the Native Americans, whose way of life depended on these animals. By 1895, less than a thousand buffalo remained on the Great Plains.\nwas too big and strong for the Native American warriors. It controlled the Plains from a system of forts.\ndestroyed the Indian way of life, because people on them were forced to become farmers. Many warriors became alcoholics. The influence of the chiefs declined, because the reservations were run by agents. The Code of Religious Offences destroyed the Native American religion, and the Dawes Act ended community ownership.\n- the Indian boarding schools (which the children were made to attend) forced Native American children to become \'white\'. They were beaten if they even whispered in their own language - the motto of one school was\n"kill the Indian to save the man"\nFed up with reading? Give your ears a treat and listen to some History audio.\nAll things historic - from ancient to modern.\nNational Museum of American History - Timeline\nPortrayals of Native Americans - UC Berkeley - Bancroft Library\nU.S National Archives and Records Administration - Pictures of Native Americans\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "Evaluating music is really about comparing one piece of music with another, identifying the elements that make pieces of music different from one another.\nInterpretation is the way performances change from player to player. For example, one player might play the music faster, or might play using different dynamics or phrasing.\nNo two performers play music in the same way, because each performer interprets the music differently. Here's a checklist of factors to bear in mind when you discuss interpretation in the exam:\n: how loud or quiet the music is\n: all referring to the speed at which music is played\n: how strictly the performers play in time\nWhen listening to two versions of the same song or piece of music you need to think about both the similarities and differences.\nUse comparative language, words like louder, quieter, faster, slower.\nthe type of instruments or voices used (eg soprano or bass voice, strings, brass or percussion)\nthe number of instruments or parts (eg solo, duet, trio, string ensemble or orchestra)\nthe structure of the music (eg introduction, movement, coda, sonata, concerto, song)\nthe type of accompaniment (eg vamping, oom-pa, Alberti bass, arpeggio)\nwhich of the versions you prefer and why\nNow have a go yourself. Listen to these two pieces which employ the same melody: first\nby Sweetbox. See if you can identify 3 features the pieces have in common (apart from the tune!) and 3 contrasting features.\nThe kind of features you should have noticed:\ntempo in second piece is quicker than the first- the first is largo, the second more upbeat\nTonality change - first minor, second major\nViolins plays melody / legato / smoothly\nInstrumentation different - second added voices and drum kit\nIf you are describing sung music, you need to be able to name the type of singing voice. Click on the pitch to hear the sound.\nYour web browser does not have JavaScript switched on at the moment. For information on how to enable JavaScript please go to the\nYou will not be able to see this content until you have JavaScript switched on.\nBelow is a list of other common musical terms that you should be able to use when describing and comparing pieces of music:\nA small group of instruments made of violins, violas, cellos and double basses\nLarge group of instruments made up of members of the four families - strings, woodwind, brass and percussion\nA scale consisting of all the 12 semitones of the octave\nA scale made up of five notes used a lot in traditional Chinese and Scottish Music- usually has no semitones\nMusic that is based on one of the scales of seven pitch classes commonly found in western music but excluding the major and minor scales- used in early and world music\nA type of scale used in Indian music\nThe end section which rounds off a piece or a movement\nMade up of three sections like a sandwich (A-B-A)\nA 3-part from, with an exposition, followed by a development, and finally a recapitulation\nPlaying block chords continuously throughout a section or piece\nChords played in three time to accompany a waltz\nAccompaniment consisting of chords broken up into patterns played in the left hand of the piano\nSounding of chord where notes are spread one after the other, usually in intervals of three\nHere is a short musical example of different musicians performing Rimsky Korsakov's\n. Listen carefully to each one, and try to decide how the piece has been differently interpreted.\nperformed by Michael Rabin, violin (Real Audio clip)\nperformed by David Helfgott, piano (Real Audio clip)\nHere are three examples of pupils work describing the performances:\nBoth versions are played allegro with crescendo, diminuendo phrases as the melodic motive rises and falls. In the first version a string ensemble enters and then the violin solo part takes over the melody. The solo violin is playing fast semi-quaver passages in separate bows. In the second version a solo pianist performs all parts, interweaving the separate parts between left and right hand. In the first version a flute enters to play an answering melodic phrase. Thus, although both version are allegro, and demonstrate the same dynamic ranges. However the orchestration changes as the first is arranged for a solo violin with string and flute backing. The second is arranged solely for piano.\nBoth versions are examples of the same tune but are played by different instruments. Both are fast. In the first example there is a solo violin and in the second a solo piano part. The first version is accompanied whereas the second is not.\nBoth versions play the same song but are played on different instruments. The speed is the same in both.\n", 'label': '5'}

{'text': 'There are two key pieces of evidence for Big Bang theory. These are\nYou may have noticed that when an ambulance or police car goes past, its siren is high-pitched as it comes towards you, then becomes low-pitched as it goes away. This effect, where there is a change in frequency and wavelength, is called the Doppler effect. It happens with any wave source that moves relative to an observer.\nThis happens with light too. Our sun contains helium. We know this because there are black lines in the spectrum of the light from the sun, where helium has absorbed light. These lines form the absorption spectrum for helium.\nWhen we look at the spectrum of a distant star, the absorption spectrum is there, but the pattern of lines has moved towards the red end of the spectrum, as you can see below.\nThis is called red shift. It is a change in frequency of the position of the lines.\nAstronomers have found that the further from us a star is the more its light is red shifted. This tells us that distant galaxies are moving away from us, and that the further a galaxy is the faster it is moving away. Since we cannot assume that we have a special place in the universe this is evidence for a generally expanding universe. It suggests that everything is moving away from everything else. The Big Bang theory says that this expansion started billions of years ago with an explosion.\nScientists discovered that there are microwaves coming from every direction in space. Big Bang theory says this is energy created at the beginning of the universe, just after the Big Bang, and that has been travelling through space ever since.\nA satellite called COBE has mapped the background microwave radiation of the universe as we see it. Big Bang theorists are still working on the interpretation of this evidence.\nA summary of some of the evidence of the Big Bang and its interpretation\nThe light from other galaxies is red-shifted.\nThe other galaxies are moving away from us.\nThe further away the galaxy, the more its light is red-shifted.\nThe most likely explanation is that the whole universe is expanding. This supports the theory that the start of the universe could have been from a single explosion.\nThe relatively uniform background radiation is the remains of energy created just after the Big Bang.\nBack to Waves, radiation and space index\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. While you will be able to view the content of this page in your current browser, you will not be able to get the full visual experience. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n', 'label': '5'}

{'text': "chemical messengers produced in glands and carried by the blood to specific organs in the body\n. This means that knowledge of hormones can be used to decide to increase, or reduce, the chances of fertilisation and pregnancy.\nThe oral contraceptive, 'the pill', greatly reduces the chances of mature eggs being produced. The pill contains oestrogen, or oestrogen and progesterone. These hormones inhibit the production of FSH, which in turn stops eggs maturing in the ovaries.\nSome women have difficulty becoming pregnant because they don't produce enough FSH to allow their eggs to mature. {'text': "The camel is adapted to life in a hot climate\nCamels live in deserts that are hot and dry during the day, but cold at night. They are well adapted for survival in the desert. Camels have:\nto spread their weight on the sand.\non the top of the body for shade, and thin fur elsewhere to allow easy heat loss.\nA large surface area to volume ratio\nability to go for a long time without water\n(they don't store water in their humps, but they lose very little through urination and sweating).\nSlit-like nostrils and two rows of eyelashes\nA cactus is adapted to life in a hot climate\nCacti are well adapted for survival in the desert. They have:\nWidespread root systems that can collect water from a large area.\n. These minimise the surface area and so reduce water loss by\nthe loss of water from leaves by evaporation. It is much faster when stomata are open than when they are closed\n. The spines also protect the cacti from animals that might eat them.\nAnimals and plants may have specific features that adapt them to their environment. These include barbs and spines, poisons and warning colours that deter predators and herbivores. {'text': "Much of the meaning of a poem is conveyed by the attitude it expresses towards its subject matter. Attitude can be thought of as a combination of the poet's tone of voice, and the ideas he or she is trying to get across to the reader.\nTo decide on the tone, you need to think about the ideas and attitudes in the poem, and then decide how you would read it aloud.\nIn a nightmarish tone, as in a horror film?\nIn a cold, dead tone, to emphasise all the horrors described?\nIn a warmer tone, to celebrate the love that does exist?\nChoose a short quotation to justify your choice.\nThe ideas in this poem concern the relationship between evil and love. In the first part, the vultures are used as a\nAn image or thing (usually something physical, like a flag) that stands for or represents something else - usually something abstract, like a nation. A crucifix is a symbol of Christianity.\nAn apparently contradictory, or impossible proposition that is actually true.\nthat evil and love can co-exist; in the second part, Achebe uses the Belsen Commandant as an actual example of this. Have a look at the quotations below, and our suggestions about how they fit in to this theme.\nKey phrases and how they fit into the theme\nStrange is isolated in a single-word line. This makes us dwell on the word and prepares us for the image of love settled in an evil place. By the end of the poem, Achebe shows that even the most evil people experience kindred love, but that love is not powerful enough to halt the evil.\nAchebe picks the most gruesome images he can find when describing the vultures to emphasise their evil. This prepares us for the human evil he goes on to explore.\nfor in the very germ... is lodged the perpetuity of evil.\nIt is poignant that Achebe concludes the poem with the idea of the predominance of evil. Evil is lodged within love - and evil is the haunting final word of the poem.\nBack to Poems from different cultures index\nGet some direction with a Bitesize revision map\nGet creative, get published and get expert writing advice at BBC Blast.\nContemporary Postcolonial and Postimperial Literature in English\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "All substances are made from atoms. Each atom is made of a nucleus - containing protons and neutrons - surrounded by electrons.\nThe atomic number is the number of protons in an atom. The elements are arranged in the Periodic Table in ascending order of atomic number.\nThe mass number of an atom is the total of protons plus neutrons. Atoms of the same element with different numbers of neutrons (and hence different mass numbers) are called isotopes of that element.\nAll material things are made from atoms. There are just over one hundred different types of atom, called elements. Atoms can join together in millions of different combinations to make\n. Protons and electrons are oppositely charged. Neutrons have no charge. This means the nucleus of an atom is always positively charged.\noverall charge because it has the same number of electrons as protons.\n. Electrons have such a small mass that this can usually be taken as zero.\nComparing the charge and mass of electrons, protons and neutrons\n(also called the proton number) is the number of protons in an atom.\n(also called the nucleon number) is the total number of protons and neutrons in an atom.\nThe elements are arranged in the Periodic Table in ascending order of atomic number so it's easy to find the name or symbol for an atom if you know the atomic number.\nSection of the periodic table showing elements ascending by atomic number\nMost elements exist in a number of different forms or varieties called\n. Isotopes have the same number of protons but different numbers of neutrons, which gives them a different total mass. That means isotopes of an element have the same atomic number but different mass numbers.\nBack to Atoms and the periodic table index\nGive your revision some visual style with a Bitesize revision map!\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "In the exam you'll be asked to write about four poems, two pre-1914 and two post-1914 (Heaney and Clarke or Duffy and Armitage), comparing and contrasting them with each other. The poems will usually have something in common - such as their subject matter, or an aspect of their language, or the ideas expressed - but also important differences. In comparing them, you may be able to notice things about the way the poems convey their meanings which you might not have noticed before.\nWhen you are asked to compare poems, it's a good idea to run through in your mind each of the headings under which we have looked at the poems in the revision bite:\nsubject matter, structure, language and imagery, sound, ideas, and attitudes and tone\nCompare We Remember Your Childhood Well with one other post-1914 poem and two pre-1914 poems of your choice that focus on the relationship between two generations.\nThree poems suitable for this comparison would be Simon Armitage's Kid, W B Yeats's Song of the Old Mother, and William Wordsworth's The Affliction of Margaret.\nWhat would you want to include in your comparison? {'text': "Seize any opportunity to use other tenses.\nUse ready made phrases to make it easier to talk in the past and future tenses eg:\nGive as much information as possible- can you answer who, where, what, when and why in your answers?\nAlways give opinions and reasons even if you haven't been directly asked for them.\nDon't just read it, practise your Spanish with downloadable audio bites.\nUse your language skills in this sinister game of intrigue and detection.\nReal Spanish, real drama from BBC languages.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "Species gradually evolve by a process of natural selection. The individuals in any population with the inherited features best suited to the environment in which they live are most likely to survive and reproduce. When they do, they pass on the genetic information for these features to their offspring.\nOver time, a species can change its appearance and may even become a new species, unable to reproduce successfully with individuals of the original species.\nSelective breeding, also called artificial selection, involves people taking charge of selection to produce new 'varieties' of various species. A variety is a type of a particular species that is different in some clear way from other varieties of that species.\nFor example, pedigree dogs come in lots of different varieties (or breeds) - they may be different colours and sizes, but they are all still dogs.\nFrom left to right - Beagle, Wheaten Terrier, Rhodesian Ridgeback, Red Siberian Husky, Irish Setter, Golden Retriever, Boxer, Sheltie\nSuppose you wanted a variety of cow that produced a lot of milk. This is what you could do:\nchoose or select the cows in your herd that produce the most milk\nselect the offspring that produce the most milk\nkeep repeating the process of selection and breeding until you achieve your goal\nThe key here is to identify the feature you want, and only breed from the individuals that have that feature. Here are some examples of what selective breeding can produce:\nhens that lay big eggs of a particular colour\ntomato plants that produce lots of tomatoes\ncrops that are resistant to certain plant diseases\nAn activity that would make Darwin proud!\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. While you will be able to view the content of this page in your current browser, you will not be able to get the full visual experience. Please consider upgrading your browser software or enabling style sheets (CSS) if you are able to do so.\n", 'label': '5'}
{'text': 'An atom is the smallest part of an element that still has the properties of that element, comprising electrons surrounding a nucleus of protons and neutrons.\nof a given element have the same number of\nSub-atomic particles with a positive charge and a relative mass of 1.\nUncharged sub-atomic particles, with a mass of 1 relative to a proton.\ncan vary. Atoms of the same element that have different numbers of neutrons are called\nof that element. The diagram shows three hydrogen isotopes.\nWhen an atom emits alpha or beta radiation, its\nThe central part of an atom. It contains protons and neutrons, and has most of the mass of the atom.\nchanges. It becomes the nucleus of a different element. This is because the number of protons in the nucleus determines which element the atom belongs to.\nThese are the changes that occur to the number of protons in an unstable nucleus when it emits a radioactive particle:\nalpha particle - the number of protons goes down by two\nbeta particle - the number of protons increases by one\nIn each case, a different element is left behind.\nPut down that pen and listen to some Science audio.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. Séamus has included lots of information about his chosen famous person and has used the past, present and future tenses effectively. He has introduced his topic well with detailed background information and has used structures and vocabulary already known to him from his description of himself. He has also chosen a topic which he is genuinely interested in, therefore making it easier for himself to adopt an enthusiastic approach to the subject. His hair is short and his eyes are blue. He lives in Ballygawley in County Tyrone in Northern Ireland. He is married and he has three children.\nHe is a very fit person and he has a big interest in Gaelic football. He plays Gaelic football for the Errigal Ciaran team and for the Tyrone team. He is a very good footballer. He is very skillful and dedicated. He trains every day and he is getting better.\nHe played in the Final last year against Armagh and Tyrone won. Peter Canavan was extremely happy that day. He played quite well that day and he got a couple of points. After the match he lifted Sam Maguire and he was very happy. He brought Sam Maguire back to Tyrone and he had a big party.\nHe is a P.E. teacher also. He teaches in a secondary school in County Tyrone. He will not be teaching this year, however, because he has a lot of work with the football. It is possible that he will not be playing football next year. He thinks that he will retire from football because he will be too old.\nI think that he is an excellent footballer and I was very happy when he lifted Sam Maguire. {'text': 'For some context on Seamus Heaney, see the Context section of\nListen to the poem and watch the slideshow\nPerch on their water-perch hung in the clear Bann River\nNear the clay bank in alder-dapple and waver,\nPerch we called \'grunts\', little flood-slubs, runty and ready,\nI saw and I see in the river\'s glorified body\nThat is passable through, but they\'re bluntly holding the pass,\nUnder the water-roof, over the bottom, adoze,\nGuzzling the current, against it, all muscle and slur\nIn the finland of perch, the fenland of alder, on air\nThat is water, on carpets of Bann stream, on hold\nIn the everything flows and steady go of the world.\nthe River Bann in Northern Ireland, famous for course fishing\nlumps in skeins of wool, yarn or thread\nmarshy shallows along the edge of the river\nThe poem describes perch apparently \'perching\' in the river, just as they did when Heaney was a boy. They seem to stay still and are apparently unchanging, in contrast to the fast-moving world.\nThe poem consists of one long sentence, formed of ten lines divided into five\nPairs of lines of poetry that rhyme and have the same length and metric pattern.\n. The single sentence encourages us to \'flow\' swiftly through the poem, perhaps reminding us of the flow of the water.\nThink about how the language the poet uses helps to convey his ideas. Here are some points to consider:\nThe title plays on the many meanings of the word\nand so does not immediately make clear what the poem is going to be about. A perch can be the branch on which a bird rests, or (more colloquially) a place to rest - or a fish.\nThe river appears to be very beautiful - the water is\n(line 1) and tree-lined, and Heaney refers to its\nin line 4 (a body or solid mass of water - but with suggestions also of a human body, \'glorified\' by the dappling sunlight).\nThe fish are the same today as they were when Heaney was a child -\n(line 4). Seeing the fish triggers off memories of childhood and makes him think about everything that changes in the world.\nWe see things not just through the poet\'s eyes, but through the fishes\' own eyes too:\n(line 6) is how they see the surface of the river.\nThe poem ends by describing the perch\n"on hold / In the everything flows and steady go of the world."\nagainst the changing world that flows around them. To Heaney the perch seem to represent things that resist change: they stay still in the water and they are still the same as they were when he was a child. Do you think he is reassured by their apparent permanence?\nA play on words, bringing together different meanings of the same word or similar meanings of different words. For example, \'perch\' the fish, and \'perch\' to sit precariously like a bird on a twig.\nin the name perch in the opening line: he portrays the fish on their water-perch, as if the fish were birds resting in a tree.\nThe perch seem to be floating in\n(line 2). Do you think this phrase describes the reflection of the trees in the water, or does it suggest that some branches are actually touching the water? Either way, it really may appear that the perch are \'perching\' in the branches.\nHeaney and his friends called the perch\n(line 3) as children. It is an earthy, rural word, reminding us of the rural scene.\n(line 3), as if they are lumps in the otherwise smooth flow of the river. (This\nA description of one thing in terms of another - implicitly comparing the two, but without using \'as\' or \'like\'. \'Sea of troubles\', and \'drowning in debt\' are metaphors. Something that represents another thing.\nalso reflects the rural setting, where many garments would have been home-knitted.)\nHe uses a military metaphor - the perch are\n(line 5), as if they are withstanding an enemy attack. It helps us to picture the fish holding their position in the water and suggests their strength.\n.. yet the next line states that they are\nThe strength of the fish is emphasised again in\n(line 7) - it is ironic that the fish look still but are actually fighting the current.\n"In the finland of perch, the fenland of alder"\n(line 8) makes us think of the country Finland - so the fish are \'citizens\' of the river - and the fins of the fish. Finland and fenland are almost identical and there is humour in the echo.\nFrom the perspective of the perch, the water is\n(lines 8/9): again, there is light humour in the idea: the fish are so at home in the river that Heaney gives them human comforts like carpets and a\nPairs of lines of poetry that rhyme and have the same length and metric pattern.\ncreate a build-up of energy through the poem, suggesting the energy of the fish\n...particularly as the phrasing often flows over the end of one line into another (called\nLines in a poem or play that run on from one to another without pause or punctuation.\nWords that sound the same through the use of similar vowels or consonants, eg hot and slop or fold and filled.\nUsing the sounds of words to express or underline their meaning, eg \'crunch\', \'pop\'; to do with onomatopoeia. (You can also say \'onomatopoetic\')\nand helps to suggest the flow of the water. There is another example of assonance in\nsounds combine with the emphatic, single-syllable words to express the small, compact, hardworking strength of the fish.\nMuch of the meaning of a poem is conveyed by the\nit expresses toward its subject matter. \'Attitude\' can be thought of as a combination of the poet\'s\nhe or she is trying to get across to the reader.\nA good way to decide on the\nThe mood or manner of a text or part of a text. The author\'s \'tone of voice\' or way in which they expect to be understood. The emotional load carried by a text.\nof a poem is to work out how you would read it aloud. Should this poem be read:\nin a lively, energetic way, to reflect the movement of the water?\nin a slow, thoughtful way, to reflect the apparent stillness of the fish?\nWell, the poem celebrates both these things - fluidity\nstillness. So either or even (if possible) both these tones of voice would be appropriate!\nAn important idea in this poem (apart from the detailed, powerful description of the perch in the river) is the relationship between permanence and change. Heaney uses the flowing river-water and the stationary fish as a\nA description of one thing in terms of another - implicitly comparing the two, but without using \'as\' or \'like\'. \'Sea of troubles\', and \'drowning in debt\' are metaphors. Something that represents another thing.\nfor this relationship. Have a look at the following quotes, and at our suggestions as to how they fit into this idea.\nI saw and I see in the river\'s glorified body..\nHeaney praises the river. He sees it as glorified, a powerful word in\nA description of all the differences between two things (in this case, two texts).\nto the starker language he uses elsewhere in the poem, which suggests his love of the river - perhaps even a religious attitude towards it.\nHeaney seems fond of the perch. Although he recognises their strength, he also describes them with gentle humour. Adoze suggests they are sleeping as they swim, while Guzzling is an affectionate word, sometimes used to describe babies drinking.\non hold / In the everything goes and steady go of the world\nThe world is described in terms of water, flowing on. This suggests that Heaney sees things as always moving and changing. The fish are \'on hold\', but they are not fighting the current so much as drinking it, letting it pass through and around them. Perhaps Heaney is suggesting that this is the only kind of permanence that is possible or desirable...\nIn the exam, you will be required to write about several poems, some pre-1914 and some post-1914. To which poems would you compare\n? There will be a number of ways in which the poems can be compared, and you may well be able to think of ones which we have not!\nA description of the similarities and differences between two things (in this case, two texts).\nBoth poems describe a living creature in its natural environment, and use this as a\nAn image or thing (usually something physical, like a flag) that stands for or represents something else - usually something abstract, like a nation. A crucifix is a symbol of Christianity.\nBut in Clarke\'s poem the mouse is a symbol of vulnerability and impermanence; while in Heaney\'s the perch represents a kind of permanence and strength.\nBoth poems celebrate a favourite waterside scene and the life of creatures within it\nPairs of lines of poetry that rhyme and have the same length and metric pattern.\nMarks used in written texts to divide them up into phrases, clauses and sentences, show speech etc, and to clarify meaning.\nto emphasise the \'flow\' of the words\nBoth describe an animal in its natural habitat, and both try to see the world from the animal\'s own viewpoint\nBoth poems emphasise the strength of the creature, and how well it is adapted to its way of life.\nIn the exam you\'ll be asked to write about four poems, two pre-1914 and two post-1914 (Heaney and Clarke or Duffy and Armitage), comparing and contrasting them with each other. The poems will usually have something in common - such as their subject matter, or an aspect of their language, or the ideas expressed - but also important differences. In comparing them, you may be able to notice things about the way the poems convey their meanings which you might not have noticed before.\nWhen you are asked to compare poems, it\'s a good idea to run through in your mind each of the headings under which we have looked at the poems in the revision bite:\nsubject matter, structure, language and imagery, sound, ideas, and attitudes and tone\nCompare Perch with one other post-1914 poem and two pre-1914 poems of your choice that focus on creatures (animals, birds and fish) in the wild. What is the poet\'s attitude in each poem?\nThree poems suitable for this comparison would be Gillian Clark\'s Field Mouse, John Clare\'s Sonnet, and Alfred Tennyson\'s The Eagle.\nWhat would you want to include in your comparison? On a piece of paper, note down some points to make in comparing Perch with each of these three poems.\nThe title of each poem shows the importance of the Field Mouse and the Perch: as we read, we realise that each is a symbol.\nThe field mouse is a symbol of all things vulnerable to outside attack, while the perch are a symbol of the few things that remain unchanged in today\'s world.\nClarke emphasises how weak the field mouse is in contrast to man, but Heaney sees the fish as independent and unaffected by man.\nSo, Field Mouse has a threatening tone, whereas Perch has a lighter, warmer tone.\nBoth poems celebrate a favourite waterside scene containing trees and wildlife. Clare writes entirely from his point of view, but Heaney manages to show things from his perspective and the perspective of the perch.\nBoth are written in rhyming couplets. Clare uses no punctuation at all and Heaney uses punctuation sparingly so as not to interrupt the flow of the poem.\nThe scene in Sonnet is very relaxed, with gentle descriptions of the Moor Hen and insects that sport, but Heaney suggests the strength of the perch too, all muscle and slur.\nAgain, the title shows the focus of the poems. Tennyson is more precise: he is writing about The Eagle, rather than Perch in general.\nBoth poets show us the creature\'s point of view. The Eagle, from his high crag, sees the wrinkled sea beneath him, while the perch see the water-roof above them.\nBoth creatures are utterly at home in their sphere. This is shown humorously by Heaney - carpets of Bann stream - and majestically by Tennyson - Ring\'d with the azure world, he stands.\nBoth show the power of the creature: Heaney uses military imagery, bluntly holding the pass, while for Tennyson the eagle is like a thunderbolt.\nOf course, these suggestions do not contain everything there is to say! You may have thought of other relevant points, and there may be other poems you have read which you could use in your comparison. The important thing is to be able to write two or three sentences pointing out similarities and differences between the poems.\n', 'label': '5'}
{'text': 'When reversible reactions reach equilibrium the forward and reverse reactions are still happening but at the same rate, so the concentrations of reactants and products do not change.\nThe balance point can be affected by temperature, and also by pressure for gasses in equilibrium.\nIf a chemical reaction happens in a container where one or more of the\nsubstances present at the start of a chemical reaction\nA product is a substance formed in a chemical reaction.\n. If a chemical reaction happens in a container where none of the reactants or products can escape, you have a\nReversible reactions are chemical reactions which can go both ways. The direction of the reaction depends on the condition of the reactants.\nthat happen in a closed system eventually reach an\nIn a chemical equilibrium, the concentrations of reactants and products do not change. But the forward and reverse reactions have not stopped -\nthey are still going on at the same rate as each other\nImagine walking the wrong way on an escalator - at the same speed as the escalator, but in the opposite direction. Your legs would still be walking forwards, and the escalator would continue to move backwards. However, the net result would be that you stay in exactly the same place. This is what happens in an equilibrium.\nIf we remove the products from an equilibrium mixture, more reactants are converted into products. If a\nA catalyst changes the rate of a chemical reaction without being changed by the reaction itself.\nis used, the reaction reaches equilibrium much sooner, because the catalyst speeds up the forward and reverse reactions by the same amount. The concentration of reactants and products is nevertheless the same at equilibrium as it would be without the catalyst.\nYour web browser does not have JavaScript switched on at the moment. For information on how to enable JavaScript please go to the\nYou will not be able to see this content until you have JavaScript switched on.\nFor the Higher Tier, you need to know what happens to the amount of product in an equilibrium mixture if the\nHeat energy is released in an exothermic reaction. We know this because the surroundings get warm.\nand the temperature is increased, the yield of products is decreased. If the temperature is decreased, the yield of products is increased.\nIn an endothermic reaction, energy is taken in from the surroundings. The surroundings then have less energy than they started with, so the temperature falls.\nand the temperature is increased, the yield of products is increased. If the temperature is decreased, the yield of products is decreased.\nHaber process - effect of temperature change on yield of ammonia\nThis is important to industrial processes such as the Haber process. The forward reaction, which makes ammonia for fertilisers, is exothermic. So the yield of ammonia is better at lower temperatures. You might think that chemical engineers would choose a low temperature for the Haber process - but the reaction runs much faster at higher temperatures. So a compromise temperature is chosen - one that is high enough to get a reasonable rate of reaction, but not so high that the yield of ammonia is low.\nThe Haber process - choosing a temperature\nThe forward reaction in the Haber process is\nHeat energy is released in an exothermic reaction. We know this because the surroundings get warm.\n. This means that if the temperature is increased, the position of equilibrium moves in the direction of the reverse reaction, and less ammonia is formed.\nYour web browser does not have JavaScript switched on at the moment. For information on how to enable JavaScript please go to the\nYou will not be able to see this content until you have JavaScript switched on.\nThe effect of varying the temperature in the Haber process\nYou might think that a low temperature would be a good choice for the Haber process: if the forward reaction is exothermic, the yield of product at\nIf the rate of the forward reaction and the rate of the back reaction in a reversible reaction are equal, the reaction is in equilibrium.\nis increased at lower temperatures. However, if the temperature is too low the rate of reaction will be too low. This would make the process uneconomical. So a compromise temperature is chosen: low enough to get a good yield of ammonia but high enough to obtain a reasonable rate of reaction.\nA catalyst changes the rate of a chemical reaction without being changed by the reaction itself.\ndoes not affect the position of the equilibrium, but it does increase the rate of the reaction. This means the ammonia is produced in a shorter time, reducing the cost of the process. Iron is a cheap catalyst.\nFor the Higher Tier, you also need to know what happens to the amount of\nA product is a substance formed in a chemical reaction.\nin an equilibrium mixture of gases if the\nChanging the pressure has little effect on an equilibrium mixture without gases - but can have a big effect on an equilibrium mixture containing gases. If the pressure is increased, the position of equilibrium moves in the direction of the fewest\na collection of two or more atoms held together by chemical bonds. The fundamental unit of compounds\nLook again at the Haber process, which makes ammonia (NH\nOn the left, there are 1 + 3 = 4 molecules of gas. On the right, there are two molecules of gas. If the pressure is increased, the position of equilibrium will move to the right and more ammonia will be made. If the pressure is reduced, the position of equilibrium will move to the left and less ammonia will be made.\nLook at the graph. You can see that for any given temperature the\nyield of ammonia increases as the pressure increases\n. You can also see that, for any given pressure, the\nyield goes down as the temperature increases\n. This is because the forward reaction is\nHeat energy is released in an exothermic reaction. We know this because the surroundings get warm.\nYou will be expected to explain the choice of a high pressure for the Haber process.\nLook at the symbol equation for the reaction in the Haber process:\nThere are 1 + 3 = 4\na collection of two or more atoms held together by chemical bonds. The fundamental unit of compounds\nof gas on the left of the equation, only two molecules of gas on the right. In an\nIf the rate of the forward reaction and the rate of the back reaction in a reversible reaction are equal, the reaction is in equilibrium.\ninvolving gases, an increase in pressure favours the reaction which produces the smallest number of molecules. In this case, an increase in pressure favours the forward reaction, and more ammonia is produced.\nYour web browser does not have JavaScript switched on at the moment. For information on how to enable JavaScript please go to the\nYou will not be able to see this content until you have JavaScript switched on.\nThere is a limit to the pressure that can be used industrially, because very high pressures require very strong and expensive equipment. This means a compromise pressure is chosen - high enough to get a good yield of ammonia, but not so high that it would add too much to the costs of the process. The pressure chosen is usually about 200 atmospheres - equivalent to about half the pressure of the water around the wreck of the RMS Titanic.\n', 'label': '5'}
{'text': 'The music of South and Central America is a rich mix of native Indian music and Western and African musical influences that arrived with the Spanish and Portuguese colonists, and their African slaves.\nBrazil is a distinct Portuguese-speaking region of Latin America. It has developed a number of traditional percussion instruments:\nBrazilian instruments include the repinique, chocolo, apito, surdo, reco-reco, tamborim, ago-go, caixa de guerro\n: A small high-pitched double-headed drum used to play solo cues such as call and response.\n: A shaker that plays notes throughout the piece/performance.\n: A whistle used by the leader to signal an instruction to the group. For example: Start the piece, tamborim and agogo start a new rhythm, silent bar, solo improvisation etc.\n: A large bass drum that is hit with soft beaters. They keep a steady pulse and alternate between higher and lower pitches to keep everyone in time. They are divided into 2 groups: high and low.\n: A scraper, which plays the same time values as the chocolo.\n: A small-headed drum with a single drumhead. The player can press and tighten the skin or dampen the sound while playing. Played with a drumstick and plays more complicated rhythms than the surdo or chocolo.\n: A cowbell with 2 pitches, high and low. Held by the left hand and is hit with a drumstick. Notes can be dampened by the left hand to stop them ringing. Plays quite complicated rhythms.\n: A snare drum that is played with one hand facing upwards and the other in a loose closed hold facing downwards.\nThe samba is a type of popular dance music with infectious rhythms and a number of features:\nTo alter a rhythm by accenting a weak beat.\nrhythm which gives the music an African sound\nUsually has a solo singer with alternating chorus, accompanied by percussion\nDancing is done in a group dance, often in a circle\nExample of Samba Batacuda (Real Audio clip)\nThere are many different types of samba but the most popular is\nListen out for these elements in this example of Samba Batacuda.\n, by the Brazilian Tropical Orchestra, listen for:\nThe main melody - a single repeated note on the saxophone\nGive your revision some visual style with a Bitesize revision map!\nFind out more about making music and send us your performances.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': 'Scientists have gathered a lot of evidence and information about the Universe. They have used their observations to develop a theory called the Big Bang. The theory states that about 13.6 billion years ago all the matter in the Universe was concentrated into a single incredibly tiny point. This began to enlarge rapidly in a hot explosion, and it is still expanding today.\nAll the galaxies are moving away from us.\nThe further away a galaxy is, the faster it is moving away.\nThese two features are found in explosions - the fastest moving objects end up furthest away from the explosion.\n. {'text': "Computer graphics software, computer printing and computer-controlled machinery are nowadays ubiquitous in all graphic design and making processes. ICT speeds up the whole design and production process, allows changes to be made much more easily, and enables designers to build\nshowing what the finished product will look like - and even how it will behave - while it's still on the drawing-board.\nThere are two main ways in which ICT is used in graphics:\nis used to standardise and automate the manufacturing of products\nAnother term you will come across is\n, which simply means computerised control of machines used in design and manufacture. CNC machines use electronic data, which can of course be sent anywhere in the world by email - so that products designed in one country can be manufactured in another.\nBoth CAD and CAM can be thought of as systems consisting of input devices, processes and output devices.\ninclude keyboards, computer mouses, scanners, digital cameras, drawing tablets and tracker balls\nCPU stands for Central Processing Unit - the central chip or 'brain' of a computer\ninclude monitors, printers, plotters, cutters, CNC lathes, CNC milling machines and stereo lithography machines\nOne of the biggest benefits of ICT to designers is that it allows them to create 3D models and\none-off working models of a product to find out if the idea works.\nof their product without going to the trouble of making them physically, using the techniques of virtual prototyping and stereo lithography.\nsoftware produces a three-dimensional on-screen representation of the product, which can be manipulated and viewed from any angle, just as if it were real.\nsoftware uses CNC to make a real-world 3D prototype from a specification stored in the computer. A detailed model of the product is first made on the computer, then 'sliced' into many very thin layers. Each slice is then cut into resin by a laser, and the resin slices assembled into a complete prototype.\nPost ideas and discuss Design and Technology here.\nGive your revision some visual style with a Bitesize revision map!\nGet creative! {'text': 'A knowledge of how seismic waves travel through the Earth provides us with evidence of the Earth’s structure. Remember that:\np-waves travel through solids and liquids, so they can travel through all of the Earth’s layers\ns-waves cannot travel through liquid rock, so they cannot travel through the outer core\nThe speed of p-waves and s-waves increases as they travel deeper into the mantle. They travel through the Earth in curved paths, but they change direction suddenly when they pass through the boundary between substances in different states. The diagrams show what happens when p-waves and s-waves pass through the Earth:\nS-waves cannot pass through the liquid outer core, but p-waves can. When p-waves pass from solid to liquid, then from liquid to solid, there are sudden changes in direction.\nis the part of the upper atmosphere where ozone is found in the highest concentrations. The ozone there absorbs ultraviolet radiation, preventing most of it from reaching the ground. This is important because ultraviolet radiation can lead to skin cancer.\n, are chemicals that were once used widely in insulating foam and aerosol spray-cans. They release reactive chlorine atoms in the upper atmosphere. These break down ozone and damage the ozone layer. CFCs have now been almost completely replaced by chemicals that do not destroy ozone.\nBack to Energy for the home index\nWireless signals are all around us, learn more in this activity!\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "Greek knowledge about the body and disease\nGreek knowledge about the body and disease\nMan's body has blood, phlegm, yellow bile and black bile. These make up his body and through them he feels illness or enjoys health. When all the humours are properly balanced and mingled, he feels the most perfect health. Illness occurs when one of the humours is in excess, or is reduced in amount, or is entirely missing from the body.\nHippocrates, 'On the Constitution of Man' (c.500BC)\nHippocrates was a real doctor, but most of the books ascribed to him were written by his disciples. (To help you remember the four humours, along with blood and phlegm, think of yellow bile as vomit, and black bile as diarrhoea.)\nI shall describe what the plague was like ... At the beginning the doctors were unable to treat the disease because of their ignorance of the right methods. Equally useless were prayers in the temples, consulting the oracles and suchlike.\nThucydides, 'History of the Peloponnesian War' (c.500BC)\nSilenus had become overtired from drinking and exercising at the wrong time and had caught a fever. He began with pains in the stomach, heavy head and a stiff neck.\n1st day: he vomited, his urine was black, he was thirsty, tongue dry, no sleep at night.\n6th day: slight perspiration about the head, head and feet cold and black, no discharge from the bowel, no urine, acute fever.\n8th day: cold sweat all over, red rashes, severe diarrhoea, urine bitter and passed painfully, hands and feet cold.\n11th day: he died breathing slow and heavy, stomach throbbing. He was about 20 years old.'\nOnce you have read the sources about Greek physiology, look for evidence that the Greeks:\nbelieved in the theory of the 'four humours'\ndid not think the gods caused disease\nbelieved that an imbalance of the humours caused disease\nstudied the 'natural history' of different diseases\nwrote down what they knew in order to pass on their knowledge\nbelieved in the theory of the 'four humours'\n'blood, phlegm, yellow bile and black bile ... make up his body.'\n'When all the humours are properly balanced and mingled ...'\ndid not think the gods caused disease\n'...unable to treat the disease because of their ignorance of the right methods ...'\nbelieved that an imbalance of the humours caused disease\n' ...through them he feels illness or enjoys health. {'text': 'Ambition and illusions versus fitting in and accepting your lot\nVictorians believed it was right to try to improve your lot, and\nexplores the issue through its events and characters:\nPip\'s yearning to be a \'gentleman\' only makes him unhappy.\nMagwitch makes a fortune as a sheep herder, and puts it to good effect, helping Pip in his ambition to be a gentleman.\nMiss Havisham is the opposite of ambitious. She has stopped the clocks and done nothing more with her life - failing even to put on her second shoe.\nEstella lives a privileged life, and cares for nothing but inheriting Miss Havisham\'s jewels. She has a meaningless life, is obviously bored and - although\nby suitors - has no real friends.\nJoe Gargery has no ambition beyond his forge, but is a good and noble man.\nBiddy is happy with her lot. She cheerfully does the drudge\'s jobs, yet she catches education "like a cold" and becomes the village schoolteacher.\nHerbert Pocket longs to make money in commerce, but is unable to do so until Pip buys him a job at Clarriker\'s. Having got the job, he goes out to Cairo, works hard, and makes a decent living.\nBentley Drummle is at the top of the social heap, but wastes his position and talents, and dies without accomplishing anything.\nMr Wopsle longs to act on the stage, pursues his dream and succeeds. Although he only has small parts in second-rate\nVariety show entertainment consisting of light comic acts, singing and dancing.\nWemmick strictly divides his working life from his personal life. Although his letterbox mouth betrays his unhappiness in his job, at home he is relaxed and happy.\nFrom the above, what do you make of Dickens\' attitude to ambition versus accepting your lot?\nOne conclusion is that Dickens felt illusions make you unhappy, and ambition does not bring success. What matters to Dickens is not what you achieve, but what kind of person you are.\nRead the full text online and make your own notes.\nGet creative, get published and get expert writing advice at BBC Blast.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. Plants grow towards sources of water and light, which they need to survive and grow.\nAuxin is a plant hormone produced in the stem tips and roots, which controls the direction of growth. Plant hormones are used in weedkillers, rooting powder and to control fruit ripening.\nto help make sure they grow towards sources of light and water.\n– growth in response to the direction of\n– growth in response to the direction of\nResponses of different parts of the plant\nis a plant hormone responsible for controlling the\nof root tips and stem tips in response to\nof stems and roots. {'text': 'For some synthesised chemical compounds - pharmaceuticals, for example - it is very important that they have a high level of\n. Just a tiny amount of an impurity in a drug could cause a great deal of harm to a patient.\nSamples of chemicals that are synthesised must be checked for purity. This is often done by carrying out a\n. A titration is used to measure the volume of one solution that exactly reacts with another solution.\nA titration is carried out using a number of steps:\nIf the sample is a solid, it is\nto make up a known volume of solution (usually 100cm\nis used to measure accurately a volume of this solution - for example, 10cm\n. A safety pipette filler is used to draw solution into the pipette. This is emptied into a\nmay be added to the conical flask. This will show a change of colour when the titration is complete.\nA second chemical is placed in a\n. This other solution is of a chemical that will react with the synthesised chemical sample in the conical flask. Often the solution in the burette is an\n, and it must be of a precise, known concentration.\nThe solution from the burette is run into the conical flask. The solution is added one drop at a time, with swirling to mix the solutions as the end-point is approached. Eventually, a colour change shows that the correct amount has been added to react completely with the synthesised chemical in the sample.\nThe volume of solution added from the burette is noted. The titration results can then be used to calculate the amount of the synthesised chemical in the sample, and therefore find its purity.\nApparatus required for titration (from left to right): burette, conical flask, safety pipette filler and pipette\nRead on if you are taking the\nPut down that pen and listen to some additional Science audio.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled.
