Many scientists at this time believed that people with disabilities or social problems were genetic degenerates whose genes needed to be eliminated from the human bloodline.\nhomosexuals, prostitutes, Jehovah's Witnesses, alcoholics, pacifists, beggars, hooligans\n- who they regarded as anti-social - into concentration camps.\nHow the Nazis persecuted the Jews: key dates\nJewish civil servants, lawyers and teachers sacked.\nRace Science lessons to teach that Jews are\nA German word for a person who is considered inferior.\n'Jews not wanted here' signs put up at swimming pools etc.\n(15 September) Jews could not be citizens. {'text': 'Fossils of ammonites - sea creatures that became extinct about 65 million years ago\nMost of the evidence for evolution comes from the\n. Fossils show how much, or how little, organisms have changed over time.\nOne of the problems with the fossil record is that it contains gaps. Not all organisms fossilise well. And many fossils are destroyed by the movements of the Earth, or have simply not been discovered.\nEvolution is difficult to observe because it usually occurs over many years. This is one reason why the theory of evolution is\n, not a law. Since no one was around millions of years ago to make observations, take notes or carry out experiments, evolution cannot be proven in the usual scientific sense. However, rapid changes in species have been observed that support the theory.\nBefore the Industrial Revolution in Britain, most peppered moths were of the pale variety. They were camouflaged against the pale birch trees they rested on. Moths with a mutant black colouring were spotted easily by birds and eaten. This gave the white variety an advantage, making them more likely to survive and reproduce.\nAirborne pollution in industrial areas blackened the birch tree bark with soot. This meant the mutant black moths were now camouflaged, while the white variety became more vulnerable to predators. It gave the black variety an advantage. They were then more likely to survive and reproduce. Over time, the black peppered moths became far more numerous in urban areas than the pale variety.\nThe pale peppered moths camouflage well against the pale birch tree\nThe darker mutant peppered moths camouflage well against the blackened birch tree\nE. coli bacteria (Photo from Rocky Mountain Laboratories, NIAID, NIH)\nSingle-celled micro-organisms, some of which are pathogenic in humans, animals and plants. Singular is bacterium.\nultramicroscopic non-cellular organisms that replicate themselves inside the cells of living hosts\nreproduce rapidly and can evolve in a relatively short time. One example is the bacterium E. coli. Its\nThe material inside the nucleus of cells, carrying genetic information. DNA stands for Deoxyribonucleic Acid.\ncan be damaged or changed during replication, and most of the time this causes the death of the cell. But occasionally the mutation is beneficial (to the bacteria). For example, it may allow resistance to certain\nSubstances that kill bacteria and fungal infections.\n. When those antibiotics are present, the resistant bacteria have an advantage over the bacteria that are not resistant. Antibiotic-resistant strains of bacteria are an increasing problem in hospitals.\nScientists can now examine the DNA from different species of organism and use the data produced to see how closely related the two species are to each other. By collecting a lot of this data, scientists can compare the results with conventional ideas about how organisms have evolved. What they found was that DNA data supported the conventional theory of evolution.\nYou need to be able to provide an explanation that links together things that were previously thought to be unrelated. For example, DNA data being used to support the theory of evolution. Also people had noticed that there was a wide variety of different things living on the planet. Darwin noticed that different islands in the Galapagos had different types of finches adapted to eating the type of food found on each island. It was only when Darwin produced his theory of evolution by natural selection that these two unrelated facts were linked together.\nBack to Evolution, nerves and hormones index\nAn activity that would make Darwin proud!\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "A polygon is a 2-dimensional closed shape with straight sides. In this section we will revise the properties of polygons.\nWe already know that the angles in a triangle add up to 180°. Angles on a straight line also add up to 180°.\na + b + c = 180° (angles in a triangle)\nc + d = 180° (angles on a straight line).\nIf we rearrange both equations (subtract c from both sides), we get:\na + b = 180° - c and d = 180° - c.\nTherefore, a + b and d must be the same (they are both equal to 180° - c):\nThe exterior angle is equal to the sum of the two opposite interior angles.\nFind each angle marked with a letter, giving reasons for your answer.\n? The exterior angle (120°) is equal to the sum of the two opposite interior angles (70° + a).\nTherefore, 70° + a = 120°, so a = 50°.\nb = 60°, because the angles on a straight line add up to 180°.\nb + 120° = 180°, so b = 60°.\nThe angles in a quadrilateral add up to 360º. There are other facts that you will need to know about special types of quadrilaterals. These are shown below:\nA square is a regular quadrilateral. All of its angles are equal (90°). All of its sides are of equal length. Opposite sides are parallel. The diagonals bisect each other at 90°. The diagonals are equal in length. It has 4 lines of symmetry. Order of rotational symmetry: 4.\nDiagonally opposite angles are equal. All of its sides are of equal length. Opposite sides are parallel. Diagonals bisect each other at 90°. It has 2 lines of symmetry. Order of rotational symmetry: 2.\nAll angles are equal (90°). Opposite sides are of equal length. Opposite sides are parallel. The diagonals bisect each other. The diagonals are equal in length. It has 2 lines of symmetry. Order of rotational symmetry: 2.\nDiagonally opposite angles are equal. Opposite sides are of equal length. Opposite sides are parallel. The diagonals bisect each other. It has no lines of symmetry. Order of rotational symmetry: 2.\nOne pair of opposite sides is parallel. It has no lines of symmetry. It has no rotational symmetry.\nTwo pairs of sides are of equal length. One pair of diagonally opposite angles is equal. Only one diagonal is bisected by the other. The diagonals cross at 90°. It has 1 line of symmetry. It has no rotational symmetry.\nDo not be too alarmed by all these facts - you probably know most of them already!\nThe simplest polygon is a triangle (a 3-sided shape). Polygons of all types can be regular or irregular.\nA regular polygon has sides of equal length, and all its interior angles are of equal size.\nIrregular polygons can have sides of any length and angles of any size.\nHere are the names of some common polygons:\nCan you give the name of a regular triangle?\ntriangle because all of its sides are of equal length, and all its interior angles are the same size (60°).\nCan you give the name of a regular quadrilateral?\nRemember that a rectangle is not a regular quadrilateral, because not all of its sides are of equal length.\nWe have seen that regular triangles and regular quadrilaterals have special names. In fact, they are the only polygons which do. All other regular polygons are simply termed 'regular pentagon', 'regular hexagon' etc.\nIn your exam, you might be asked to find angles of polygons.\nThe formula for calculating the sum of the interior angles of a regular polygon is:\nis the number of sides of the polygon.\nThis formula comes from dividing the polygon up into triangles using full diagonals.\nWe already know that the interior angles of a triangle add up to 180°. For any polygon, count up how many triangles it can be split into. Then multiply the number of triangles by 180.\nThis quadrilateral has been divided into two triangles, so the interior angles add up to 2 × 180 = 360°.\nThis pentagon has been divided into three triangles, so the interior angles add up to 3 × 180 = 540°.\nIn the same way, a hexagon can be divided into 4 triangles, a 7-sided polygon into 5 triangles etc.\nCan you see the pattern forming? The number of triangles is equal to the number of sides minus 2.\nWhat is the sum of the interior angles of an octagon?\nYou calculate 6 × 180 = 1080°.\nRemember that the formula for the sum of interior angles is (n - 2) × 180. An octagon has\n. So n = 8, and n - 2 = 6.\nIf you find it difficult to remember formulas, just add 180° each time in the following way:\nThe exterior angle of a polygon and its corresponding interior angle always add up to 180° (because they make a straight line).\nFor any polygon, the sum of its exterior angles is 360°.\n(You can see this because if you imagine 'walking' all the way round the outside of a polygon you make one full turn.)\nCalculating the interior and exterior angles of regular polygons\nWe already know how to find the sum of the interior angles of a polygon using the formula\nWe also know that all the interior angles of a regular polygon are equal.\nInterior angle of a regular polygon = sum of interior angles ÷ number of sides\nFind the interior angle of a regular hexagon.\nWe know from the formula that the interior angles of a hexagon add up to 720°.\nAs a hexagon has six sides, each angle is equal to\nWe know that the exterior angles of a regular polygon\nadd up to 360°, so the exterior angle of a regular hexagon is\nThe interior angle and its corresponding exterior angle always add up to 180°. The exterior angles add up to 360°, so if we divide 360° by 60° we find there are 6 exterior angles. Therefore, there are\nThe interior angles of a regular polygon are each 150°. Calculate the number of sides.\nIf not, remember that the exterior angles are each 30° (180° - 150°).\n360 ÷ 30 = 12, so there are 12 exterior angles, and 12 sides.\n", 'label': '5'}

{'text': "Marketing is about responding to consumers' needs. It is very important to find out what these needs are before a marketing plan is put together.\nThis Revision Bite will help you understand why and how a company conducts market research.\nMarket research is the collection of information or data to better understand what is happening in the market place. A firm's marketing department needs to know about economic trends, as well as consumers' views. Based on this information, they can put together a marketing plan, which will meet their own needs as well as those of their consumers.\nThere are two general types of research:\nPrimary research provides new data for a specific purpose\nThe marketing department of a firm or a specialist research organisation can provide this. Typically, the data is gathered in face-to-face interviews, by telephone, by post or via the internet, using questionnaires. This is called a\n. Sometimes potential consumers are asked to test products, and their responses are recorded.\nGathering primary or new data - questionnaires, surveys etc.\nhas the advantage that the firm itself has control over the whole process. The disadvantages are that it takes longer and is more expensive.\nIt can be anything from a company's own sales statistics to Department of Trade and Industry reports. Other secondary sources of information include journals, company reports, government statistics, and surveys published by research organisations. Traditionally, these have been paper-based, but more and more information is now available on CD-ROM or on-line through the Internet.\nGathering secondary or existing data - internet, newspapers etc.\nhas the advantages of being cheaper and quicker than field research. The disadvantages are not knowing if the findings are accurate, or how relevant they will be to your product.\nGet down to business and discuss Business Studies here.\nLosing your way? Make a Bitesize revision map!\nFor news that really does the business!\nAmerican Marketing Association â€“ Dictionary of Marketing Terms\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': '(Mishnah and Gemara collected together) describe different roles for men and women.\nTraditionally women have a sacred role - they bear children, run the home and take responsibility for their children’s Jewish upbringing. The woman passes on Jewish values and it is because of the mother’s Jewish faith (not the father’s) that a child is born Jewish.\nWhile Jewish law excuses women from some religious duties (eg, they don’t have to wear the\nFringes on the corners of the Tallit (prayer shawl).\nSmall leather boxes containing passages from the Torah, strapped to the forehead and arm for morning prayers on weekdays.\n) there are some duties that women are obliged to carry out like the lighting the\nis the day of spiritual renewal and rest commencing at sunset on Friday, terminating at nightfall on Saturday.)\n. Men and women sit separately in Orthodox services and women cannot take an active part in this worship. Some Jewish women today accept these limitations, but they are as well-educated as men and choose to combine a career with family responsibilities.\nProgressive Jews (which includes Jews of both liberal and reform traditions) think that this attitude is wrong and treat women equally in all respects, so they too can become rabbis (Jewish teacher) if they choose to do so.\nPost ideas and discuss Religious Studies here.\nGet some direction with a Bitesize revision map\nUnderstand the beliefs of others and develop your own opinion.\nThe BBC is not responsible for the content of external internet sites.\nThis page is best viewed in an up-to-date web browser with style sheets (CSS) enabled. {'text': "Other people's ideas - the internet - your journal's 'look'\nOther people's ideas - the internet - your journal's 'look'\nArtists and writers own the copyright for anything they have created. They are protected by copyright law - this prevents other people from copying it without their permission.\nCopyright law protects anything you can copy - whether it is images or text from books, magazines or the internet. You are allowed to copy images and text for your own\nas long as you do not plan to use it in your own artwork or make any money from it.\nIf you are including secondary sources in your work journal then that's fine - but do acknowledge where you got them from whereever possible.\nIf you are planning to use somebody else's work in your artwork, then you must get permission from whoever owns the copyright. The copyright details are usually included in books and magazines on the front page. For TV programmes you may need to contact the production company. Websites usually have copyright information at the bottom of the webpage. For example if you look at the bottom of the BBC Schools website there is a link that says Schools Copyright (\nEven if you do not need copyright permission, it is always good practice to acknowledge where your images or text come from. It shows the range of sources you have used.\nBack to AO1 - Record and observe index\nPost ideas and discuss Art and Design here.\nGet some direction with a Bitesize revision map\nGet creative! {'text': 'The music of South and Central America is a rich mix of native Indian music and Western and African musical influences that arrived with the Spanish and Portuguese colonists, and their African slaves.\nBrazil is a distinct Portuguese-speaking region of Latin America. It has developed a number of traditional percussion instruments:\nBrazilian instruments include the repinique, chocolo, apito, surdo, reco-reco, tamborim, ago-go, caixa de guerro\n: A small high-pitched double-headed drum used to play solo cues such as call and response.\n: A shaker that plays notes throughout the piece/performance.\n: A whistle used by the leader to signal an instruction to the group. For example: Start the piece, tamborim and agogo start a new rhythm, silent bar, solo improvisation etc.\n: A large bass drum that is hit with soft beaters. They keep a steady pulse and alternate between higher and lower pitches to keep everyone in time. They are divided into 2 groups: high and low.\n: A scraper, which plays the same time values as the chocolo.\n: A small-headed drum with a single drumhead. The player can press and tighten the skin or dampen the sound while playing. Played with a drumstick and plays more complicated rhythms than the surdo or chocolo.\n: A cowbell with 2 pitches, high and low. Held by the left hand and is hit with a drumstick. Notes can be dampened by the left hand to stop them ringing. Plays quite complicated rhythms.\n: A snare drum that is played with one hand facing upwards and the other in a loose closed hold facing downwards.\nThe samba is a type of popular dance music with infectious rhythms and a number of features:\nTo alter a rhythm by accenting a weak beat.\nrhythm which gives the music an African sound\nUsually has a solo singer with alternating chorus, accompanied by percussion\nDancing is done in a group dance, often in a circle\nExample of Samba Batacuda (Real Audio clip)\nThere are many different types of samba but the most popular is\nListen out for these elements in this example of Samba Batacuda.\n, by the Brazilian Tropical Orchestra, listen for:\nThe main melody - a single repeated note on the saxophone\nTango is a modern ballroom dance from Argentina. It was introduced into Latin America in the early 1920\'s and soon became popular.\nTango is a slow, graceful dance, in 2/4 time or 4/4 time, with dotted rhythms.\nAn accompaniment is usually provided by an orchestra, but a bandoneon (type of accordion) can be used.\nnotation of commonest rhythm patterns in tango\nby Bizet, with its slow 2/4 tango rhythm. (This is not itself a tango, but has been heavily influenced by this style.)\nIt is a slow dance in 24 time.\nThe central Andean regions includes Ecuador, Peru, Bolivia, Argentina, and Chile. Its musical traditions date back at least 1000 years to before the Inca civilisation.\nAndean music is usually in a minor key, highly\nTo alter a rhythm by accenting a weak beat.\nand accompanied by a steady simple drum beat.\nAndean instruments include the charango, wancara, zampona, quena, tarka\nis a small guitar originally made from the shells of armadillos due to the lack of wood in the high lands of the Andes.\nis a Bolivian drum made from wood and shell with a goatskin head, around 26" in diameter and 13" deep, with a big sound.\nis a cane panpipe native to the highlands around lake Titicaca between Peru and Bolivia.\n, pronounced kay-na, is generally tuned in G.\nis a flute carved out of wood with a whistle-type mouthpiece and small air hole. The sound and scale are different from any other Andean flute.\nSince the 1970\'s there has been a more universal musical style originating from southern Peru and Bolivia. It is played on quena flutes, siku panpipes and charango guitars.\n', 'label': '5'}
